column1: Why Cisco Is Spending $3.7 Billion on AppDynamics;3/17/2017;"Many were surprised whenCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) announced in late January its decision to buy   AppDynamics. Not the acquisition itself -- Cisco's major   strategy
column2: after all
column3: involves buying tech start-ups and   rebranding them under the Cisco parent name. What was   surprising was the price and timing of the purchase.Cisco announced the deal the evening before AppDynamics was   set to go public. Public investors interested in the company may   have been disappointed
column4: but Cisco did shell out a big number
column5: buying the company for $3.7 billion in cash and equity options.   This was more than double what the IPO price would have been
column6: as   shares at the top end of the company's range would have priced   the company at $1.7 billion.The $3.7 billion seems steep. AppDynamics only generated $158   million in first the nine months of 2016
column7: for an annual run rate   revenue of roughly $210 million
column8: which means Cisco paid roughly   17 times revenue for the company. While AppDynamics did sport an   impressive growth rate of 54% in the first nine months of 2016
column9: that's still a hefty price. Moreover
column10: a previous round of   financing for AppDynamics had come in at avaluation of $1.9 billion
column11: so the IPO could have even been considered a ""down round.""makeArticleAd();So
column12: why did Cisco pay up? Let's go through some of the   possible rationales.Image source: Getty Images.What is AppDynamics?AppDynamicsis an enterprise software company that is essentially a   diagnostic tool for large IT departments. Many businesses now   have a complex assortment of applications
column13: databases
column14: on-premise   servers
column15: and cloud infrastructure
column16: plus other networking   components that form the backbone of their businesses. The   interplay between all of these tools can cause bottlenecks
column17: slow   performance
column18: or even crashes. Traditionally
column19: IT professionals   would have to do extensive detective work to find trouble spots   and get everything performing at an optimum level.AppDynamics makes software that will detect what is wrong and   can vastly cut down the amount of troubleshooting IT teams have   to do. It also allows real-time monitoring of all of the elements   in a company's network. That type of insight is very valuable.   For instance
column20: if a company's webpage is not loading correctly
column21: that can result in lost sales.AppDynamics boasts a laundry list of high-profile companies   that rely on its services
column22: fromCharter Communications(NASDAQ: CHTR) toKraft-Heinz(NASDAQ: KHC) . The Motley Fool is also a customer.It appears Cisco didn't want to let this product and   management team slip through its grasp
column23: so out came the   checkbook.AppDynamics has been compared toNew Relic(NYSE: NEWR) and  Solarwinds.New Relic has a market cap around $1.93 billion and the stock   trades around eight times revenue. That being said
column24: New Relic's   year-over-year revenue growth of 43% in the third quarter is   slightly slower than AppDynamics at 54%.Solarwinds used to be a public company
column25: but was bought out by   private equity firms in early 2016 for $4.5 billion. The buyout   represented a 44% premium over the stock's price before news of   the deal surfaced. Solarwinds had a somewhat larger suite of   products
column26: though
column27: beyond merely application management.Don't forget attach ratesWhile some people may scoff at the premium Cisco is paying
column28: one must always remember the concept of attach rates in these   types of acquisitions. An attach rate is when a large company is   able to cross-sell a secondary product into its existing customer   base
column29: thereby giving the secondary product a much larger market   than it would have had on its own.While AppDynamics has an impressive list of public and private   clients
column30: it is nowhere near the level of penetration that Cisco   has among enterprise
column31: commercial
column32: and service provider   businesses.Taking this into account
column33: investors should assess the attach   rate Cisco can produce for AppDynamics. Surely Cisco is looking   to add software and services capabilities to its suite of   enterprise products. The company is struggling with its legacy   hardware businesses
column34: which are becoming more and more   commoditized. In response
column35: Cisco is attempting to boost its   software and services portfolio via venues including   cybersecurity
column36: performance-enhancing solutions such as   AppDynamics
column37: or 2016's IOTservices acquisition
column38: Jasper   Technologies.Thus
column39: if Cisco can immediately ""attach"" AppDynamics to its   existing product bundle and spread it quickly
column40: it's possible   Cisco can make a good return. Moreover
column41: AppDynamics had been   losing money because of its high sales and marketing efforts
column42: so   perhaps Cisco
column43: in folding the company into its own sales force
column44: can boost profitability as well as growth. We just don't know yet   how successful Cisco will be in this regard.To be sure
column45: Cisco investors may have been wary about the price   it's paying for AppDynamics. Still
column46: the company does appear to   have a best-in-class offering
column47: and it's possible Cisco can   accelerate the company's growth and margins.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Cisco Systems
column2: Inc.;3/16/2017;"Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column3: one of the biggest networking companies in the   world
column4: is generally known as a slow-growth company which sells   switches
column5: routers
column6: and other networking products. If you had   invested just $3
column7: 000 in Cisco's IPO in  1990
column8: your position   would be worth $1.64 million today and be generating nearly   $56
column9: 000 in annual dividends.Investors might know that Cisco grew massively in the 1990s   and 2000s
column10: and that its revenue growth peaked in recent years.   However
column11: investors might be less familiar with these seven   lesser-known facts about the networking giant.Image source: Cisco.makeArticleAd();1. Cisco is short for San Francisco""Cisco"" is short for San Francisco
column12: the city where Stanford   computer scientists Leonard Bosack and Sandy Lerner founded the   company in 1984. That's why in Cisco's early days
column13: Bosack and   Lerner insisted on branding its products with the lowercase   ""cisco"". Cisco's logo
column14: which may initially appear to be just a   series of vertical lines
column15: represents the Golden Gate Bridge
column16: with   the two taller lines signifying the towers.2. Early troubles at StanfordBosack and his wife Lerner founded Cisco when both of them   were still employed at Stanford. Bosack continued working at   Stanford with Cisco co-worker and co-founder Kirk Lougheed
column17: where   they developed the company's first router. However
column18: it was an   exact replica of Stanford's ""Blue Box"" router and ran an   unlicensed copy of the university's multiple-protocol router   software
column19: which was adapted into the foundation of Cisco IOS.In 1986
column20: Bosack and Lougheed were forced to resign from   Stanford over the product's development
column21: and the university   considered filing criminal charges against Cisco over the theft   of its intellectual property. However
column22: Stanford eventually agreed   to license its router software and two computer boards to Cisco   in 1987.3. It was the most valuable company in the     worldCisco's price surged to nearly $80 at the apex of the dot-com   bubble in March 2000
column23: making it the most valuable company in the   world with a market cap of $500 billion. However
column24: that rally   wasn't sustainable
column25: since the stock was trading at nearly240 timesearnings. The bubble popped
column26: and Cisco's subsequent plunge made   it a cautionary tale of the dot-com bust.Cisco stocknever came close to its dot-com bubble levels again. Today
column27: Cisco   has a market cap of just over $170 billion and trades at 18 times   earnings. The most valuable company in the world today isApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column28: which has a market cap of $730 billion and   trades at 17 times earnings.Source:YCharts4. It used to make camerasBack in 2009
column29: Cisco tried to expand its presence in consumer   electronics by  buying Pure Digital Technologies
column30: the maker   of the popular Flip Video camcorders
column31: for $590 million. At the   time
column32: Cisco stated that connecting those cameras to the internet   would allow ""people to share
column33: publish
column34: and [easily] get access to   video
column35: which fit its ""vision of visual networking.""That proclamation sounded very similar to the strategyGoPro(NASDAQ: GPRO) unveiled five years later. At the time of the   acquisition
column36: Flip cameras accounted for 75% of the handheld   digital camcorder market. But just like GoPro's cameras
column37: Flip   video cameras were gradually rendered obsolete by smartphones --   and Cisco quietly killed the Flip two years later.5. It sold its set-top box business to     TechnicolorIn 2005
column38: Cisco acquired set-top box maker Scientific Atlanta   for $6.9 billion to beef up its video streaming technologies.   Those technologies strengthened Cisco's service provider video   and collaboration products
column39: but the set-top boxes themselves were   a dead weight on its top line growth.That's why Cisco sold  the set-top box business toTechnicolorfor $600 million in late 2015. That's also why Cisco has reported   two sets of top line results over the past few quarters. Last   quarter
column40: its total revenue fell 3% annually
column41: but only fell 2%   after excluding the impact of the set-top box business across all    comparable periods.6. Cybersecurity is its fastest growing     businessCisco's fastest-growing business is its cybersecurity unit
column42: which grew its revenue by 14% annually to $528 million last   quarter and accounted for 6% of its product revenues. Cisco has   been aggressively expanding that business through big investments   and acquisitions.It also bundles its security products with its networking   hardware and software
column43: which gives it tremendous leverage against   smaller stand-alone security companies likeFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) -- which is frequently cited as apotential takeover targetfor the company.The key takeawaysCisco may be a ""mature"" tech stock which is owned for income   instead of growth today
column44: but investors shouldn't neglect its   colorful history as a Stanford computer science project
column45: the   world's most valuable company
column46: an aspiring connected camera   maker
column47: and a growing cybersecurity company. These facts indicate   that Cisco is much more than a maker of switches and routers
column48: and   investors should keep an eye on its investments in other   markets.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Service Provider Router Revenues Thrive Worldwide in 2016;3/15/2017;"According to a recent report by Dell'Oro

column3: the places where two or more networks connect. In 2016

Several industry analysts have estimated that the global router market will reach around $72 -- $73 billion by 2022.Massive growth in the usage of mobile devices has heightened transportation of data traffic substantially. In order to manage this burgeoning demand for photo

column1: 178 Million Reasons Why Fitbit Needs an Operations Executive;3/14/2017;"Image Source: Fitbit.comFitbit(NYSE: FIT) took a hit of $178 million last quarter due   to issues with the supply chain
column2: warranty
column3: and soft sales. So   it's not a surprise that Fitbit hired Jeff Devine as an Executive   Vice President (EVP) of Operations reporting directly to the CEO.   With Fitbit's business becoming more complex and sales volumes   reaching almost one fitness tracker per second
column4: small mistakes in   the supply chain can quickly impact the bottom line. This new   position
column5: and Jeff Devine's experience
column6: should help Fitbit   improve its operations engine to match the pace of sales and   aggressive product transitions the company has planned
column7: while   keeping gross margins high.makeArticleAd();Let's look at why Devine was hired
column8: what he brings to the   table and what impact he could have on Fitbit's global   operations.Why now?A picture is worth 1
column9: 000 words.Source: Fitbit's Q4-2016 earnings release presentationFitbit's 2016 gross margins took a 9.4% or $178 million hit   related to:Tooling equipment and component scrapIncreased rebates and promotionsIncreased return reserveIncreased warranty reserve for legacy productsAll these items are due to poor operations execution and could   be helped with a focused operations team with a voice in the   executive boardroom.Despite these issues
column10: Fitbit continues to enhance its product   line
column11: making trackers smaller with more capabilities and   therefore more difficult to manufacture.A new smartwatchwith technologies from three separate companies will further add   to the operational challenge. Additionally
column12: James Park
column13: Fitbit's   CEO
column14: wants to streamline the existing product line to make room   for the smartwatch. These upcoming product transitions will be a   challenge to pull off with minimal scrap and no gaps in   supply.Significant improvements to Fitbit's operations are required   or these issues from 2016 will only become worse. James Park   has taken the first step to addressing the problem and hired Jeff   Devine as EVP of Operations.Why Jeff Devine?Jeff Devine has a broad base of high-tech experience that   Fitbit needs to breath new life into the company's ever growing   operations. With a BS in Mechanical Engineering
column15: Devine started   his career in the heart of operations
column16: as a production manager atTexas Instruments. He quickly moved to a leadership position at Boeing overseeing   a high quality electronics manufacturing facility while   completing an MBA at the same time. Devine then moved through   progressively larger and more global roles atNokia
column17: Hewlett-Packard's Palm division
column18: Ciscoand finally Chief Operating Officer at start-up uBeam. It seems   from Devine's resume that he has the ""right stuff"" for the   job.What impact could the right operations executive have?Devine will have responsibility for the functions of   ""operations
column19: customer service
column20: and overall quality"" which should   bring a number of benefits. Because of this functional alignment
column21: when a problem is brought to customer service
column22: it should be   quickly addressed by the operations team. As Devine owns both   overall quality and customer service this should facilitate   customer service data being used to enhance the customers'   overall experience.This new EVP role will report directly to Fitbit's CEO
column23: giving   operations a voice and a seat at the table at the top levels of   the business. This reporting structure could help bring attention   tomanufacturing issuessuch as the problems with the Flex 2
column24: potentially resolving these   types of issues more quickly. Lastly
column25: Devine should own all of   the end-to-end functions to manufacture and deliver products to   the end customer. As the sales teams make future sales   projections
column26: Devine can have input to ensure the plans can be   executed well.James Park is setting Devine up for success with his breadth   of functional responsibility and reporting structure. James Park
column27: indicated the importance of this role in the recent   announcement.Jeff and Samir bring valuable experience to our leadership     team and these new roles will help us increase speed and     efficiency throughout the company as we continue to create     world-class health and fitness solutions that people can't live     without.Investors should be able to see whether this executive change   is making a difference by watching whether gross margins can   improve back to the 2015 levels.10 stocks we like better than FitbitWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column28: it can pay to listen. After all
column29: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column30: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column31: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Fitbit wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: How to Short Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock for Free;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThis year has been kind toCisco Systems
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) stock
column5: which has risen all the way back to 2007 levels. If I zoom out
column6: the monthly chart shows more upside potential relative to all-time highs
column7: but on the daily chart
column8: CSCO stock looks extended.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFundamentally
column9: Cisco is a solid mega-cap stock
column10: and with the world becoming more digitally dependent
column11: it should prosper for years to come. Shorting Cisco stock now would be more of a proxy short to the equity markets in general.This is a potentially pivotal week for markets. Among other things
column12: such as the Brexit and ""TrumpCare
column13: the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates. Wall Street isn't showing much fear yet
column14: though
column15: as markets are plowing into record territory in the face of tremendous uncertainty.Because of this so-called animal spirit
column16: the long trade has been the easier one to take.Today
column17: I want to short CSCO stock. Before you send out for my arrest
column18: though
column19: understand that I'm not short on the company's prospects. In fact
column20: this pair trade is an affirmation of the longer-term potential in Cisco.Don't Follow Warren Buffett Into Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock ... YetWhat's even better is that the trade will be free. I plan to finance a debit put spread by selling risk against the perceived value of Cisco Systems.These are levels where CSCO buyers would defend the stock in times of trouble.How to Trade CSCO Stock Right NowThe Bet:Buy the CSCO April $35/$34 debit put spread for 30 cents per contract. This is my maximum potential loss for the chance to double my money. This is a bearish spread where I need Cisco to fall through the $34 strike by mid-April.Since I don't have a specific fundamental reason to short CSCO stock
column21: I want to hedge it. So I'm going to lower my out-of-pocket risk by selling downside risk.The trick is to find levels where I think Cisco buyers would support the stock in times of trouble.The Hedge (Optional):Sell a CSCO Oct $28 put for 55 cents per contract. This would more than completely finance my bearish bet
column22: but do so with zero out-of-pocket expense. However
column23: buy selling the put
column24: I do commit to buying Cisco shares at $28 if they fall below there.Sell Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Before the Rate Hike!Taking both trades results in a net credit into my account. So I would be profitable as long as CSCO stock stays above $28 per share. Furthermore
column25: any premium I recapture from selling the debit spread would be additional profits. So instead of chasing a price with this pair trade
column26: I have an opportunity to profit almost regardless.I am not required to hold my positions open through expiration. I can close them at anytime for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column27: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackValeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Stock Doesn't Look Attractive Even 'Fixed'Why Home Depot Inc (HD) Stock Could Rise Another 15%The postHow to Short Cisco Systems

column1: 5 Technology Companies That Could IPO in 2017;3/14/2017;"After a tepid 2016
column2: the Initial Public Offering (IPO) market has been rejuvenated in 2017
column3: primarily on the back of the recent $24 billion Snap Inc. IPO. Snap's public market debut was the biggest technology IPO since Alibaba's in 2014 and the second-largest U.S. technology based IPO ever
column4: behind onlyFacebookFB
column5: its closest competitor and a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock. You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 (Strong Buy) Rank   stocks here.makeArticleAd();Snap's blockbuster IPO clearly demonstrated investors' pent-up demand for technology companies. The loss-making company sold 200 million non-voting shares for $17 per share
column6: above the expected range of $14-$16. Shares were up a massive 44% from its IPO price at the very first day of trading.Snap's hit IPO has opened up flood gates for the next round of public money seekers. This includes the likes of Mule Soft
column7: Alteryx
column8: Carbon Black
column9: AppNexus
column10: Forescout
column11: and Cloudera
column12: all of which are primarily tech unicorns (emerging technology companies that have a valuation of more than $1 billion).However
column13: two high profile technology companies - Uber and Airbnb - are not expected to debut this year as both of them have raised funds in recent times.  Reportedly
column14: Uber raised $3.5 billion from the investment arm of Saudi Arabia in Jun 2016. Airbnb recently closed $1 billion in funding
column15: which puts the company's valuation at $31 billion.Technology IPO Market is HotAlthough Snap's recent price slide is a deterrent to IPO investors
column16: we note that most of the issues are company specific. In fact
column17: we believe that the current macro-economic environment is most conducive for IPO investing based on President Donald Trump's plan of spending $1 trillion on U.S. infrastructure overhauling along with regulatory and tax reforms.We note that lowering of tax rate from 35% to 15% - as proposed by President Trump during his campaign days - will be beneficial to small and mid-cap companies
column18: particularly in the technology sector. This will surely attract IPO investors to this market going ahead.The IPO pipeline remains strong as evident from recent Renaissance Capital data
column19: which showed that 25 IPOs have already been filed this year
column20: up 13.6% compared with the same period last year. Moreover
column21: technology trails only healthcare in filing most IPOs in the last 12 months.Further
column22: ongoing consolidation in the technology market provides a significant opportunity for investors to buy new stocks that have significant growth prospects over the long term.Tech IPOs for the Rest of 2017If a favorable environment prevails
column23: there are a number of privately funded technology companies that can taste the appetite of IPO investors in the rest of 2017. Among them
column24: we would love to see the following five company's debut this year.Headquartered in San Francisco
column25: Cloudflareoffers content distribution network (CDN) and distributed denial of service (DDoS) mitigation services. Per VentureBeat
column26: the company has more than 4 million customers including the likes of CiscoCSCO
column27: Nasdaq among others. In Sep 2015
column28: the company raised $110 million from strategic investors like Google Capital
column29: MicrosoftMSFT
column30: BaiduBIDUand QualcommQCOM.Another San Francisco-based companyDropboxhas been a IPO candidate for a long-time. Dropbox is a file backup service that offers cloud-based file management
column31: storage systems and client software. It enables users to access and synchronize files
column32: and use applications through multiple devices. The company boasts of more than 500 million users. Per Tech Crunch
column33: the company had raised $350 million at a valuation of $10 billion way back in 2014.Palo Alto-basedPalantir Technologiesanalyzes Big Data and is best known for two different software projects - ""Palantir Gotham"" and ""Palantir Metropolis"". It also offers a wide variety of solutions related to fraud identification
column34: homeland and cyber security
column35: disaster preparedness
column36: and investing. Numerous government agencies are its customers. Late 2015
column37: the company completed a funding round that raised $880 million and put its valuation at $20 billion. (Read More:Will Peter Thiel's Palantir Technologies Be the Best IPO of 2017?)Headquartered in San Francisco
column38: cloud-based office messaging tool providerSlackwas valued at almost $3.8 billion in Apr 2016
column39: when it raised $200 million from a list of investors that include Andreessen Horowitz and Google Ventures among others. The startup is a competitor of Microsoft Office 365 as well as Atlassian's HipChat. Per Recode
column40: the company has two million active daily users and 800
column41: 000 subscribers.Music streaming service providerSpotifyhad been valued at over $8.5 billion in 2016
column42: when it raised $526 million. Per Reuters
column43: investors included Northzone
column44: Creandum
column45: DST Global and Accel Partners. The company has almost 50 million paid users in around 60 countries. The service continues to expand with recent launch in Japan. However
column46: the company faces significant competition from AppleAAPLMusic. (Read More:Will Spotify Stream Into an IPO in 2017?)Hear more about the current state of the IPO market on the latest episode of the Zacks Friday Finish Line:Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: Arrow and Cypress Join Forces to Support Internet of Things;3/13/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Leading electronic parts distributor
column2: Arrow Electronics
column3: Inc.ARW
column4: has teamed up with Cypress Semiconductor Corp.CYto deliver pioneering solutions that will facilitate new
column5: inventive business models for the Internet of Things (IoT).The collaboration will allow Arrow to leverage Cypress' IoT connectivity platform to help its customers in providing analytic platforms
column6: cloud and security technologies. This will bring continuous and complete IoT solutions to market.Cypress is a semiconductor company that offers high-performance
column7: mixed signal and programmable solutions. Its important customers include Lucent Technologies Inc.
column8: Seagate TechnologySTX
column9: Cisco Systems
column10: Inc.CSCOand Sony Corporation.About IoTThe ""Internet of Things"" is a concept seeking to connect devices used for everyday living to the Internet
column11: so that they can share and exchange data and thereby operate more intelligently. It may also enable devices to communicate with each other wherever required (such as in connected homes).Since it is still in a nascent stage
column12: it is currently dominated by innovative startups. Larger companies like Intel and Alphabet's Google are attempting to provide building blocks. But since the value of the technology might in some cases be a significant percentage of the device cost itself
column13: some of these big companies will become device providers in the IoT world.Despite many companies having come up with their versions of interconnected devices comprising doorbells
column14: thermostats and light bulbs
column15: none has emerged as an industry leader yet.Scope of the IoT MarketThe IoT concept foresees billions of connected devices and systems with applications ranging from sensors and mobile devices to home appliances and cars. According to research firm IDC
column16: as reported by the Wall Street Journal
column17: the IoT market could nearly triple in the coming years. In 2014
column18: the global IoT market was worth $655.8 billion
column19: but it could reach $1.7 trillion by 2020.According to the news source
column20: more than 90% of the world's data has been created over the last two years. We believe that that the chance to tap such an opportunity within the fast-growing IoT market is astounding. In its Jun 2015 report
column21: the McKinsey Global Institute projected that IoT applications could reach as much as $11.1 trillion every year by 2025.  We believe that by adding IoT cloud into its existing solutions
column22: Arrow will gain the most from the continued proliferation of IoT devices.Advantage ArrowThe collaboration will help Arrow becoming a key player in the automotive and industrial IoT segments.Going forward
column23: Arrow will also benefit by gaining wireless technology prowess and bringing more intellect to their products while speeding up time to market.Cypress's WICED software development kit has been designed keeping hardware manufacturers in mind.  The collaboration will help Arrow to enable quick installation of WiFi and Bluetooth in their devices.Per
column24: Aiden Mitchell
column25: global vice president of IoT sales at Arrow
column26: ""Wi-Fi is essential for IoT device connectivity
column27: and Cypress' Wi-Fi and combo solutions will enable us to bring robust cloud connectivity to our customers around the world.""Bottom LineGiven the ever-increasing number of connected products making their way into our everyday lives
column28: IoT is poised to grow strongly. This collaboration brings Arrow some key capabilities to cater to this huge opportunity.5 Trades Could Profit """"Big-League"""" from Trump PoliciesIf the stocks above spark your interest
column29: wait until you look into companies primed to make substantial gains from Washington's changing course.Today Zacks reveals 5 tickers that could benefit from new trends like streamlined drug approvals
column30: tariffs
column31: lower taxes
column32: higher interest rates
column33: and spending surges in defense and infrastructure.See these buy recommendations now >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

column1: NVIDIA (NVDA) Unveils Jetson TX2; Strengthens Foothold in AI;3/8/2017;"Graphic chip behemoth
column2: NVIDIA Corp.NVDAcontinues to strengthen its foothold in the artificial intelligence (AI) space. The company introduced NVIDIA Jetson TX2
column3: a smaller open platform to develop more energy-efficient AI computer
column4: making possible a new class of intelligent machines.This new Jetson TX2 is doubly efficient than its predecessors (Jetson TX1 and TK1). At the same time Jetson TX2 uses less than 7.5 watts of power supply and is specially designed for factory robots
column5: commercial drones and smart cameras for AI cities. We believe this will result in smarter devices with higher accuracy and faster response times.The technical specifications of the product are quite impressive. With 32GB eMMC storage
column6: 1GB Ethernet networking and Dual 64-bit NVIDIA Denver 2
column7: Quad ARM A57 CPU
column8: this new Pascal-based GPUs mark the biggest enhancement in the history of embedded computing. Priced at $599
column9: Jetson TX2 is now available in the U.S. and Europe. The company will begin shipping the product on Mar 14.According to Deepu Talla
column10: vice president and general manager of the Tegra business at NVIDIA
column11: ""Jetson TX2 brings powerful AI capabilities at the edge
column12: making possible a new class of intelligent machines."" He also added
column13: ""These devices will enable intelligent video analytics that keep our cities smarter and safer
column14: new kinds of robots that optimize manufacturing
column15: and new collaboration that makes long-distance work more efficient.""With the launch of this open platform
column16: NVIDIA can maximize user experience by offering more energy-efficient AI capabilities. Hence
column17: the launch of this product will enable NVIDIA to increase its customer base and help in garnering additional revenues.Consumers are increasingly using cameras to stay in their lane and lower accidents but this is not the primary reason behind the development of this technology. The chipmaker also shared that more companies are already using the TX2 in different ways. One of them is Cisco Systems
column18: Inc.CSCOwhich is using this open platform that aids screen sharing
column19: interactive whiteboarding and video conferencing. NVIDIA is trying to revolutionize technology to make devices faster
column20: smarter and more accurate. This
column21: in turn
column22: is expected to benefit NVIDIA going forward.To ConcludeRecently
column23: NVIDIA posted impressive fourth-quarter fiscal 2017 results and provided an encouraging first-quarter revenue guidance. Also
column24: the company registered year-over-year growth on both counts
column25: primarily due to growth across all its four platforms. Also
column26: better-than-expected demand for its gaming chips used in personal computers helped the company to post encouraging results.Moreover
column27: we believe that NVIDIA's innovative product pipeline and strength in gaming and high-end notebook GPUs keep it well positioned. The higher adoption of NVIDIA's Tegra processors could also act as a catalyst
column28: going forward.Nonetheless

column1: Verizon to Commercially Deploy 5G Fixed Wireless in 2018;3/8/2017;"The U.S. telecom behemothVerizon Communications Inc.VZis currently conducting field trials for its upcoming 5G wireless network with partners. The company is looking at mobile hotspot and home-based fixed wireless for initial deployment of the next-generation 5G wireless networks in the U.S. in 2018. However
column2: a full phased 5G wireless network will be offered only in 2020.Currently
column3: Verizon is conducting customer trials in 11 U.S. cities for fixed 5G wireless network. The company is focusing on building a fiber and wireless infrastructure in a bid to deliver mobile video efficiently. Recently
column4: John Stratton
column5: Verizon's EVP and president of operations
column6: revealed this plan at the Deutsche Bank 25th Annual Media & Telecom Conference.The wireless giant
column7: which was the first to deploy the 4G LTE (Long-Term Evolution) network nationwide
column8: is initially testing equipment at 15GHz
column9: 28GHz
column10: 39GHz and 64GHz frequency bands for 5G network deployments. The company's partners in the 5G project are Cisco Systems Inc.CSCO
column11: Ericsson LMERIC
column12: Nokia Corp.NOKand Samsung.Advantage of 5GVerizon claims that its 5G network will provide a download speed of 1 Gbps (gigabit per second) which is 200 times the throughput of the currently available standard 4G LTE network. Latency period of data delivery will be in single milliseconds. Further
column13: 5G technology is designed to be more power efficient than any other standard wireless networks available these days. Therefore
column14: 5G-enabled mobile devices are likely to last much longer than their 3G or 4G counterparts.Additionally
column15: superfast 5G mobile networks will be of utmost necessity in managing the exponential growth of Internet-connected devices
column16: popularly known as Internet of Things (IoT). The U.S. telecom industry has lately emerged as an intensely contested space where success thrives largely on technical superiority
column17: quality of services and scalability. Thus
column18: in order to stay ahead of competitors
column19: existing players need to be constantly on their toes to introduce innovative products. At this juncture
column20: we believe Verizon's drive for 5G wireless network bodes well for future growth.Price performance of VerizonIn the last six months
column21: the stock price of Verizon has witnessed a negative growth of 7.80%
column22: in contrast to the Zacks categorizedU.S National Wirelessindustry's positive growth rate of 1.34% in the same time period. Nevertheless
column23: Verizon has a very powerful diversified business model. In the wireless front
column24: it will start initial deployment of the upcoming 5G network in 2018 while on the wireline front
column25: the company is aggressively expanding fiber-based footprint. In the digital media front
column26: Verizon has become a major contender for the lucrative online advertisement business. We believe these are primary reasons behind the stock currently carrying a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: Retirees
column2: Maximize Your Income From Dividends;3/8/2017;"Dividend investing is supposed to be a bit like watching grass grow: steady progress
column3: few surprises. But lately
column4: investors holding dividend-paying stocks have suffered some jarring setbacks.SEE ALSO:8 Great Dividend Stocks for RetireesHigher-yielding sectors such as utilities and real estate investment trusts saw valuations soar through much of 2016
column5: then suffered sharp pullbacks later in the year. Analysts see more pain ahead for high-dividend-yielding stocks as interest rates start to rise
column6: diverting income-focused investors from stocks into bonds. A stretch of stagnant earnings growth
column7: meanwhile
column8: put the brakes on the double-digit dividend growth that investors have grown accustomed to since the financial crisis. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dividends climbed just 5% in 2016.""It's realistic to start thinking that the best might be over in terms of dividend growth
column9: says Christine Benz
column10: director of personal finance at investment-research firmMorningstar.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');Does this mean older investors should scale back dividend holdings? Hardly. The idea of getting income from stocks still ""makes a lot of sense
column16: particularly in this low-rate world
column17: says Tony DeSpirito
column18: co-manager ofBlackRock Equity Dividend fund. At roughly 2.5%
column19: the yield on theRussell 1000 Value Indexis about the same as the yield on the 10-year Treasury
column20: he notes. But while the Treasury bond offers a fixed coupon
column21: stocks offer potential dividend growth and share-price appreciation.The challenge is to pick the rightdividend stocksor funds. Rounding up the usual suspects--high dividend-yielding utilities
column22: REITs
column23: consumer staples and telecom stocks--may not be the best approach. One reason: You'd be ignoring some of the biggest dividend-paying sectors
column24: including technology and financials.The higher-yielding stocks also look expensive
column25: even after their late-2016 sell-off
column26: money managers say. Investors have used them as bond substitutes in a low-rate era
column27: and as rates rise
column28: these bond proxies will suffer more than lower dividend-yielders.Stocks that can deliver steady dividend growth
column29: rather than the richest yields
column30: offer the most fertile ground for dividend investors. These holdings look cheaper than the high-yielders
column31: they can hold up well in a rising-rate environment
column32: and they can offer a buffer against market volatility.You can maximize the income you get from these holdings by minimizing fees and taxes. In a dividend-focused mutual fund
column33: a lofty expense ratio can chew through most of your yield. And although the 15% tax rate paid by most investors on qualified dividends seems relatively benign
column34: many holdings favored by dividend investors and dividend funds don't get this treatment. Most REIT payouts
column35: for example
column36: are taxed as ordinary income.Follow these tips to build a dividend portfolio that can deliver reliable income despite rising rates and slowing dividend growth--so you can get back to watching the grass grow.Go for GrowthReliable dividend growers have proved resilient during the roughest times in the market. In a recent study
column37: S&P Dow Jones Indices compared the performance of dividend ""aristocrats""--S&P Composite 1500 stocks that have raised their dividends every year for at least 20 years--against high-yielding stocks in the S&P 500. During the 15 worst months for the broader stock market from the end of 1999 through September 2016
column38: the aristocrats lost 5.9%
column39: on average
column40: versus an 8.6% loss for the high-yielders and an 8.9% average decline for the S&P 1500.Thearistocrats tend to be more resilientduring the worst market downturns in part because raising dividends year after year reflects a certain level of financial health and discipline
column41: S&P notes.So where can you find dependable dividend growers at a decent price? For old-school dividend investors raised on Ma Bell and Coca-Cola
column42: the answers may be a bit surprising.One sector that's highly favored by value-minded dividend fund managers these days: technology. In 2016
column43: the sector surpassed financials to become the biggest contributor to S&P 500 dividends
column44: accounting for 15.5% of payouts.SEE ALSO:25 Dividend Stocks You Can Buy and Hold ForeverMature tech companies
column45: such as Microsoft (symbolMSFT; recent price
column47: Cisco Systems (CSCO
column48: $32) and Qualcomm (QCOM
column50: generate loads of free cash flow and are finding fewer opportunities to re-invest in their businesses
column51: says Mike Liss
column52: co-manager of theAmerican Century Value fund. That leaves them with an ""ability to increase their dividends at a rate better than the average stock
column53: Liss says.Microsoft
column54: which yields 2.3%
column55: has nearly doubled its quarterly dividend in the past five years
column56: to 39 cents a share. Money managers see more healthy dividend growth ahead as the company's leadership in cloud computing improves its earnings-growth prospects.Cisco
column57: which yields 3.3%
column58: is known for making the switches and routers that move data around computer networks. But Cisco is also expanding into faster-growing areas such as collaboration and security. The company has boosted its dividend every year since initiating its payout in 2011.Patient investors should also take a look at Qualcomm
column59: which yields 3.8%
column60: says John Buckingham
column61: chief investment officer atAFAM Capitaland manager of theAl Frank fund. The stock has been crushed this year
column62: in part because Apple is suing Qualcomm over its business practices
column63: and it now trades at just 11 times analysts' estimate of earnings in the coming year. Buckingham believes the litigation will ultimately be settled and ""the magnitude of the decline has created opportunity for those who can take a long-term view.""Look for Healthy PayoutsHealth care stocks have looked rather sickly lately. Concerns about repeal of the Affordable Care Act
column64: as well as talk from Washington about negotiating lower drug prices
column65: have weighed on the sector.But the political noise has created an opportunity for long-term dividend investors
column66: particularly in drug stocks. ""If you continue to create drugs that are innovative and meet unmet needs
column67: you're going to get premium pricing for those products
column68: Liss says.Holdings in Liss's fund include drug giants Pfizer (PFE
column69: $32) and Merck (MRK
column70: $64). Pfizer yields 3.8% and trades at just 13 times analysts' estimate of its full-year earnings. While the loss of patent protection on several drugs is a headwind
column71: the company maintains an impressive portfolio of patent-protected drugs and is launching several potential best-sellers in cancer
column72: immunology and other areas.Like Pfizer
column73: Merck has a strong pipeline of new drugs to balance out upcoming patent losses. Cancer drug Keytruda has been a notable success as the company sharpens its focus on unmet medical needs. Merck yields 2.9% and has raised its dividend six years in a row.Swiss drug giants Roche Holding (RHHBY
column74: $30) and Novartis (NVS
column75: $75) also look like good values
column76: says Matt Burdett

column113: which excludes stocks with yields in the top 10% of the broader stock universe. The fund charges 0.08% annually and yields 2.3%.Whether you're choosing a dividend-focused fund or picking your own stocks
column114: pay attention to the potential tax hit. Qualified dividends
column115: which include most U.S. stock dividends
column116: get favorable tax treatment. Taxpayers in the 25% to 35% tax brackets pay 15% on qualified dividends. Taxpayers in the 10% and 15% brackets pay zero; those above the 35% bracket pay 20%. If your adjusted gross income is more than $200
column119: you'll owe an additional 3.8% on your net investment income

column130: losing an average annual 0.73% over the period.Another taxing question for dividend investors is whether to hold foreign dividend-paying stocks--or funds that invest in those stocks--in an IRA. Many countries withhold taxes from dividends that their companies pay to overseas investors. U.S. investors are taxed a second time on those dividends
column131: either when they report dividend income for their taxable accounts or withdraw money from their IRA. You can claim a foreign tax credit on your federal return for the taxes withheld by the foreign country--but only if you hold the stocks in a taxable account. If you hold the investments in an IRA

column1: Cisco Is Now an Even Better Dividend Stock;3/7/2017;"While networking hardware giantCisco Systems'(NASDAQ: CSCO) fiscal second-quarter report was a bit of a mixed   bag
column2: it contained one great piece of news for investors. Cisco   announced that it was raising its quarterly dividend to $0.29 per   share
column3: up 11.5% from the previous payment of $0.26 per share.   With the stock now yielding 3.4%
column4: an already great dividend stock   has gotten even better.Cisco only began paying a dividend in 2011 after it became   clear that its days as a rapidly growing company were over. The   initial quarterly dividend was just $0.06 per share. Cisco has   raised its dividend at least once a year since then
column5: almost   quintupling it in just six years.Data source: Cisco. Chart by author.makeArticleAd();Among the technology giants
column6: Cisco has one of the highest   dividend yields. A stronger focus on share buybacks over   dividends at many of Cisco's peers is one reason for Cisco's   higher yield. Cisco has spent billions over the past few years   buying back its own shares
column7: but the company's capital return   policy is more balanced than most.CompanyForward Dividend YieldCisco3.40%Microsoft2.43%Apple1.64%Intel2.92%IBM3.10%Data source: Morningstar.Cisco spent $4.75 billion on dividends in fiscal 2016 and   $3.91 billion on share buybacks. Apple sent shareholders $12.15   billion in dividends while plowing $29.72 billion into share   buybacks. Microsoft paid $11.0 billion in dividends and spent   nearly $16 billion on share buybacks. Share buybacks can be a big   win for investors if the price paid is favorable
column8: but I generally   prefer Cisco's dividend-heavy approach.Will the dividend keep growing?Cisco generated $12.4 billion of free cash flow in fiscal   2016
column9: putting the payout ratio based on free cash flow
column10: the new   $0.29-per-share payment and the most recent share count at about   47%. This gives Cisco some room to grow the dividend over the   next few years even if earnings growth doesn't resume. Share   buybacks
column11: which reduce the share count and thus the total   dividend payment
column12: will also help the cause.The company's earnings growth has hit a wall in recent   quarters
column13: creating a situation where the dividend is growing far   faster than earnings. This will eventually become a problem as   the payout ratio grows
column14: and if Cisco can't return to consistent   earnings growth eventually
column15: middling dividend growth will be the   likely result.Its long-term growth plan involves shifting its business more   heavily toward software and services
column16: particularly subscriptions.   Switching and routing hardware will remain the core of the   company
column17: but those businesses have been inconsistent and are   likely unable to drive meaningful growth.Image source: Cisco.Cisco's deferred revenue related to subscription software and   servicesreached $4 billionat the end of the second quarter
column18: up 51% year over year. This is   spread across Cisco's entire business
column19: but faster-growing   segments like collaboration
column20: security
column21: and wireless make up the   majority. The move to subscriptions is hurting Cisco's results in   the near term
column22: as revenue recognition is pushed into the future
column23: but the subscription business should eventually become big enough   to start driving growth for the company as a whole. At least
column24: that's the plan.Acquisitions are a big part of Cisco's growth strategy
column25: and   heavy spending on acquiring companies may put a lid on dividend   growth over the next few years. Cisco recently agreed to pay a   whopping$3.7 billion for AppDynamics
column26: a software company that was on pace to generate about $230   million of revenue in 2016. More acquisitions are a near   certainty as Cisco looks to further build out its software   portfolio.One wild card when it comes to dividend growth is the   possibility of corporate tax reform and a tax repatriation   holiday. A lower tax rate and the ability to bring billions of   dollars in overseas cash back to the U.S. inexpensively would   free up a lot of cash for acquisitions
column27: buybacks
column28: and perhaps a   higher dividend. Cisco's balance sheet features around $36   billion of cash net of debt
column29: which could fuel dividend growth   even if earnings growth remains sluggish.With another double-digit dividend increase
column30: Cisco has made   its stock even more enticing to dividend investors. Dividend   growth may slow down going forward
column31: but with a 3.4% yield
column32: Cisco   is one of the best techdividend   stocksaround.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: One Put
column2: One Call Option To Know About for Cisco Systems;3/6/2017;"Consistently
column3: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Cisco Systems Inc (Symbol: CSCO). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column4: and one interesting call contract
column5: from the June expiration for CSCO. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column6: is at the $32 strike
column7: which has a bid at the time of this writing of 56 cents. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 1.8% return against the $32 commitment
column8: or a 6.3% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to CSCO's upside potential the way owning shares would
column9: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Cisco Systems Inc sees its shares decline 6.3% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $31.44 per share before broker commissions
column10: subtracting the 56 cents from $32)
column11: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 6.3% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Worth considering
column12: is that the annualized 6.3% figure actually exceeds the 3.4% annualized dividend paid by Cisco Systems Inc by 2.9%
column13: based on the current share price of $34.15. And yet
column14: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column15: there is greater downside because the stock would have to fall 6.3% to reach the $32 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column16: in general
column17: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Cisco Systems Inc
column18: looking at the dividend history chart for CSCO below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column19: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 3.4% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column20: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the June expiration
column21: for shareholders of Cisco Systems Inc (Symbol: CSCO) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 3.4% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $35 strike and collecting the premium based on the 76 cents bid
column22: annualizes to an additional 8% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column23: for a total of 11.4% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $35 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column24: but CSCO shares would have to climb 2.5% from current levels for that to occur
column25: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column26: the shareholder has earned a 4.7% return from this trading level
column27: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Cisco Systems Inc
column28: highlighting in green where the $32 strike is located relative to that history
column29: and highlighting the $35 strike in red:The chart above
column30: and the stock's historical volatility
column31: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the June put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Cisco Systems Inc (considering the last 251 trading dayCSCO historical stock pricesusing closing values

column1: Server Revenues Continue to Decline Per Gartner and IDC;3/6/2017;"The year 2016 was certainly not a good one for worldwide server vendors. According to recently released data for fourth-quarter 2016 by two independent research firms - Gartner Inc.ITand International Data Corporation (""IDC"") - global server market revenues witnessed a year-over-year decline.Notably
column2: this was the fourth consecutive quarter of decline for the industry. Prior to that
column3: it had witnessed seven straight quarters of year-over-year growth.What the Report SaysAccording to preliminary data released by Gartner
column4: worldwide server revenues decreased 1.9% year over year to $14.838 billion in the fourth quarter while overall shipment inched down 0.6% to 2.939 million. For full-year 2016
column5: server revenues declined 2.7% despite a 0.1% increase in shipments.IDC's views were also more or less similar to Gartner. IDC reported a 4.6% decline in server revenues with fourth-quarter revenues coming in at $14.613 billion. Shipments increased 3.5% to 2.55 million units.The reasons highlighted by the two research firms for this dismal performance were also more or less similar. According to IDC
column6: sluggish investment in hyperscale data center
column7: declining high-end server sales and tough year-over-year comparisons due to the end of the robust enterprise refresh cycle were the main reasons behind the dismal performance.Jeffrey Hewitt
column8: research vice president at Gartner highlighted some distinct aspects of 2016. He revealed that ""Enterprises grew at a lower rate as they continued to leverage server applications through virtualization and in some cases
column9: service providers in the cloud."" However
column10: he added that ""Hyperscale data centers (e.g.
column11: Facebook
column12: Google) grew and
column13: at the same time
column14: drove some significant server replacements.""With respect to individual server manufacturers
column15: both the firms have a similar view on the top three vendors. With respect to revenues
column16: according to Gartner and IDC
column17: Hewlett Packard EnterpriseHPEretained its leading position
column18: followed by Dell and International Business MachinesIBM.The research firms had different views when it came to the fourth and fifth positions. As per Gartner
column19: Huawei and Lenovo were at the fourth and fifth position
column20: respectively. On the other hand
column21: according to IDC
column22: the fourth place was a tie between Lenovo and CiscoCSCO. Furthermore
column23: IDC did not mention the vendor's name occupying the fifth position
column24: Instead
column25: for the first time
column26: it provided revenue and shipment data for ODM Direct group of vendors.As per Gartner
column27: it was Dell and Huawei that registered year-over-year growth in revenues as well as shipments. Dell witnessed an increase of 1.8% and 6.5% in revenues and shipments
column28: respectively

column1: Nutanix (NTNX) Q2 Loss Wider than Expected
column2: View Disappoints;3/3/2017;"Nutanix Inc.NTNXshare price fell 13.8% in after hour trading on Mar 2
column3: after the company reported wider loss in second-quarter fiscal 2017. Moreover
column4: the company's third-quarter guidance failed to impress investors. Apart from facing seasonal impact
column5: its results will be affected by higher memory costs and aggressive investments on product development.makeArticleAd();Loss of 28 cents per share (excluding stock-based compensation) was wider than 26 cents reported in the year-ago quarter despite registering a strong top-line growth. However
column6: the loss figure was much narrower than management's guided range of 35-36 cents. Including stock-based compensation Nutanix reported loss of 65 cents per share.Revenues surged 77.4% from the year-ago quarter to almost $182.2 million
column7: driven by 70.5% and 103.5% growth in product and support & other services revenues to $138.5 million and $43.7 million
column8: respectively.Nutanix Inc. Price
column9: Consensus and EPS SurpriseNutanix Inc. Price
column10: Consensus and EPS   Surprise|Nutanix Inc. QuoteNotably
column11: since its Initial Public Offering (IPO) on Sep 30
column12: the share price is down 17.8% as compared with the ZacksIt-Servicesindustry's gain of 10.2%.We expect the stock price to remain under pressure at least in the near term due to headwinds related to North American productivity issues
column13: gross margin impact from increasing costs of NAND and DRAM along with intensifying competition from the likes of NetAppNTAPand Hewlett Packard Enterprise in the hyper-converged market.Quarter DetailsNutanix's enterprise cloud platform ""converges traditional silos of server
column14: virtualization and storage into one integrated solution and can also connect to public cloud services."" The company's offerings include two software products Acropolis and Prism
column15: which are delivered on x86 servers.Billings were up 58.6% year over year to $227.4 million (40% from new customers up from 35% in the previous quarter)
column16: reflecting strength in the company's expanding product portfolio. The billings growth was negatively impacted by lesser-than-expected large deals (contract worth $500
column17: 000). Nutanix noted that North America productivity suffered due to realignment in the sales force.Meanwhile
column18: international bookings continued to remain strong representing a record 48% of total bookings in the quarter. The bill-to-revenue ratio was 1.25 in line with the normal range of 1.25 to 1.3
column19: which the company expects to continue
column20: going forward.Acropolis Hypervisor (AHV) continued to gain strong adoption
column21: with AHV nodes as a percentage of total nodes improving to 21% compared with 17% in the previous quarter. Management noted that certifications from OracleORCL
column22: SAP and Citrix are helping AHV to penetrate the enterprise market.Based on the Dell partnership
column23: Nutanix continues to add ""Global 2000"" customers. Moreover
column24: the company's software supports Cisco'sCSCOUnified Computing System (UCS) servers
column25: which is helping it to win more of these kinds of customers. Notably
column26: penetration into total ""Global 2000"" surged 68% from the year-ago quarter to 473 at the end of the second quarter.Nutanix added 200 new customers during the quarter bringing total end-customer count to 5
column27: 300 at the end of the reported quarter.Operating DetailsGross margin (including stock-based compensation) contracted almost 500 basis points (bps) from the year-ago quarter to 58%. This was primarily due to higher memory costs (DRAM and NAND) in the quarter.As percentage of revenues
column28: Sales & Marketing (S&M) expense decreased 350 bps from the year-ago quarter. However
column29: this was fully offset by higher Research & Development (R&D) and General & administrative (G&A) expenses.R&D as percentage of revenues surged to 38.9% as compared with 25.3% from the year-ago quarter. Similarly
column30: G&A expense as percentage of revenues increased 70 bps on a year-over-year basis.As a result
column31: operating loss (including stock-based compensation) widened to $91.4 million as compared with a loss of $35.2 million in the year-ago quarter.Balance Sheet & Cash FlowAt the end of the quarter
column32: Nutanix had cash & cash equivalents of $355 million
column33: up from $347 million in the prior quarter. The company generated $20 million of cash flow from operations and free cash flow was $7 million during the quarter.GuidanceFor third-quarter fiscal 2017

The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $187.4 million for the quarter.The third quarter is a seasonally slow quarter for Nutanix and management believes that the rebound in North American sales productivity will take some time. Moreover

column1: Are Investors Too Excited About Cisco Systems' Anemic Growth?;3/2/2017;"Shares ofCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) recently rose to a 16-year high after it beat   second-quarter estimates on both the top and bottom lines.   Despite that enthusiasm
column2: the headline numbers looked anemic.   Revenue fell 3% annually to $11.58 billion
column3: narrowly beating   expectations by $30 million. Non-GAAP net income stayed flat    year over year at $2.9 billion
column4: or $0.57 per share
column5: which   still beat estimates by a penny.As a Cisco shareholder
column6: I was glad to see the stock climb. But   it also made me wonder -- did Cisco deserve to rise to pre-dot   com bust levels? Or was Cisco's rally merely fueled by demand for   dependable dividend plays with low valuations in a low interest   rate market? Let's take at a closer look at Cisco's earnings   report to find out.Image source: Cisco.makeArticleAd();First
column7: the good news...Cisco's Security business has been its fastest-growing unit   over the past few quarters. Revenue at the business rose 14%   annually to  $528 million
column8: and deferred revenue -- a key   indicator of future demand -- surged 45%. Cisco attributes that   growth to robust demand for its advanced threat solutions   products
column9: next-gen firewall
column10: and secure internet gateway.Cisco's collaboration revenue also rose 4% to $1.06 billion
column11: and deferred revenue grew 14%. That growth was  attributed   to WebEx and Spark
column12: the cloud-based enterprise collaboration   platform it launched in late 2015. However
column13: Spark currently faces   tough competition in the collaboration space fromrival platforms.Cisco's Spark. Image source: Cisco.Cisco's wireless revenues rose 3% to $632 million
column14: fueled by   the ongoing expansion of wireless infrastructure to satisfy data   hungry customers
column15: strong sales of its 11ac Wave 2 (a new Wi-Fi   standard) portfolio of products
column16: and growing demand for its   Meraki cloud-based services.Cisco's total deferred revenues rose 13% annually to $17.1   billion
column17: thanks to higher demand for subscription-based and   software offerings. That growth will gradually allow Cisco to   pivot away from its slower-growth hardware businesses. Cisco also   hiked its dividend by three cents to $0.29 per share
column18: giving it a   forward yield of 3.4% and marking its sixth consecutive dividend   hike. Lastly
column19: Cisco generated $12.3 billion in free cash flow   over the past 12 months -- which gives it plenty of capital to   buy up additional companies inhigher-growth marketslike security
column20: analytics
column21: and the Internet of Things.Now
column22: the bad news...The big problem for Cisco is that its security
column23: collaboration
column24: and wireless businesses only generated less than a fifth of its   total revenue. Nearly half of Cisco's revenues still come from   its switches and routers units
column25: which are both experiencing   sluggish growth due to market saturation and commoditization.Cisco's switching revenue fell 5% annually to $3.31 billion   during the quarter
column26: due to weaker demand from campus customers
column27: which was partly offset by rising demand for its ACI   (application-centric infrastructure) products. Routing revenue   fell 10% to $1.82 billion
column28: as growth in orders failed to offset   pricing pressure.Those declines indicate that cloud-based SDN (software-defined   networking) rivals likeArista Networks(NYSE: ANET) -- which Cisco is trying to tackle with    lawsuits -- are causing a disruptive paradigm shift across   the market. Cloud-based networking solutions are more scalable   and require less on-site hardware like routers and switches
column29: which could turn Cisco's business upside down. Arista has even   claimed that combining its Jericho switches with its FlexRoute   software can completelyreplacerouters with  cheaper SDN solutions.Cisco's data center revenue also fell 7% to $790 million due   to the ""blade to rack"" shift in which enterprise consumers are   favoring smaller
column30: cheaper
column31: and more scalable rack servers over   pricier
column32: higher-powered blade servers.Lastly
column33: Cisco's guidance was mediocre at best. For the current   quarter
column34: it expects -2% to break-even revenue growth with   non-GAAP earnings of $0.57-$0.59
column35: which would be nearly flat from   prior year levels. Analysts expect its revenue to  fall 2%   and earnings to grow 1% for the full year.But it's all about the valuations...Based on those numbers
column36: it seems odd that Cisco is hovering   near a 16-year high. However
column37: Cisco's P/E of 18 is actually much   lower than its industry average of 25 and the S&P 500's P/E   of 25. Moreover
column38: the last time Cisco's P/E was at 18 (in early   2015)
column39: it traded in the upper $20s -- indicating the stock isn't   as expensive as its long-term price chart makes it look.When we combine that low valuation with Cisco's recent   dividend hike
column40: the stock has a good balance between a low   valuation and a high yield -- which has become increasingly rare   in today's frothy market. Therefore
column41: investors shouldn't be   thrilled by Cisco's lackluster top and bottom line growth

column1: How Cisco - With Jasper Technologies - Plans To Expand The Internet Of Things;3/2/2017;"When Cisco (CSCO) acquired Jasper Technologies for $1.4 billion a year ago

column4: 500 enterprises - a number that has grown to 9

column23: smart cities

The wearable device works without a smartphone and will leverage the “Samsung Gear S3 smartwatch and purpose-built software from Jupl.” Thedatafor December quarter suggests that 15.6% of consumers in the U.S. own a smartwatch or fitness band.These devices
column29: managed via the Cisco Jasper Control Center IoT platform

column1: Better Buy: Cisco Systems Inc. vs. Oracle Corp.;3/1/2017;"BothCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andOracle(NYSE: ORCL) have been under scrutiny from investors as they   navigate through significant business transitions. For Cisco
column2: the   ongoing transformation means less reliance on its legacy routers   and switches business
column3: and a greater focus on cloud-based   security solutions
column4: enterprise communications
column5: and the Internet   of Things (IoT).Though it took Oracle co-founder and current CTO Larry Ellison   a while to get aboard the cloud bandwagon
column6: his company has   finally done so
column7: and that's beginning to pay significant   dividends. Last quarter marked the first time Oracle's cloud   sales topped the magic $1 billion plateau. However
column8: Oracle's   cloud results come with a caveat.So of these two veteran tech majors looking to capitalize on   the next waves of change
column9: which is the better buy?makeArticleAd();Oracle headquarters Image source: OracleThe case for OracleBased on its year-over-year results
column10: Oracle's second quarter   was close to a home run. Each of its key cloud units --   software-as-a-service (SaaS)
column11: platform-as-a-service (PaaS)
column12: and   infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) -- performed admirably.The hands-down leaders in terms of revenue growth were   Oracle's SaaS and PaaS units
column13: which together climbed a whopping    81% to $878 million. Yes
column14: that's a mere fraction of   Oracle's total sales -- which were flat year-over-year at $9   billion -- but it's a  fraction that's growing larger with   each passing quarter.The aforementioned $1 billion-plus in cloud sales includes the   $175 million in IaaS revenue Oracle generated last quarter
column15: good   for a meager 6% improvement -- which represents a tremendous   opportunity. Combined with infrastructure software
column16: IaaS and   related software generated an estimated  $471 billion last   year with the majority -- $294 billion -- from IaaS alone.Which begs the question: Why is Oracle seemingly putting such   a significant opportunity on the back burner? The upside   potential in its cloud software business is also significant
column17: but   at these relatively early stages
column18: Oracle shouldn't leave anything   cloud-related unexploited.All the positive cloud news has been good for Oracle stock
column19: pushing its share price up 10% in 2017
column20: but there's a caveat.   Oracle's late arrival to the cloud translates to awfully tame   comparables
column21: so investors would be wise to take that into account   before over-celebrating.Cisco IoT. Image source: CiscoThe case for CiscoThough the cloud and related solutions are also on Cisco's   radar
column22: it's the focus on IoT and the fast-growing data security   markets that will drive this company's long-term growth. The good   news is that Cisco is making inroads in both key areas
column23: which it   demonstrated yet again the past couple of days.Connected cars are one avenue of IoT growth
column24: and Cisco is   among a host of providers going all in to win market share as   suppliers to the auto industry. Its recent deal withHondato power its new connected car platform is the latest in a   string of wins for Cisco in a market  expected to grow to   more than $46 billion in three years. So Cisco is moving the   needle with its efforts in two of the fastest growing areas of   IoT -- the other being smart cities. Better still
column25: its work to   dominate data security could give it a position that surpasses   even its IoT ambitions.As with Oracle's cloud results
column26: Cisco's strong data security   growth should be viewed in context. Through the first two   quarters of Cisco's fiscal 2017
column27: security sales have climbed    13% to $1.07 billion. That's a small fraction of Cisco's   $23.9 billion in total revenue
column28: but therein lies the opportunity.   One report  suggests data security spending will reach $1   trillion between now and 2021
column29: and Cisco is leading the   charge.Cisco expects there will be 26.3 billion connected devices   globally in 2020
column30: which is why its new ""security architecture for   mobile service providers"" solution is such a timely addition to   its offerings. Targeting telecoms with data security solutions in   an increasingly mobile
column31: digitized world is a no-brainer for it.   And Cisco's new mobile security platform has already gained a   number of fans among some of the leading telecoms on the   planet.The envelope pleaseSo which is the better buy
column32: Oracle or Cisco? Both are sound
column33: long-term plays
column34: but given Cisco's 3.4% dividend yield --   Oracle's is 1.4% -- and its early leadership position in IoT and   data security
column35: each of which could dwarf the opportunities in the   highly competitive cloud market
column36: over the long haul
column37: Cisco gets   the nod.10 stocks we like better than OracleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Palo Alto Networks (PANW) Earnings on Tap: What to Expect?;2/28/2017;"Can Palo Alto Networks (PANW) win back investors’ trust? That’s the company’s main objective when the cyber security and anti-hacking specialist reports second quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.Once a Wall Street darling
column2: the company has suffered growing pains over the past couple of years
column3: thanks to increased competition from the likes of Cisco (CSCO) and Fortinet (FTNT)
column4: whose products have enhanced their offerings due to R&D and — in some cases — acquisitions. These moves have pressured Palo Alto’s best-of-breed status. The California-based company has posted only in-line results in two of its previous three reporting periods
column5: while revenue growth has decelerated for almost 60% to 34% last quarter.Palo Alto stock closed Monday at $153.95
column6: up 0.61%. The stock has rebounded strongly since reaching a 52-week low of $114.64. But with better-than-expected results recently released from security software peers Check Point (CHKP)
column7: Palo Alto has more to worry about than just the aforementioned Cisco and Fortinet. Investors now want to know if the stock's hot streak can continue or if taking profits would be the better move.makeArticleAd();For the three months that ended January
column8: Wall Street expects Palo Alto to deliver adjusted earnings per share of 62 cents
column9: which would rise 44% year over year
column10: while revenue of $429.6 million would risen 28% year over year. For the full year that ends July
column11: earnings are projected to rise 66% year over year to $2.78 per share
column12: while revenue of $1.8 billion would rise 30.70%.Despite the strong 28% projected revenue growth for the quarter
column13: this would mark another growth deceleration of six percentage points from the third quarter. And this is why investors have gotten gun-shy. The stock was punished in November after the company’s billings
column14: which refers to sales that had not closed
column15: missed expectations.Billings is a closely-watched metric that underscores the strength of future business. Notably
column16: the billings miss arrived even as the rate at which cyber threats continue to climb. To the extent Palo Alto’s weak first-quarter billings manifest into higher revenue and billings in the second quarter
column17: these shares may yet be a bargain. But it makes more sense to not only wait for the actual results to be announced
column18: but also hear what Palo Alto forecasts in terms of corporate security spending in 2017."
