column1: The 5 Best Dividend Stocks for Beginning Investors;2/27/2017;"According toFinviz.com
column2: there are currently more than 3
column3: 500 publicly traded stocks that   pay a dividend. That's an overwhelming number that can make it   difficult for a new investor to get started.To help you narrow down your selection
column4: we asked a team of   Fools to each pick a stock they think is a great choice for a   beginner. They chooseWaste Management(NYSE: WM)
column5: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column6: American Express(NYSE: AXP)
column7: Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column8: andCostco(NASDAQ: COST) . Read on to find out why.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The benefits of buying disruption-proof     businessesTyler Crowe(Waste Management):One of the things beginning investors should learn when making   their first dividend investment is how to identify companies in   essential functions of our everyday lives with nearly   insurmountable competitive advantages over their competition.   These are the kinds of companies that will have the pricing power   to grow revenue and profits for decades to come
column9: and return   considerable value to shareholders.One company that fits this mold incredibly well is refuse   handler Waste Management. The company is the largest refuse   collection company
column10: and it has a large network of landfills
column11: disposal centers
column12: and recycling facilities across the U.S. The   waste-handling business inherently has lots of competitive   advantages for its well-established players. It's extremely   capital-intensive to build out a fleet of waste collection   vehicles
column13: there are lots of regulatory hurdles involved in   opening new landfills and maintaining existing ones
column14: and it's   extremely difficult to disrupt how humans generate and handle   waste. These things combine to give Waste Management a very   favorable operating environment where it can pass along rising   costs to customers pretty easily and generate a steady stream of   profits.For years
column15: Waste Management has taken these competitive   advantages and turned them into a very shareholder-friendly   business. For more than a decade
column16: the company has steadily raised   its dividend payments and bought back shares to generate high   rates of return in what many would consider a slow-growth   business.WM Return on Equity (TTM)data byYCharts.For beginning investors
column17: companies with huge competitive   advantages like Waste Management are a great lesson in why it   pays to hang onto stocks for the long term. The company's share   price gains will never blow anyone's socks off
column18: but its high   rates of return in an industry that will likely be around for   decades will reward those who hold onto their position.The transition is workingBrian Feroldi(Microsoft):I'm a firm believer that new dividend investors should seek out   big
column19: highly profitable companies for their first investment. That   criteria perfectly describes Microsoft
column20: which is why I think it's   a fantastic stock for beginners.Microsoft has been cranking out profits for decades thanks to   its stranglehold on the software industry. Products such as   Windows and Office are cash cows that have been a dependable   source of revenue for decades. That should hold true for a long   time to come.However
column21: Microsoft's stock stagnated for years over worries   that the ever-changing tech world would render this company's   products obsolete. Thankfully
column22: that worry got put to rest when   Satya Nadella took over the top chair in 2014. CEO Nadella   has placed an emphasis on moving Microsoft's products into the   cloud
column23: a decision that's paying off handsomely as revenue from   products like Azure
column24: Office 365
column25: and Dynamics CRM Online are   surging. When you add in the growth of other product lines such   as Xbox
column26: Bing
column27: and Surface
column28: Microsoft's bottom line has been   posting healthy gains in recent years.Looking ahead
column29: market watchers believe Microsoft's bottom line   will grow by more than 9% annually over the next five years. That   seems realistic when combining the growth in cloud product sales   with its recently completed acquisition of LinkedIn. Add to that   the company's rock-solid dividend yield of 2.4%
column30: and I can't help   but think Microsoft is a terrific stock for new dividend   investors to buy.Buy one of Buffett's favorites at a great valueJasonHall(American Express):Warren Buffett first bought shares of American Express when the   company's stock was selling for bargain prices. Decades later
column31: those shares are worth almost 10 times whatBerkshire Hathawaypaid -- but that's only the tip of the iceberg of what American   Express means for Buffett and Berkshire today.At the current $0.32 per share quarterly dividend
column32: American   Express will pay Berkshire almost $195 million in dividends in   2017. That may seem like a paltry yield on its $12 billion stake
column33: but when we look at the yield on cost -- that is
column34: how much   American Express' dividend pays based on the original investment   -- the math is much better: Berkshire gets paid a roughly 15%   yield on its cost for those AmEx shares. And with its prospects   and track record
column35: that payout is likely to keep growing for years   to come.There's a wonderful lesson for beginning investors: Don't skip   the small-yielding stocks if you're looking for dividends.   Sometimes your best choice is one like American Express
column36: which   has spent far more time yielding below 2% of its market price   than above 3%
column37: but it has steadily and regularly raised its   dividend for decades:AXP Dividenddata byYCharts.Don't let today's paltry yield cause you to miss an excellent   dividend growth stock. American Express stock is cheap today
column38: trading near 14 times last year's earnings. And with its track   record of dividend growth
column39: it could be paying you 15% or more on   your original investment in a couple of decades.The company at the core of our digital worldChuck Saletta(Cisco Systems):Cisco is the ubiquitous networking giant responsible for many of   the high-speed routers and switches that move financial   transactions
column40: videos
column41: pictures
column42: and text all over the internet.   It's also establishing itself as a strong dividend player with   both a decent history of increasing its dividend and reasonable   room to continue raising it going forward. That combination sets   it up as a great potential investment for someone just now   dipping into the realm of dividend investing.Cisco paid its first dividend of $0.06 per share per quarter   in 2011
column43: and it has been increasing it since then. The company's   current yield is almost 3.5%
column44: which is a decent premium over   the general market. It recently raised its dividend from $0.26   per share per quarter to $0.29

Costco manages to sell its inventory before the bill even comes   due.Oh -- and it somehow created a cult following thatForbesonce dubbed ""Costcoholics"" for the fact that its loyalists visit   the store several times a week to see what's new. Not many   retailers have rabid fans of their off-label brands

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere's little doubt 2016 was a downer forTeva PharmaceuticalsIndustries Ltd (ADR)(NYSE:TEVA) shareholders. Nevertheless

column6: though

column8: tied-at-the-hip resignation of its CEO and restructuring of management has been a definite drag on shares of TEVA. And if that weren't enough to pressure TEVA stock

column16: but as a well-funded payout

column18: too. Shares also trade at a low eight times trailing free cash flow and management expects it can cut operating expenses by roughly $1.4 billion over the next couple years.Bottom line
column19: I'd guess Teva Pharmaceuticals would gladly take a mulligan regarding its price-fixing scandal if it could. More importantly
column20: with a recent $1 billion settlement with authorities
column21: changes happening in the C-suite and value rearing its head off and on the TEVA price chart; it could be time to forgive and forget.TEVA Stock Monthly ChartClick to EnlargeIn looking at the monthly chart of TEVA stock

column24: while marginally breaching key pivot lows in 2008 and 2011.A potential monthly doji ""decision"" candle that's taking shape as we enter the last days of February is another sign a bottom could be forming.Yet

If TEVA stock is above $34 at expiration the sold premium amounts to a return of 29% for a less-than-one-month holding period.The return represents the equivalent of taking in the quarterly dividend of 34 cents in TEVA

column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) has justdelivered second-quarter FY17 earningsthat beat expectations on Wall Street
column6: but once again proved that Cisco stock will not be returning to growth any time soon.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockCisco reported fourth-quarter revenue of $11.6 billion
column7: $50 million above Wall Street consensus estimate
column8: but -1.7% year-over-year. That marked the fifth straight quarter that the company has posted falling revenue.Sadly
column9: things appears set to remain that way for at least the next few quarters. After all
column10: Cisco guided to revenue growth of -2% to breakeven for the current quarter
column11: and sees non-GAAP per-share earnings coming in at 57 cents 59 cents
column12: in line with Wall Street's consensus of 58 cents.Oddly enough
column13: Cisco stock has tucked on gains of 6% since the earnings call
column14: reversing the selloff that happened immediately after the results. Cisco stock is now up a solid 13.3% year-to-date. So why
column15: pray
column16: are investors celebrating Cisco's revenue tailspin?Business Model Transition for Cisco StockCSCO is stuck in the throes of a serious business model transition. Since its early days
column17: the company has been in the business of selling switches and routers that move data around the internet. That's still true in a big way since the company still derives more than 40% of its revenue from this networking business.But with more and more companies relying on rented computing services from the likes ofMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAmazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column19: they are buying less and less of Cisco's hardware for their data centers.Even worse is the fact that when they do buy
column20: they are upgrading to newer devices less often. Further
column21: Cisco is increasingly facing tougher competition and cheaper offerings from the likes ofArista Networks Inc(NYSE:ANET)
column22: a company that was founded by former top Cisco executives.Throw in the fact that more companies are experimenting with software-defined networking (SDN)
column23: and Cisco is finding itself caught between a rock and hard place. Last quarter's results say it all: Cisco's switching and routing revenue for the quarter fell 5%  and 10% to $3.3 billion and $1.8 billion
column24: respectively.But CSCO has
column25: over the past few years
column26: been working on a grand plan that involves pushing for a recurring subscription-based revenue model. This essentially means developing businesses that will protect it from the vagaries of the boom-and-bust cycles of its core business.Chief executive Chuck Robbins is optimistic that Cisco can leverage the lessons gleaned from its subscription-based businesses
column27: such as Meraki cloud-controlled WiFi
column28: Security software and Collaboration to build a solid subscription revenue businesses. Cisco's Security segment was the brightest spot in the earnings report after growing 14% to reach $528 million. Meanwhile the Collaboration business grew 4% to hit $1
column29: 062 million.Investors were pleased with Cisco's latest report is because it showed that the company is making progress discovering new recurring revenue streams. The company announced that product deferred revenue related to software and subscriptions grew 51% to reach $4 billion. Meanwhile
column30: 10% of its $9 billion Product sales is now of a recurring nature
column31: up from virtually zero a couple of years ago.Cash Cow and Dividend MachineFor all its troubles
column32: Cisco remains by far the most dominant player in the networking business
column33: something that has helped the company preserve its fat margins. During the last quarter
column34: the company's Product gross margin decreased from 63.4% to 61.1%
column35: but its Services gross margin increased from 65.1% to 67.7%. Improving margins is a good sign that the company's pricing power remains undiminished.Healthy margins have allowed CSCO stock to become a cash cow
column36: with annual free cash flow approaching $13 billion. Cisco spends a lot of this cash on M&A activity. During the latest earnings call
column37: Cisco announced that it was taking AppDynamics off the IPO table by doling out $3.7 billion for the application performance management startup. But income investors need not worry - in the same vein
column38: Cisco announced that it was hiking its quarterly dividend by 3 cents to 29 cents.Cisco stock now yields a generous 3.5%
column39: among the highest yields in theDow Jones Industrial Average.Bottom Line for Cisco StockCisco instituted the dividend six years ago when it declared a quarterly payout of 6 cents
column40: good for a modest 1.4% yield. Since then
column41: the company has hiked dividends at least once every year.Cisco is also sitting atop a cash hoard north of $60 billion
column42: most of it stashed in overseas accounts. With the Trump administration looking to quickly enact legislation to lower corporate tax from 35% to 15% to 20%
column43: Cisco will be in a position to repatriate at least some of that cash and continue rewarding investors.Mobile World Congress: Apple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Everyone ElseThe 10-year Treasury note has been rising
column44: but at 2.52% remains well below the yield by Cisco stock. With such a healthy backdrop
column45: Cisco stock remains a prime long-term holding especially for income investors.As of this writing
column46: Brian Wu did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right Now7 Food Stocks That Will Deliver Tasty ReturnsThe postCisco Systems

column1: 3 Stock Valuation Metrics Every Investor Should Know;2/27/2017;"Whether you're just beginning to invest or are a seasoned   investor
column2: evaluating stocks can be a daunting task
column3: due in part   to the hundreds of metrics out for gauging a company's worth.   However
column4: while the number of metrics may make investing look   complicated
column5: not all of them are truly useful when you're looking   for stocks worthy of your money and time.To help you invest better
column6: we asked our contributors to   explain the three most important valuation metrics that every   investor should understand: the price-to-earnings ratio
column7: enterprise-value-to-free-cash-flow ratio
column8: and price-to-cash flow   ratio.P/E ratio: An easy-to-use
column9: useful metricKeith Noonan(Price-to-earnings ratio):The price-to-earnings ratio is one of the most common metrics for   evaluating a stock
column10: and while it's not a helpful indicator in   every scenario
column11: it can provide insights on how the market values   a company's earnings.makeArticleAd();As the name implies
column12: the P/E ratio is derived by taking the   price of a share of stock
column13: and dividing it by the annualized   earnings per share. This value can then be compared to other   P/Es
column14: whether of an index
column15: industry
column16: or an individual company. A   relatively low P/E may be an indication that a stock is   undervalued compared to its earnings
column17: while a high P/E might   suggest the opposite. As an example
column18: Cisco Systems'(NASDAQ: CSCO) forward P/E of roughly 14 suggests the stock is   inexpensive when compared to the networking and communications   hardware sector's average of 24.7 and theS&P 500's average forward earnings multiple of roughly 18.Confused about valuation metrics? Knowing the important ones     helps. Image source: Getty ImagesP/E ratios are used to evaluate price in comparison to both   past performance and anticipated returns. Trailing-12-month P/E   is calculated using actual earnings over the last four quarterly   reporting periods
column19: while forward P/E typically is derived using   expected earnings over the next fiscal year or 12-month period.   Stock prices are forward looking
column20: and past performance won't   necessarily be repeated
column21: so forward P/E is often a better    indicator than trailing P/E. However
column22: the company guidance   and analyst expectations used to estimate future earnings often   disagree
column23: and both can be inaccurateP/E ratios can be useful tools
column24: but they won't provide   meaningful insights in every situation. Companies that are young   or otherwise undergoing periods of rapid expansion or high   spending might have small profits or still be posting losses
column25: and   price-to-earnings ratios don't provide a useful point of   comparison for the value of an equity in these instances.   Earnings can also be affected by accounting practices and other   factors
column26: so digging deeper into a company's operations and   financials and using other metrics to supplement the information   presented by P/E values is essential.EV/FCF ratio: A metric that matters to business ownersChuck Saletta(Enterprise-value-to-free-cash-flow ratio): When you own a company outright
column27: you care about your total   capital structure -- your debtandyour equity. You also care deeply about how much cash the company   is generating
column28: as cash is frequently much more valuable to a   business than accounting profits are. That combination is what   makes the enterprise-value-to-free-cash-flow ratio such a   powerful one to look at for investors who want to act and think   like owners rather than speculators.Start with the enterprise value side of that ratio. To   calculate the enterprise value for a company
column29: start with its   market capitalization
column30: thensubtractany cash and equivalents andaddany debt
column31: minority interest
column32: and preferred shares.  That   basically tells you what the market is valuing the company at in   a takeover situation
column33: as any new owners would benefit from its   cash or be responsible for its debts.While there's no official definition of free cash flow
column34: a   common approach to calculating it is to start with a company's   cash from operations and subtract any capital expenses. Cash from   operations measures how much cash a company generates from   running its business
column35: while the capital expenses acknowledge that   generating that cash generally requires ongoing investments in   growth and renewal of equipment.Calculate the enterprise-value-to-free-cash-flow ratio by   dividing the enterprise value number by the free cash flow   number. The ratio can be more valuable in some situations than   the more common P/E ratio
column36: as it looks at the bigger picture of   things that typically matter more to true owners.The table below shows how you would calculate the ratio for   technology giantApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . Note that Apple's EV/FCF ratio of 14.8 is below   its price to earnings ratio of 16.3. Since Apple carries more   debt than it has cash and equivalents
column37: that lower EV/FCF ratio   indicates that Apple is doing a strong job of converting the   revenue in takes in into cold
column38: hard cash.MetricAmount (in Billions)Market Capitalization$712.06Cash and Equivalents$16.37Debt$87.55Enterprise Value$783.24Cash from Operations$65.42Capital Expenditures$12.46Free Cash Flow$52.96EV/FCF Ratio14.8Table by the authorStill
column39: the usefulness of the EV/FCF ratio to investors has   limits. Chief among them is that unless you have enough of a   stake to truly influence the company's use of its cash and   capital structure
column40: you have no control over with it will   appropriately use its cash or avoid overleveraging on debt. In   addition
column41: the free cash flow number can be juiced in the short   term by underinvesting in maintenance expenditures. Those   short-term gains can lead to long-term pain as equipment   ages.Despite those limits
column42: the enterprise-value-to-free-cash-flow   ratio is an incredibly useful metric for investors who want to   view their investments through the lens of the business owner.   Even if you don't control what the company does with its cash
column43: you can at least use changes in the numbers that make up that   measure over time to help you judge whether you think its   management is putting its cash to good use. And that's a number   worthy of the time it takes you to calculate and track it.P/CF ratio: Loss-making companies can be valuable tooNeha Chamaria(Price-to-cash-flow ratio): My fellow Fool Keith Noonan rightly pointed out how popular the   P/E ratio is as a valuation metric
column44: but as he also stated
column45: several factors can impact earnings. More importantly
column46: earnings
column47: as reflected on profit-and-loss statements
column48: can be manipulated by   way of non-cash expenses
column49: distorting the true picture of a   company's financial health.What matters more to investors is a company's operating cash   flow
column50: which excludes non-cash items to reflect the actual cash a   company generates from core operations. After all
column51: it is this   cash that the company uses to pay debts
column52: reinvest in the   business
column53: or return to shareholders via dividends and share   buybacks. That is why I always consider cash flow while analyzing   a company
column54: and price-to-cash-flow ratio when valuing a stock.To compute the P/CF ratio
column55: all you have to do is divide a   company's stock price by its cash flow per share. To derive that
column56: simply look up the company's cash flow statement to find its cash   from operations or net cash provided by operating activities
column57: and   divide that by the number of shares outstanding to get the cash   flow per share. While there's no standard to define an   ""attractive"" P/CF
column58: a lower ratio is generally better when looking   for value stocks.More often than not
column59: a stock that you may write off as pricey   based on its P/E ratio could prove a lot more attractive in terms   of P/CF
column60: as appears to be the case with the broader markets right   now. Here's a solid example to help you understand why:Caterpillar Inc.(NYSE: CAT) .The heavy-equipment manufacturer's stock has soared a   staggering 50% in the past year
column61: as of this writing. Given the   persistent headwinds in the mining and oil and gas sectors
column62: Caterpillar's rally and the consistent flow of ratings upgrades   from analysts have left many investors bewildered. After all
column63: how   can a company with a trailing P/E of 88 or a forward P/E of 33 be   undervalued -- especially if its earnings are expected to decline   this year?Enter the P/CF ratio. You'll be surprised to see how   dramatically different things suddenly appear when you measure   Caterpillar's based on its P/CF.CAT PE Ratio (TTM)data byYChartsAt only 10 times P/CF
column64: Caterpillar is anything but overvalued.   While Caterpillar's net earnings have slumped in recent years
column65: it   continues to generate strong cash flow. For perspective
column66: Caterpillar generated almost $5.6 billion in operating cash flow   compared to net losses worth $59 million during the trailing 12   months. That also explains how Caterpillar has maintained its   dividends despite plunging profits.Of course
column67: no valuation metric is foolproof
column68: including the   P/CF ratio
column69: but it's especially useful in analyzing companies   that aren't profitable or have taken big hits to their bottom   lines primarily because of macro factors
column70: as is the case with   Caterpillar. You could even go a step further and use the   price-to-free-cash-flow ratio. (Psst... Caterpillar isn't   insanely valued on a P/FCF basis either. Don't believe me? Go   compute the ratio now that you've learned about cash flows.)10 stocks we like better than CaterpillarWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column71: it can pay to listen. After all
column72: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column73: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column74: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Caterpillar wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofCisco Systems
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) have rallied roughly 8% since Feb. 10 without much of a breather. CSCO stock now increasingly looks to be in need of a pause as it has bumped into a key technical area of resistance
column5: before it may stand a better chance again of resuming its multi-year up-trend.makeArticleAd();Before looking at Cisco's charts below
column6: allow me to remind ye faithful of the importance of understanding the correlation among stocks.Unlike other asset classes - such as commodities and to some extent currencies - stocks in general tend to be highly correlated. While the price of pork bellies has little correlation with
column7: say
column8: the price movement in crude oil (both commodities)
column9: about 80% of stocks on average tend to move up and down together.In other words
column10: on down days in the stock market about eight out of ten stocks on average will tend to drop
column11: and vice versa on up days. This statistic holds particularly true in strong up or down trends
column12: such as what we have witnessed on the upside since the U.S. election results from last November.Looking at the current juncture in the stock market as represented by theSPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust(NYSEARCA:SPY)
column13: we see a broader stock market that has not had a down day of 1% or more in about three months and that from a momentum perspective looks well exhausted.As I always say
column14: markets can continue trending in one direction or another regardless of overbought or oversold readings
column15: yet the odds of overstaying ones welcome also significantly increase over time.What does all of this have to do with CSCO stock?7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowTo my eyes
column16: shares of Cisco are now reaching a critical technical resistance area just as the broader stock market
column17: too

column19: we see that CSCO stock over the past few days has reached its reaction highs from the year 2007.Click to EnlargeAlso note that the stock is getting closer to reaching the upper end of the multi-year up-trending channel (marked by the purple-dotted parallels).While Cisco stock ultimately can and likely will overcome this technical area of confluence around the $34 area on a more sustainable basis
column20: for the time being the stock likely needs to consolidate before taking this next leg higher.On the daily chart
column21: we see that CSCO as a result of the latest two-week breakout rally has reached a notable overbought reading in its Relative Strength Index (RSI) at the bottom of the chart.Click to EnlargeLast time Cisco's RSI reached such overbought readings it was late 2014 and the stock promptly corrected 6% over the course of a couple of weeks.Weibo Corp (ADR) (WB) Stock Goes Cold Despite Hot Q4 EarningsFrom here

column1: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd (ADR) (TEVA) Stock Is CRAZY Cheap;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTeva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd (ADR)(NYSE:TEVA) desperately needed some good news heading into its fourth quarter earnings report. TEVA stock hit its lowest level in over a decade the week before
column3: after its CEO resigned abruptly.makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler (Modified)The departure of CEO Erez Vigodman came amidst reports of bribery investigations in the company's home country of Israel. And it came after a long decline in TEVA stock
column4: driven by pricing pressure
column5: questionable acquisitions
column6: and a ""patent cliff"" for Teva Pharmaceutical's key drug
column7: Copaxone.And while Q4 earnings delivered
column8: the news wasn't great. Revenue increased 33%
column9: but that came almost solely from the acquisition ofAllergan plc's(NYSE:AGN) generics business. Teva Pharmaceutical paid $40.5 billion in a transaction that has boosted sales as well as Teva's debt load. Margins were pressured
column10: reflected in non-GAAP EPS that increased just 8% despite the 33% rise in sales.But the company also reaffirmed 2017 non-GAAP EPS guidance of $4.90-$5.30. That eased fears of another reduction in the 2017 outlook
column11: which had been cut in January from $6-$6.50. The news was enough to drive a ""relief rally"" in TEVA stock
column12: which now has climbed more than 10% from its lows.There should be more upside ahead
column13: even if the road might be bumpy. Teva does have numerous risks
column14: both near-term and long-term. But it also has tremendous potential
column15: a cheap multiple
column16: and a new CEO on the way. There's a turnaround opportunity in TEVA stock and it doesn't look quite priced in.Why It's Crazy to Buy Teva StockAdmittedly
column17: there are concerns across the board for Teva stock. Thepatent invalidationfor Copaxone
column18: a multiple sclerosis treatment
column19: puts an estimated 20% of revenue
column20: and possibly 40%-plus of profit
column21: at risk. On the Q4 call
column22: CFO Eyal Desheh estimated an $800 million cash flow impact in 2017
column23: should competition enter immediately.That entrance - which would occur if Teva loses its appeal - also would shave 75 to 95 cents off EPS.The combination of lower earnings and higher debt after the Allergan deal raises another risk. Teva's leverage ratio (net debt to EBITDA) at the end of 2016 was 4.7. That doesn't imply immediate risk of bankruptcy
column24: to be sure. But Teva bonds that mature in 2026 have fallen about 12% just since September. Clearly
column25: the debt markets are pricing in a greater
column26: if still modest
column27: possibility of a restructuring that could wipe out TEVA stock.The company now faces the challenge of finding a new CEO.Both previous CEOsleft relatively quickly
column28: amid questions of fit within Teva's culture and clashes with the company's board. The company's current bylaws require the CEO to reside in Israel
column29: though it's possible those could be changed for the next candidate.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99The bear case for TEVA stock is that
column30: yes
column31: it is cheap - and for good reason. Declining profits
column32: a $36 billion debt load
column33: concerns about generic pricing
column34: and the loss of Copaxone all present significant risks. And those risks justify a 7x multiple to the midpoint of 2017 EPS guidance.Why Teva Stock Is a Buy NonethelessThose concerns are valid. But they're also backward-looking.Teva has numerous options to improve its situation
column35: and interim CEO Yitzhak Peterburg said on the Q4 call that Teva would ""leave no stone unturned"" in considering those options.And what's important to keep in mind is that the situation isn't all that dire. Yes
column36: bonds have fallen; but the yield to maturity still is just 4.4%
column37: implying a very low chance of bankruptcy over the next decade. The leverage ratio could move above 5x if Copaxone competition moves in; but that remains a manageable level. This isn'tValeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc(NYSE:VRX); Teva's back isn't against the wall.The company has options. TEVA is targeting a 3.5x leverage ratio
column38: and likely will consider asset sales as a path to those levels. There's still the possibility of a split between the branded and generic businesses
column39: something Wall Street has long targeted. (That decision appears up to the new CEO
column40: per the Q4 call.)Copaxone sales and profits aren't going to zero
column41: even if generic competition enters immediately. And the same goes for Teva Pharmaceutical earnings. This remains the largest generic drug manufacturer in the world based on revenue. With rising health care costs a concern pretty much everywhere
column42: and drug pricing a key part of those concerns
column43: that's a major long-term competitive advantage for Teva.The Apple iPhone 8 Will Be Revolutionary (AAPL)And TEVA stock is cheap - even assuming the worst about Copaxone. Using the low end of 2017 guidance and the high end of the guided Copaxone impact still puts 2017 EPS near $4
column44: and TEVA stock's P/E multiple below 10. Simply stabilizing the business at those levels likely implies a 12-13 multiple - and gets TEVA stock to $50.It's always difficult to time the bottom in any stock. But the Q4 earnings from Teva Pharmaceutical seem to imply that the company at least has a handle on its challenges. Looking forward
column45: the debt load isn't so big that the company is forced to do anything
column46: and a new CEO will bring fresh eyes.There are concerns
column47: to be sure. But Teva Pharmaceutical has a lot of tools still at its disposal to answer those concerns
column48: and push TEVA stock higher.The author has no position in any securities mentioned.More From InvestorPlace9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.997 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialWatch Cisco Systems

column1: 1 Number Cisco Wants Investors to Focus On;2/21/2017;"The headline numbers fromCisco Systems'(NASDAQ: CSCO) fiscal second-quarter report were far from   impressive. Revenue slumped by 2% year over year
column2: driven by   weakness in the core switching and routing segments. Non-GAAP EPS   was flat
column3: aided by share buybacks.There were some bright spots. The security business expanded   by 14%
column4: continuing its impressive streak of growth. And the   collaboration business returned to growth after a disappointing   first quarter. But data center
column5: another growth business
column6: suffered   a decline in revenue
column7: and weakness in the core businesses   overwhelmed any pockets of strength.Image source: Cisco Systems.makeArticleAd();Cisco has been shifting toward a recurring-revenue business   model
column8: embracing subscription software and services as it aims to   lower its dependence on hardware sales. This shift is hurting the   company's results
column9: knocking at least 2 percentage points off   revenue growth
column10: according to CFO Kelly Kramer.The good news for Cisco investors is that progress is clearly   being made. Deferred revenue
column11: particularly deferred revenue   related to subscriptions
column12: is soaring. With a weak top line
column13: that's the number that Cisco wants investors to focus on.   However
column14: investors shouldn't ignore the price tag associated with   the acquisitions that are helping to drive that growth.$17.1 billion and countingDeferred revenue is booked as a liability on the balance sheet   when a company receives payment for a product or service which it   has yet to deliver. In the case of a subscription
column15: this deferred   revenue is transformed into real revenue over the length of the   contract. Subscription businesses that take payment upfront for   software or services that will be delivered over time often use   deferred revenue growth as a proxy for future revenue growth.   It'sfar from a perfect measure
column16: but it gives investors a rough way to judge a subscription   company's performance.Cisco's total deferred revenue reached $17.1 billion at the   end of the second quarter
column17: up 13% year over year. Deferred   revenue related to services grew 9% year over year to $10.5   billion
column18: while product deferred revenue jumped 19% to $6.6   billion. The rapid growth of the product deferred revenue was   mostly due to a surge in software and subscriptions.Deferred revenue from software and subscriptions was up 51%   year over year at the end of the second quarter
column19: reaching $4   billion. This explosive growth has yet to drive meaningful   revenue growth for the company overall
column20: but the numbers are   starting to get big. Roughly two-thirds of this growth can be   attributed to the security
column21: collaboration
column22: and wireless   businesses
column23: with the rest coming from Cisco's larger   segments.Even growing by 51%
column24: $4 billion of subscription deferred   revenue doesn't yet mean much for a company that does nearly $50   billion in revenue each year. Cisco remains highly dependent on   hardware sales
column25: and that's unlikely to change anytime soon. But   if the company can continue growing its subscription businesses   at a rapid pace
column26: revenue should eventually start consistently   growing once again.Driving growth with acquisitionsOne pillar of Cisco's growth strategy is acquisitions. The   company has made plenty of software acquisitions in recent years
column27: adding to its security
column28: collaboration
column29: and Internet of Things   portfolio. But thedeal announced in January to acquire   AppDynamicsrepresents an escalation. Cisco agreed to pay $3.7 billion   for the application monitoring company
column30: a staggering 16 times   sales.The deal makes strategic sense
column31: and it will help Cisco further   fill out its software business. But the price tag suggest that   Cisco is putting growth ahead of discipline. Cisco has tens of   billions of dollars of excess cash earning next to nothing
column32: but   dramatically overpaying for start-ups is a good way to waste   it.More software acquisitions are likely
column33: especially if Cisco is   able to repatriate some of its foreign cash at favorable rates in   the near future. Additional deals will help turbocharge the   company's shift to software and subscriptions
column34: but investors   should be concerned about the company's newfound willingness to   pay excessive premiums.The rapid growth of Cisco's deferred revenue is an encouraging   sign that the company's shift to subscriptions and software is   making progress and will eventually pay off. But acquisitions are   driving a portion of that growth
column35: and Cisco is paying a high   price for AppDynamics to keep the ball rolling.As a Cisco investor
column36: I have mixed feelings about all of this.   The push toward subscriptions and software is the right move
column37: but   the price tag for AppDynamics
column38: which Cisco plucked right before   its planned IPO
column39: is troubling. I'm hoping that the company will   be a little less eager to close deals in the future.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column40: it can pay to listen. After all
column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: How to Invest in the "Internet of Things";2/21/2017;"All around us
column2: the world grows more intertwined every day. Thanks in part to our global web connections
column3: we have the ability to interact with people and things on an incredible level. This online experience can be life-saving and important
column4: or it can be as arbitrary as simplifying monotonous tasks.There are many industries and companies that aim to advance this experience. One growing market
column5: known as the Internet of Things (IoT)
column6: connects our household or commercial items to a wireless network by embedding them with electronic
column7: software
column8: or sensor technology. This network of devices allows us to take the next step into a wireless world that relies less and less on direct human-to-computer interaction.You might actually be using products in the IoT without knowing it. Some common examples include the remote operation of a house's security system
column9: wearable motion and activity tacking products
column10: and even public trash bins that automatically alert a municipality when it is full.The Internet of Things is definitely present in our everyday lives right now
column11: but it also has a lot more room to grow. According to research firm IDC
column12: via theWall Street Journal
column13: the IoT market could nearly triple in the coming years. In 2014
column14: the global IoT market was worth $655.8 billion
column15: but it could reach up to $1.7 trillion by the year 2020.With the industry showing that much room for growth
column16: investors need to start thinking about investing in the IoT now
column17: and we've highlighted a few companies and strategies for those who would like get the IoT into their portfolios.ETF SuccessPerhaps the easiest way for investors to make a play on the Internet of Things is with a themed ETF. If that interests you
column18: check out Global X Internet of Things Thematic ETFSNSR
column19: the first IoT-related ETF on the market.Big Name Patent HoldersOne of the most important steps a company needs to take to capitalize on emerging technology is locking down patents at the earliest possible point. In regards to the Internet of Things market
column20: we've seen a lot of companies filing for patents that put them in a good position to grow as the IoT grows.One such company is technology behemoth AppleAAPL. Apple holds a patent named ""Local Device Awareness""
column21: which describes an automated relationship between multiple close-range devices. The technology could be used for position tracking
column22: such as finding a lost remote control
column23: or even proximity-based virtual reality
column24: like a video game that depends on one's actual position in a room.Another major IoT patent holder is IBMIBM. Primarily an information technology-focused company
column25: IBM figures to be a major player in the IoT. Currently
column26: IBM holds a patent regarding data filtering in Internet of Things devices
column27: which describes a process in which devices receive and interpret information. This patent puts IBM amongst the frontrunners in technology that allows devices to communicate without human interaction.Furthermore
column28: IBM just announced an Internet of Things partnership with Cisco SystemsCSCO. IBM will implement its Watson technology into Cisco's wide network of edge devices and end points in an effort to provide real-time feedback and data for the oil & gas
column29: manufacturing
column30: shipping
column31: and mining industries.Today's Leading ProductsWhile patents are important for future growth and development
column32: we also have to look at the already-available IoT devices. Again
column33: we are looking at some of the world's biggest tech companies here.One of the more obvious industry leaders is Alphabet Inc.GOOGLand its line of Nest home monitoring products. Alphabet
column34: under the Google name at the time
column35: acquired Nest for $3.2 billion in early 2014
column36: and since then the brand has become one of the biggest names in home automation with its smart thermostats
column37: smoke detectors
column38: and safety cameras.Another leader in the IoT market right now is AmazonAMZN. Amazon's Dash Buttons
column39: which allow users to re-order specific products with the click of an actual physical button that can be placed anywhere in the home
column40: could be considered an entry-level IoT device. Additionally
column41: the company's Echo smart speakers
column42: which utilize its Alexa home connectivity technology
column43: are probably the most popular consumer IoT product on the market right nowGoogle actually recently responded to Amazon's Echo speaker with a home automation device of its own
column44: the Google Home. The Home runs on Google's new voice assistant
column45: which also powers its new Pixel phone and represents Google's new era of hardware/software interaction.(Also read:Google's New ""Home"" Internet of Things Device   Challenges Amazon Echo)Finally
column46: SamsungSSNLFis another major player with its SmartThings brand. Samsung SmartThings are a series of in-home products
column47: ranging from electric outlets to motion sensors
column48: which allow for easier control of a users' entire home.Unsung HeroesThe technology giants will certainly be leaders in the IoT market
column49: but investors should also look into the smaller companies that will be the manufacturers of the actual hardware. For every product IoT product sold by Apple
column50: the supplier who built one of the components within the device also stands to benefit.One of Apple's key suppliers is Skyworks SolutionsSWKS. Skyworks is the industry leader in semiconductor manufacturing and currently produces a chip that is a vital part of the iPhone. Similar technology will be the backbone of the IoT movement
column51: as semiconductors and sensors move beyond their usual homes in phones and computers and into our other household items. Skyworks is currently a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).Investors should also focus on some smaller cap stocks that have potential to grow in correlation with the IoT market. One such company would be Sierra WirelessSWIR
column52: a wireless communications expert with a product line that should fit perfectly in the IoT market. Sierra is currently a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).Another company to consider is Iridium CommunicationsIRDM
column53: a low-Earth orbit satellite company that has recently partnered with IoT platform providers as the industry has discovered a use for LEOs in connecting the world. IRDM currently has a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).Bottom LineThe Internet of Things has the potential to change the consumer electronics industry as we know it. The growth of the market will be another indication of humanity's expansion into an autonomous world
column54: and investors need to start taking note of the IoT now.Whether you want to focus on the major technology players or the small companies at the heart of the IoT movement
column55: the time is now to add this industry to your portfolio.Also
column56: investors interested in the Internet of Things should check out this episode of theZacks Friday Finish Linepodcast:Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above
column57: would you like to know about our 10 finest buy-and-hold tickers for the entirety of 2017?Who wouldn't? Last year's market-beating Top 10 portfolio produced 5 double-digit winners. For example
column58: oil and natural gas giant Pioneer Natural Resources and First Republic Bank racked up stellar gains of +44.9% and +44.3% respectively. Now a brand-new list for 2017 has been hand-picked from 4
column59: 400 companies covered by the Zacks Rank.See the 2017 Top 10 right now>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

column1: Can Amazon's Chime Challenge Microsoft's Skype and Cisco's Spark?;2/21/2017;"Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) recently introduced Chime
column2: an  enterprise   collaboration service for online meetings
column3: video conferencing
column4: voice calls
column5: chat
column6: and content sharing. Chime's apps work on iOS
column7: Android
column8: Windows
column9: and Mac
column10: and the content is synchronized across   all platforms via Amazon Web Services (AWS).Chime comes in three versions -- Chime Basis
column11: for 1:1 voice   and video calls and chat; Chime Plus
column12: which adds screen sharing   and the integration of company directories; and Chime Pro
column13: which   adds tools for scheduling
column14: hosting
column15: recording
column16: and personalizing   meetings for up to 100 people.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();These features indicate that Amazon is taking aim at   collaborative tools likeMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Skype andCisco's(NASDAQ: CSCO) Spark. But are those rivals already too deeply   entrenched in the enterprise market for Amazon to disrupt? Let's   take a closer look at Amazon's game plan to find out.Entering the crowded SaaS marketAmazon's AWS
column17: which has an annual run rate of $14 billion
column18: is   the  biggest cloud infrastructure platform in the world.   It's several times larger than its closest competitor
column19: Microsoft's Azure. But while AWS dominates the cloud platform   (infrastructure/platform as a service) market -- which hosts   storage space
column20: processing power
column21: and other tools for companies   and developers -- it doesn't have a major presence in the SaaS   (software as a service) market yet.The SaaS market is the crowded
column22: consumer-facing side of the   cloud
column23: which includes services like Microsoft's Office 365
column24: Dynamics CRM
column25: and Skype. The lion's share of Microsoft's   commercialized cloud revenue run  rate of $14 billion is   generated by those SaaS products instead of Azure. Microsoft has   also been expanding Skype's capabilities as an enterprise   collaboration tool with  Microsoft Teams
column26: which enhances   Skype's cloud-based communication features and tightly integrates   the service into Office 365.Microsoft Teams. Image source: Microsoft.Meanwhile
column27: networking giant Cisco aggressively bundles   software and security products with its routers
column28: switches
column29: and   unified computing systems. Those bundles include collaboration   tools like Spark
column30: the cloud-based platform for  messages
column31: meetings
column32: and calls it launched in late 2015. Last quarter
column33: Cisco's collaboration revenues rose 4% annually to $1.06 billion   -- making it its third largest business after its  core   businesses of router and switches.But Microsoft and Cisco aren't the only players in the crowded   field of cloud-based collaborative tools.Alphabet's Google has been promoting Hangouts to enterprise customers   over  the past year
column34: Boxhas added collaborative tools on top of its cloud storage   platform
column35: andLogMeInacquiredCitrix's GoToMeeting video conferencing platform for the same purposes.   However
column36: all these challengers notably lack Microsoft and Cisco's   clout in the enterprise market.That's why Amazon believes it can succeedBut like Microsoft and Cisco
column37: Amazon also has leverage -- the   growing importance of AWS to enterprise customers. Amazon likely   believes that by offering Chime as an extension of AWS   (especially with its 30-day free trial) to its enterprise   customer base
column38: it can gain a foothold in the crowded ""unified   communication"" platform market.Amazon previously launched enterprise SaaS products like    WorkSpaces
column39: WorkDocs
column40: and WorkMail
column41: but it hasn't ever   released official growth figures for those products. However
column42: most industry watchers believe that those products are still   dwarfed by comparable solutions from Microsoft and Cisco. This   strongly indicates that AWS' dominance of the PaaS/IaaS markets   doesn't guarantee that Chime will become a Skype or Spark killer   anytime soon. Chime Pro also  costs more than Skype for   Business -- so it doesn't look like Amazon plans to undercut its   way into the market.The key takeawayChime sounds like a logical way for AWS to straddle the   PaaS/IaaS and SaaS markets
column43: but it's easier said than done. The   market for cloud-based unified communication platforms is   incredibly crowded
column44: and it's doubtful that a new service -- even   one bundled with AWS -- can claim a meaningful slice of the   market. However
column45: Amazon investors should still keep an eye out   for future SaaS products to see if the company can eventually   challenge heavyweights like Microsoft and Cisco.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column46: it can pay to listen. After all
column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column49: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: SaaSy B2B Sales Are in the Clouds;2/21/2017;"My pet project the last six months has been to learn everything I can about Facebook (FB) advertising. Let me explain why I chose that specific niche.I decided last year that it would be counter-productive to try and master the understanding of too many areas of technology. Between industry areas like big data
column2: cloud computing
column3: artificial intelligence and robotics there are hundreds of companies with dozens of different business models and customers.After looking at those four related areas
column4: I also decided that the best way to conquer the investment puzzle would be to simply buy the four most important players who will likely dictate the future markets for those technologies. Those four companies I profiled in my June Zacks Confidential reportBig Economic Disruption: Big Data
column5: AI
column6: & Robotics.They were Alphabet (GOOGL)
column7: Amazon (AMZN)
column8: Microsoft (MSFT)
column9: and IBM. To me
column10: keep it simple and just own the powerhouses who were already investing heavily in those areas
column11: while also busy swallowing up advanced tech and startups before the other guy.And the competition is heated as tech titans clash with war chests of cash. A fifth name could have been Cisco (CSCO)
column12: the arms dealer for the infrastructure of the Internet. Last month
column13: they plunked down $3.7 billion for a software company that was within days of going public.You can read about that ""buzzer beater"" in my January 27 articleCisco Snatches IPO Baby from the Arms of Wall Street.Why Facebook Advertising?So with all this ""battle of the tech titans"" going on
column14: why settle on the boring niche of FB ads? Two reasons: first
column15: it was easier to understand and more tangible than all the different things Google
column16: Amazon
column17: Microsoft
column18: and IBM were doing. And second
column19: something explosive and fascinating occurred last year in Facebook when they grew ad revenue to $26.5 billion
column20: representing 55% annual growth.I wanted to know what was driving that growth. And I was very intrigued to find it was a whole new world of marketing and sales freedom for small and medium-sized businesses around the world.Giving access to the little guy to advertising power that formerly belonged only to big corporations didn't just steal market share from the pie that Google Adwords had baked in the past decade.It created a much bigger pie altogether as local businesses
column21: online marketers
column22: and digital nomads found magic in the FB Power Editor to target ad campaigns
column23: audiences and even their ad budgets.Study SaaSy SalesThe universe of technology is changing exponentially. Disruption is the norm for most industries. But one way to keep it interesting and engaging is to pick a software company and learn more about their business
column24: customers and vendors.In the video that accompanies this article
column25: I show a jungle of companies and industries related to SaaS (software-as-a-service) providers and cloud computing.Along the theme of marketing and sales ""SaaS for the little guy
column26: ala Facebook
column27: I really like the business model of HubSpot (HUBS) who claims to have invented ""inbound"" marketing solutions where leads are generated online and then nurtured through email campaigns to eventually drive customer conversions.HUBS offers a free CRM to lure clients in. And speaking of CRM
column28: be sure to watch my video where I tell the story of the war of words between Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella and Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff over the former's bid for LinkedIn.A private competitor in this space is Infusionsoft. You have probably noticed a link or two from an email
column29: landing page or autoresponder that was being driven by Infusionsoft.Getting Giggy TooAnd some of the most exciting companies to study are those involved with services in the ""sharing"" or ""gig"" economy.While Angie's List invented the model 20 years ago
column30: and CraigsList keep it ""underground
column31: plenty of money is being invested by VC in new freelancer portals like Upwork
column32: TaskRabbit
column33: and Thumbtack.Thumbtack raised over $200 million in 2015 from Google Ventures and Sequoia. And just this year
column34: Australia's Airtasker nailed a Series B funding round worth $23 million.Be sure to watch my video to get more details on all these industries and trends. I've got some great graphics with hundreds of companies listed.Kevin Cook is a Senior Stock Strategist for Zacks Investment   Research where he runs theTAZR   Traderservice.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Cisco
column2: FireEye
column3: Barracuda
column4: NetApp and Ixia;2/21/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - February 21
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeCisco(NASDAQ:CSCO-Free Report)
column7: FireEye(NASDAQ:FEYE-Free Report)
column8: Barracuda Networks(NYSE:CUDA-Free Report)
column9: NetApp(NASDAQ:NTAP-Free Report) andIxia(NASDAQ:XXIA-Free Report)Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:Why Cisco Is Increasing Focus on CybersecuritySince Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO-Free Report) provides high-end hardware that connects computing devices at both the edge and core of the network
column11: it can add value to its offerings by making the network more secure.What's Going for the Market Right NowWith Internet of Things (IoT) devices continuing to grow and enterprises increasingly adopting policies like bring-your-own device (BYOD)
column12: the number of network end-points is increasing rapidly. On the other side
column13: the concept of shared resources in the cloud to be accessed by these devices has greatly increased the need for adequate security at the core.The changing work environment has greatly increased data flow between devices and the cloud and between each other. The advent of autonomous cars will increase these data flows exponentially
column14: as each car will generate a huge amount of data.Data is extremely important these days because when analyzed
column15: it can help businesses make better-informed decisions. So securing the data is in the interest of individuals on account of privacy concerns
column16: corporations on business considerations and the government on intelligence considerations.President Obama recently increased the budget for cybersecurity. But with President Trump taking office last month
column17: cybersecurity is expected to become an area of even greater focus. The draft cybersecurity order
column18: which he has yet to sign
column19: seeks to overhaul a policy under which each government agency was responsible for its own networks.The responsibility for hacks will now be placed on the White House's Budget and Management Office after a comprehensive review of the most critical hacking vulnerabilities in military
column20: intelligence and civilian government computer systems is completed within 60 days of the day the order is signed. What's more
column21: the Commerce Secretary will do the necessary to push the private sector to increase ""investments in cybersecurity tools
column22: services and software.""Cybersecurity Ventures reportedly estimates that the global cybersecurity space will grow at a CAGR of 9.8% from around $106.3 billion in 2015 to around $170.2 billion by 2020. Approximately $1 trillion is expected to be spent globally on cybersecurity from 2017 to 2021.IDC estimates that worldwide businesses will spend $101.6 billion on cybersecurity in 2020
column23: a 38% increase from the estimated $73.7 billion spend in 2016 with the banking sector spending the most. Geographically
column24: the U.S. will lead with $31.5 billion on cybersecurity tools and services and Western Europe will be second with $19.5 billion.The Asia/Pacific region
column25: while still a smaller contributor
column26: will grow the fastest in spending by 2020. (India will be one of the fastest-growing countries
column27: with the Data Security Council of India [DSCI] estimating that the market will grow from $4 billion in 2015 to $35 billion in 2025.) Middle East

column1: 2 Top Internet-of-Things Stocks to Buy Now;2/18/2017;"The Internet of Things (IoT) is a $19 trillion   opportunity
column2: according to formerCisco SystemsCEO John Chambers. That figure may be overstating it
column3: but the IoT   does present one of the most significant investment opportunities   of our times.One of the best ways to invest in broad-based movements such   as the IoT is by buying shares in the companies that supply the   hardware and infrastructure powering the trend -- such asSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) andNXP Semiconductor(NASDAQ: NXPI) . Let's dig into each company to see what makes   them two of the top IoT investments on the market today.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Skyworks SolutionsThough it manufactures about 2
column4: 500 kinds of   chips
column5: Skyworks Solutions mostly touches on a single theme   with its products: making complex connectivity tasks simple. For   example
column6: Skyworks' chips power a number of mission-critical tasks   inApple's iPhones
column7: such as solving connection interference problems
column8: increasing data transfer speeds
column9: and saving battery   power. The company's unique ability to offer turnkey   solutions for important tasks like this has made it a go-to   supplier for mobile devices
column10: a trend that will only grow with the   continued rise of the IoT.Skyworks' compelling value proposition continues to reveal   itself in its quarterly results. In its most recent quarter
column11: Skyworks increased sales 9% sequentially to $914 million
column12: which   also helped the company establish a new record for quarterly free   cash flow and net income. The company's financial   performance stands a strong chance of accelerating later this   year
column13: thanks to the anticipated debut of Apple's redesigned   iPhone; the Mac maker accounts for 40% of Skyworks' sales via its   contract manufacturing partner
column14: Foxconn. Overall
column15: the company should be able to maintain its   above-average earnings growth for years to come. The analyst   community estimates that Skyworks will grow its EPS at an average   annual rate of 14.7% over the next five years.Trading at 18 times its last 12 months'   earnings. Skyworks Solutions looks like an appealing way to   play the rise of the IoT.NXP SemiconductorDutch IoT player NXP Semiconductor specializes in enabling   secure connections between devices
column16: which makes the company a   candidate for strong growth as the number of devices that ""talk""   with one another increases in the years to come. The company   enjoys market leadership positions across a host of   connected-device applications
column17: including automotive in-car   networking and near-field communication
column18: to name just a   few. Its various leadership positions also provide NXP with   a strong margin profile
column19: as seen in its 48% GAAP gross margin   last quarter. This situation allows NXP to reinvest in R&D
column20: which spurs further innovation and extends its market leadership   in a virtuous cycle that CEO Rick Clemmer and team have   implemented to great effect.However
column21: for all of NXP's opportunity
column22: investing in the   company also comes with some important risks. Last October
column23: for   instance
column24: it agreed to a buyout offer from chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) for $110 per share; its shares trade at $102 at   the time of this writing. Qualcomm's offer was an all-cash   deal
column25: meaning that participating in NXP's continued growth will   require investors buy Qualcomm stock outright after the buyout   closes. But the outlook for Qualcomm's business -- aside from NXP   -- hasworsenedin the months since news of the NXP buyout broke.Qualcomm's patent licensing business
column26: which produces the bulk   of the company's profit
column27: has come under pressure in recent years
column28: as government regulators in China and the EU have accused the   company of charging excessive royalty rates to mobile-device   makers. This trend seems to have accelerated in recent months
column29: as   regulators in South Korea and the U.S. FTC have also sued   Qualcomm over charges of anticompetitive business practices.   Adding insult to injury
column30: Qualcomm customer Apple sued the   company in January over its patent licensing practices.Qualcomm plans to defend itself to the hilt and has presented   compelling counterarguments to some of the accusations. However
column31: given the weight of its current legal entanglements
column32: Qualcomm   seems risky as an investment
column33: even despite the long-term benefit   the NXP Semiconductor buyout is likely to add.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Skyworks Solutions wasn't   one of them! column1: 3 Cloud Stocks That Doubled in a Year;2/17/2017;"Over the past 12 months
column2: the S&P 500 rallied 25% and the   NASDAQ climbed 33%. Those gains -- which propelled both indexes   to record highs -- are impressive
column3: but a few other stocks crushed   even those returns with triple-digit gains.Three such stocks --Veeva Systems(NYSE: VEEV)
column4: Paycom Software(NYSE: PAYC)
column5: andProofpoint(NASDAQ: PFPT) -- all develop cloud-based software. Let's take a   look at why these three cloud stocks surged
column6: and whether   investors should consider buying them this year.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Veeva SystemsVeeva Systems provides a cloud-based CRM (customer   relationship management) platform for healthcare companies. It   usesSalesforce's SFA (Sales Force Automation) tools as the foundation of its   CRM platform for drug companies. Its core products include the   Veeva Vault
column7: which tracks prescribing habits
column8: clinical trials
column9: regulatory filings
column10: and industry regulations; and the Veeva   Commercial Cloud
column11: which helps companies manage customer   relationships.Shares of Veeva have soared more than 110% over the past year
column12: fueled by four straight quarters of 30%+ annual sales growth and   rising profitability. Veeva's revenue rose 34% annually to $142.8   million last quarter
column13: and its non-GAAP earnings surged 83% to   $0.22 per share. GAAP earnings more than doubled to $0.15 per   share.Veeva attributes all that growth to the growth of new cloud   services and new companies signing up for its Commercial Cloud.   Intense competition between drugmakers and new regulatory   pressures have also sparked fierce demand for Veeva's   industry-tracking services. For fiscal 2017 (which ended on Jan.   31)
column14: Veeva expects its revenue and non-GAAP earnings to   respectively grow 32% and 79%. For fiscal 2018
column15: analysts expect   Veeva's revenue to rise 21%
column16: and for its earnings to grow another   18%.Paycom SoftwarePaycom Software provides cloud-based tools for payroll   processing and human resources. It runs five main businesses --   Talent Acquisition tools for streamlining the recruiting process
column17: Time and Labor Management tools for managing employee work   schedules
column18: Payroll tools for automated payments
column19: Talent   Management tools for monitoring performance and setting employee   goals
column20: and HR Management tools for organizing virtual   documents.Paycom stock has surged more than 110% over the past 12   months. Its revenue growth rate has remained well above 30% ever   since its IPO in 2014
column21: and its profitability has gradually   improved. Last quarter
column22: its revenue rose  35% annually to   $87.8 million
column23: and its non-GAAP earnings grew 80% to $0.18 per   share. Its GAAP earnings rose 67% to $0.15 per share
column24: and its   adjusted EBITDA nearly doubled to $20.7 million.Paycom attributed that growth to its higher brand visibility
column25: expansion into new cities
column26: new client wins
column27: and market share   gains. For fiscal 2017 (which started on Jan. 1)
column28: Paycom expects   its revenue to rise 29% and for its  adjusted EBITDA to grow   about 20%.ProofpointProofpoint is a cloud-based security-as-a-service provider   that serves medium and large enterprises around the world. Its   platform includes a suite of threat protection
column29: incident   response
column30: regulator compliance
column31: email archiving
column32: electronic   discovery
column33: and secure communication tools.Image source: Getty Images.Shares of Proofpoint more than doubled over the past 12   months
column34: thanks to its robust earnings growth and improving   non-GAAP profitability. Its revenue has risen more than 40%   annually over the past three quarters -- which CEO Gary Steele   attributed to  ""robust demand for advanced threat solutions
column35: high competitive win rates
column36: traction with new products
column37: robust   add-on activity
column38: and consistently high renewal rates.""Like many of its cybersecurity peers
column39: Proofpoint has great top   line numbers but wobbly bottom line ones. Revenue rose  43%   annually to $106.8 million last quarter
column40: and billings grew 42% to   $138.4 million; but GAAP net loss only narrowed slightly from   $27.4 million in the year-ago quarter to $22.9 million. But on a   non-GAAP basis
column41: it reported a net profit of $8.5 million
column42: compared to a loss of $0.4 million a year ago.Proofpoint faces fierce competition from rival cloud security   players likeFireEyeand bigger bundled players likeCisco
column43: but it remains confident in its growth prospects. For fiscal   2017 (which started on Jan. 1)
column44: it expects revenue to grow 30%   and non-GAAP earnings to improve 36%.But mind those valuationsVeeva
column45: Paycom
column46: and Proofpoint all boast impressive revenue   growth
column47: but their valuations have also been inflated by their   year-long rallies. Veeva trades at nearly 100 times earnings and   Paycom has a P/E of 77 -- which are both much higher than the   industry average of 54 for application software companies.Proofpoint has a negative P/E due to its uneven profitability
column48: but it trades at 90 times forward earnings and 10 times sales --   which is double the industry average P/S ratio of 5 for software   companies. Therefore
column49: investors interested in these three hot   stocks should do some more homework to see if their future growth   potential can be justified by these lofty valuations.10 stocks we like better than ProofpointWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Cisco (CSCO) Is Increasing Focus on Cybersecurity;2/17/2017;"Since CiscoCSCOprovides high-end hardware that connects computing devices at both the edge and core of the network
column2: it can add value to its offerings by making the network more secure.What's Going for the Market Right NowWith Internet of Things (IoT) devices continuing to grow and enterprises increasingly adopting policies like bring-your-own device (BYOD)
column3: the number of network end-points is increasing rapidly. On the other side
column4: the concept of shared resources in the cloud to be accessed by these devices has greatly increased the need for adequate security at the core.The changing work environment has greatly increased data flow between devices and the cloud and between each other. The advent of autonomous cars will increase these data flows exponentially
column5: as each car will generate a huge amount of data.Data is extremely important these days because when analyzed
column6: it can help businesses make better-informed decisions. So securing the data is in the interest of individuals on account of privacy concerns
column7: corporations on business considerations and the government on intelligence considerations.President Obama recently increased the budget for cybersecurity. But with President Trump taking office last month
column8: cybersecurity is expected to become an area of even greater focus. The draft cybersecurity order
column9: which he has yet to sign
column10: seeks to overhaul a policy under which each government agency was responsible for its own networks.The responsibility for hacks will now be placed on the White House's Budget and Management Office after a comprehensive review of the most critical hacking vulnerabilities in military
column11: intelligence and civilian government computer systems is completed within 60 days of the day the order is signed. What's more
column12: the Commerce Secretary will do the necessary to push the private sector to increase ""investments in cybersecurity tools
column13: services and software.""Cybersecurity Ventures reportedly estimates that the global cybersecurity space will grow at a CAGR of 9.8% from around $106.3 billion in 2015 to around $170.2 billion by 2020. Approximately $1 trillion is expected to be spent globally on cybersecurity from 2017 to 2021.IDC estimates that worldwide businesses will spend $101.6 billion on cybersecurity in 2020
column14: a 38% increase from the estimated $73.7 billion spend in 2016 with the banking sector spending the most. Geographically
column15: the U.S. will lead with $31.5 billion on cybersecurity tools and services and Western Europe will be second with $19.5 billion.The Asia/Pacific region
column16: while still a smaller contributor
column17: will grow the fastest in spending by 2020. (India will be one of the fastest-growing countries

column1: Cisco Systems Reaches Analyst Target Price;2/17/2017;"In recent trading
column2: shares of Cisco Systems Inc (Symbol: CSCO) have crossed above the average analyst 12-month target price of $32.89
column3: changing hands for $33.60/share. When a stock reaches the target an analyst has set
column4: the analyst logically has two ways to react: downgrade on valuation
column5: or
column6: re-adjust their target price to a higher level. Analyst reaction may also depend on the fundamental business developments that may be responsible for driving the stock price higher - if things are looking up for the company
column7: perhaps it is time for that target price to be raised.makeArticleAd();There are 19 different analyst targets contributing to that average for Cisco Systems Inc
column8: but the average is just that - a mathematical average. There are analysts with lower targets than the average
column9: including one looking for a price of $22.00. And then on the other side of the spectrum one analyst has a target as high as $40.00. The standard deviation is $3.97.But the whole reason to look at theaverageCSCO price target in the first place is to tap into a ""wisdom of crowds"" effort
column10: putting together the contributions of all the individual minds who contributed to the ultimate number
column11: as opposed to what just one particular expert believes. And so with CSCO crossing above that average target price of $32.89/share
column12: investors in CSCO have been given a good signal to spend fresh time assessing the company and deciding for themselves: is $32.89 just one stop on the way to an evenhighertarget
column13: or has the valuation gotten stretched to the point where it is time to think about taking some chips off the table? Below is a table showing the current thinking of the analysts that cover Cisco Systems Inc:Recent CSCO Analyst Ratings BreakdownCurrent1 Month Ago2 Month Ago3 Month AgoStrong buy ratings:15151515Buy ratings:2222Hold ratings:7776Sell ratings:0000Strong sell ratings:1111Average rating:1.81.81.81.75The average rating presented in the last row of the above table above is from 1 to 5 where 1 is Strong Buy and 5 is Strong Sell. This article useddata provided by Zacks Investment Research via Quandl.com.Get the latest Zacks research report on CSCO - FREE.The Top 25 Broker Analyst Picks of the S&P 500 »"

column40: 000 clients

column44: usage and reference pattern of customers. If such advanced mechanisms are coupled with adequate cybersecurity protections
column45: businesses and individuals will have unique payment experiences in the times to come. The whole ecosystem of paying for anything will change dramatically and it won’t be long before your running shoes will tell you that it’s time for you to get a new pair."

column9: the dollar was lower

column13: Fossil Group Inc(NASDAQ:FOSL) fell 14.8% after a messy Q4 report with below-consensus revenues and weak profit margins as watch sales remain soft and the ""Wearables Revolution"" has been a disappointment.LendingClub Corp(NYSE:LC) fell 4.7% on slightly better Q4 results as investors worried about weaker-than-expected loan originations and weak forward guidance.A batch of strong economic data seemed to be the main catalyst for the day
column14: confirming real growth and inflation is heating up.Headline retail sales rose 0.4% in January over December pushing the annual rise to levels not seen since 2014. Headline consumer price inflation jumped 0.6% month-over-month - double the expected gain - for the hottest print since February 2013. On an annual basis

column16: the February Empire State manufacturing survey increased to its strongest print since September 2014.On the political front
column17: attention was paid to President Trump's reiteration that his tax reform plans are forthcoming and would ""substantially"" lower rates for consumers and businesses.Cisco Systems
