column1: Tech Stock Roundup: INTC Analyst Day
column2: AAPL Smartphone Lead;2/15/2017;"Intel Analyst DayIntel's analyst day was mostly about the growing importance of the data center business as a driver of both revenue growth and margin pressure. Within data center
column3: the enterprise and government segment is expected to be the weakest due to delays related to the transition from on-premises to public cloud-based deployment
column4: which is why it will grow a mere 2%.But this will be strongly supplemented with 15%+ growth in cloud service provider (helped by TAM expansion and higher prices) and 10%+ growth in communications service provider revenues. The much larger CPU portion will post a 6% CAGR dropping from 87% of revenue in 2017 to 75% in 2021. Non CPU parts of the data center business will record a 30% CAGR during the same time period.Intel put out some rather convincing charts showing the artificial intelligence opportunity and Intel's position within it along with its significance for total server revenue. Accordingly
column6: AI was just 7% of revenue
column7: of which 60% was classic machine learning with the remainder being deep learning.In 2010
column8: when NVIDIANVDAentered the market
column9: Intel HPC accounted for 93% of the market with NVIDIA making up the rest. NVIDIA grew strongly for the next two years but Xeon Phi has started taking back share again. As a result
column11: Intel's combined technologies gained back some market to end at 84%.Because of the huge opportunity
column12: Intel will be devoting more R&D dollars to strengthen this business and its new chips starting from the last iteration of 10nm will be first available to its data center customers. Increasing costs will therefore have a negative impact on this business over the next few years.In 2017
column13: management expects revenue growth in the low single digit range
column14: a gross margin of around 63% and EPS of around $2.80. DCG will be up high single digits
column15: CCG will be down mid single-digits
column16: NSG up 20%+
column17: IoTG up 10%+ and PSG up mid-single-digits.Intel expects to spend $12 billion (+/- $500 million) on capex this year
column18: of which $2.5 billion will be on memory. But capacity additions will account for most of the rest.Management also pointed to future opportunities: memory ($100 billion TAM)
column19: autonomous vehicles in 2025 ($10 billion TAM) and 5G connected devices (more than $50 billion TAM).Intel's U.S. Factory Endears It to TrumpIntel CEO Brian Krzanich met with Trump and promised to invest an additional $7 billion in an Arizona factory it originally started building back in 2011. The plant will employ 3K high-tech high-wage employees and it is estimated that indirect jobs relating to it will take employment up by about 10K.Intel has struggled to take the x86 architecture below 10nm
column20: which could be partially responsible for construction being put on hold. Intel is one of the few technology companies that stuck with its U.S. fabs as a matter of policy even when many of its peers moved offshore. Intel owns leading edge IP that it wouldn't want to outsource to places where IP laws are suspect.The CEO made no bones about the fact that conducive tax and regulatory measures had prompted the company's decision to complete the investment now
column21: so he may have eked out some concessions from Trump.Apple Sells More Smartphones Than SamsungAccording to IDC data published Feb 1
column22: Apple shipped slightly more smartphones in the holiday quarter than Samsung
column23: despite the fact that iPhone shipments were down for the first time in 2016. This is the first time in five years that the company gained the top spot.Apple's success was attributed to the iPhone 7 and Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 fiasco. Samsung said the exploding phones cost it $3 billion in sales. Overall smartphones grew just 2.3% in 2016 compared to 10.4% the previous year. Apple's 4.7% growth rate was better than the industry. Samsung shipments declined 5.2%.IDC expects the market to rebound this year
column24: in part because of expectations of a landmark phone from Apple and renewed demand in the Middle East and Latin America
column25: which didn't have a good 2016. Separately
column26: Canaccord Genuity has said that while Apple accounted for just 18% of the smartphone market last quarter
column27: it took 92% of the profits.Google Selling Its Satellite CompanyGoogle has agreed to sell its high-resolution satellite imaging business
column28: Terra Bella
column29: to imaging startup Planet Labs for somewhere between $300 and $500 million. Planet Labs has a number of medium resolution satellites that will complement the ones it has acquired
column30: according to Planet.Google is not quitting the mapping business and a long-term agreement to license the technology back from Planet is reportedly a part of the deal. This may not be a hugely profitable deal for Google given that it originally acquired Terra Bella for $500 million in 2014 when the company was called Skybox. But it may be a part of the realignment of its business units and goals under CFO Ruth Porat.CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+2.36%+22.12%FB+2.45%+7.12%GOOGL+1.79%+3.68%MSFT+0.50%+10.23%INTC-3.23%+0.86%CSCO+0.61%+1.61%AMZN+2.12%+7.94%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateApple Submits on Aussie Bank Boycott: Apple has submitted a statement to the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) charging the top four banks (Commonwealth Bank of Australia
column31: National Australia Bank Ltd.
column32: Westpac Banking Corp. and Bendigo & Adelaide Bank Ltd) in Australia of delaying the expansion of Apple Pay
column33: which could prove detrimental to smaller card issuers while reducing options for consumers.The banks
column34: which are in the process of developing their own mobile technology
column35: are seeking to bargain collectively with Apple to have their apps included in Apple Pay. Apple would rather have card issuers add their cards to its wallet and have the banks pay for inclusion. Apple said it won't give the banks a ""free ride"" while the banks responded saying Apple's assertion was ""incorrect and unsupported."" In its draft ruling
column36: the ACCC denied the banks' request. The final ruling is expected in March.Apple Hires Away Amazon Executive: Timothy D. Twerdahl
column37: who formerly headed Amazon's Fire TV unit as its general manager and director
column38: has now joined Apple as its VP in charge of marketing Apple TV. Pete Distad who previously played that role will now help Apple negotiate content deals. Twerdahl has vast experience in streaming: before his four-year stint at Amazon he was VP of consumer devices at Roku and before that
column39: he was an executive at Netflix. The executive changes seem to indicate that Apple is finally going to make some bold moves in this business
column40: which hasn't really done that well versus competitors.Facebook VR Demo Stations Shutting Down: Facebook (FB) is closing down around 200 of its 500 VR demo stations at Best Buy stores. It appears that the Oculus wasn't as much of a success as anticipated because few people came in for a demo at all and store attendants said that frequent software issues with the headsets made them unsellable. But the headsets aren't going out of circulation. The stores will continue to sell them and Facebook has promised that there will be pop up and other stores that will continue with the demos. The program started with 50 stores that were later expanded to 500 in August last year.Facebook Hires MTV Executive: Facebook is very serious about content
column41: video content in particular. On the earnings call
column42: Zuckerberg mentioned how video was the next big thing just like mobile. So it has done everything possible to help share videos of every description and host Facebook Live streams. But in order to increase differentiation and the price of ads running adjacent to these videos
column43: Facebook needs a little bit more. And now it's apparent that that is original content. The company has snapped up Mina Lefevre
column44: who was in charge of scripted programming at MTV to head up its content development efforts. She will report to Ricky Van Veen
column45: co-founder of CollegeHumor.Legal/RegulatoryMicrosoft Battles with Govt Spying: The court hasn't allowed the government's request to throw out a MicrosoftMSFTlawsuit
column46: in which it contended that the Electronic Communications Privacy Act violates the first amendment. The act allows the government to issue gag orders when asking for data housed on third-party servers like those owned by Microsoft.The Justice Department had asked the government to dismiss the lawsuit saying that it needed to keep investigations confidential so as not to alarm possible wrong-doers and that they did eventually get to know when charges were filed. Microsoft succeeded in convincing the judge that this affected its ability to do business. But the court held that Microsoft couldn't assert constitutional rights for someone else
column47: so it couldn't talk on behalf of its customers.Google Wants Warrants for Govt Snooping: Google's head of information security Richard Salgado visited senators to speed up the passage of a bill that has previously been endorsed by the House of Representatives. The bill seeks to do away with one clause of the current law that allows the government to obtain access emails that are more than 180 days old without a warrant. Google would like the law to be applicable for all emails irrespective of age. The bill was in the hands of Senator Jeff Sessions prior to the elections
column48: when he was elevated to the position of Attorney General by President Trump.New Technology/ProductsCisco Announces First SIG: CiscoCSCOhas created a new Secure Internet Gateway (SIG) in the cloud that will allow on-field or mobile enterprise users to connect securely to the Internet even when they aren't connected through VPN. Cisco's solution is called Umbrella. Umbrella can identify which SaaS apps are being used and enforce policies to block risky or inappropriate apps; analyze over 100 billion internet requests every day
column49: correlating with over 11 billion historical events to identify patterns
column50: detect anomalies
column51: and create models to automatically uncover attacker infrastructure being staged for the next threat; and other security checks through machine learning
column52: Cisco Talos threat intelligence
column53: and Cisco Advanced Malware Protection (AMP).Microsoft Extends Support to Cloud Customers: Boston Consulting Group says that while IP lawsuits have increased 22% over the last five years
column54: patent trolls - companies that don't have a business but acquire patents to benefit from litigation - increased patent acquisitions by 35%. It is perhaps these trends that prompted Microsoft to expand its patent protection coverage to all users of its Azure infrastructure. Microsoft will give customers one of its own patents to help them deal with the litigation. Microsoft also expanded its indemnification program under which it provides funds or legal counsel to help customers defend themselves.M&A and CollaborationsNES and Google Have a Deal: Nashville Electric Service has withdrawn its lawsuit against the Metro Council and telecom companies filed last October
column55: after Google promised to indemnify it against liabilities that may arise out of Metro's One Touch Make Ready policy. The current law requires that when a new provider's line is added to a utility pole
column56: each existing provider is required to move its line
column57: resulting in needless delay and disruption on the sidewalk.The new policy allows one person to move the poles
column58: thus making the process more efficient. Existing providers like AT&T and Comcast object to the law on the grounds that Metro is not authorized to make the law
column59: which is a matter for the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). The deal is significant because NES owns 80% of the utility poles in Nashville and Google is likely to succeed because the action promotes competition in the market and can force incumbents to match Google Fiber's high-speed services.Some NumbersMicrosoft Azure Price Cuts: Microsoft has taken the lead in announcing price cuts for its Azure Virtual Machines. The company said that compute-optimized F Series instances would cost its customers up to 24% less
column60: while A1 Basic instances would drop by up to 61%. Azure HotBlock Blob Storage and Cool Block Blob Storage costs are also down. Suntrust analyst Kunal Madhukar expects Amazon to follow soon
column61: as price cuts are ""business as usual"" for cloud infrastructure service providers.Amazon Payments: Amazon's payments service called Pay With Amazon
column62: which allows people to check out quickly using the details saved on Amazon says that the service now has 33 million users
column63: 32% of which access it with mobile devices. Pay With Amazon had 23 million users last April. Amazon's alliances with companies like PrestaShop
column64: Shopify and Future Shop have brought more users over the past few months.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above
column65: would you like to know about our 10 finest buy-and-hold tickers for the entirety of 2017?Who wouldn't? As of early December
column66: the 2016 Top 10 produced 5 double-digit winners including oil and natural gas giant Pioneer Natural Resources which racked up a stellar +50% gain. The new list is painstakingly hand-picked from 4
column67: 400 companies covered by the Zacks Rank.Be among the very first to see it>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

column1: Reasons to Bet on Cisco (CSCO) Stock Ahead of Earnings;2/15/2017;"Cisco (Shutterstock photo)Cisco (CSCO) is set to report second quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after the closing bell today. With fiscal 2016 revenues climbing less than 1%
column2: the San Francisco-based networking giant has a lot to prove in 2017. But you’ll be hard-pressed to find a more stable large-cap company
column3: which still has a virtually monopoly when it comes to hardware/software that powers the internet.CSCO stock closed Tuesday at $32.31
column4: netting yet another 52-week high. The shares have risen about 7% year to date and almost 30% over the past year. This afternoon
column5: analysts will be eager to see the extent to which Cisco’s big bets on software have paid off
column6: particularly on the heels of its multibillion-dollar software acquisition of AppDynamics for which Cisco paid roughly twice what AppDynamics was to get in its own public offering.makeArticleAd();For the quarter that ended January
column7: Cisco is expected to earn 56 cents per share on revenue of $11.55 billion
column8: according to Thomson Reuters. This compares to the year-ago quarter when the company earned 57 cents per share on $11.93 billion in revenue.Cisco
column9: which in November reported first-quarter earnings results that beat Wall Street estimates on both the top and bottom lines
column10: has focused on higher-margin businesses such as the Internet of Things and the cloud is working to reverse the recent slide in revenue. Software initiatives that focus on enhancing its capabilities in visualization and security will also be a focus of analysts this afternoon.From an investment perspective
column11: Cisco offers many qualities that should appeal to value seekers.Despite the solid year-to-date performance
column12: CSCO stock is priced at just 13.8 times forward earnings
column13: which is some six points below the S&P 500 Index. Assuming the stock was priced on par with the rest of the market the stock would trade today at around $45
column14: or 40% above current levels.Combined with Cisco's strong dividend yield of 3.30%
column15: which is more than one full percentage point above the rest of the market
column16: there are tons of reasons to be bullish on Cisco for the next 12 to 18 months. Assuming a beat on raise this afternoon
column17: CSCO stock
column18: which has a consensus Buy rating
column19: should reach $40 by the end of 2017
column20: delivering 25% returns."

column1: Better Buy: Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. vs. General Electric;2/14/2017;"At first glance
column3: Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andGeneral Electric(NYSE: GE) don't seem that similar. The former sells networking   hardware and software
column4: while the latter sells a wide array of   industrial products and services for the utility
column5: healthcare
column6: transportation
column7: aviation
column8: and automotive industries.But if we look closer
column9: some similarities appear. Both   companies are Dow components and are generally owned for income   instead of growth. Both companies are also aggressively expanding   into theInternet of Things (IoT)
column10: which links various objects to each other and the cloud. Cisco   estimates that the total number of connected devices across the   IoT
column11: including GE's industrial machinery
column12: will double from 25   billion in 2015 to  50 billion in 2020.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Cisco and GE are both slow-growth plays
column13: yet both stocks have   rallied more than 50% over the past five years. But since past   performance doesn't guarantee future gains
column14: we should take a   closer look at their core businesses to see if they can keep   rising over the next few years.How fast are Cisco and GE growing?Cisco's revenue stayed nearly flat at $49.2 billion in    fiscal 2016. But after excluding the sale of its set-top   box to Technicolor for $600 million
column15: its full-year revenue rose   3% to $48.7 billion. Cisco's revenue grew  1% annually on   that same ""normalized"" basis during the first quarter
column16: but is   expected to decline 2%-4% annually during the second quarter.   Analysts expect Cisco's reported revenue to fall 2% in fiscal   2017
column17: but potentially rebound 2% in 2018.That lackluster growth is mainly attributed to the sluggish   growth of its core businesses of networking routers and switches
column18: which generated nearly half its revenue last quarter. The only   part of Cisco which posts consistent growth is its cybersecurity   business
column19: which posted 11% sales growth during the first quarter   but only accounts for 4% of its top line. Looking ahead
column20: Cisco is   expected to acquire more companies to strengthen its hardware and   software bundles while boosting its top line growth.Image source: Cisco.General Electric's revenue rose 5% to $123.7 billion in fiscal   2016. The company's top line received a big boost from its $10   billion purchase of  Alstom's power division in late 2015.   GE's core businesses also grew on robust demand across the   aviation
column21: renewables
column22: healthcare
column23: and oil and gas industries. Its   healthcare business benefited from solid growth in China
column24: and its   oil and gas business was lifted by reboundingoil   prices. Orders for wind turbines also rose on an increased appetite for   renewable energy solutions worldwide.GE's backlog -- a key indicator of future demand -- rose 2% to   $321 billion in 2016. Looking ahead
column25: analysts expect GE's revenue   to rise 2% in fiscal 2017 and 7% growth in 2018. But on an   organic basis
column26: which excludes currency impacts
column27: acquisitions
column28: and   divestments
column29: GE expects its revenue to rise 3%-5% in fiscal   2017.How profitable are Cisco and GE?Since Cisco and GE are both heavily exposed to currency   headwinds and often acquire or divest units
column30: which distorts   year-over-year comparisons
column31: they report their earnings in both   GAAP and non-GAAP figures.On a non-GAAP basis -- which excludes currency impacts
column32: stock-based compensation
column33: certain acquisitions
column34: divestments
column35: and   other charges -- Cisco's earnings rose 8% in fiscal 2016.   GAAP-adjusted earnings
column36: which include the gain from the set-top   box divestment
column37: rose 21%. Analysts expect Cisco's non-GAAP   earnings to remain nearly flat in 2017 and rise 5% in 2018.GE's total earnings remained flat on a GAAP basis in fiscal   2016. However
column38: its non-GAAP earnings (which include its   industrial operating and related verticals) rose 14% during the   year. On that basis
column39: analysts expect GE's earnings to rise 10% in   2017 and another 16% in 2018.Dividends and valuationsCisco currently pays a forward yield of 3.3%
column40: which is   supported by a payout ratio of 47%. It's raised that dividend   annually for the past six years. GE also pays a forward yield of   3.3%
column41: but it has a much less sustainable payout ratio of 106%
column42: due to the Alstom acquisition throttling its cash flows. GE   raised its dividend by a penny last December
column43: but that was its   first hike intwo years.Cisco trades at 15 times earnings
column44: which is lower than the   S&P 500's current P/E of 24 and the industry average of 25   for networking and communication device makers. GE trades at 25   times earnings
column45: which is higher than the S&P 500's multiple   but lower than the average P/E of 39 for diversified machinery   companies.The winner: CiscoGeneral Electric initially seems like a better pick than   Cisco
column46: since it has better top and bottom line growth and a more   diversified business. But GE's poor record of dividend hikes

column1: What to Expect When Cisco Systems Reports Earnings;2/14/2017;"Expectations are low going intoCisco Systems'(NASDAQ: CSCO) fiscal second-quarter report. The networking   hardware giant expects the troubles of the first quarter to   continue
column2: with its guidance calling for a sizable year-over-year   revenue decline
column3: even after excluding divestitures.Growth businesses like collaboration
column4: data center
column5: and   security have helped the company grow in recent quarters despite   weakness in the core switching and routing segments
column6: but two of   those businesses suffered declines during the first   quarter. Here's what to look for when Cisco reports on   Wednesday.What analysts are expectingThe average analyst estimate calls for a year-over-year   revenue decline of 3.2%
column7: to $11.55 billion. That's near the   midpoint of Cisco's guidance range -- a decline of 2% to 4%.   Cisco's outlook excludes revenue from the SP Video CPE business
column8: which the company agreed to sell back in 2015.makeArticleAd();That deal closed in November 2015
column9: about one month into the   fiscal second quarter. The discrepancy between Cisco's reported   and adjusted revenue in the second quarter will only include one   month of that divested revenue
column10: and the transaction will be fully   lapped in the fiscal third quarter.Image source: Cisco Systems.Cisco reported a revenue decline of 3% and an adjusted revenue   increase of 1% during the first quarter
column11: so the company's   second-quarter guidance represents a deterioration. The companypointed to global uncertainty
column12: driven by the U.S. presidential election
column13: as one reason for its   weak guidance. Cisco isn't modeling any improvement going   forward
column14: but it does believe that business-friendly polices from   the Trump administration could reverse some of these   headwinds.Cisco expects to produce GAAP earnings per share (EPS)   between $0.42 and $0.47
column15: and non-GAAP EPS between $0.55 and   $0.57
column16: during the second quarter. That compares to GAAP EPS of   $0.62 and non-GAAP EPS of $0.57 during the prior-year period.A $519 million tax benefit boosted GAAP EPS last year
column17: so the   steep decline called for in Cisco's guidance isn't something to   worry about. Analysts are expecting non-GAAP EPS of $0.56
column18: right   at the midpoint of Cisco's guidance range.Despite the weak numbers Cisco expects to report
column19: it's likely   that the company will announce a dividend boost along with its   second-quarter report. Cisco announced a 24% increase to its   quarterly dividend in February of last year
column20: along with a massive   $15 billion share-buyback authorization. Any dividend increase   this year will almost certainly be smaller
column21: but a high   single-digit or low double-digit percentage boost would still be   a nice reward for long-term investors.Pay attention to the growth businessesCisco's first-quarter results
column22: while beating analyst   estimates
column23: were disappointing due to the severe slowdown of the   company's main growth businesses. The data center segment
column24: which   was growing by more than 20% annually as recently as late 2015
column25: has now been weak for multiple quarters. The segment posted a 3%   year-over-year decline during the first quarter
column26: with the company   blaming a shift from blade servers to rack servers for the   disappointing performance.The collaboration segment
column27: which produces about $4.4 billion   of revenue annually
column28: has also slowed down. The segment grew by 9%   during fiscal 2016
column29: but the first quarter
column30: saw a 3%   year-over-year decline. One thing hurting the top line is Cisco's   ongoing shift to subscription software. Collaboration-deferred   revenue rose by 14% in the first quarter
column31: and order growth was   solid despite the revenue weakness.The security business has managed to continue growing at a   double-digit rate
column32: driven
column33: in part
column34: by acquisitions. Security   revenue expanded by 11% year over year during the first quarter
column35: and investors should expect to see continued growth in the second   quarter. This will help offset some of the weakness in other   areas.Cisco is a company in transition
column36: shifting toward software and   subscriptions while remaining dependent on sales of its core   switching and routing hardware. The first quarter was lackluster
column37: and the second quarter will be worse if Cisco hits its guidance.   A likely dividend hike will provide some good news

column1: 3 Internet of Things Stocks You Don't Have to Babysit;2/13/2017;"The technology sector isn't always the best place for   investment stability
column2: nor are new technology trends ever much of   a safe investment. But it doesn't have to be this way. The   Internet of Things (IoT) is ushering in a massive wave of   technological changes -- nearly 50 billion things will be   connected to the IoT by 2020 -- and there are three companies at   the forefront of this $7 trillion market that should remain   steady
column3: long-term investments:Verizon Communications(NYSE: VZ)
column4: Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column5: andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Verizon CommunicationsVerizon is stalwart dividend stock that has plenty of   long-term potential in the IoT. The company already   dominates the wireless network space despite cutthroat   competition fromAT&TandT-Mobile
column6: and it's only getting stronger.Verizon is making early investments in 5G networks that should   give the company an edge over its competitors in the IoT network   space
column7: much like the company's early push into 4G kept it ahead   of the competition. Verizon calls 5G the ""foundation for creating   more internet-connected devices"" and says that it will use the   network to bring traffic lights
column8: stop signs
column9: parking meters
column10: and   other city systems online.Over the next few months
column11: the company plans on rolling out   commercial 5G field tests in a few locations. Verizon CEO Lowell   McAdam said at an investor conference in December that he   believes the company is two to three years ahead of the   competition for 5G because of its early tests and the company's   recent purchase of the fiber-optic network company XO   Communications.5G will allow new types of faster-than-ever device   connections
column12: and Verizon's early mover advantage could pay off   down the road.Cisco SystemsCisco is a perfect example of a company that will plug away in   its respective field without offering investors much drama -- and   at the same time provide a nice 3.3% dividend yield to boot.Cisco has been talking about the IoT for quite some time
column13: but   one of biggest moves came early last year when the company   announced it was buying Jasper Technologies for $1.4 billion.Jasper is a cloud-based IoT service platform that allows   enterprise and service customers to ""launch
column14: manage and monetize   IoT services on a global scale."" In short
column15: Jasper allows   companies to bring nearly any device online (think cars or jet   engines) and then manage those connections through its   proprietary software.Jasper brings with it 3
column16: 500 enterprise customers from around   the world that have devices running on 27 service providers.   And Cisco said that it will be able to add to Jasper's   services with its own enterprise Wi-Fi
column17: IoT security solutions
column18: and advanced analytics.With Jasper
column19: Cisco transitions further into the the   software-as-a-service (SaaS) market that brings recurring   revenue
column20: and allows the company to rely a little less on the   traditionally cyclical hardware market.AlphabetAlphabet and its subsidiaries have been extremely aggressive   in the IoT space
column21: and given the company's massive market size and   its quarterly revenues north of  $26 billion
column22: this is   certainly a company investors don't need to babysit.Most of Alphabet's IoT opportunities stem from Google
column23: which   is already a leader in the connected home space with Google Home   and Nest Labs. By having a slew of IoT devices for the home
column24: along with an embedded smart assistant in Google Home
column25: the   company is helping to lead the way in IoT home connections.But one of Alphabet's biggest IoT pushes right now comes from   a company called Waymo
column26: which wasrecently spun out of Google. Waymo is the product of years of research and real-world   testing of self-driving cars and Google is looking to the company   to now stand on its own and start generating revenue.Waymo has partnered withFiat Chryslerto bring 100 self-driving minivans to to the roadways to begin   testing an autonomous driving service. The company is likely   still years away from bringing in any significant revenue for   Google
column27: but it's clear that under Alphabet's umbrella   self-driving tech is a big part of the company's IoT plans.On top of that
column28: other companies under Alphabet are exploring   IoT possibilities
column29: like usingnanoparticles to find diseasesin the bloodstream
column30: by pairing them to wearable tech devices.Whatever you do
column31: just don't miss this opportunityInvestors looking for steady companies shouldn't overlook themassive opportunities that the IoT has to   offer. Nearly 50 billion things will be connecting the internet in   just a few years and the IoT market has the potential to   transform many aspects of our lives. The three stocks above are   all big tech names that are tapping into the IoT's potential in   their own way
column32: offering investors growth opportunities on top of   stable existing businesses.10 stocks we like better than Verizon     CommunicationsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: One Put
column2: One Call Option To Know About for Cisco Systems;2/13/2017;"Consistently
column3: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Cisco Systems Inc (Symbol: CSCO). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column4: and one interesting call contract
column5: from the June 2018 expiration for CSCO. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column6: is at the $25 strike
column7: which has a bid at the time of this writing of $1.19. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 4.8% return against the $25 commitment
column8: or a 3.6% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to CSCO's upside potential the way owning shares would
column9: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Cisco Systems Inc sees its shares decline 21.4% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $23.81 per share before broker commissions
column10: subtracting the $1.19 from $25)
column11: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 3.6% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Worth considering
column12: is that the annualized 3.6% figure actually exceeds the 3.3% annualized dividend paid by Cisco Systems Inc
column13: based on the current share price of $31.84. And yet
column14: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column15: there is greater downside because the stock would have to lose 21.43% to reach the $25 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column16: in general
column17: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Cisco Systems Inc
column18: looking at the dividend history chart for CSCO below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column19: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 3.3% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column20: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the June 2018 expiration
column21: for shareholders of Cisco Systems Inc (Symbol: CSCO) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 3.3% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $37 strike and collecting the premium based on the $1.00 bid
column22: annualizes to an additional 2.4% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column23: for a total of 5.6% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $37 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column24: but CSCO shares would have to climb 16.3% from current levels for that to happen
column25: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column26: the shareholder has earned a 19.4% return from this trading level
column27: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Cisco Systems Inc
column28: highlighting in green where the $25 strike is located relative to that history
column29: and highlighting the $37 strike in red:The chart above
column30: and the stock's historical volatility
column31: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the June 2018 put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Cisco Systems Inc (considering the last 251 trading dayCSCO historical stock pricesusing closing values
column32: as well as today's price of $31.84) to be 16%.Top YieldBoost CSCO Calls »"

column1: 2 Rock Solid Cheap Stocks with P/Es Under 15;2/13/2017;"With the market hovering near all-time highs
column2: it might seem   tough to find ""cheap"" stocks that are still worth buying. But   with the S&P 500's P/E ratio currently near a multi-year high   of 24
column3: investors should focus on undervalued stocks with less   room to fall. Let's take a closer look at two big tech names that   have P/E ratios of 15 or less --Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) andHewlett-Packard Enterprise(NYSE: HPE) .Cisco SystemsCisco is one of the world's largest vendors of networking   hardware and software. Its core businesses of routers and   switches are slow growth -- sales of routers fell 4% in    fiscal 2016
column4: while sales of switches stayed flat. Those two   businesses accounted for nearly half of its top line during the   year.Image source: Cisco.makeArticleAd();Both businesses face twomajor headwinds-- the rise of cheaper rivals likeHuawei
column5: and companies likeArista Networks
column6: which specializes in hardware for SDN (software-defined   networking) solutions. SDN (or cloud networking) platforms reduce   the need for on-site hardware like routers and switches.However
column7: Cisco is diversifying away from those businesses with   increased investments in higher-growth businesses likecybersecurity
column8: collaboration
column9: and service provider video solutions -- which it   can bundle with its networking hardware. It also expanded its   presence in the Internet of Things (IoT) market with its   acquisition of Jasper Technologies
column10: and will strengthen its   networkwide app analytics capabilities with its planned purchase   of AppDynamics.Cisco plans to use its robust free cash flow ($12.4 billion   over the past 12 months) to buy more companies
column11: boost its   earnings with buybacks
column12: and pay out dividends. On the surface
column13: Cisco's growth looks glacial
column14: with analysts expecting a 2% sales   decline and nearly flat earnings growth this year. But Cisco's   P/E of 15 is also much lower than its industry average of 25
column15: and   its forward dividend yield of 3.3% easily beats the S&P 500's   average yield of 2% -- making it a good conservative income play   for 2017.Hewlett-Packard EnterpriseHewlett-Packard Enterprise retained HP's enterprise hardware   and software businesses after splitting with the PC
column16: printer
column17: and   imaging businesses. But like many of its industry peers
column18: HPE has   struggled to grow its top line amid sluggish enterprise spending
column19: macroeconomic issues
column20: currency headwinds
column21: and rising competition   from smaller rivals. Analysts expect HPE's revenue to dip 2% this   year and remain flat next year.HPE's CEO is Meg Whitman
column22: who previously led both halves of   HP. Whitman's core strategy has been to streamline the enterprise   business with divestments
column23: spinoffs
column24: and layoffs. Prior to the   big split
column25: HP exited the highly competitive public cloud market   to focus more on on-site and hybrid deployments.Image source: HPE.After the split
column26: HPE agreed to spin off and merge its   slow-growth IT services unit withComputer Science Corp.in an $8.5 billion deal
column27: then agreed to a similar spin-off of its   ""non-core"" application delivery management
column28: big data
column29: and   enterprise security businesses toMicro Focus Internationalin an $8.8 billion deal. Those spin-mergers resulted in several   rounds of layoffs
column30: but those lower expenses boosted HPE's   margins. That's why analysts expect HPE's earnings to grow 6%   this year and another 1% next year.To pivot away from slow-growth businesses
column31: HPE agreed to buy   smaller companies in high growth markets -- including   supercomputer maker SGI for $275 million and hyperconverged   infrastructure vendor SimpliVity for $650 million. Both   acquisitions strengthened HPE's position in the hybrid cloud   market. As HPE pivots toward more of these high growth   businesses
column32: their revenues could juice up its top line growth   again.HPE's P/E of 13 is much lower than its industry average of 21
column33: and it pays a forward yield of 1%. That yield is low
column34: but HPE's   payout ratio of 12% indicates that it has plenty of room to raise   its dividend in the near future.The key takeawayMany low P/E stocks tend to have low growth potential. Cisco   and HPE's growth won't impress analysts anytime soon
column35: but their   low valuations will limit their downside potential during market   downturns. That stability could be valuable if the market's lofty   valuations catch up to it later this year.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column3: 2017makeArticleAd();Q4 earnings season even performed better than analysts had hoped for. Of course
column4: we're not completely through the entire cycle - retailers have yet to report en masse
column5: and we see industry leaders like CiscoCSCO

column3: but with around 850 companies reporting in the next five trading days

column5: and today I'd like to share a few thoughts.7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsSo here are three more upcoming reports that should provide a good pulse on telecom

column1: 3 Big Bets Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. Is Making -- Will They Be Enough?;2/10/2017;"Cisco Systems Inc.(NASDAQ: CSCO) has been best known in the past for its enterprise   network hardware
column3: but the company continues to build out and grow   its other segments with some interesting recent innovations and   acquisitions. Here are some of the areas of growth Cisco is   betting on
column4: the pressure it's getting from new competitors likeAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column5: and why the stock looks like a fine holding as   the company transitions for the future.1: Building smart
column6: connected citiesIn a recent blog post
column7: Cisco management said that cloud   computing is ""the fourth industrial revolution."" The company   estimates that by 2020
column8: over 90% of total data center traffic   will be via cloud networks. While there are many companies   working to provide services for individuals' and companies' cloud   needs
column9: Cisco is gearing up to offer its services to cities around   the world.Cisco launched the ""Smart+Connected City Platform"" at   the Smart City Expo World Congress 2016 in Barcelona in   November
column10: and the company says this service is ""a centralized   layer for addressing the infrastructural need to connect cameras
column11: water meters
column12: traffic meters
column13: and so on in a reliable
column14: secure
column15: robust and seamless manner."" This initiative was recently   implemented in Jaipur
column16: India
column17: which joins Hamburg
column18: Germany;   Barcelona
column19: Spain; Kansas City
column20: Missouri; and Adelaide
column21: Australia   as test smart cities. The video below shows the CIO of Adelaide   explaining the importance Cisco has played in his city.makeArticleAd();2: Becoming an all-encompassing IoT platform""Internet of Things"" has become a buzzword in 2016
column22: but really   it just describes the growing trend of consumer or otherwise   low-tech items that are being connected to the internet and to   each other
column23: usually through a wireless cloud network. In fact
column24: the smart cities initiative is mostly about IoT on city level.   Estimates on just how big this market could be vary widely
column25: but   most analysts predict it could continue growing by tens ofbillionsof devices in the next few years.Cisco is increasingly making itself the bedrock for various   parts of this ecosystem
column26: including the actual hardware that makes   these consumer products connectivity possible
column27: the connectivity   through cloud networks
column28: and the security to make sure the IoT   connectivity isn't easily compromised. Cisco acquired a   cloud-based IoT company called Jasper Technologies last March for   $1.4 billion
column29: which
column30: among other things
column31: enables more   data-tracking and IoT management. This acquisition and others   like it
column32: along with Cisco's own innovation in this space
column33: have   helped the company to launch various new products and bundles   into this space recently.Similar to Cisco's smart+connected cities push
column34: the company   believes it has the breadth of expertise and support to be the   IoT platform for enterprise and governmental accounts. Remember   that Cisco already has a large footprint in these spaces
column35: so it   might be easier for them to win over these big clients as they   seek an IoT solution.Image source: Cisco Systems.3: CybersecurityWhile the first two areas above are incredibly exciting in   terms of what they could mean for the future of the digital   world
column36: they also open up the world to many more risks in the form   of cyber-threats. A recently intensified focus on hacking threats   and the need to build secure solutions throughout cloud networks
column37: IoT platforms
column38: and all other connected technology creates an   opportunity Cisco is taking advantage of.In February
column39: the company launched Cisco Firepower
column40: a new   firewall series
column41: and the company says its advanced security   systems have been proven to help customers ""dramatically reduce   time to detection of attacks."" Throughout the year
column42: the company   also launched new tools such as Cisco Umbrella and Umbrella   Roaming
column43: which are increased defenses on routers and VPN devices   to block suspicious activity. In September
column44: Cisco   acquired CloudLock
column45: a company that helps provide integrated   security solutions for cloud-based networks.Cisco's security revenue in its fiscal Q1 ended Oct. 29 rose   11% from the year-earlier quarter to about $540 million. Even   though that makes up less than 5% of Cisco's total revenue
column46: management believes that having the focus and expertise in this   area will help them win over more business within its other   segments as consumers and businesses start to consider the need   for the most secure network possible a top priority.Can Cisco fend off competition?Cisco's traditional markets
column47: which still make up the bulk of   sales
column48: have declined in recent quarters. Switching
column49: which still   makes up nearly a third of total sales
column50: slumped 7% in the most   recent quarter year over year. Overall
column51: even with the growth   above
column52: total sales in the quarter gained a paltry 1%.   Additionally
column53: management gave less-than-exciting guidance for   early fiscal 2017.More concerning is that in the company's new growth areas
column54: it   faces some serious competition. The biggest of them   is Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column55: which offers both public and   private cloud hosting solutions
column56: as well as IoT solutions
column57: usually for a lower cost than traditional options. The service   has success stories from some big names likeNetflixandComcast
column58: just to name a few
column59: which has helped raise its prestige. In   terms of security
column60: Amazon provides cloud services to U.S.   intelligence agencies
column61: so clearly
column62: security is important to them   as well. AWS is growing quickly -- up nearly 50% year over year   in the most recent quarter to over $3.5 billion.The early successes of the segments above are encouraging.   Additionally
column63: Cisco has been able to gain a lot of expertise and   value from acquiring smaller tech companies in these high-growth   segments
column64: and Cisco is in a great position to continue that   strategy with around $70 billion in cash that it's likely to   start deploying more heavily in the quarters and years to come.   While Cisco will certainly face increased growth pressure ahead
column65: especially with AWS disrupting this space
column66: it looks to be making   some smart moves to transition its focus. Finally
column67: Cisco is   trading at just 15 times earnings
column68: just 2.5 times book value   (compared with Amazon's P/B at 21.7 times)
column69: and has a 3.3%   dividend yield that continues to grow. It looks like there's   plenty of reason to hold Cisco to see how these markets transform   in the years ahead -- and how this behemoth tech company will   play a part in them.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column6: because these funds are only required to disclose theirlongpositions with the SEC
column7: but are not required to disclose theirshortpositions. A fund making a bearish bet against a stock by shorting calls
column8: for example
column9: might also be long some amount of stock as they trade around their overall bearish position. This long component could show up in a 13F filing and everyone might assume the fund is bullish
column10: but this tells only part of the storybecause the bearish/short side of the position is not seen.makeArticleAd();Having given that caveat

column1: 3 Stocks to Watch in February;2/9/2017;"February will be a busy month for investors.NVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) will report this week
column2: looking to extend its   streak of impressive earnings beats. Networking hardware giantCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) reports next week
column3: aiming to convince investors   that its transition to a softwarecentric company will eventually   return it to growth. Meanwhile
column4: Wal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) will report in two weeks
column5: in the midst of a major   shift in its e-commerce strategy .Sky-high expectationsGraphics chip company NVIDIA destroyed analyst estimates   throughout 2016
column6: with its latest quarterly report in November   beating expectations by a wide margin. Its gaming business is   booming
column7: driven by strong demand for its Pascal graphics cards   and the soon-to-launchNintendoSwitch game console. The data center and automotive businesses
column8: both much smaller than gaming
column9: are growing at an even faster   rate.Image source: NVIDIA.makeArticleAd();When its fourth-quarter results are revealed after the market   close on Thursday
column10: Feb. 9.
column11: all eyes will be on whether NVIDIA   can keep up its incredible growth rate. Its stock more than   tripled in 2016 as revenue and profit expanded rapidly
column12: but withAMDset to launch competing high-end graphics cards in the next few   months
column13: NVIDIA's significant market share may take a hit.NVIDIA's early focus on pushing its graphics chips as machine   learning accelerators has paid off in a big way. The data center   segment
column14: which includes NVIDIA's Tesla GPUs aimed the data center   and high-performance computing
column15: nearly tripled year over year   during the third quarter. That kind of growth rate can't go on   forever
column16: but it's clear that NVIDIA has struck gold.With the stock now trading for around 60 times   trailing-12-month earnings
column17: the company will need to continue to   impress investors in order to keep the stock price afloat. Any   disappointing numbers could send this highflier tumbling.A tough quarterCisco Systems
column18: the dominant provider of networking hardware
column19: doesn't expect a remarkable fiscal second quarter. The company   sees its revenue declining by 2% to 4% year over year even after   excluding divestitures
column20: a slowdown that reflects both uncertainty   among its major customers and its ongoing shift to a recurring   revenue business model.Image source: Cisco Systems.Cisco's core switching and routing businesses were   inconsistent throughout 2016
column21: with growth in some quarters and   declines in others. This was counteracted by solid growth in its   smaller businesses
column22: including collaboration
column23: data center
column24: and   security. During the first quarter of fiscal 2017
column25: though

column27: but the results raise questions about Cisco's growth   strategy.Its fiscal second-quarter results are expected after the   market close on Feb. 15. Analysts aren't expecting much

column31: and weakness in its core   businesses will continue to hurt its results.Two-day shipping for everyoneAfter testing a subscription shipping program similar toAmazonPrime
column32: Wal-Mart has scrapped that effort
column33: instead shifting to   free two-day shipping on millions of items for orders over $35.   This is far more generous than Amazon's non-Prime free shipping   offer
column34: which has a minimum order of $50 and shipping times that   vary.Image source:     Wal-Mart.http://corporate.walmart.com/galleries/e-commerceWal-Mart has been accelerating its push into e-commerce
column35: paying $3 billion for start-up Jet.com last year and putting   Jet's CEO in charge of its entire e-commerce business. The   company's online grocery service

column37: is another facet of the e-commerce strategy

column1: Burned by FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? Try These Rebound Trades;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere was much hype surroundingFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) back in 2015. The company had just come off revenue growth of 163% the year prior
column3: and FireEye was the first cybersecurity firm to be certified under the Safety Act. But the company fell prey to a major faux pas in the technology world - it didn't innovate fast enough
column4: and FEYE stock is now paying the price.makeArticleAd();Source:Fortune Brainstorm TECH via FlickrIn 2014
column5: the cloud business model was breaking onto the scene
column6: and it was creating enough of a stir that even major players likeCisco Systems
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) were making significant moves into the new market. It was a lesson FireEye learned too late
column8: as evidenced by the company's recent quarterly earnings report.Despite a major push and a plethora of incentives to boost sales
column9: FireEye's revenue of $184.7 million missed Wall Street's estimates of $191 million. But the topline figure wasn't the only concern
column10: as FireEye guided to a 3% decline in first-quarter revenue
column11: compared to the Street's expected 5% growth.Among the myriad of problems facing the company
column12: including slower corporate enterprise spending and increased competition in the cybersecurity market
column13: FireEye's late restructuring into a cloud-subscription model is almost unforgivable - especially when blue-chip security firms were already headed that direction.But there is a bright side for FEYE stock investors
column14: at least over the short term. Barring any other major surprises or management short-sightedness (CFO Mike Berry and board chairman David DeWalt are both stepping down
column15: which could help)
column16: the worst appears to be already factored into FEYE's price. As such
column17: literally any positive news for the company could kick off a short-term bounce.7 High-Risk
column18: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowAs usual
column19: potential drivers for such a bounce would come from FEYE's sentiment backdrop. For instance
column20: Thomson/First Call reports that 21 of the 31 analysts following FEYE stock rate the shares a ""hold"" or worse. The fact that there aren't more ""sell"" ratings after last week's quarterly report tells me that Wall Street is ready to reward FireEye for moving in the right direction. In other words
column21: upgrades are a distinct possibility following any positive progress.Elsewhere
column22: short sellers are already taking profits on FEYE. As of the most recent reporting period
column23: the number of FEYE shares sold short dropped by 3% to 20.3 million. Still
column24: roughly 13.3% of FireEye's float remains sold short
column25: and could spark a round of profit taking or a covering rally if the stock can find its feet and move higher.Click to EnlargeJudging by FEYE's options configuration
column26: short sellers may be preparing for just such an outcome. Currently
column27: the March put/call open interest ratio for FEYE stock rests at 0.44
column28: with calls more than doubling puts among options set to expire on March 17.FEYE is trading well below all major put and call accumulations in the series
column29: with the $13 strike home to peak put OI and $14 representing the next significant call OI strike
column30: leaving little in the way of potential options headwinds in the short term.March implieds
column31: meanwhile
column32: are pricing in a potential move of about 12.6% for volatile FEYE stock. This places the upper bound at $12.39
column33: while the lower bound rests at $9.61.2 Trades for FEYE StockCall Spread:Bearish sentiment on an underperforming stock is to be expected
column34: but FEYE stock is trading at oversold levels following a post-earnings beating. With said beating now out of the way
column35: FEYE should trend higher
column36: with any positive news providing additional lift.Those traders looking to take a risk on an FEYE comeback over the short-term might want to consider a March $12/$13 bull call spread. At last check
column37: this spread was offered at 19 cents
column38: or $19 per pair of contracts. Breakeven lies at $12.19
column39: while a maximum profit of 81 cents
column40: or $81 per pair of contracts
column41: is possible if FEYE stock closes at or above $13 when March options expire.The Smart Money: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Is Already InsolventPut Sell:Those looking for a more bullish-to-neutral position may want to look at a FEYE March $10 put sell position. At last check

column1: Why the Stock Market Under Trump Will Probably Lag the Market Under Obama;2/9/2017;"President Donald Trump's @POTUS Twitter feed sounded off in   celebration on Jan. 25 when theDow Jones Industrial Averagereached 20
column2: 000 for the first time ever
column3: just five days   after his inauguration:Great!#Dow20Khttps://t.co/wXFhXBLgag-- President Trump (@POTUS)January 25
column4: 2017In her own Tweet
column5: former campaign manager and now presidential   advisor Kellyanne Conway credited ""The Trump Effect.""makeArticleAd();The administration was right to celebrate what has been a very   bullish market rally following the election results on Nov. 8.   The market reacted bearishly to the unexpected results on   election night
column6: but ever since then
column7: it's been on the rise.However
column8: the Dow's 9%-plus rise since Election Day is just a   fraction of how much the stock market rose during President   Obama's eight-year tenure. It's very early in the Trump   administration
column9: but can we predict whether the market will   perform better or worse under President Trump than under   President Obama?Image source: Getty Images.Timing mattersThe chart below shows how theDow Jones Industrial Averagehas performed during the terms of the last 10 presidents
column10: all the   way back to when Lyndon Johnson took office in 1963 (the black   arrows mark the year in which each president was first   elected):Image source: MacroTrends.net
column11: with presidents' names tied     to election dates added by author. Gray lines = recession     periods.Now let's put that in terms of total market returns under each   president:PresidentDates of PresidencyStock Market Performance During TenureLyndon Johnson11/22/63 - 1/19/6926%Richard Nixon1/20/69 - 8/8/74(28%)Gerald Ford8/9/74 - 1/19/7740%Jimmy Carter1/20/77 - 1/19/81(1%)Ronald Reagan1/20/81 - 1/19/89147%George H.W. Bush1/20/89 - 1/19/9341%Bill Clinton1/20/93 - 1/19/01226%George W. Bush1/20/01 - 1/19/09(27%)Barack Obama1/20/09 - 1/19/17148%Donald Trump1/20/17 - present*1%*Present = Feb. 9
column12: 2017 (date of publication). Data source:MacroTrends.net.Obama took office at the tail end of the Financial Crisis.   Even though the administration enacted policies that would   typically seem to limit the earnings ability of some corporations   within the Dow
column13: such as stricter reporting regulations
column14: the   market rose handily (in percentage terms) during his eight years   in office. Setting aside any economic policies the Obama   administration enacted
column15: the fact that President Obama took office   near the market's trough meant that the market
column16: which is cyclical   in nature
column17: had a much stronger chance of rebounding during his   tenure.Meanwhile
column18: Trump assumed the presidency after an   eight-year-long bull run that saw no sustained corrections.   History shows that corrections happen at somewhat regular   intervals
column19: and many market analysts believe one is due soon.   Based on how market the cycle has worked through recent decades
column20: it seems unlikely that we'll see consistent growth during   President Trump's tenure -- but
column21: of course
column22: it's not   impossible.What business leaders are sayingMany business leaders have been speaking optimistically of   Trump's proposed financial policies in their earnings calls.Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) CEO Chuck Robbins said during the company's fiscal   first-quarter earnings call in November
column23: ""I think President-elect   Trump appears to be very business-oriented and is very focused on   driving the U.S. economy
column24: and anytime the U.S. economy improves   that's certainly good for us.""Southwest Airlines(NYSE: LUV) is another company that is looking forward to lower   taxes and less regulation. In the most recent earnings call
column25: CEO   Gary Kelly finished answering an analyst question about upcoming   policy changes by saying:""We've looked at the tax reform proposals and we're quite     excited about that on the corporate front
column26: but that's just     about income tax. So that doesn't really speak to the very     heavy burden that we have for aviation taxes
column27: which we also     want to take up with the administration. So
column28: that's a long     answer to your question and I think the bottom line is: No
column29: we     don't know anything specific yet
column30: but we sure like what we're     hearing so far.""Of course
column31: there's also rising concern among many CEOs and   other business leaders about how certain policies that have been   floated or initiated could negatively affect their businesses or   the broader economy. These include tariffs on imported goods and   the controversial executive order restricting travel to the   U.S.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) management has said positive things about   potential tax cuts
column32: especially those related to repatriating cash   kept overseas
column33: of which Apple has around $200 billion. However
column34: Apple is also one of the biggest companies that in recent weeks   have come out against Trump's immigration policy. And it is one   of many companies taking legal action against Trump's immigration   stance
column35: citing (along with moral opposition) concerns that it   could ultimately damage the company financially.How to invest during a Trump presidencyThe Dow Jones' average price-to-earnings ratio is currently   around 20 -- relatively high by historic standards. Additionally
column36: you can probably expect politics
column37: and the market's reaction to   them
column38: to be volatile in the months and years ahead. Nonetheless
column39: that shouldn't scare away investors. As the investing proverb   goes: Time in the market is more important than timing the   market.Regardless of how you believe the stock market will perform   based on cyclicalty or political volatility -- barring a massive   shift in policy that derails corporate earnings ability
column40: or a   major economic disaster resulting from an environmental
column41: social
column42: or defense crisis -- you should note that the market performance   graph above has marched upward over the long term.As a long-term investor
column43: you should continue to look for   valuable investments to buy and hold while also watching the   economic and political climate closely. And whatever you do
column44: remember that your investment horizon should be greater than four   -- or even eight -- years.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
