column1: Can FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Salvage Some Value Through a Sale?;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt has been a rough ride forFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) stock. FEYE stock went public in September 2013
column3: priced at $20 per share. FireEye doubled on its first day of trading; it cleared $90 by March. A quick plunge followed
column4: and after a modest rebound
column5: shares have been in a consistent downtrend
column6: falling from above $50 in June 2015 to a current price around $11.makeArticleAd();Source:David via Flickr (Modified)With FEYE stock now near an all-time low
column7: investors are looking to see if there's a way to salvage some value.FireEye itself has been in the middle of a turnaround
column8: to be sure. The company has cut costs
column9: and worked to shift from legacy hardware products to a more cloud-based model. But the departure of the chairman and CFO after last week's Q4 earnings report could hamper those plans. Already
column10: restructuring has left several key positions open and affected FireEye's sales and marketing efforts.There is a case for the company to be a takeover target
column11: which almost certainly would value FEYE stock above current levels. But investors expecting a deal in the near-term seem likely to be disappointed. FireEye could be of interest to a larger player
column12: but it still has a lot of work to do.What FireEye Needs To DoIt's always tempting to see a M&A opportunity in a growth stock that has fallen on hard times. According to aBloombergreport last year
column13: FireEye already has turned down several buyout offers. Those deals almost certainly would have been struck at a price much higher than $11. Surely
column14: the rumored buyers - among themInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) andCisco Systems
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) - would still be interested at a lower price?12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThe problem
column16: however
column17: is that FEYE's business looks much worse than it did even six months ago. 2016 as a whole doesn't look that bad
column18: to be sure: Revenue increased 15% over 2015
column19: and the company managed to cut non-GAAP operating expenses by 3% at the same time. That combination moved FireEye closer to profitability: The non-GAAP loss narrowed from $1.61 per share to $0.99 per share.Those numbers don't show the real issue
column20: however. Billings
column21: which reflect revenue added in the quarter - not necessarily recognized sales - increased just 3% for the year. More concerning: That figure became progressively worse as the year went on. In Q1
column22: billings growth was over 20%; in Q3
column23: the figure increased just 4%. Q4 billings then declined 14% and the midpoint of Q1 guidance implies a 25% decrease next quarter.Nothing good will happen for FEYE stock until that trend is reversed. Acquirers don't want to buy a declining business. FireEye is already both unprofitable and burning cash. Declining billings will only worsen its losses. And FEYE can't blame its market. PeerFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT) announced 22% billings growth in its first quarter on the same day FEYE stock was plunging after its report. To be even considered as an M&A target with a market cap still over $2 billion
column24: FireEye has to fix its sales problems.Can FEYE Stock Rebound Through M&A?For its part
column25: FireEye management believes those issues will be fixed. After Q4
column26: outgoing CFO Mike Berry said the company would return to growth in the second half of 2017. New cloud-based offerings and the recently rolled out Helix platform are projected to start boosting sales by then.The huge decline in product billings - down 50% in Q4
column27: and guided the same in Q1 - will start to be lapped. And CEO Kevin Mandia pointed out on the Q4 call that FireEye for months had no head of sales
column28: either worldwide or in Europe.Combined with easy comparisons
column29: FEYE expects to get back to billings growth toward the end of this year
column30: which likely would translate into revenue growth in early 2018. But until that happens
column31: it's hard to expect much in the way of M&A interest.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column32: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingWhile FireEye seems confident in its prospects
column33: the price of FEYE stock shows that many observers remain skeptical. The company is shifting from products to clouds
column34: but there's a real concern that it's ""too little
column35: too late
column36: with rivals like Fortinet andPalo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW) having beaten FireEye to market.Any sale of FEYE is going to depend on that top-line rebound taking place. Lower spend is nice in the near-term
column37: but isn't going to be the primary consideration of a strategic acquirer like IBM or Cisco. A larger company looking to enter the cybersecurity market through a takeout of FireEye stock is going to plan for substantial cost cuts regardless. Whether FEYE makes those cuts in 2017 or IBM does so in 2019 doesn't much change the possibility of a takeover - or the price to be paid for FireEye stock.Simply put
column38: it's revenue that will drive FEYE's attractiveness as an M&A target. Thus
column39: it's revenue that will drive the performance of FireEye stock this year. Sales performance seems to hinge on whether the company succeeds in pivoting away from its legacy appliance business. That puts a lot of pressure on Helix
column40: in particular. The platform may rise to the challenge
column41: to be sure. But any investors expecting a takeout of FEYE stock should at the least
column42: be patient. FireEye has a lot to prove before bigger companies come calling.As of this writing
column43: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Dividend Growth Stocks on Sale TodayThe postCan FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Salvage Some Value Through a Sale?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How FireEye Inc. Burned to the Ground;2/7/2017;"Shares ofFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) plunged 16% on Feb. 3 after the cybersecurity firm   posted a big  fourth quarter sales miss and a weak first   quarter forecast and revealed the departures of key executives.   FireEye's revenue stayed roughly flat year-over-year at $184.7   million
column2: but that represented a big slowdown from its   double-digit growth in previous quarters and missed forecasts by   $6.3 million.Billings fell 14% annually to $221.8 million
column3: which missed the   company's prior forecast of $230 million to $250 million. Gross   margin fell one percentage point annually to 74%
column4: but operating   margin of -1% -- boosted by layoffs and cost cutting measures --   represented a solid improvement from -28% a year earlier. That's   why FireEye's non-GAAP net loss narrowed from $0.36 per share a   year ago to just $0.03 per share
column5: beating estimates by $0.13.Image source: FireEye.makeArticleAd();But looking ahead
column6: FireEye expects its first quarter revenues   to fall 1%-5% annually
column7: which would mark its first year-over-year   decline since its 2013 IPO. Analysts had expected 5% growth. But   on the bottom line
column8: FireEye expects a non-GAAP loss between   $0.26-$0.28 per share
column9: which represents an improvement over its   loss of $0.47 per share a year earlier. Unfortunately
column10: analysts   were expecting a narrower loss of $0.24. To top off all that bad   news
column11: FireEye disclosed that  CFO Mike Berry and Executive   Chairman and former CEO David DeWalt were both leaving the   company.Faced with all these challenges
column12: it isn't surprising that   FireEye trades at just over half its IPO price of $20. Let's   discuss the main headwinds facing FireEye
column13: and why they could   blow the company even further off course this year.How FireEye lost its sparkFireEye provides a threat detection platform that intercepts   attacks before they breach a company's network perimeter. It   serves over  5
column14: 000 customers in 67 countries
column15: including   nearly half of the Forbes Global 2000. It was also the first   cybersecurity firm to be certified by the U.S. Department of   Homeland Security back in  2015.FireEye's ""best in breed"" reputation and the rise of data   breaches worldwide fueled its explosive revenue growth over the   past few years
column16: but that growth is decelerating. Its annual   revenue rose  163% in 2014
column18: but just 15%   in 2016. That slowdown can mainly be attributed to slower   enterprise spending
column19: tougher competition in the threat detection   market
column20: and a shift away from on-site appliances toward more   scalable cloud-based subscription services.Image source: Getty Images.FireEye is still considered the ""best in breed"" player in   threat detection
column21: but companies likeCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) are now challenging it with bundled threat   detection services. Cisco's acquisitions of SourceFire and    ThreatGRID enhanced its ability to detect threats across   networks powered by its hardware and software. Demand for Cisco's   bundled security solutions notably boosted its cybersecurity   revenues by  13% to nearly $2 billion in fiscal 2016.Microsoft recently launched Windows Defender ATP (Advanced   Threat Protection) for Windows 10
column22: which uses the company's   cloud-based Security Graph (containing data from over 1 billion   Windows devices worldwide) to intercept threats in a similar way.   The tech giant also recently pledge to invest$1 billion annuallyinto its cybersecurity business
column23: which could make it tough for   smaller stand-alone players like FireEye to stay competitive.Widening the moat is a sluggish processFireEye's core turnaround strategy is to pivot away from its   sluggish on-site appliance business and toward FireEye as a   Service (FaaS)
column24: a scalable cloud-based platform that continuously   detects and analyzes threats without the need for appliances
column25: on-site security teams
column26: or managed security services   providers.Last November
column27: FireEye expanded that ecosystem with Cloud MVX   and MVX Smart Grid
column28: which added new private
column29: hybrid
column30: and public   cloud deployment options for mid-sized and larger businesses. It   also launched Helix
column31: an all-in-one platform that bundles its   network
column32: endpoint
column33: Threat Analytics Platform
column34: Advanced Threat   Intelligence
column35: and FireEye Security Orchestrator in a unified   system under  a single user interface.However
column36: turning customers toward that cloud-based platform is   very tough on FireEye's revenue growth
column37: since the company   generates more upfront revenue per appliance sale than   cloud-based subscription. That's why analysts expect its revenue   to rise just 4% in fiscal 2017. FireEye hopes that this growth   will stabilize over time
column38: but its dismal billings growth in the   fourth quarter indicates that it's a tough balancing act to pull   off.The silver liningOn the bright side
column39: CEO Kevin Mandia has reversed FireEye's   widening losses and slowed down its cash burn rate by downsizing   its operations over the past few quarters. The bad news is that   reducing FireEye's sales and marketing spend (down 38% annually   last quarter) could cripple its ability to combat other   competitors and bundled challengers like Cisco and Microsoft.Therefore
column40: I believe that FireEye is in serious trouble
column41: and   that its only real salvation is a buyout. Unfortunately
column42: that   might not happen anytime soon if potential suitors believe that   the company can be bought out at a lower price in the near   future.10 stocks we like better than FireEyeWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and FireEye wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column47: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool owns shares of     and recommends FireEye. The Motley Fool recommends Cisco     Systems. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Can Ubiquiti’s Run Continue in 2017?;2/7/2017;"While many technology investors no doubt enjoyed major gains   in the high-profile large-cap tech names in 2016
column2: mid-cap   wireless companyUbiquiti Networks(NASDAQ: UBNT)  also had itself quite a year
column3: rocketing 125%   in just the past 12 months. The company continues to fly under   the radar
column4: despite having 38-year-old CEO who not only owns the   Memphis Grizzlies but can alsodunk a basketball.Take that
column5: Zuckerberg and Musk!In its most recent quarter ended Sept. 30
column6: revenues grew 35%
column7: and non-GAAP EPS grew a whopping 55% year over year
column8: largely on   the strength of the Unifi segment. With the recent move in the   stock
column9: investors may be wondering if they've missed the boat
column10: but   I think the momentum can continue in 2017 for the following   reasons.makeArticleAd();IMAGE SOURCE: UBIQUITI NETWORKS
column11: INC.Unifi goes up the value chainAs I mentioned
column12: the star of 2016 for Ubiquiti was Unifi
column13: which   grew 75% in the September quarter. This segment makes low-cost   enterprise hardware products
column14: such as wireless access points
column15: switches
column16: routers
column17: security cameras
column18: and VOIP phones
column19: along with   software that allows IT professionals to track large networks   from a single user interface. Ubiquiti's low-cost business model   -- the company employs almost no sales force or service   professionals
column20: and hires a limited number of ""all-star"" engineers   -- enables it to produce solid wi-fi products at rock-bottom   prices
column21: and the product line caught fire in 2016. In January
column22: however
column23: the company unveiled a new line of advanced products   aimed at higher-end customers
column24: which is the turf of IT giants   such asCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andHP(NYSE: HPE) . The new products included the US-16-XG Switch for   $599 and a new Wave 2 access point for $349. These are much   higher price points than traditional Unifi products
column25: but still   much lower than high-end access point vendors such as   Cisco's Meraki ($1
column27: HP's Aruba ($1
column28: 395) andBrocade's(NASDAQ: BRCD) Ruckus ($1
column29: 295). Should Ubiquiti make inroads   into higher-end deployments
column30: these new products could drive   Ubiquiti's already-sky-high 35% operating margin even higher.Ubiquiti looks as if it is finally making its move to disrupt   legacy IT players
column31: just as prominent venture capitalist (and   former Ubiquiti board member) Bill Gurley predicted in 2014:""The fact that Cisco has never had a price disruptor over 30     years seems to violate the rules of the ""Innovator's Dilemma.""     I think many people believe that a disruption from underneath     is overdue. If I had to bet on anyone pulling that off it would     be [Ubiquiti CEO] Robert [Pera].""Airmax refreshWhile Unifi was the star of 2016
column32: Ubiquiti's biggest segment   is still Service Provider
column33: which accounts for 59% of total   revenues. Under the Airmax and Airfiber brands
column34: this segment   makes high-powered radios that beam Wi-Fi over long distances   while achieving cable-like speeds. These radios are the building   blocks for Wireless Internet Service Providers (WISPs) in rural   and emerging markets worldwide
column35: where fiber or satellite is too   expensive
column36: and the spectrum is less cluttered. Airmax growth had   stalled in the past two years from its hyper-growth period a few   years ago
column37: yet still grew 15% year over year in the September   quarter.There are reasons to think that 2017 could bring a   reacceleration for Airmax and its associated products. First
column38: Ubiquiti dropped the ball somewhat when it initially released   Airmax AC
column39: as these hyper-fast products were not   backwards-compatible with older Airmax M radios. That meant   service provider customers would have to refresh their entire   networks of radios in order to upgrade
column40: as opposed to upgrading   radio-by-radio. This was fixed in December with the release of   new firmware AirOS 8.0
column41: which was no small task (it took over a   year!). Second
column42: Pera recently revealed several new Airmax   products for 2017
column43: including a GPON fiber product. While   Ubiquiti's radios are normally used to replace fiber
column44: Ubiquiti   found out that many of its emerging-market customers can lay   fiber along power lines very cheaply
column45: and this new product should   add to their arsenals. Even more exciting
column46: the company revealed   an entirely new ASIC (application-specific integrated chip) it   has developed called LTU. As Pera explained:""It's been well over 3 years in the making
column47: and we're going     to launch it next year. And it's going to be essentially     airFiber multipoint. But it's going to be light-years ahead of     anything in the market
column48: and at cost points relevant to airMAX
column49: we're going to price it higher. The margins are going to be a     lot better... we think that's going to be a really big     differentiator in the market.""Again
column50: we see Ubiquiti making a move to grow out of its   reputation as just a low-cost vendor
column51: and into a company that   sells higher-quality (and
column52: therefore
column53: higher-margin) products as   well.AmplifiWhile Pera & Co. are at it
column54: why not enter a completely new   customer segment? That's what Ubiquiti did this summer with the   introduction of Amplifi
column55: a consumer router that will take onNetgear's(NASDAQ: NTGR) Orbi andGoogle's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) home router. Amplifi is gettingstellar reviewsso far
column56: and just like Unifi's access points
column57: it might pave   the way for other ancillary products for the connected home.Even though the Amplifi was unveiled last summer
column58: it hasn't   produced much revenue for Ubiquiti yet. This is not because the   product wasn't great
column59: but because the company was   capacity-constrained for the last half of 2016. As Pera said:""What I'm really
column60: really
column61: really frustrated about
column62: is we     didn't execute on the production side. So we had demand for     tens of thousands of units out of the gate
column63: and we've just been     slow to get these out.""That is what I'd call having ""champagne problems."" And while   Ubiquiti is going up against strong competitors such as Google
column64: Netgear
column65: and others
column66: the price-performance characteristics of the   product
column67: as well as the secular tailwind of the connected home   makes me a believer that Amplifi could become a meaningful growth   driver as early as this year.The valuation is still reasonableEven after Ubiquiti's big move
column68: the stock trades at a fairly   reasonable 23 times trailing earnings
column69: which means the market is   pricing in decent
column70: though not spectacular
column71: growth from here.   Still
column72: with a disruptive business model
column73: a rock-solid balance   sheet
column74: and a long runway in a secular growth industry
column75: I think   Ubiquiti's stock can exit 2017 a good deal higher than where it   entered.Offer from the Motley Fool: The 10 best stocks to buy       nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. In fact
column76: the newsletter     they run
column77: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column78: has tripled the S&P 500!*Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for     investors to buy right now.Click here to get access to the full       list!*Stock Advisor returns as of 1/30/2017Suzanne Frey

column81: Netgear
column82: and Ubiquiti Networks. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 4 Stocks to Buy for Big February Dividend Hikes;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsToday
column3: I want to talk to you about my favorite strategy for beating the market and building long-term wealth.makeArticleAd();If you've been reading my regular columns onForbesand ContrarianOutlook.com
column4: you probably already know what it is: buy dividend growth. (I'll name 4 individual stocks that should be on your list now in just a moment.)Becauseas I've written before
column5: stocks that regularly hike their payouts outperform any other kind of company over time. You can give yourself a bigger edge if you invest in companies that surprise the market with bigger-than-expected dividend hikes.TakeCisco Systems
column6: Inc.(CSCO)
column7: which ""accelerated"" its quarterly payout last February: after three years of 2 cents per share- and 3 cents per share-a-year increases
column8: Cisco ""went big
column9: boosting its dividend by 5 cents per share
column10: or 23.8%.Management declared the new dividend on February 10
column11: 2016; if you'd bought the day before
column12: you'd be up 37% right now:Big Payout Hike Ignites CSCOProblem is
column13: Cisco's sales and earnings are flattening out
column14: and its payout ratio (or the percentage of earnings paid out as dividends) is edging up near 50%.So even if it does drop another outsized hike on investors this month
column15: I don't expect that run to continue.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryBut that's not the case with the fourotherstocks I've got for you today.Sherwin-Williams Co (SHW): The Color of MoneySherwin-Williams Co(SHW)investors can count on a dividend hike in mid-February
column16: when the paint maker typically announces its quarterly payout for the coming year.Sherwin has raised its dividend for 37 straight years
column17: and it's unlikely to break that streak now. Quite the contrary: in the last three years
column18: the payout has jumped 18.8%
column19: on average
column20: and I expectat leastthat again this month.Why? For one
column21: the company just reported fourth-quarter revenue and earnings that blew past expectations. Management will be keen to draw attention to that
column22: and a fat dividend hike is a great way to do it.They have plenty of room: SHW's payout ratio is minuscule
column23: even with the outsized dividend raises it's been dishing out:A Safe
column24: Growing PayoutYou might think Sherwin's upside is capped by its seemingly high forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 22.2
column25: but that's still below its five-year average of 22.5.And investors are right to expect growth: according to the Leading Indicator of Remodeling Activity
column26: US home-reno spending will jump 6.7% this year. With 37% of the paint market-and likely closer to 50% once it closes its merger with rivalThe Valspar Corp(VAL)-Sherwin's perfectly placed to capitalize.Meantime
column27: the all-but-guaranteed dividend hikes will keep driving the stock price higher. Check out how SHW has risen in lockstep with the payout:Dividend Doubles
column28: SHW TriplesThis 151-year-old company currently offers a 1.1% forward dividend yield. The time to buy is now.Lear Corporation (LEA): A Dividend in OverdriveLear Corporation(LEA) may not get your blood pumping on the current yield front - it pays just 0.85% - but itcertainlyshould when it comes to dividend growth. In the past five years
column29: the automotive seat maker's payout has more than doubled. As with Sherwin
column30: that's helped ignite the stock:Another Triple-DoubleLast February
column31: Lear handed out a 20% dividend increase
column32: and I see another double-digit hike coming this year
column33: likely mid-month.Sure
column34: North American car sales have plateaued
column35: but Lear gets 60% of its revenue from outside the continent
column36: and it's forecasting gains in all of its other regions.Car Sales Roll OnSource: Lear Corp.That will help drive Lear's revenue up to $19.5 billion
column37: topping the record $18.6 billion it posted in 2016. And it's sitting on a record order backlog
column38: to boot.The company also has a relatively small number of locations (just 9% of its total) in Mexico
column39: the country that's taken the brunt of President Trump's ire lately. Meantime
column40: Trump's tax and infrastructure proposals could goose job and wage growth in the US-and send more Americans to their local dealership.Above all
column41: Lear is a free-cash-flow machine
column42: cranking out $1.1 billion worth in the last 12 months. Its dividend accounts for a mere 7.1% of that-one of the lowest ratios I've ever seen in a dividend stock.Finally
column43: Lear is cheap
column44: trading at just 9.0 times forward earnings. That
column45: plus management's aggressive buybacks
column46: give you some added downside protection:A Buyback ChampNational Health Investors Inc (NHI): A Long-Term OutperformerNational Health Investors Inc(NHI)is a real estate investment trust (REIT) that finances seniors' housing facilities through mortgage
column47: sale-leaseback
column48: joint-venture and other forms of financing.You won't find Sherwin- or Lear-style double-digit payout growth here. What youwillfind is consistency: NHI's payout has risen for 14 straight years
column49: and those hikes are still healthy
column50: with the dividend growing at 7.7% annualized over the past five years. Plus
column51: the REIT sets you up with an outsized 4.9% forward dividend yield right off the bat.And if you bought NHI a decade ago
column52: you're no doubt happy today. On a total-return basis
column53: the REIT has crushed the benchmarkSPDR S&P 500 ETF(SPY):Built for the Long HaulWhen it comes to REITs
column54: the key figure is funds from operations (FFO)
column55: not earnings. And a surge in FFO-as demand for the facilities NHI finances marches higher-has been the driving force behind both the soaring share price and the payout growth.Surging FFO Launches NHI's DividendI fully expect that to continue
column56: thanks to demographics: roughly 10
column57: 000 Americans turn 65 every day
column58: and that will fuel soaring demand for senior care in the years ahead. NHI
column59: with a presence in 32 states
column60: stands directly in the way of that trend.Investors
column61: for their part
column62: can look forward to February pay raises for years to come.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThe dividend currently represents 73.2% of normalized FFO
column63: a very manageable level for a REIT. NHI is also attractively priced at just 13.3 times trailing-twelve-month normalized FFO. Buy this one and tuck it away for the next 20 years.Wyndham Worldwide Corporation (WYN): Another Yield-and-Growth PlayWyndham Worldwide Corporation(WYN)also offers an above-average yield - 2.5% vs. 2.1%
column64: on average

column67: because the earnings behind that payout growth keep arcing higher:The company's payout ratio has also held steady at just 28%

column69: with more than 7
column70: 900 hotels and 112
column71: 000 vacation-rental properties worldwide.)The hotel business is competitive

column1: Forget Palo Alto Networks Inc: These 2 Stocks Are Better Buys;2/4/2017;"Image source: Getty.The good news for shareholders ofPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) is that the stock has rebounded following a dismal   2016
column2: jumping 16% in January. The not-so-good news is that wild   stock price fluctuations are par for the course with Palo Alto.   Now
column3: after nearly two years of growing revenue more than 50%
column4: Palo Alto is seeing its sales growth -- like that of many of its   peers -- slowly coming back down to earth.makeArticleAd();Without the sky-high revenue
column5: investors and some pundits are   taking a closer look at the rest of Palo Alto's financials
column6: and   what they see doesn't paint a pretty picture. However
column7: there are   data-security providers that offer exposure to a market expected   to soar in the coming years and are financially sound
column8: offer   industry diversification
column9: and carry less volatility than Palo   Alto. Two that come to mind as better buys -- though for   different reasons -- areCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) andCheck Point Software(NASDAQ: CHKP) .Image source: Cisco.Security and beyondData security sales are fairly low on the list of revenue   drivers for Cisco today
column10: but that's changing with each successive   quarter. Of its primary units
column11: security was handily Cisco's   fastest-growing business last quarter
column12: and don't be surprised to   see more of the same when it announces fiscal 2017 second-quarter   results on Feb. 15.Cisco's security sales accounted for $540 million of its $12.4   billion in total revenue last quarter
column13: and that's already more   than Palo Alto and Check Point. Security grew 11% compared with a   year ago
column14: and with Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins' strategy of shifting   to burgeoning markets
column15: including cloud data centers and the   Internet of Things
column16: data security will become increasingly   important.That's one of the upsides to Cisco in the security space.   Because Cisco is also leading the charge in other fast-growing   opportunities
column17: it isn't overly reliant on one market. The   introduction of Cisco's new ""Digital Building Switch"" that   delivers ""smart"" functionality to buildings is one recent example   of its diverse offerings. And with a 3.4% dividend yield
column18: Cisco   is a much better buy than Palo Alto for growth and income   investors.Image source: Check Point Software.Slow and steadyWhen Check Point shared its fourth-quarter results on Jan. 19
column19: its stock jumped about 7% and has maintained those gains since.   That may come as a surprise
column20: given that its revenue climbed only   6%. Palo Alto disappointed last quarter
column21: reporting a 34% sales   improvement. Why the different response? The answer to that   question is why Check Point is a better buy
column22: particularly for   investors who prefer relative stability.Though Check Point's revenue grew 6%
column23: its earnings per share   (EPS) climbed 21% including one-time items. Palo Alto's EPS
column24: despite its 34% increase in sales to $398.1 million
column25: was a loss   of $0.69 a share
column26: 47% worse than a year ago. Check Point's 26%   increase in its low overhead
column27: recurring subscription revenue of   $110 million
column28: and CEO Gil Shwed's cost-management efforts   translate to a strong bottom line.Check Point was able to report such stellar EPS results   because its total expenses -- both cost of revenue and operating   expenses -- equaled 50% of its $486.7 million in revenue. Palo   Alto spent $50 million more than its total revenue in the   quarter
column29: which is why EPS continues to decline along with its   sales growth.Still a favoriteAnalysts aren't quite as enamored with Palo Alto as they were   a few months ago
column30: though the consensus price target is still   $176.67
column31: equal to nearly 20% appreciation in the near term. One   pundit suggests Palo Alto shares will climb as high as $210.Neither Cisco nor Check Point has earned analysts' good   tidings
column32: at least to the extent Palo Alto has. That said
column33: Cisco's   market diversification
column34: its fast-growing security sales
column35: and an   industry-leading dividend make it a hands-down better buy. And   for a pure-play data-security alternative
column36: Check Point offers a   few things Palo Alto doesn't: increasing profits; a focus on   consistent
column37: sustainable growth; and relative stock price   stability.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Best ETF for 2017;2/2/2017;"The exchange-traded-fund industry is exploding in size and   scope. Global ETF assets are expected to soar to more than $7   trillion by 2021

column5: according to a newreportby the Identity Theft Resource Center and CyberScout. These   incidents exposed more than 36 million sensitive records. Even   worse

column7: and a startling 52% included Social Security   numbers.""The database compromises of 2016 confirmed yet again that   breaches are the third certainty in life and we are all living in   a constant state of cyber-insecurity
column8: said CyberScout chairman   and founder Adam Levin. ""Hackers and identity thieves continue to   evolve. They are very sophisticated
column9: extremely creative
column10: and   dogged in their pursuit of what is ours.""In response to this worrisome trend

column19: with each stock   having a market cap of at least $100 million. Index components   are reviewed and reset quarterly.Top holdings include pure play cybersecurity companies such asCheck Point Software(NASDAQ: CHKP) andPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW)

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column19: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column21: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs   experienced notable outflows »"

column1: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Better Dividends Than Apple;2/2/2017;"Technology stocks
column2: once the domain of high-flying growth investors
column3: are becoming an increasingly generous source of dividends for income investors. The information technology sector led the market by total dividends paid both for the third quarter of 2016 and for the 12 months that ended September 30
column4: according to a FactSet analysis of the 419 dividend payers in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple (symbolAAPL) was tops in the IT sector
column5: paying $12.2 billion in dividends over the 12-month stretch.But just because Apple handed out the most money to its shareholders doesn't mean it's the best source of income in the sector. In fact
column6: Apple's stock currently yields just 1.8%
column7: even less than the S&P 500's 2.1%. So we set out to find mature tech stocks with solid business outlooks that offer superior yields to Apple. Our search turned up three blue-chip names. How blue? Like Apple
column8: all three of our picks are components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Take a look.makeArticleAd();Cisco SystemsCisco Systems
column9: which makes the routers
column10: switches and modems that form the backbone of the internet
column11: is poised for better-than-expected sales growth
column12: analysts say. A recent survey of its customers by UBS Securities revealed that spending on Cisco products remains a top budgetary priority. The tech company gets good marks for being easy to work with
column13: and two-thirds of respondents said it has the best overall security offering. The growth of cloud-based computing (storing data and applications on remote servers) and the Internet of Things (the expanding digital interconnectivity of everyday items
column14: from cars to refrigerators) are long-term tailwinds for the company and the stock. UBS has a ""buy"" rating on Cisco shares.Analysts
column15: on average
column16: expect Cisco's earnings to rise by just a penny this fiscal year ending July 30
column18: according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Sales are forecast to slip 1.9% in fiscal 2017. The more bullish case for Cisco stems from projections for the following fiscal year (ending in July 2018)
column19: when profits are projected to climb 5% to $2.49 a share
column20: and revenue is expected to gain 2.4%.Cisco's dividend
column21: which dates back to 2011
column22: has increased annually. The company disbursed $5 billion in common dividends for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. That was supported by $12 billion in free cash flow
column23: or cash left over after spending the money required to operate and expand the business.SEE ALSO:10 Stocks Every Retiree Should OwnIntelConsumers are increasingly forgoing desktop computers for mobile devices. As a result
column24: PC sales have become a slowly melting iceberg. Market research firm Gartner found that PC sales fell for eight consecutive quarters as of the third quarter of 2016. That has forced Intel
column25: the world's largest maker of the central processing units that serve as a PC's brain
column26: to find new ways to generate revenue growth.The expansion of cloud-based services has been a boon to Intel
column27: thanks to its market-share dominance in server chips. True
column28: Intel faces changes in customer demands and competition from rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column29: but analysts at Stifel say it's responding well. ""Intel has been acquiring technologies and recruiting outside managerial talent to prepare for the changing market
column30: Stifel analyst Kevin Cassidy
column31: who rates Intel shares a ""buy
column32: said in a recent note to clients.Analysts expect 2017 earnings to rise to $2.79 from $2.72 a share in 2016
column33: according to Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to increase 1% to $60.1 billion. Intel paid its first cash dividend in 1992
column34: and the company resumed annual dividend hikes two years ago. Intel's payout ratio
column35: or dividends as a percentage of earnings
column36: is a conservative 37% and below even the S&P 500's average ratio of 40%.SEE ALSO:3 Reasons to Own Apple Stock in RetirementMicrosoftMicrosoft is another tech company that's benefiting from the rise in cloud computing. An increasing number of customers now pay a recurring subscription fee to use its software rather than purchasing it outright. It's proving to be a hot area of growth. ""The closely watched commercial cloud business -- which includes Office 365
column37: Azure and Dynamics 365 -- continued to grow at a torrid rate
column38: reaching over $14.0 billion in annualized revenue in the second quarter [which ended December 31
column40: William Blair & Co. analyst Jason Ader said in a recent note to clients.Importantly
column41: the analyst expects Microsoft to become more profitable over time because of its ""disproportionate growth in its commercial cloud business
column42: which is being boosted by rapid customer adoption of Office 365 and Azure."" Azure is Microsoft's cloud-computing platform
column43: and Office 365 is the subscription version of its popular Office applications. Cloud-based services can have higher profit margins than traditional licensed software.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters project earnings to rise to $2.97 a share for the current fiscal year ending June 30
column44: from $2.79 in fiscal 2016. Revenue for fiscal 2017 is expected to increase 4.9% year over year
column45: to $96.5 billion. For its second quarter
column46: which ended December 31
column47: Microsoft generated $1.3 billion in free cash flow after disbursing $3 billion worth of dividends. The company has paid a dividend to its shareholders since 2003. By contrast
column48: Apple resumed paying a regular quarterly dividend only in 2012
column49: following a 17-year layoff.SEE ALSO:10 Best Dividend-Paying Stocks for 2017"

column1: 5 Safe Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirement;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWith President Donald Trump into his first month in office
column3: it's time for investors to focus on how to navigate what likely will be a bumpy investing road - certainly this year
column4: but potentially for years to come.makeAd('4'
column6: 'mktsnews'
column7: 'vanguard'
column9: '');Source:Steve Buissinne via Stock SnapIndeed
column10: possible changes to Wall Street rules and regulations (including Glass-Steagall)
column11: re-negotiations of trade agreements (including the long-established NAFTA pact
column12: oroutright cancellationof newer agreements like TPP) and an America-focused trade policy will shape the way investors peer into their investment crystal balls.What always will matter for investors - particularly those planning for retirement - is building a portfolio that includes no-brainer dividend stocks that can stand the ups and downs of the markets.Picking winners and losers for the next few months will be fraught with uncertainty. My advice? Focus on things like balance sheets
column13: cash flows
column14: dividend hike histories and diversification. That'll provide you with a solid base for the future.As a note: These dividend stocks don't come with screamingly high yields
column15: and instead sit around the 3%-4% area. That's because what we're looking for here is good dividend yield
column16: but excellent dividend quality. Plus
column17: in most of these cases
column18: there's room for dividend growth
column19: which will improve your yield on cost over time.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryHere's a look at five safe dividend stocks that fit our retirement needs:Safe Dividend Stocks for Retirement: Cisco Systems (CSCO)Source: ShutterstockCSCO Dividend Yield:3.5%Cisco Systems
column20: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) continues to be virtually eponymous with routers
column21: switches
column22: and integrated networks.The problem is
column23: those businesses are waning.Cisco didn't have a smooth recovery coming out of the financial crisis
column24: though management did manage to right the ship starting around 2012. That said
column25: revenues have been mostly flat thanks to its aging legacy businesses.Nonetheless
column26: Cisco is primed for strong growth thanks to moves well beyond its roots
column27: including in the internet of things.Cisco's dividend is relatively fresh
column28: having started in 2011 at 6 cents per share. Now
column29: the dividend stands more than quadruple that at 26 cents
column30: good for a yield well north of 3%. And given that CSCO still pays out less than half its profits in earnings
column31: you can expect Cisco to keep hiking its dividend - albeit
column32: maybe notasaggressively as it has in the past half-decade.Also reassuring is just under $70 billion in cash and short-term investments
column33: which it can use to make deals like its recent$3.7 billion buyout of AppDynamics.Cisco's flat revenues aren't reassuring
column34: but earnings are expected to grow this year and next
column35: and Wall Street even expects a modest 2% uptick in revenues next year
column36: so that's something.Also
column37: CSCO trades at just 12.3 times forward earnings. That's just less thanInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column38: and a couple points underOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL). And both of those dividend stocks don't have Cisco matched for yield right now.Safe Dividend Stocks for Retirement: Consolidated Edison (ED)Source:WikimediaED Dividend Yield:3.8%Well
column39: if nothing else
column40: Consolidated Edison
column41: Inc.(NYSE:ED) gets my mom's stamp of approval: She has owned the dividend stock in her retirement portfolio since 1980.ConEd primarily serves New York City and most of its northern suburbs
column42: and has been around since 1832. Today it delivers gas
column43: electric and steam service (think radiators) to more than 10 million customers
column44: generating nearly $13 billion in revenue for 2016.New York and its suburbs continue to grow in population
column45: housing starts are up
column46: NYC is still home to a multitude of corporate headquarters locations
column47: and tourists still flock to the Big Apple in droves. But ConEd isn't simply resting on what the New York area has to offer.To start
column48: ConEd is working to find ways to produce cleaner energy that costs less for it to produce
column49: like acustomer-centric program in Brooklyn and Queensthat's helping to provide customers with incentives to lower costs instead of needing to build a $1 billion substation. ConEd is also building out anAdvanced Metering Infrastructure program- a smart meter technology that will help identify local power generation problems and possible power outages more quickly for customers
column50: allowing ConEd to administer services more quickly.What ConEd lacks in size - for comparison
column51: Duke Energy Corp(NYSE:DUK) runs at about $23bb per year - it makes up for in steady net income of just over $1 billion per year over the past few years
column52: and grown profits for the past three years. Steadier still is ED's operating cash flow of over $3 billion - a tidy sum considering its $12 billion in revenue.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsED's payout ratio is nearly 65%
column53: but for a utility company
column54: that's not terribly high.Southern Co(NYSE:SO) and Duke Energy clock in above 80%. So ConEd has a bit more room to improve its dividends. Indeed
column55: Consolidated Edison has increased earnings for 42 consecutive years
column56: including a 3% hike recently to 69 cents quarterly.Safe Dividend Stocks for Retirement: Lockheed Martin (LMT)Source:Praveer Sharma via FlickrDividend Yield:2.9%Defense is one of President Trump's biggest areas of focus
column57: andLockheed Martin Corporation(NYSE:LMT) is … well
column58: it's a solid bet for the years ahead
column59: despite what the headlines might indicate.This global aerospace and security giant operates within five segments
column60: including Aeronautics
column61: Information Systems & Global Solutions (IS&GS)
column62: Missiles and Fire Control (MFC)
column63: Mission Systems and Training (MST) and Space Systems. Lockheed's diversity of product offerings and industries provides the ability to weather some difficult times.With programs that run the gamut fromhelicopter and fighter jetsto advancedmaterial manufacturing
column64: Lockheed's $46 billion business model is set to cushion the possible blow of lowering the price of its signature F-35 jet after President Trump jaw-boned CEO Marillyn Hewson onthe cost of the program. At $379 million
column65: the F-15 is roughly 20% of LMT's revenue.But that's not the only program in the Lockheed portfolio
column66: and Lockheed is far from a company hoping to hold on to the past and hope for the future. Its most recent blockbuster move was the purchase ofUnited Technologies(NYSE:UTX) Sikorsky Helicopter division in 2015 - a move once thought foolish but that haspanned outbig-time for LMT.LMT is also knee-deep in one of the biggest growth sectors in the tech sector: cybersecurity. Lockheed technology is everywhere
column67: from building firewalls for commercial users to national security.On the dividend front
column68: LMT has raised its dividend for 14 consecutive years
column69: and those haven't been meager upticks. Lockheed's quarterly payout has grown 82% in just the past five years alone.If President Trump is indeed on the side of the defense industry in his quest to restore American military power abroad
column70: Lockheed Martin is going to sit in the front row of procurement.Safe Dividend Stocks for Retirement: PepsiCo (PEP)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Dividend Yield:2.9%If President Trump's policies do indeed break the economy wide open for growth
column71: consumer products giantPepsiCo
column72: Inc.(NYSE:PEP) is among the dividend stocks that will be on the front lines of prosperity.PepsiCo management's decision to expand its branding footprint well beyond it eponymous ""Pepsi"" soda lineup over the years has helped smooth over difficult times for the industry. In fact
column73: Pepsi is more than beverages
column74: also boasting a massive snack line that has taken some of the sting out of the weakening popularity of sugary beverages.Buried within each of PepsiCo's six divisions are brand names that will stand the long-game test of time:  Aquafina water
column75: Gatorade sports drinks
column76: Tropicana and Ocean Spray juice products
column77: Aunt Jemima pancakes
column78: Cap'n Crunch cereal
column79: Cheetos
column80: Cracker Jack
column81: Diet Pepsi
column82: and Diet Sierra Mist are among the standouts.PepsiCo isn't afraid to spend
column83: either - PEP poured out $4 billion on advertising and $700 million on R&D in 2015 - so its brands should continue to saturate both the markets and consumers' brains with each commercial or product promotion.PepsiCo isn't among the highest-yielding dividend stocks for retirement. Instead
column84: it's a dual play on both price appreciation and dividend growth.Indeed
column85: PepsiCo's 2016 dividend hike to 75 cents per share (quarterly) was its 44th consecutive annual raise. Free cash flow was just under $8 billion last year
column86: plus Pepsi has about $15 billion in cash and short-term investments
column89: PepsiCo's dividend payout ratio of 63% leaves way more room for dividend hikes thanThe Coca-Cola Co's(NYSE:KO) 83% payout.The 10 Best Vanguard Funds for 2017While PepsiCo isn't terribly cheap
column91: it's still a hair less expensive than KO
column92: and PEP offers much better earnings growth prospects (6% vs. 2% over the next five years) to boot.Safe Dividend Stocks for Retirement: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)Source:Dawn Via FlickrDividend Yield:2.8%Johnson & Johnson(NYSE:JNJ) is one of my personal favorites among retirement-focused dividend stocks
column93: and full disclosure: I own it myself.JNJ straddles two critical sector of the economy in healthcare and pharmaceuticals. Both in and of themselves also intersect
column94: which brings us to the key point behind JNJ's longevity
column96: and investment selling point: its Consumer
column97: Pharmaceutical and Medical Devices divisions.Pharmaceuticals and Medical combine to make up just more than 80% of total revenues
column99: healthcare is the biggest driver of JNJ. But having essentially 20% exposure to consumer products buffers Johnson & Johnson from significant economic or sector downturns
column100: including arecent turndownin the medical sector.A key to JNJ's longevity
column101: and that of any pharm stock of course
column102: is its pipeline of future medicines and drugs. Here
column103: the company has several late-stage trial drugs
column104: which includes additional indications for already-approved myleoma treatment Imbruvica and heart treatment Xarelto.Johnson & Johnson's biggest claim to dividend fame
column106: is its standing as a Dividend Aristocrat
column107: having raised its payout for 54 consecutive years
column108: including a 6.7% bump in 2016.Free cash flow has been steadily on the rise
column109: including just less than $16 billion in FCF in 2015. Meanwhile
column110: Johnson & Johnson just used $30 billion in cash to buy up Switzerland-basedActelion Ltd
column111: a maker of products for pulmonary arterial hypertension … which means it still has a decent war chest of about $10 billion remaining.JNJ trades about the same as the broader S&P 500
column112: and offers long-term stability and income. This is a good time to strike.As of this writing
column113: Marc Bastow was long JNJ.The post5 Safe Dividend Stocks to Buy for Retirementappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will Microsoft's $1 Billion Cybersecurity Play Hurt Smaller Players?;2/1/2017;"Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) recently announced that  it will invest over   $1 billion per year on cybersecurity research and development.   That amount
column2: which is equivalent to roughly 8% of its R&D   spend over the past 12 months
column3: doesn't include any acquisitions   that Microsoft might make. Let's see why Microsoft is beefing up   its cybersecurity efforts
column4: and what that could mean for smaller   players across the fragmented industry.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();What cybersecurity means to MicrosoftMicrosoft's Windows is the most widely used PC operating   system in the world
column5: Office is the  most popular   productivity suite
column6: and Azure is the second largest cloud   platform in the world afterAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS. Much of this massive ecosystem has   traditionally been protected by third party companies.   Microsoft's own products -- like Windows Firewall
column7: Windows   Defender
column8: and Microsoft Security Essentials -- were  often   considered inferior to third-party ones.However
column9: Microsoft's ecosystem has become more cohesive under   CEO Satya Nadella's ""One Windows"" strategy
column10: which aims to install   the same OS and app store across multiple platforms. Since users   would ideally download apps from the Windows Store and deliver   their data to Cortana and Bing via Azure
column11: it would be logical to   add first-party
column12: self-updating security solutions across the   entire ecosystem. Microsoft claims that the number of weekly   cyber attacks has risen from 20
column13: 000 to as many as 700
column14: 000 over   the past two to three years.To counter those threats while expanding its ecosystem
column15: Microsoft acquired three Israeli cybersecurity firms over the   past two years -- enterprise security start-up Aorato
column16: cloud   security firm Adallom
column17: and data protection firmSecure Islands. Those acquisitions and its planned R&D investments could   help Azure challenge AWS
column18: which already integrates an    arsenal of security features into its cloud infrastructure   platform. Azure's revenue surged 93% annually last quarter
column19: but   Microsoft hasn't revealed its exact sales figures yet.How this could hurt smaller playersAs Microsoft's cybersecurity ecosystem grows
column20: it could overlap   with the services of many smaller stand-alone third-party   players. For example
column21: Microsoft recently  launched Windows   Defender ATP (Advanced Threat Protection) for Windows 10. That   endpoint service matches events with Microsoft's cloud-based   Security Graph
column22: which gathers data across over a billion Windows   devices worldwide. It also works with Microsoft's email   protection services from Office 365 and Microsoft Advanced Threat   Analytics.This platform directly competes against ""perimeter"" players   like threat prevention firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) and next-gen firewall vendorPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) . During last year's RSA Conference
column23: Microsoft   principal research lead Tanmay Ganacharya toldDark Readingthat Windows Defender ATP can ""help capture network traffic out   of a given endpoint""
column24: so that it could ""detect the same attacks""   as FireEye and other threat detection services.Consider what $1 billion means to these smaller cybersecurity   companies. Palo Alto and FireEye are expected to respectively   generate $1.8 billion and $720 million in revenues this year --   so there's no way that they could match Microsoft's R&D   investments. Windows
column25: Office 365
column26: Azure
column27: Dynamics
column28: and other   platforms all give Microsoft the ability to bundle and scale up   its cybersecurity services very quickly. It can also offer lower   prices and offset those losses across other parts of its   ecosystem.But ""best in breed"" cybersecurity firms could still     surviveMicrosoft's growing interest in the cybersecurity market could   render some smaller players obsolete
column29: but ""best in breed"" players   like FireEye and Palo Alto have survived similar assaults from   bundled players before.Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column30: for example
column31: has aggressively bundled threat   prevention and next-gen firewalls into its networking hardware   and software. Yet FireEye still serves 5
column32: 000 customers across 67   countries
column33: which includes nearly half of the Forbes Global 2000.   Palo Alto serves over 35
column34: 500 customers in more than  140   countries
column35: including 80 of the Fortune 100 and half of the Global   2000.Those numbers indicate that companies will likely value a   company's track record and reputation over the convenience of   cheaper bundles. They also indicate that it could be smarter for   Microsoft to either acquire or partner with smaller stand-alone   players instead of trying to render them obsolete.The key takeawayBeefing up its cybersecurity business will help Microsoft   counter Amazon and tighten up its ""One Windows"" ecosystem. While   some of the new features seem destined to crush third-party   security players
column36: investors should remember that companies will   likely stick with ""best in breed"" players instead of the cheapest   bundle
column37: and a mass switch to a new security platform can be   costly and time consuming.Therefore
column38: investors in cybersecurity companies should be   mindful of Microsoft's ambitions
column39: but they should remember that   many ""best in breed"" companies have weathered similar attacks   from companies like Cisco before.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column40: it can pay to listen. After all

column1: Apple (AAPL) Q1 Earnings and Revenues Beat
column2: Increase Y/Y;2/1/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Shares ofApple Inc.AAPLwere up over 3% in aftermarket trading following better-than-expected first quarter of fiscal 2017 results.Earnings of $3.36 per share and revenues of $78.4 billion easily topped the respective Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.22 and $76.9 billion. On a year-over-year basis
column3: both metrics registered growth of 2.4% and 3.3%.Product DetailsThe good show was driven by impressive sales of Apple's latest smartphone model iPhone 7 and 7 Plus. Performance of Apple's Services business was also impressive.Total iPhone unit sales came in at about 78.3 million
column4: up 5% year over year. Revenues from iPhone also grew 5% from the year-ago quarter to $54.4 billion (69.4% of total revenue).Services
column5: which include revenues from Internet Services
column6: App store
column7: Apple Music
column8: AppleCare
column9: Apple Pay
column10: licensing and other services
column11: surged 18% year over year (with extra one week in the quarter) to nearly $7.2 billion. App Store sales in December alone topped $3 billion. Apple said that it expects Services ""revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company this year.""Apple Inc. Price
column12: Consensus and EPS SurpriseApple Inc. Price
column13: Consensus and EPS Surprise|Apple Inc. QuoteManagement also noted that Apple Pay reported transaction volume growth of 500%
column14: buoyed by expansion to markets like Spain
column15: Japan
column16: Russia and New Zealand. At present Apple Pay is available in 13 markets.Apple Mac unit sales were up 1% year over year to approximately 5.4 million
column17: while revenues grew 7% from the prior-year quarter to $7.2 billion.Coming to iPad
column18: Apple sold 13.1 million units in the quarter
column19: down 19% year over year. Revenues of $5.5 billion were down 22% from the prior year quarter.Other products
column20: which include revenues from Apple TV
column21: Apple Watch
column22: Beats products
column23: iPod and Apple-branded and third-party accessories
column24: declined 8% year over year to over $4 billion. Again
column25: there were no data available on Apple Watch sales or its latest product launch
column26: AirPods.Geographical PerformanceDemand for Apple's products improved across most of the geographical regions except greater China. As much as 64% of sales were from the International markets.Americas (the biggest market for Apple) generated revenues of approximately $32 billion in the quarter
column27: up 9% year over year.Europe generated nearly $18.5 billion in revenues
column28: up 3% on a year-over-year basis.Revenues from Japan rose 20% year over year to $5.8 billion while the rest of Asia Pacific generated revenues of $5.8 billion
column29: up 8% year over year.Owing to persistent macroeconomic weakness
column30: Apple revenues declined around 12% year over year in the Greater China region to $16.2 billion.MarginsGross margin was 38.5%
column31: a decline of 160 basis points (bps) from the year-ago quarter.Operating expenses increased 9% year over year to $6.8 billion due to higher research & development expenses as well as selling
column32: general and administrative expenses. As a result
column33: operating margin plunged 210 bps from the year-ago quarter to 29.8%.Balance Sheet and Cash FlowApple's cash and cash equivalents (and short-term marketable securities) were $60.5 billion at the end of the quarter
column34: compared with $67.2 billion at fiscal 2016-end. Long-term debt was $73.6 billion compared with $75.4 billion at the end of fiscal 2016.For the quarter
column35: cash generated from operating activities was $27.1 billion.Apple returned about $15 billion in capital returns this quarter through dividends and share repurchases. Apple also said that it has so far returned $201 billion out of the $250 billion capital returns program announced in April last year.The company also declared its quarterly dividend of 57 cents per share payable on Feb 16 to shareholders of record as on Feb13.GuidanceFor the second quarter of fiscal 2017
column36: Apple forecasts revenues in a range of $51.5 billion to $53.5 billion.Gross margin is expected within 38% to 39%
column37: while operating expenses are projected within $6.5 billion to $6.6 billion. Other income/ (expense) is likely to be $400 million
column38: while tax rate is expected to be 26%.Our TakeBetter-than-expected iPhone sales have definitely come as a respite. But the macroeconomic headwinds remain for now
column39: especially in China
column40: one of the high-growth regions for Apple. Also
column41: competition from local players has been hindering iPhone's growth in China.Nonetheless
column42: Apple is optimistic about long-term growth prospects in regions like China and India. In the last few months
column43: Apple has increased its focus on India
column44: which is expected to become the second largest smartphone market in the world. In fiscal 2016
column45: Apple sales in India grew approximately 50% over the prior fiscal.Apple's Services business is also expected to remain strong as it is mostly dependent on the already installed Apple devices. Also
column46: in the long run
column47: Apple is expected to benefit from its robust cash position
column48: strength in technology and the ecosystem that it has built
column49: given its loyal customer base. Further
column50: its enterprise collaborations with the likes of Deloitte
column51: IBM Corp.IBM

column1: Why Shares of Cisco Systems Rose 11% in 2016;1/31/2017;"Image source: Cisco Systems.What happenedShares of networking hardware giantCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) jumped 11.3% in 2016
column2: according to data provided   byS&P Global Market Intelligence. While revenue declined slightly in each of the past four   quarters
column3: Cisco has put together a long streak of beating analyst   estimates for both revenue and earnings. The stock rose slightly   more than theS&P 500index last year
column4: driven by these earnings beats.makeArticleAd();So whatWhile Cisco reported year-over-year revenue declines in each   of its four quarterly reports in 2016
column5: the sale of the SP Video   CPE business was the main culprit. Adjusting for this   divestiture
column6: Cisco managed to grow revenue by between 1% and 3%   each quarter. This was enough to beat analyst estimates for   revenue in all cases.About 45% of Cisco's revenue comes from its core switching and   routing segments
column7: which are no longer consistently growing
column8: with   the rest coming from faster-growing segments like security and   collaboration. While switching revenue was flat in fiscal 2016   and routing revenue slumped 4%
column9: collaboration and security   revenue rose by 9% and 13%
column10: respectively. This growth helped   balance out weakness in the core business.CSCOdata byYCharts.Cisco also beat analyst estimates for earnings each quarter
column11: with profitability holding up better than revenue. Share buybacks   helped
column12: with the company spending nearly $4 billion in fiscal   2016 buying back its own shares. Cisco does expect a decline in   revenue and earnings during the second fiscal quarter of 2017.   That guidance sent the stock lower during the last few months of   last year.Now whatSome of Cisco's growth businesses performed poorly during the   last reported quarter. Collaboration and data center revenue each   fell by 3% year over year. Security remained strong
column13: growing by   11%
column14: but Cisco's guidance suggests that this wasn't an   anomaly.Cisco has made plenty of acquisitions as it aims to diversify   away from hardware. The biggest in quite a while
column15: the$3.7 billion purchase of software provider   AppDynamics
column16: was announced in January 2017. Cisco is paying a steep price
column17: and I'm a little concerned that the company is becoming   undisciplined when it comes to splurging for start-ups.   Acquisitions are important for Cisco
column18: but dramatically overpaying   will do more harm than good.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column20: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
