column1: The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTheDow Jones Industrial Averagehas long been sold to investors as one of the best
column3: safest places to put your money. Dow dividend stocks
column4: as a result
column5: have been a buy-and-hold safe haven for decades.makeArticleAd();Source: StockSnap.ioDividends - those sweet regular payments that companies make to shareholders - mean vital income for many older investors.Safety and dividend yield were what Charles Dow was looking for when he crafted his first list of 12 industrial stocks on May 28
column7: for his and Edward Jones'Wall Street Journal. One company -General Electric Company(NYSE:GE) - remains from that original group. The others were broken up by the government
column8: turned into divisions of other firms or (likeNational Lead) just sank out of sight.Today's list is heavy on technology but also includes oil companies
column9: retailers
column10: tech companies and financials. In my 30 years as a self-directed retirement investor
column11: I have owned a dozen of them at one time or another.As we age
column12: our investing goals change. At 62
column13: I'll soon be less interested in growth
column14: more interested in income to take me through my retirement. That's where Dow dividend stocks shine.For those on the hunt for income
column15: we'll examine the top 10 Dow Jones Industrial Average components by yield as we head into February. Every stock on here yields at least 3.2% - not too shabby in a world where the 30-year U.S. bond is still yielding just 3.03%.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatBut important to note is that while all of these stocks are good yielders
column16: not all of them are winners. This look at the Dow 30's highest-yielding dividend stocks is meant to help you separate the wheat from the chaff.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #10
column17: Caterpillar (CAT)Source:Anthony via FlickrCAT Dividend Yield:3.2%Caterpillar Inc.(NYSE:CAT)
column18: the Peoria
column19: Ill.-based maker of heavy equipment
column20: has been shrinking since 2012
column21: because much of its equipment is sold for moving coal and other resources out of the ground and to the market.Caterpillar is heavily tied to agriculture
column22: and farm income has also been falling since 2012. Oversupply means lower income
column23: and many farmers can't pay their debts - much of which were taken out to buy Caterpillar equipment. On a trip to the Midwest last summer
column24: I saw corn that was literally as high as an elephant's eye
column25: but I saw very few happy farmers.That may change this year.Prices on corn futures have been risingand corn prices should be at $4 per bushel early next year. In anticipation of better days
column26: CAT stock is up 40% over the last year. This comes on top of a 77-cent quarterly dividend that currently yields a little more than 3%.Most analysts have Caterpillar rated only as a hold
column27: estimating earnings for 2017 at $3.26 per share - not enough to cover that dividend.I have not added CAT to my portfolio
column28: but that doesn't mean I'm not optimistic about this Dow stock. Caterpillar still has positive operating cash flow. Management has held the line on debt
column29: even while asset values have gone down. Belts have been tightened
column30: and better business anywhere -as from a big Trump infrastructure plan- would fall mostly to the bottom line.Caterpillar's $2-per-share loss last week on revenues of $9.6 billion sent shares down a bit
column31: as many investors see this as the bottom for the current cycle.CAT is leveraged to profit from growth. I see the price as rich here - the stock has been on fire since the election - but a realistic price in the low $90s could be a buying opportunity.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #9
column32: IBM (IBM)Source: ShutterstockIBM Dividend Yield:3.2%I am known aroundInvestorPlaceas a hater ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column33: but I have not always hated the company. I owned it early in this decade
column34: seeing a nice dividend and a share price that by 2012 was pushing $200 per share.Now
column35: among Dow dividend stocks
column36: IBM is a loser.IBM reported its full-year results on Jan. 19
column37: and fourth-quarter revenues of $21.77 billion were indeed more than the previous quarter's $19.23 billion. But don't be fooled. During the previous quarter
column38: the company had revenue of $22.06 billion
column39: and it delivered over $250 million more net income during that quarter than in 2016
column40: too.For all the brave talk about Watson - the artificial intelligence software IBM has been using in ads the way it used Charlie Chaplin in the 1980s - much of its profit still comes from mainframes. Mainframes are dying. A lot of its software serves mainframes and corporate networks. Corporate networks are being replaced by IP networks.As in the past
column41: IBM has been trying to buy its way out of trouble
column42: buyingTruven HealthAnalyticsa year ago
column43: for $2.6 billion
column44: aSalesforce.com Inc.(NYSE:CRM) integrator calledBlue Wolffor $200 million
column45: and some other pieces in cloud security and recovery - areas that are growing.But the boat continues to open new leaks. In recent years
column46: IBM was forced to literally give away its chip-making business
column47: payingGlobal Foundries$1.5 billion to take it off its hands. Businesses likeRational Software
column48: bought in 2003 for $2.1 billion
column49: are being sold in pieces because they no longer make sense. IBM is out of PCs
column50: out of mini-computers
column51: out of printers
column52: even out of what used to be cash registers.IBM is like a beautiful old house with a huge mortgage whose owners are selling the china and silver to pay for their healthcare. They may look good at the club
column53: in their tennis whites
column54: butbehind the curtain
column55: it's Grey Gardens.IBM has growing debts
column56: declining profits and an ossified corporate culture where selling and marketing mean more than creating technology breakthroughs and solving real problems.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsI don't care ifWarren Buffett still loves IBM. I don't. I'm afraid I never will again.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #8
column57: General Electric (GE)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)GE Dividend Yield:3.3%Charlie Dow knew a good long-term play when he saw one.General Electric Company(NYSE:GE)has the longest tenure among Dow dividend stocks
column58: 121 years on.Dow might even recognize Jeff Immelt's GE. So might Charles Coffin
column59: who was president of the General Electric Co. in 1896. GE today
column60: as in 1896
column61: is mostly in the power business. It makes engines and generators. It also makes products that bring fuel to the surface
column62: and last November bid to take over most ofBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI).GE is up 8% over the year and sports a 3%-plus dividend
column63: which means a total return of about 11%.Almost half the analysts following it say to buy
column64: and the average rating is ""overweight."" They expect earnings of $1.69 per share this year - plenty to cover the 98-cent annual dividend
column65: which rose by a penny late last year.As I recently wrote
column66: GE is a company thatover-promises and under-delivers.It isn't going to fail
column67: but it isn't going to boom
column68: either.It may do well if oil booms again
column69: but under Immelt
column70: GE has become aWaiting for Godotstock … and in the play
column71: Godot never showed up.I owned GE for most of this decade
column72: and enjoyed a decent return
column73: but I see a limited horizon for the oil and gas business - higher prices will just bring more supply
column74: driving prices back down again. Add to that the fact that renewable energy supplies
column75: especially efficiency
column76: are increasing and getting cheaper.Yes
column77: it makes wind turbines and it's all over efficiency
column78: but I'm not feeling the return there.Sorry
column79: Charlie.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #7
column80: Cisco Systems (CSCO)Source: ShutterstockCSCO Dividend Yield:3.4%For one brief shining moment in the year 2000
column81: Cisco Systems
column82: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) was the world's most valuable company. Their Internet switches and routers connected the world
column83: and the ceiling for growth seemed unlimited.This was back when my kids were in grade school and I rocked a red beard
column85: CSCO is a solid dividend stock. The 26-cent quarterly dividend yields 3.4%. It's a little like me: a distinguished white-haired gentleman. If you bought it when it made that turn in 2011
column87: its 6-cent payout has more than quadrupled
column88: and you have an annual yield of 6% on that investment. Cisco can afford the dividend
column90: as it usually earns about twice its payout.But there is danger in the air.Hardware is becoming software. The function of a switch or a writer can be done by any PC with ports and the write software. The trend is called Software Defined Networking. Cisco is thus rushing to become a software company
column92: becoming a force in computer security
column93: and raising the percentage of revenue from software to 29%.Analysts are divided between those who tell people to buy Cisco
column94: and those who just want you to hold it. I once owned this stock
column95: and I am not divided. I say avoid it. If you're to buy into technology
column96: you need to get in on the leading edge
column97: and switches are no longer the leading edge.Technology evolves rapidly. When a technology company ceases to be on that leading edge
column98: it starts to die. This can happen very quickly
column99: asNokia Corp. (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) discovered with the debut of the iPhone 10 years ago. And there may be nothing that can be done
column100: as Novell learned when the internet replaced its networking system. Also
column101: the industry seldom allows for second acts.The 7 Best High-Yield Investments for RetirementI do not envy the job of Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins
column102: who succeeded the legendary John Chambers in 2015. Selling any kind of hardware in a cloud-based era is a very difficult thing to do
column103: and margins will remain compressed.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #6
column104: Coca-Cola (KO)Source:Leo Hidalgo via Flickr (Modified)KO Dividend Yield:3.4%I admit to a bias on behalf ofThe Coca-Cola Co(NYSE:KO).I was raised on Coke on Long Island. I never liked Pepsi. (Pro tip: The secret ingredient is vanilla.)I moved to Atlanta in 1981
column105: and Coca-Cola built Atlanta. There is no other reason for a city to be here
column106: save the sugar water that Robert Woodruff took around the world. Woodruff convinced corporations to put regional offices here
column107: his boyhood friend Bill Hartsfield (of the airport) helped make the city an island of relative peace during the Civil Rights era
column108: and as ""Mr. Anonymous"" he contributed much of the civic infrastructure
column109: like the Arts Center and most of the Emory University campus
column111: did you ever wonder why Santa Claus wears a red coat?That's Coca-Cola red.I have owned Coca-Cola stock in the past. I got out because it's just not growing - revenues are down 10% since 2012
column112: and operating margins have been declining. Don't let anyone fool you about what they make
column113: either. It's not so much sugared water as it is treated water. Mr. Woodruff said in 1923 to make every Coca-Cola (we call it Co-Cola down here) taste like every other Coca-Cola
column114: no matter where you bought it
column115: and that made the company an early leader in water treatment. If you don't trust the water on your travels
column116: buy a Coke. It won't hurt you.That said
column117: there may finally be a reason to buy Coke stock again
column118: and his name is James Quincey.Quincey becomes CEO on May 1and is already credited with growing profits through smaller cans and buying new brands likeJugo de Valle
column119: a Mexican juice producer.Coke now has 20 brands with over $1 billion in sales
column121: Odwalla juices and Honest Tea. If you buy a can of hot coffee from a vending machine in Japan
column123: another Coke product.Coca-Cola delivers a steady $10 billion in operating cash flow each year
column124: and continues to cover its 35-cent quarterly dividend with earnings. A 10% price decline since April has goosed the yield a bit - and you want to buy a dividend stock when the price is down
column126: but when there is a little bit of excitement around it
column127: like now.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #5
column128: Boeing (BA)Source:Phillip Capper via FlickrBA Dividend Yield:3.5%I am a former shareholder ofBoeing Co(NYSE:BA)
column129: having sold out last spring at about $130 per share.This was a mistake
column130: as Boeing shares are now worth $169 - one-third more than they were when I sold. Even at that price
column132: the recently announced $1.42-per-share dividend sports a yield of 3.5%. Boeing delivered $10.5 billion in operating cash flow during the fourth quarter
column133: and forecast 2017 earnings of $9.10 to $9.30 per share
column134: meaning that new dividend should be safe.Since orders for new planes peaked in 2014
column135: Boeing has been focused on productivity and cost-cutting
column140: which for now is not unionized.But aftera failed attemptto move production offshore early in the decade
column141: I questioned just how much more costs could be driven out of plane production
column142: which is why I foolishly sold.Boeing is increasing its delivery of aircraft in 2017 and plans to get into the space business in 2018. If it can pick up more military contracts
column143: the stock could be worth its current price
column144: which has reached analyst targets and thus could be subject to profit-taking.If profits are taken and the price falls
column146: jump in. Profit-taking will be limited by the increased dividend
column147: whose yield puts a floor under that price.In short
column148: Boeing truly is among the ""top"" Dow dividend stocks
column149: in that it makes more than enough to cover what it pays out
column150: and it has good enough prospects to be worth holding for years to come.The 7 Best REITs to Buy for High Yield AND GrowthEverybody goofs at some point.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #4
column151: Exxon Mobil (XOM)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)XOM Dividend Yield:3.6%No Dow stock was as ready for Trump asExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM)
column152: whose CEO Rex Tillerson is close to being confirmed as Secretary of State.Exxon rose sharply after the election
column153: by more than 10% in about a month. But it has since given up most of those gains
column154: helping expand its yield to 3.6%. The question is whether that dividend can be sustained into the future. Exxon hasn't brought in more than 75 cents per share in net income since the end of 2015
column155: and that was not expected to changewhen it reported earnings on Jan. 31.The street's ""whisper number"" of 68 cents per share - what analysts are supposedly telling each other what to expect - is below the consensus earnings estimate of 72 cents.The bull case for Exxon has always been based on its balance sheet. The company has nearly $340 billion in assets
column156: and the $46 billion in debt it had against those assets in October was among the lowest figures in the industry. Tillerson managed Exxon Mobil conservatively during the oil bust
column157: which turned out to be a wise move as operating cash flow deteriorated sharply through the first quarter of 2016.Exxon Mobil is called an ""integrated international"" oil company
column158: with production assets around the world
column161: and gas stations. This let it squeeze out margins even when oil prices were at their lowest
column163: trading and running gas stations.The company is hedging its bets on international growth
column164: buying oil assets in Texas' Permian Basin for $5.6 billion up-front and as much asanother $1 billion over the next few years. It's also hedging its bets on the climate
column165: appointing environmental scientist Dr. Susan Avery to its board of directors - a move Tillerson would have been unlikely to make and one that shocked some Trump allies. The fact is XOM now has allies in Washington to fight its political battles
column166: and it can expect good news on that front for some time to come.In the near-term
column167: this makes Exxon Mobil stock a buy and
column169: a bargain.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #3
column170: Chevron (CVX)Source:swong95765 via Flickr (Modified)CVX Dividend Yield:3.9%Chevron Corporation(NYSE:CVX) is the anti-Exxon. More precisely
column171: Chevron is everything Exxon Mobil is accused of being
column172: and a little bit more.Chevron is a more aggressive polluter - and a more aggressive litigant against paying for pollution - than Exxon Mobil. Chevron is also less committed to downstream retail
column173: thus more dependent on crude prices
column174: than Exxon Mobil.CVX also is a bit more generous
column175: with its dividend near 4% to current buyers. But should you be one?Personally
column176: I don't think so. Chevron lost money for three of the last four quarters
column177: making that dividend harder to justify. Its debt-to-assets ratio has been rising faster than Exxon Mobil's
column179: its operating cash flow had been falling steadily.Things are getting worse for Chevron
column180: even while they seem to be getting better for Exxon Mobil. CVX missed badly on optimistic estimates for its December quarter
column181: with a profit of 22 cents per share on revenue of $31.5 billion. Analysts had been expecting a 65-cent profit. That's not a miss … that's a mile.Bulls expect Chevron to score big profits from a return to drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. I do not.Going back to Q4 earnings
column182: note that revenues did beat. But profits were down because profits from refining fell 65% year-over-year
column183: to $357 million. If the Gulf doesn't yield big profits
column184: if oil prices don't stay high
column186: that dividend - which was hiked a penny last fall to $1.08 per share - will be at serious risk.Income investors can't just look at yield. They need to look at earnings as well. If earnings don't match the dividend for long enough
column188: you're going to take some big losses.7 Straight-A Stocks to Build Your Portfolio AroundI think the risk of that happening to Chevron is bigger than that happening to Exxon Mobil.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #2
column189: Pfizer (PFE)Source:Kojach Via FlickrPFE Dividend Yield:4.1%Pfizer Inc.(NYSE:PFE) is a great dividend stock as far as yield is concerned. But can you trust it?But can you trust it? This is not just a question of whether the company can afford to pay shareholders out of earnings (which Pfizer usually can't). It's also a question of whether the company even wants torunas a dividend company.In November 2015
column190: Pfizer said no to that. It announced a $160 billion deal to merge withAllergan plc(NYSE:AGN)
column191: which was only paying 5 cents per share in dividends
column192: and to move its headquarters to Ireland for tax purposes. The hope was that the combined company would deliver fat capital gains to shareholders. A change in rules from the Treasury Department forced the two companies apart last April. If the deal were presented today
column193: it's likely the new administration would approve it.What investors are getting today is a company whose profit margins have been falling steadily for years
column194: as its biggest drugs (like Lipitor) come off-patent
column196: and with operating cash flow which
column198: still represents less than 10 cents for each dollar of equity.Pfizer
column200: looks like a very lazy company that may
column202: pull a rabbit out of its hat and become something that it is not
column203: which is a company you buy for capital gains. The company was expected to earn 50 cents per share but reported 47 cents.The question remains
column204: is Pfizer good for its dividend? Does management evenwantit to be a dividend stock? There are opportunities in this Dow dividend stock
column205: but also risks - the kind an income investor learns to avoid.Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February: #1
column206: Verizon Communications (VZ)Source:Via FlickrVZ Dividend Yield:4.7%The best yield among Dow dividend stocks
column208: is the 4.7% presently paid to shareholders ofVerizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ) - the former Baby Bell that has emerged as one of two duopolists in the mobile and Internet backbone businesses.Verizon is the very model of a stock you buy for income. Its performance usually matches that of the market
column209: and the dividend is regular. The company delivered 46 cents per share to shareholders at the bottom of the last recession
column210: and now delivers almost 58 cents.This means that when the stock becomes oversold
column212: which happened last November and in September 2015
column213: and which some sayis happening right now
column214: you buy. Then you hold and enjoy the yield.The latest bargain time comes on an earnings miss announced Jan. 24. Traders may have been disappointed
column215: but the $1.10 per share in income still covers the dividend almost twice over
column216: and Verizon remains committed to maintaining the dividend. Verizon is a cash flow monster
column217: delivering about $30 billion in operating cash flow each year. Its business model works.Verizon buys income-producing assets and then milks profit from them. That's why it bought the rest of its mobile arm
column219: payingVodafone Group PLC (ADR)(NASDAQ:VOD) $130 billion in 2014 and dramatically hiking its debt-to-assets ratio. That's why is said to be considering a tie-up withCharter Communications
column221: which recently boughtTime Warner Cable.The Charter interest comes as rivalAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) moves to buyTime Warner Inc.(NYSE:TWX) to get programming to fill its delivery systems
column222: which along with the mobile arm include wired Internet (sold under the name U-Verse) and DirecTv. Verizon's moves in the direction of content have been more modest
column223: buyingAOLand the operating assets ofYahoo! Inc.(NASDAQ:YHOO) for Internet advertising assets.But this is the model for an income stock. You buy assets you can make a profit on
column224: you extract that profit as aggressively as you reasonably can
column225: and you pay that income out to shareholders
column226: holding just enough so you can become an acquirer again.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsVZ is the very model of a high-yielding income stock.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column227: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column228: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The postThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for Februaryappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Cisco Snatches IPO Baby from the Arms of Wall Street;1/27/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();On January 24
column2: Cisco (CSCO)revealed they were buying a private company called AppDynamics for $3.7 billion. The funny thing is that the little guy already had a stock symbol picked out
column3: APPD
column4: for its scheduled IPO this week. Talk about a buzzer-beater.But Cisco is also viewed as paying a hefty premium for a software firm specializing in a niche called application performance management (APM). Why would they do that?According to Pacific Crest Securities
column5: ""AppDynamics is a natural fit for Cisco's portfolio
column6: in our view
column7: given its ability to monitor legacy applications and infrastructure and its growing presence in next-generation application deployments.""AppDynamics' software stack now allows Cisco's product portfolio to extend its insight across the network
column8: security and application layers. The acquisition broadens Cisco's software portfolio as Cisco attempts to diversify its revenue base with more subscription and recurring revenue.""Tech Titans Clash With War Chests of CashThis was precisely a theme that I discussed on the Zacks Ultimate webinar January 12: tech titans like Amazon (AMZN)
column9: Microsoft (MSFT)
column10: IBM
column11: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) ""battling for innovation"" with war chests of cash to scoop up ""off-the-shelf"" technology before the other guy.And MarketWatch reported in a story on January 25 that there is a trend of the smaller companies gladly accepting these buyouts to avoid the market volatility of the public markets. ThinkTwilio (TWLO)there. Here were a couple of interesting lines from the story by Caitlin Huston...""Just last week
column12: SimpliVity
column13: a software company
column14: took a big valuation cut after it agreed to be bought by Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) for $650 million in cash
column15: compared with a $1 billion private valuation.""Cisco and HPE show that large legacy tech companies are willing to swoop in to acquire startups
column16: but the wide range of potential outcomes could lead to startups trying to stay private another year
column17: said Max Wolff
column18: market strategist at 55 Capital Partners. The top-tier of unicorn companies
column19: such as SnapChat and Airbnb are not as affected
column20: he added.Stifel: Potential Takeout Candidates After APPD DealCourtesy of TheFly.com...Cisco's acquisition of AppDynamics is a sign that the wave of Software deal activity in 2016 has carried over into the new year
column21: Stifel analyst Brad Reback tells investors in a research note. He believes the deal bodes well for the small- and mid-cap names across his firm's coverage list

I show their chart in the webinar.And my latest research project is focused on Facebook advertising which grew 55% to $26.5 billion last year and will add another $10 billion this year.Facebook Ads are truly an economic phenomenon because they are actually expanding the pie that Google Adwords created with PPC (pay per click).In other words

column1: Cisco Gambles $3.7 Billion on Software;1/26/2017;"Image source: Cisco Systems.Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column2: the dominant provider of enterprise switches and   routers
column3: is still predominantly a hardware company. Just 29% of   total revenue during the latest quarter was recurring
column4: coming   from either software subscriptions or services.makeArticleAd();The software business
column5: which is spread across all of Cisco's   reportable segments
column6: is growing fast: deferred revenue from   recurring software and subscription businesses grew by 48% year   over year to $3.8 billion during the latest quarter. But hardware   is still the core of Cisco's business.Cisco has managed to maintain its dominance and its margins in   the switching and routing businesses despite major shifts in the   world of IT
column7: like the emergence of cloud computing and   software-defined networking. But neither business is growing   consistently. Software will be one of the key growth drivers for   Cisco going forward
column8: and the company hasn't been shy about making   acquisitions to push software revenue higher.A $3.7 billion bet on softwareOn Jan. 24
column9: Cisco announced that it had agreed to pay $3.7   billion in cash and assumed equity awards for privately held   AppDynamics
column10: a provider of a cloud applications and   business-monitoring platform. AppDynamics was just one day away   from going public
column11: and Cisco paid a hefty premium to scoop up the   company at the last second. AppDynamics' last private fundraising   round yielded a valuation of $1.9 billion
column12: and the high-end of   its IPO price range represented a market capitalization of just   $1.7 billion.""Applications have become the lifeblood of a company's   success
column13: said Cisco SVP Rowan Trollope. Cisco believes that   the acquisition will allow it to provide ""end to end visibility   and intelligence from the network through the application.""   AppDynamics will become a new software business unit within   Cisco's Internet of Things and applications business
column14: with the   deal expected to close during Cisco's fiscal third quarter.Because AppDynamics was so close to going public
column15: this is a   rare case where the financials of an acquired private company   have been publicly disclosed. Cisco isn't getting much revenue   for its $3.7 billion investment. AppDynamics has produced $158   million of revenue through the nine months ended Oct. 31
column16: up   about 55% year over year. Full-year revenue would be somewhere   around $230 million if that rate of growth holds. Cisco is paying   roughly 16 times sales.AppDynamics is also unprofitable
column17: producing a net loss of $134   million during the last fiscal year and $95 million through the   nine months ended Oct. 31. Big spending on sales and marketing
column18: a   common feature of fast-growing subscription software companies
column19: is the main culprit. Operating expenses are growing slower than   revenue
column20: a sign that things are moving in the right direction
column21: but this deal won't provide any boost to Cisco's bottom line.Not a fan of this dealAs a Cisco shareholder
column22: it's hard for me to get behind this   acquisition. Cisco's timing
column23: racing against the clock to close   the deal
column24: led to a price that was more than twice the expected   IPO price. Granted
column25: the stock may have surged following its   now-cancelled IPO. But this doesn't seem like a company that   Cisconeededto own
column26: price be damned.Cisco has always been acquisitive
column27: but many of its deals have   been smaller
column28: measured in the hundreds of millions of dollars.   Bigger recent deals include the $1.4 billion purchase of Jasper   Technologies in early 2016 and the $2.7 billion purchase of   Sourcefire in 2013. The deal for AppDynamics is bigger than both   of those
column29: and one of the largest Cisco has made in years.To be fair
column30: putting Cisco's resources behind AppDynamics could   turbocharge growth. But it will take an awful lot of growth to   justify the $3.7 billion price tag. I'm not convinced that this   deal is a good idea. If Cisco starts making a habit of overpaying   for start-ups valued in the billions of dollars
column31: shelling out   more than a dozen times sales
column32: I may have to reconsider my   investment in the company.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column35: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column36: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cisco Systems wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column2: Inc.CSCOannounced Tuesday that it is on track to acquire AppDynamics

column1: Bull of the Day: Broadcom (AVGO);1/26/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Seems it was only a month ago I writing aboutBroadcom (AVGO)as the Bull of the Day and explaining why I've been strongly recommending and trading the stock since 2014 from $70.And it's true. I did choose AVGO on December 22 when it was trading around $180. Here's how I described this powerhouse technology company in that report...3 Key SegmentsThough Broadcom is generally classified as a semiconductor designer and developer
column2: its solutions serve telecom and enterprise networking customers in the build-out of data centers and high-speed
column3: broadband communications. I can't say for sure ifAT&T(T)
column4: Cisco(CSCO)
column5: orAlphabet(GOOGL) are customers
column6: but I would be surprised if they weren't.Thus about half of Broadcom's sales come from the Wired Infrastructure segment which has been seeing steady double-digit growth as these big customers transition to the 100 Gigabit Ethernet protocol.Approximately 30% of Broadcom's revenues come from its Wireless Communications division which serves top-end mobile smart-device makers likeApple (AAPL)with radio frequency (RF) chips
column7: amplifiers
column8: and FBAR technology filters. Broadcom FBAR (Film Bulk Acoustic Resonator) filters are a form of bulk acoustic wave (BAW) filter that have superior performance with steeper rejection curves compared to surface acoustic wave (SAW) filters.The third major segment at Broadcom is Enterprise Storage
column9: which connects back with many customers from the Wired division and supplies just under 20% of revenues. The company's products enable the high-speed movement of digital data with a secure connection among multiple PCs
column10: servers and storage devices such as hard disk drives and solid state drives.While AVGO's Wireless business is ""dependent"" on Apple
column11: that's not exactly a bad problem to have. The coming next wave of 5G technology will keep both companies rolling in sales growth.And Broadcom's largest business
column12: the Wired segment
column13: is very busy meeting the demand of companies building high-speed
column14: broadband networks
column15: especially with the data-hogging loads of video and the storage requirements of the Internet of Things.I Have $250... Do I Hear $300?So what has changed in a month to make Broadcom the Bull of the Day again?Simply this: the stock took off over 10% to new highs in the past six sessions as a couple of analysts bolstered their view of this must-own tech ""arms dealer."" While I've been following fund managers into AVGO for nearly 3 years
column16: the growth story is not over.On January 18
column17: RBC Capital analyst Amit Daryanani reiterated his Top Pick rating on AVGO shares and raised his view of the company's long term earnings potential to $17 EPS on the heels of the acquisition of Brocade (BRCD). Here's what he had to say...""Our analysis suggests the underlying EPS power of AVGO increases materially post BRCD (especially assuming they raise $1.5-2.0B from networking & real estate sales). We think AVGO could achieve >$17.00 of EPS by FY19 (prior $16) and the stock should work in an upside scenario to $250+.""Oddly
column18: the analyst did not raise his existing price target from $200.So we'll leave that to a bolder fan of the company...On January 24
column19: Morgan Stanley analyst Craig Hettenback raised his price target on Broadcom to $240 from $210
column20: and obviously reiterated his Overweight rating. Here's the MS view...""Increasing our PT to $240 from $210 and highlighting a bull case valuation of $300. Our PT is based on a 15X P/E on CY18 EPS
column21: representing a turn increase from the current multiple but still a conservative 20% discount to the high end Semiconductor peers and 15% below the market. AVGO's multiple has been flat (100% of stock appreciation has been driven by growth in EPS) compared to a roughly 2x turn increase in semiconductor stocks
column22: with investors unwilling to pay up for acquired growth.""However
column23: we now have increased conviction that clearer focus on its outperforming core business
column24: materially higher cash returns and ongoing margin expansion will drive a re-rating over the next 6-12 months.""The combination of Avago and Broadcom is unmatched in Networking (40% sales) in our view
column25: which has positive implications for both growth (share gains) and profitability. We also think the company remains well positioned in RF to exploit the next growth driver of carrier aggregation
column26: leveraging its leadership in premium filters and multiplexers.""The AVGO CampaignAnd there you have an update on the continuing saga that I call ""The AVGO Campaign."" It tells you what works and makes you money in a bull market: finding earnings momentum winners that you know institutions will continue to buy until the cycle ends.Consider AVGO your ""playbook stock"" for how to use the Zacks Rank to swing trade fundamentally-strong companies quarter after quarter.You can find out more by following me in myTAZR Traderservice.Zacks' best stocks under $10As a Zacks Rank #1 Strong Buy

column1: Tech Stock Roundup: AAPL-QCOM Deal
column2: FB's Zuckerberg Testifies;1/25/2017;"With the 45thPresident of the United States vowing to bring back jobs to the country
column3: teach China a lesson and institute large-scale tax reform
column4: there has been a great deal of uncertainty surrounding technology stocks. To make matters worse
column5: President Trump has an axe to grind with AmazonAMZNand AppleAAPLwhile most AlphabetGOOGLexecutives have openly supported the democrats going into the elections.So companies are now making nice with the President like Tesla's Elon Musk
column6: who has changed tunes and is now tweeting his support. It's been reported that Google's Schmidt has also found reasons to visit the President. Executives that have supported Trump from the start are better off: some speculate that Zuckerberg is considering politics while ex-MicrosoftMSFTand GM employee Chris Liddell is moving to the White House as assistant to the President and director of strategic initiatives. Oracle CEO Safra Catz joined the executive committee of Trump's presidential transition team in December.Then there's Cramer
column7: promising us that the post inauguration sell-off won't last and that it's actually an opportunity to buy stocks.Amidst all the excitement surrounding the swearing in
column8: the FTC sued QualcommQCOMfor anti-competitive practices while Mark Zuckerberg took the stand to defend Facebook'sFBpurchase of Oculus. So let's dig in.Apple Forced to Use Qualcomm ChipsFollowing similar lawsuits
column9: huge fines ($1 billion in China and $890 million in Korea) and anticompetitive investigations in Taiwan and the EU
column10: the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has sued Qualcomm for ""de facto exclusive deals that were as effective as express purchase requirements and that effectively foreclosed Qualcomm's competitors from gaining processor business at Apple.""The FTC alleges that Qualcomm allowed Apple billions in discounts for exclusively using its chips and not using the competing 4G Wi-Max standard that Intel was pushing. This agreement
column11: running from 2011 to 2016
column12: ultimately killed WiMax. Apple wasted no time in sourcing from Intel after the expiry of the agreement in Sep 2016.Another point in contention is Qualcomm's practice of limiting access to its cellular chips and then hiking royalty payments
column13: amounting to ""a tax on the manufacturers' use of baseband processors manufactured by Qualcomm's competitors."" The FTC filed the lawsuit after a 2-1 vote. Qualcomm has of course denied the charges while Apple chose not to comment.Following the FTC lawsuit
column14: Apple filed one of its own against Qualcomm for a billion dollars. The amount is what Apple alleges that Qualcomm is witholding for rebates. Like the FTC says
column15: the deal was to keep Qualcomm chips in Apple products and is a fair indication that Qualcomm finally has some real competition.Mark Zuckerberg TestifiesFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg took the stand last week to deny charges that Facebook was aware of the violation of any employee agreement between Occulus head John Carmack and its former employer id Software
column16: a unit of ZeniMax
column17: the plaintiff in this case. He also denied that the technology developed by the startup Occulus and its founder Palmer Luckey was based on copyrighted technology belonging to ZeniMax.Carmack previously testified that he copied files from ZeniMax before moving to Occulus but did not use the information in Occulus and the terms of his employment allowed him to get involved with Occulus even while in ZeniMax employ. But the thing that could cost Facebook at this point is ZeniMax lawyer Toni Sammi's question: ""So your plan for a $2-point-something billion deal was to begin legal diligence on Friday
column18: and sign the deal on Monday
column19: over a weekend
column20: right?"" to which Zuckerberg said
column21: ""Yeah.""CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+2.09%+21.62%FB+0.33%+6.42%YHOO-0.14%+10.80%GOOGL-0.16%+9.94%MSFT+0.21%+16.26%INTC+0.63%+5.38%CSCO+0.20%+0.64%AMZN-0.65%+9.82%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateIndia Considering Apple Case: It's hard to tell just how badly India wants Apple to manufacture in the country. But if government officials agree to Apple's demands
column22: it would indicate that they want it bad. Because Apple has asked for just about every concession possible
column23: ranging from reduction in import duties on smartphones
column24: customs duty exemption on manufacturing equipment and raw materials
column25: a ""less-intrusive"" customs procedure to be completed in 30 minutes
column26: the right to import and refurbish iPhones that are more than 3 years old so they can be exported
column27: and so forth.Apple is trying to convince government officials that Indian made iPhones won't be competitive unless they give in to these demands even as its manufacturing costs in China are on the rise. But Asian phone makers are already manufacturing in the country with no such concessions
column28: so the regulations themselves may need to be altered and relaxed to accommodate not just Apple but also other manufacturers. This could take time.On a positive note
column29: Reuters reports that Information Technology Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has mentioned the setting up of a government panel headed by the cabinet secretary that would now clear investment proposals in the electronics sector above $1 billion
column30: instead of them going through multiple government departments.Microsoft Executive Joins Baidu: Baidu has appointed Qi Lu as its Chief Operating Officer and Group Head as it turns focus to artificial intelligence as the next growth driver. The company was mixed up in a scandal involving medical ads that led to stricter government regulations and consequently hit its revenues.Lu left Microsoft last year on health concerns but was in charge of its search business and also part of the team involved in architecting its artificial intelligence and bots technology. He holds more than 40 U.S. patents.Google Ad Auctions Are Suspect: The Wall Street Journal has independently confirmed that ads for Google products and the products of its sister companies usually find the top spot on the search engine results page. On checking 25K search results
column31: it found that Google products occupied the top spot 91% of the time and the top two spots 43% of the time.Google has said that this is because it is also a buyer of ads
column32: so its position comes from paying a higher price. It also says that this doesn't raise prices because when others bid for the price
column33: it's as if Google isn't bidding. Bottom line: other advertisers lose the top spot no matter what they bid for it. Google reportedly removed its ads in a number of cases when confronted with the data last December.Amazon
column34: Apple End Audiobook Exclusivity Deal: Apple and Amazon have decided to end the deal initiated back in 2008
column35: according to which Amazon subsidiary Audible became the exclusive supplier of audiobooks to Apple and was barred from selling to any other party. The agreement was actually serving no one because the market for audiobooks has advanced since then and it's now in the interest of both parties to be able to source from others and in Audible's case
column36: to also be able to sell on other platforms. Nonetheless
column37: it was preceded by regulatory scrutiny of the deal by German and EU competition authorities that felt it was inflating prices.Pandora Shares Gain: Pandora preannounced fourth-quarter results that it said exceeded its revenue and EBITDA targets. This came as a relief because it has been lowering expectations the last two quarters indicating continuing bad news. Moreover
column38: Pandora also said that the $5-a-month Pandora Plus garnered 365K new subscribers in the quarter and the Pandora Premium service remained on track to launch later this quarter. It also expects to lay off around 7% of the U.S. workforce
column39: which will further boost margins.Legal/RegulatoryCisco-Arista Developments: The U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agency has expressed concern that its earlier decision to lift the ban on Arista switches may have been incorrect. Following conversations with CiscoCSCO
column40: the CBP therefore intends to reinstate the ban. Arista has said that it will respond to Cisco points and re-engage with the CBP.In the meantime
column41: U.S.-manufactured switches will have to make do
column42: which can result in supply glitches and pressure on its gross margin. On Dec 2
column43: the ITC judge ruled that Arista patents infringe on Cisco's and Arista has subsequently produced workaround while denying the charges. A full commission review of the judge's decision will be completed by Apr 9.New Technology/ProductsGoogle to Launch Android One Phones In U.S.: Google's high-end Pixel phones are mostly unavailable
column44: but it's already gearing up to launch the low-end ($200-$300) Android One devices in the country by the middle of the year. The goal seems to be to build brand value and familiarize people with the Android ecosystem.Android One was first launched in India and later in other countries including Japan and then Europe. It is a system under which Google agrees beforehand with handset manufacturers to push out Android updates as soon as they are available so the experience is true to the latest iteration of the software.M&A and CollaborationsHPE Buying Simplivity: Hewlett Packard Enterprise is dishing out $650 million to buy SimpliVity
column45: the second largest provider of hyperconvergence software (after Nutanix which has over 50% market share). The company describes a hyperconverged system as one that integrates compute
column46: storage and networking into a pre-configured system
column47: managed by a user-friendly software platform that doesn't require extensive IT staff for set up and management.Within a couple of months after the deal closes
column48: HPE will offer a range of integrated HPE SimpliVity hyperconverged systems based on HPE ProLiant Servers. The acquisition significantly strengthens its position in the space where competitors like Cisco and Dell/EMC base their hyperconvergence solutions on market leader Nutanix or Simplivity software. HPE will initially support current SimpliVity customers.Cisco
column49: Ericsson Join Forces in Australia: The collaboration between Ericsson and Cisco on telecom cloud infrastructure has yielded a major customer in Vodafone Hutchison Australia (VHA). The companies will virtualize Vodafone's infrastructure
column50: enabling it to improve customer service and user experience while increasing network agility
column51: reducing opex and capex
column52: and speeding up the deployment of services. The partnership has reportedly generated 60 new deals and is expected to generate revenue of a billion dollars to each partner by 2018.Microsoft Acquires Simplygon: Microsoft has acquired 3D data optimization specialist Simplygon of Sweden for an undisclosed sum. This is intended to play an important role in developing its 3D For Everyone strategy
column53: which is part of the Windows 10 Creators Update. 3D optimization is used by game developers and others to facilitate 3D content creation.Simplygon also does more than this: it has already started optimizing content for AR and VR technology
column54: including for Microsoft's Hololens. Microsoft believes that by making the technology a part of its creators update
column55: users will be empowered to capture
column56: create and share 3D content thus augmenting their productivity
column57: collaboration and creativity.Google Buys Twitter Developers Platform: Google has acquired Fabric
column58: which is based on Crashlytics technology (crash analytics
column59: app feedback and real-time analytics) that Twitter acquired back in 2013. Google hasn't said how much it's paying for Fabric
column60: but has said that it will be a part of its cloud based mobile software effort called Firebase that was itself acquired in 2014. Firebase offers mobile app developers tools to build and monitor their apps
column61: so any attempt to build its capabilities should help the company attract developers.Alibaba Has Long-term Digital Deal: Alibaba and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) signed a deal
column62: according to which Alibaba will be responsible for the IOC's digital presence through its cloud platform. The deal makes Alibaba the digital sponsor of the Olympics in cloud services

column1: Ignore Palo Alto Networks Inc: Here Are 3 Better Stocks;1/25/2017;"Palo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) kicked off the year with a bang

column1: Cisco Acquires AppDynamics: What It Means For CSCO;1/25/2017;"Cisco (Shutterstock photo)Cisco (CSCO) made its first merger and acquisition for 2017
column2: with its intent to acquire AppDynamics
column3: a leading privately held application intelligence software platform. Cisco rushed to acquire AppDynamics just before the tech unicorn’s IPO. At $3.7 billion
column4: Cisco has picked AppDynamics for twice its valuation price at $1.9 billion (at the time of its fundraising)
column5: making this its largest acquisition in recent times.Acquisitions are integral to the growth strategy for companies to drive more recurring revenue streams by enabling new market access
column6: bringing in mature products and solutions
column7: business models
column8: as well as technology and talent.makeArticleAd();The acquisition comes as a part of Cisco’s broadercommitment“to capitalize on market transitions as sources of future opportunities as part of the continued transformation of its business.” Cisco believes that the market transition is happening at a great speed in the IT space and thus has been working to enhance its capabilities in the fast-emerging areas of security
column9: collaboration
column10: services
column11: the Internet of Things (IoT)
column12: cloud computing
column13: software
column14: and silicon.Cisco
column15: an active player in the acquisition market
column16: has acquired 44 companies in the past five-years.Why AppDynamics?Software apps
column17: application software
column18: or simply apps
column19: have become increasingly important for a company's success. Almost all businesses are faced with immense pressure to accelerate innovation while ensuring that those apps run and perform perfectly. Customers expect easy-to-use apps
column20: but complexities at the company’s end are on the rise and all this requires a huge amount of IT back-end support.To ensure competitiveness with the increasingly demanding customers and stiffer competition
column21: organizations cannot deploy legacy IT operations management products to monitor and manage their software applications and underlying IT infrastructures. Thus
column22: Application Performance Monitoring (APM) companies have emerged as a preferred choice for enterprises to do the task.GartnerdefinesAPM “as one or more software and hardware components that facilitate monitoring to meet five main functional dimensions: end-user experience monitoring
column23: runtime application architecture discovery modeling and display
column24: user-defined transaction profiling
column25: component deep-dive monitoring in application context
column26: and analytics.”AppDynamics is among the major vendors of the global APM market and offers an innovative
column27: enterprise-grade app intelligence software platform. AppDynamics has approximately 2
column28: 000customersall over the world
column29: including leading companies such:TESCONasdaqExpediaOverstock.comNikeReserve Bank of New ZealandUBSDIRECTVExactTargetProgressiveThe company has grown rapidly
column30: reflected by the rise in its revenue which was reported at $23.6 million
column31: $81.9 million and $150.6 million during FY14
column32: FY15 and FY16 (ended January of each year) respectively.With Cisco and AppDynamics coming together
column33: enterprises can expect actionable insight not just into apps but across their technological stack that can be applied to improve business performance and customer experiences while generating revenue opportunities.David Wadhwani
column34: CEO of AppDynamics
column35: will continue to lead the company as a new software business unit under Rowan Trollope
column36: Cisco's senior vice president and general manager of its IoT and Applications business. The acquisition is expected to close in Cisco’s third quarter of fiscal year 2017.With the complementary business AppDynamics brings to Cisco
column37: the acquisition should result in a smooth integration and a boost to the revenue stream. Cisco’s shares are up 36.79% over the past one-year."

column1: Juniper Earnings Preview: Sluggish Demand For Routing
column2: Security Products To Impact Results;1/24/2017;"Juniper Networks(JNPR) is scheduled to announce its Q4 and full year results on Thursday
column3: January 26. The networking giant has reported 2% revenue growth through the first three quarters of the year to $3.6 billion. Growth was largely driven by the services segment
column4: with combined product sales stagnating.Low product sales have led to discounted selling prices
column5: which ultimately drove down product margins. This trend has continued over the last few years
column6: with the adjusted gross margin for the product divisions combined falling from 67.6% in 2011 to around 65.3% in 2015. This has further compressed to 62.4% through the first three quarters of 2016. Additionally
column7: Juniper's operating expenses in the same period increased by around 3% to $1.64 billion as shown below. Resulting earnings per share were down by around 5% over the comparable prior year period to $1.04.makeArticleAd();Guidance For Q4Juniper's management expects the trend from the first three quarters of the year to continue through the December quarter as well. Net revenues could grow at a steady 2% to $1.35 billion
column8: with the most revenue growth coming from switching product sales and the services division. Gross margin could compress by around 80 basis points to around 63% as shown below. Management targets a long-term gross margin of around 64% in the coming quarters
column9: which can be achieved by higher sales volumes and a high attach rate of customers in the services segment.In an attempt to improve profitability and earnings per share
column10: management mentioned that the company aims to improve its cost structure in coming quarters. For December quarter
column11: operating expenses are expected to fall by 9% y-o-y to around $510 million. If the company can successfully reduce operating expenses in the fourth quarter
column12: Juniper's full year EPS could be around 3% higher than 2015 levels at $1.66 per share.Performance Across Product LinesJuniper has struggled in the network security domain with a double digit revenue decline over the last few years. For the first three quarters of the year
column13: network security revenues were down 26% y-o-y to $237 million. In the same period
column14: rival networking company Cisco (CSCO) reported 4% y-o-y growth in network security revenues to $1.6 billion. (Read:Cisco's 2016 In Review: Higher Profits Despite Revenue Slowdown)Similarly
column15: Juniper's core routing revenues have witnessed limited growth over the last few years with a CAGR of 1% from 2011 through 2015. This trend continued in 2016 with revenues falling by 1% through the first three quarters of the year to $1.7 billion.On the other hand
column16: Juniper's switching segment has performed well this year
column17: with revenues rising by 9% y-o-y to $607 million through the first thee quarters of the year. The company has witnessed strong demand for its new QFX product line from various cloud providers
column18: telecom customers
column19: cable providers and Federal government agencies. In the most recent quarter
column20: the company reported a 50% annual increase in revenues generated by sales of the QFX switch product line.In the same period
column21: theservices segment has driven much of the top line growthfor the company
column22: with revenues increasing by 12% y-o-y to just under $1.1 billion. In addition to revenue growth
column23: the services segment has become more profitable for the company while falling hardware prices have compressed the product segment's margins. Juniper's services gross margin has improved by almost 2 percentage points to 62.1% through the first three quarters of the year due to a higher rate of maintenance contract renewals and a higher proportion of services-based networking solutions on offer. Despite an improvement in services gross margin
column24: the company-wide gross margin was down by almost a percentage point to 62.3% through the first three quarters of the year. While the services segment should continue to help drive growth
column25: the slowdown in the product division is likely to weigh on profits.We have a $25 price estimate for Juniper
column26: which is around 10% lower than the current market price. Juniper's stock price has fluctuated between $22 and $32 this year.See Full Analysis For Juniper HereView Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis Research"

column18: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column19: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column20: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column21: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column22: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows »"

column1: Donald Trump Inauguration: Stocks To Buy
column2: Sell For The Next Four Years;1/20/2017;"Donald Trump (Shutterstock photo)Donald Trump has been sworn in as the 45th president of the United States. The President-elect
column3: who pledged to “Make America great again
column4: ” promised plenty of things he would do regarding his first day in office. From repealing and replacing Obamacare to renegotiating NAFTA and beginning the construction of the wall on the Mexican border.We won’t know for certain which of Trump’s policies will take priority or how they will be enforced. But what we do know is that for Trump to make good on his promises to bring back jobs
column5: grow GDP and strengthen industry
column6: he needs businesses to lead
column7: innovate and hire workers. For that to happen
column8: businesses leaders need to know their government is on their side. To that end
column9: here are some names to own for the next four years (at least) as Trump’s policies take shape.makeArticleAd();Lower Corporate TaxesTrump’s promise to lower corporate taxes can have a boosting effect on the tech sector
column10: which has an estimated $1.4 trillion stashed in overseas tax havens. These include some America's largest corporations such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT)
column11: which could face a huge tax hit if they bring that cash home. Not only has Trump promised to lower the business tax rate from 35% to 15%
column12: he pledged to eliminate the corporate alternative minimum tax.Beyond lowering the tax rate
column13: it would hardly shock anyone if Trump — given his pro-business stance — were to enact a tax holiday at some point during his presidency. Companies like Cisco (CSCO)
column14: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) would thrive. They would no longer need to borrow cheap cash to fund their operations. Likewise
column15: a better capitalized Tesla (TSLA) can accelerate the building of its Gigafactory
column16: helping it achieve not only higher profit margins
column17: but also higher vehicle production. In the process
column18: Tesla would ignite the state of Nevada as an innovative hub
column19: while mass-producing producing emission-free vehicles at affordable prices.“Repeal and Replace”The Affordable Care Act
column20: a.k.a Obamacare was designed to — among other things — “insure the un-insurable.” Notably
column21: to provide insurance coverage to people with pre-existing conditions who were blocked under the then-existing rules. Depending on what side of the aisle you’re on
column22: Obamacare either did its job or was a “complete disaster
column23: ” according to Trump. Still
column24: whether Obamacare is entirely dismantled or parts of it is kept
column25: you don’t have to look too far beyond UnitedHealth (UNH) to find a stock can will thrive.UnitedHealth has worked aggressively to exit the Affordable Care exchanges
column26: which reduces its  exposure to any changes Trump might make. What’s more
column27: added from being the nation's largest health insurer
column28: UnitedHealth owns Optum
column29: which provides pharmacy benefit management services. Last week
column30: not only did the company beat top- and bottom-line estimates
column31: UnitedHealth raised its fiscal 2017 financial outlook
column32: suggesting it is ready for whatever Trump decides to do.Not every company will be as lucky. Conversely
column33: companies such HCA Holdings (HCA) and Universal Health Services (UHS) that prospered under Obamacare may suffer. As will government health care providers such as Centene Corporation (CNC) and Molina Healthcare
column34: Inc. (MOH).Scale Back Dodd-FrankCutting down strict regulations imposed on financial institutions has been another policy Trump has proposed. After all
column35: how can he achieve economic growth and strengthen small business if banks aren't lending money — something banks collectively struggled to do under Dodd-Frank. But as evidenced by the strong earnings results released so far from the likes of Bank of America (BAC)
column36: JPMorgan Chase (JPM)
column37: Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS)
column38: financials are once again the sector to bank on.Written to strengthen consumer protection and create tougher rules on excessive risk-taking
column39: the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act has been cited by bank executives as a prohibiter of growth. ""There's many aspects of it that we've got to kill
column40: said Steven Mnuchin
column41: Trump's pick for Treasury secretary. Mnuchin former partner at Goldman Sachs
column42: called Dodd-Frank ""the number one priority on the regulatory side.”To that end
column43: I would be surprised if Trump doesn’t take to “repeal and replace” Dodd-Frank in his first 100 days in office. Combined with the prospect of higher interest rates
column44: lower taxes it’s tough to ignore the potential upside a bank like Morgan Stanley (MS) can provide. It’s not just the big banks that will prosper
column45: however. Keep an eye on super regionals like Comerica (CMA)
column46: US Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial (PNC)
column47: which Trump has made great again."

column5: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsU.S. equities are drifting lower again on Thursday

column7: includingFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT)
column8: Qualcomm
column9: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) andCisco Systems
column10: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO).Much of the post-election dynamic has already reversed amid   profit taking
column11: nervousness about the incoming Trump   administration
column12: and rate hike concerns. Bonds are strengthening
column13: safe havens like gold are perking up
column14: and bank stocks - the   vanguard of the historic rally of the last few months - have   rolled over amid tepid earnings results.makeAd('4'
column16: 'mktsnews'
column17: 'vanguard'
column19: '');But now
column20: a number of familiar technology-related stocks are   rolling over too. Here are three that are on the slide:Fitbit Inc (FIT)Shares of wearables maker FIT look set for a new drawdown out   of a three-month consolidation range. The $7-a-share level looks   vulnerable here - representing new record lows and a crushing   loss from the high of $52-a-share set back in the summer of 2015   amid red-hot hype for wearables.Fitbit was downgraded on Dec. 8 by analysts at Deutsche   Bank on weakness in the wearables market as interest by consumers   wanes.International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)       Q4 Beat Isn't EnoughFitbit will next report results on Feb. 22 after the   close. Analysts are looking for earnings of 17 cents per share on   revenues of $735 million.Cisco Systems
column21: Inc. (CSCO)CSCO stock is drifting lower
column22: threatening to break out of   a very tight two-month consolidation range that has capped a   five-month descent from the September high.Analysts at Stifel have been lukewarm on the stock

Analysts are looking for earnings of 56 cents per   share on revenues of $11.6 billion.Qualcomm
column24: Inc. (QCOM)QCOM shares have been hit have the past week after government   regulatorsfiled antitrust chargesthat the company maintained a monopoly in cell phone   semiconductors. The company has fired back that it will   ""vigorously contest"" the charges since they are
column25: in their   opinion
column26: based on ""flawed legal theory."" But investors are   worried these charges will undermine the company's lucrative   licensing revenue stream - especially since the lawsuit mirrors   similar charges faced overseas.Qualcomm will next report results on Jan. 25 after the close.   Analysts are looking for earnings of $1.18 per share on revenues   of $6.1 billion.Anthony Mirhaydari is founder of theEdgeandEdge Proinvestment advisory newsletters. column1: Why Arista Networks
column2: Progress Software
column3: and Regions Financial Slumped Today;1/17/2017;"The stock market lost ground on Tuesday
column4: with the Dow Jones   Industrials falling nearly 60 points and the S&P and Nasdaq   posting similar declines. Investors are waiting anxiously to see   whether anticipated new policies that President-elect Donald   Trump has previously announced will actually become law in the   near future
column5: and others are nervous that potential political   turmoil could hamstring the new administration's early efforts on   some fronts. Moreover
column6: some individual companies had bad news   that contributed to a poor day for the market
column7: andArista Networks(NYSE: ANET)
column8: Progress Software(NASDAQ: PRGS)
column9: andRegions Financial(NYSE: RF) were among the biggest decliners of the day. Below
column10: we'll look more closely at these stocks to tell you why they did   so poorly.Image source: Arista Networks.Arista gets bad news from a key court caseArista Networks fell 12% after an adverse decision by the U.S.   Customs and Border Protection agency. U.S. Customs said on Friday   that it had granted a revocation request fromCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column11: with the effect of undoing a judgment back in   November that had allowed Arista to continue importing products   from abroad. Arista will still be able to fulfill U.S. orders   from domestic manufacturers of its products
column12: but others fear the   decision could eventually create a supply bottleneck that could   lead to customer discontent. Arista has said that it will fight   the decision by responding to Cisco's allegations
column13: but the only   thing that's fairly certain is that the dispute is likely to last   well into the future.makeArticleAd();Progress reports a lossProgress Software dropped 14% in the wake of its fiscal   fourth-quarter earnings report late Monday. The application   development specialist said it saw total revenue jump 4% on   strength in software licenses
column14: but a substantial $92 million   goodwill impairment charge sent Progress to a $73.8 million loss
column15: working out to $1.52 per share. On an adjusted basis
column16: earnings of   $0.62 per share were better than the consensus forecast
column17: but   Progress' guidance for revenue of $387 million to $395 million   and adjusted earnings of $1.64 to $1.69 per share were below what   investors had hoped to see. Progress hopes that its new strategic   plan will generate long-term growth
column18: using measures such as a   streamlined operating approach
column19: a new product strategy for   development
column20: and more efficient use of resources. Yet investors   remain concerned that strong competition in the industry could   weigh on Progress Software going forward.Regions gives back some gainsFinally
column21: Regions Financial declined 6%. The regional bank has   performed extremely well recently
column22: having posted gains of nearly   40% following the November election. Investors have gotten more   optimistic about regional banks in general
column23: and rising interest   rates could lead to steeper yield curves that would be beneficial   for Regions Financial and its peers. Yet shareholders seemed   content to give back a small portion of those gains
column24: given   uncertainty about whether the best-case scenario for the bank   will actually play out. Even with today's loss
column25: Regions has seen   its stock climb more than 70% over the past year
column26: and favorable   economic conditions could create even more growth in the   future.10 stocks we like better than Arista NetworksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Arista Networks
column2: Inc. Stock Plunged Today;1/17/2017;"IMAGE SOURCE: ARISTA NETWORKS
column3: INC.What happenedShares ofArista Networks Inc.(NYSE: ANET) fell 12% on Tuesday on the heels of a negative court   ruling in its ongoing patent infringement case withCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) .makeArticleAd();So whatLate Friday
column4: the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agencyrevokedits November ruling thatredesigned productsfrom Arista Networks don't infringe a key patent owned by   Cisco.""The revocation covers all Arista products
column5: stated Mark   Chandler
column6: Senior VP
column7: General Counsel and Secretary of Cisco.   ""This means that Arista has lost the authorization to import or   continue selling its products in the U.S.
column8: or to import   components to build those products.""Of course
column9: Arista will almost certainly appeal the decision.   But Wall Street analysts aren't sure exactly what kind of impact   this may have to the business over the near term.According toBarron'stoday
column10: for example
column11: Barclays' Mark Moskowitz
column12: for example
column13: ""[I]t is important to highlight   that even with the updated CBP ruling
column14: Arista can continue to   fulfill orders through domestic manufacturing sources with   products that contain work-arounds. [...] Reason being
column15: the   company did not shift its manufacturing back toward international   manufacturers after the initial ruling
column16: in an effort to hedge   against an unfavorable ruling in the 945 investigation.""Meanwhile
column17: MKM Partner's Michael Genovese simultaneously   reduced his price target on shares from $95 to $84
column18: citing   reduced profit margin expectations even as he believes Arista   will likely continue to deliver industry-leading growth.Now whatIt's obvious this patent battle isn't over yet. But investors   will need to wait for more color on the situation when Arista   releases fiscal Q4 2016 results next month
column19: assuming the company   doesn't issue an informational press release before then. In the   meantime
column20: given this negative development and caution from Wall   Street

column1: The 6 Biggest Risks to Twilio Inc. Stock;1/17/2017;"Twilio(NYSE: TWLO) has taken investors on a gut-churning roller-coaster   ride since its IPO last June. The company
column2: which integrates calls   and SMS messages into apps with a cloud platform
column3: saw its shares   surge from an IPO price of $15 to nearly $70 before pulling back   to the high $20s on concernsabout its valuation.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();But is Twilio now a worthy rebound play after that rout? Let's   take a closer look at the six biggest risks facing the company   (as outlined in its SEC filings) to find out.1. Its dependence on FacebookTwilio is heavily dependent onFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) . Facebook's WhatsApp generated 10% of Twilio's   revenues in the first nine months of fiscal 2016. That represents   a decline from 17% in 2015
column4: but Facebook recently added Twilio's   services to Messenger
column5: which should increase its weight on   Twilio's top line again.To make matters worse
column6: Facebook is a ""Variable Customer   Account"" which has ""never entered into  12-month minimum   revenue contracts with Twilio."" This means that Facebook can drop   Twilio's services at any time
column7: and it isn't obligated to pay   Twilio a certain amount of guaranteed revenue.2. Its dependence on AmazonTwilio's cloud infrastructure is outsourced toAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS (Amazon Web Services). This means that an   outage at  AWS
column8: which happened several times in recent   years
column9: would knock all of Twilio's in-app phone and SMS services   offline -- which would be devastating for top customers like   WhatsApp
column10: Uber
column11: and Airbnb.Amazon could also emerge as a potential rival to Twilio if it   develops similar call and message processing services for AWS.   AWS' superior scale would then enable it to offer those services   at lower prices and render Twilio obsolete. But Amazon was an   early investor in Twilio
column12: and it uses its platform to deliver SMS   messages for AWS -- so competing against Twilio would be    counterproductive.3. Its dependence on network service providersAs a middleman between network service providers and mobile   apps
column13: Twilio is highly vulnerable to service providers hiking   their prices. Twilio admits in its latest 10-Q filing that ""the   fees that we are charged by network service providers may change   daily or weekly
column14: while we do not typically change our customers'   pricing as rapidly.""Twilio also warns that ""many of these network service   providers do not have long-term committed contracts with us
column15: and   may terminate their agreements with us without notice or   restriction."" This means that if the carriers decide to launch   their own cloud platforms for integrating calls and SMS messages   with apps
column16: they could cut Twilio out of the loop and gut its core   business.4. Potential competition from CiscoTwilio also admits that legacy on-premise network equipment   vendors likeCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) could bundle Twilio-like services into their   networking hardware bundles for service providers. Doing so could   strengthen Cisco's service provider revenue
column17: which dipped 2%   annually last  quarter.Integrating more cloud-based services would widen Cisco's moat   against rivals in the software-defined networking market while   pivoting its core business away from itsslower-growthrouters and switches -- but it could be devastating for   Twilio.5. Its dependence on growth abroadTwilio generated 15% of its revenue from international markets   in the first nine months of 2016. That's up from 14% in 2015 and   12% in 2014. Therefore
column18: Twilio notes that it's been expanding its   overseas sales team
column19: but that its experience in selling products   in non-U.S. markets was ""limited.""Twilio also warns that the no-stack
column20: developer-first model   that generated such explosive growth in the U.S. might not gain   ""the same traction outside the United States."" Moreover
column21: carriers   might not be as agreeable
column22: similar platforms might emerge in   different countries
column23: and developers might prefer to develop their   own call and SMS integration services from scratch. A   consistently strong dollar could also gobble up the company's   profits abroad.6. Its lack of profitabilityTwilio is still unprofitable by both GAAP (generally accepted   accounting principles) and non-GAAP (adjusted) metrics
column24: and will   likely remain so for the foreseeable future. The company's   expenses will likely rise as it spending on sales teams to   acquire new customers and expand overseas goes up
column25: and margins   could be pressured by competition from bigger rivals. This means   that Twilio's cash position will keep declining -- which could   lead to yet another share-diluting stock offering.The key takeawayI personally own a small position in Twilio
column26: but I believe   that it will remain volatile this year due to the aforementioned   risks. However
column27: if investors are willing to ride out that   volatility and Twilio maintains its ""best in breed"" reputation in   call and SMS integration
column28: they could be well rewarded over the   next few years.10 stocks we like better than Twilio Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
