column1: 3 High-Yield Dividend Stocks You Don't Have to Babysit;1/13/2017;"With interest rates set to rise this year
column2: many dividend   investors are likely worried that their stocks will slip as bond   yields become more attractive. While somedividend   stockswillinevitably decline
column3: investors can still find some low-risk income plays that have   high yields and cheap valuations. Let's take a look at three such   stocks --AT&T(NYSE: T)
column4: Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column5: andReynolds American(NYSE: RAI) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();TheDividend Aristocrat: AT&TAT&T's forward yield of 4.8% is much higher than the   S&P 500's 2.1% yield
column6: and it's comfortably supported by a   payout ratio of 81%. It spent 72% of its free cash flow over the   past 12 months on dividends. AT&T has hiked its dividend   annually for over three decades
column7: surpassing the 25-year threshold   for becoming a Dividend Aristocrat.In addition to being a rock-solid income play
column8: AT&T is   becoming a growth play again with its acquisition of DirecTV and   proposed takeover ofTime Warner. Bundling its pay TV
column9: wireless
column10: and broadband internet services   together gives the telco gianttremendous leveragein delivering media content across multiple platforms --   especially if it excludes that content from data charges across   its own networks.Analysts expect AT&T's revenue and  earnings to rise   12% and 5%
column11: respectively
column12: this year. The stock already rallied   22% over the past 12 months
column13: but it remains surprisingly cheap at   17 times earnings -- which is much lower than its industry   average of 25.The mature tech stock: Cisco SystemsCisco Systems is often described as a slow-growth
column14: ""mature""   tech stock. Analysts expect the networking giant's revenue to   fall 2% and its  earnings to rise less than 1% this year due   to tough competition in routers and switches
column15: slower enterprise   spending
column16: and thedisruptive threatof cloud-based networking solutions that require less   hardware.Due to those challenges
column17: Cisco trades at just 15 times   earnings
column18: which is much lower than its industry average of 25.   Its forward yield of 3.5% is also much higher than the market   average
column19: and it's easily supported by a payout ratio of 47%. It   spent 40% of its FCF on those dividends over the past 12 months.   Cisco has hiked its dividend every year since it started paying   one in 2011.Cisco rallied more than 20% over the past 12 months
column20: but those   gains can mainly be attributed to the popularity of dividend   stocks in a low-interest-rate environment instead of any real   enthusiasm for its core business. But looking ahead
column21: Cisco might   rekindle its top-line growth with the robust growth of its   cybersecurity business
column22: the growth of its newly acquired Jasper   Internet of Things (IoT) platform
column23: and additional   acquisitions.The overlooked tobacco play: Reynolds AmericanTobacco stocks are often considered solid income investments
column24: but some investors only focus on the two former halves of the   Philip Morris empire --AltriaandPhilip Morris International. Altria is a good domestic play
column25: but its price-to-earnings ratio   (P/E) of 25 is higher than the industry average of 22. Meanwhile
column26: PMI's all-overseas business is too exposed to the strong   dollar.A better play is Reynolds American
column27: which became the   second-largest domestic cigarette maker after it acquired   Lorillard last year. Reynolds trades at just 15 times earnings   and generates most of its revenue in the United States. Reynolds'   flagship Camel brand counters Altria's Marlboro. The company also   dominates the menthol market with Newport
column28: leads the e-cigarette   market with Vuse
column29: and controls the ""additive-free"" niche with   Natural American Spirit.Reynolds pays a forward yield of 3.3%
column30: which is supported by a   payout ratio of 44%. Its dividend payments have eclipsed its free   cash flow (FCF) over the past year due to the Lorillard   acquisition
column31: but that payout ratio should drop to manageable   levels as its FCF grows again. Reynolds has raised its dividend   annually for seven straight years.Analysts expect Reynolds to post 4% sales growth and 11%   earnings growth next year -- which tops Altria's projected sales   growth of 2% and earnings growth of 10%. Reynolds could   eventually be hurt by declining smoking rates
column32: but it can likely   raise prices
column33: cut costs
column34: and repurchase stock to boost its   earnings for years to come.The bottom lineThere's no perfect dividend stock that can be bought and   forgotten about
column35: but AT&T
column36: Cisco
column37: and Reynolds American won't   cause you to lose much sleep. All three stocks trade at discounts   to their industry peers
column38: have hiked their dividends for years
column39: and have manageable payout ratios. I personally own shares of all   three stocks and haven't ever felt compelled to babysit them.10 stocks we like better than AT and TWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: 5 Stocks With Bigger Dividends Than ExxonMobil;1/13/2017;"Steady income is within reach with these five stocks. Image   source: Getty Images.ExxonMobil Corporation(NYSE: XOM) has an enviable track record of paying and growing   its dividend for many years. But at the same time
column2: there are   plenty of reasons to skip this biggest of the big oil companies
column3: particularly if you're looking for a solid source of income. We   reached out to five of our top contributors and asked them to   write about some companies with bigger dividends than   ExxonMobil.They gave us compelling reasons to consider oil and gas   logistics specialistHolly Energy Partners L.P.(NYSE: HEP)
column4: tech stalwartCisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column6: telecom and media giantVerizon Communications Inc.(NYSE: VZ)
column7: pharma blue chipPfizer Inc.(NYSE: PFE)
column8: and healthcare real estate upstartCaretrust REIT Inc.(NASDAQ: CTRE) . Keep reading to find out which of these   companies would make a great addition to your dividend stock   portfolio.makeArticleAd();Little company
column9: big dividendTyler Crowe(Holly Energy Partners): One thing dividend investors want from an investment in   ExxonMobil is stability with modest growth. For decades   ExxonMobil has been able to deliver that
column10: even through some of   the biggest times of crisis for the oil and gas industry. It's   one thing to recommend a company that has a higher dividend yield   than ExxonMobil. It's an entirely other thing to find one that   can deliver a dividend that has the ability to weather any storm   the market can throw at it and even give room for growth.Image source: Getty Images.One that has developed a decent reputation for doing just that   over the years is oil and gas logistics specialist Holly Energy   Partners. While it may not have the size and scale of many other   transportation and logistics companies
column11: it makes up for it with   its contract structures and management's prudent approach to   growth. All of the services the company provides are done on 100%   fee-based contracts with strong minimum volume commitments from   its customers. In doing so
column12: it takes out almost all of the   commodity price risk associated with the oil and gas industry.   Also its modest growth profile is done in a way to maintain a   manageable debt level and continue to deliver payout increases.   The most recent distribution increase marked the 48th consecutive   quarter in which management raised its payout.With its distribution yield of 7.1% and a history of raising   its payout in a sustainable
column13: consistent manner
column14: investors looking   for a little more yield than shares of ExxonMobil should take a   look at Holly Energy Partners.A dominant tech companyTim Green(Cisco Systems): Networking hardware giant Cisco Systems has been increasing its   dividend at an impressive pace over the past few years. Cisco's   quarterly dividend has more than tripled since mid-2012
column15: with the   most recent payment of $0.26 per share good for a yield of about   3.45%.Cisco's long-term growth includes industrial users
column16: not just     traditional tech applications.Cisco dominates its core switching and routing markets
column17: although growth has been elusive in recent years. The company has   been investing in growth businesses such as security and   collaboration
column18: but broad weakness during Cisco's most recent   quarter and lackluster guidance suggests that a return to growth   may take a while.The good news for dividend investors is that Cisco generates a   tremendous amount of cash. Free cash flow came in at $12.4   billion during fiscal 2016
column19: putting the payout ratio based on   this number at about 42.5%. That leaves plenty of room to grow   the dividend even without much earnings growth. Investors   shouldn't expect Cisco's rapid dividend growth of the past few   years to continue unless earnings pick up. But a solid yield and   the potential for modest dividend growth going forward make Cisco   a good choice for dividend investors.A low-risk telecom giantSteve Symington(Verizon Communications): With a 4.7% dividend that's been raised every year for the past   decade
column20: Verizon stockoffers an attractive mix between stability and growth   potential.Of course
column21: there's no denying Verizon has had a hard time   finding growth
column22: given its increasingly competitive core markets.   Excluding 2015 contributions of its since-divested landline   business
column23: revenue and adjusted net income per share fell 2.9%   year over year last quarter
column24: to $30.9 billion and $1.01
column25: respectively. But Verizon also boasts exceptional customer   loyalty
column26: with retail postpaid phone churn below 0.9% for the past   six straight quarters -- a testament to its continued investments   in its market-leading network. And that leadership should only   become more pronounced after it fulfills its promise to be the   first company to launch a 5G fixed wireless broadband network in   the United States.Image source: Getty Images.Meanwhile
column27: Verizon's Fios fiber-optic services are enjoying   renewed growth
column28: with FiOS revenue up 4.4% last quarter
column29: to $2.8   billion
column30: thanks to the additions of 90
column31: 000 FiOS internet   connections and 36
column32: 000 FiOS Video connections.Verizon has also made a number of acquisitions to position   itself for longer-term growth
column33: including its purchase of   connected vehicle solutions company Telogis and an agreement to   acquire Yahoo! last July
column34: the acquisition of smart-city solutions   company Sensity Systems in September
column35: and its acquisition of   fleet and mobile workforce management company Fleetmatics   completed in November. The fruits of these purchases will   take time to realize
column36: but collectively they should serve to only   expand the scope and power of Verizon's business over the long   term. And the earlier you buy shares
column37: the longer you'll have to   allow the power of Verizon's juicy dividend and compounding   returns to do their work.This drugmaker is a great way to gain exposure to the   high-flying pharma spaceGeorge Budwell(Pfizer): With a yield of 3.88% at current levels
column38: Pfizer offers a   slightly richer payout than ExxonMobil. But the real difference   between these two income-generating stocks is arguably the   tailwinds facing their respective industries.Image source: Getty Images.The pharmaceutical industry
column39: after all
column40: is experiencing a   golden era stemming from an uptick in innovation
column41: an aging and   rapidly expanding global population
column42: and broader access to modern   healthcare around the world. The same positive outlook simply   can't be said for traditional oil and gas giants like Exxon that   are facing significant pricing pressure at the moment
column43: along with   the ongoing global transition to renewable forms of energy
column44: such   as advanced biofuels and solar.So even though Pfizer has been resoundingly criticized for its   hefty price increases on older medicines
column45: the cumulative effect   of these tailwinds should be more than enough to offset any   political blowback. Simply put
column46: Pfizer should have little problem   increasing sales volumes for new drugs such as its breast cancer   treatment Ibrance
column47: or its slate of novel vaccines
column48: to drive   growth over the long haul. As such
column49: this drugmaker's   comparatively high dividend for a large-cap pharma stock should   not only be safe in the near term
column50: but it should continue to grow   at a fairly regular clip going forward.A small company riding a very big long-term trendJason Hall(Caretrust REIT Inc.): If you're looking for a strong contender for long-term growth   in both the dividend and share price
column51: Caretrust REIT should be on   your list. Caretrust owns senior housing and healthcare   facilities and then works with healthcare operators
column52: which lease   and operate the properties Caretrust owns. Caretrust is in   an excellent position to grow much larger
column53: as this market is both   underserved and will need to expand significantly over the next   couple of decades to support an aging baby boomer population.According to a recent company presentation
column54: there are nearly   10%fewerskilled nursing facilities operating in the U.S. now than there   were 15 years ago
column55: while the over-65 population is growing.   Between 2010 and 2040
column56: the elderly population is expected to more   than double
column57: to over 80 million Americans. Caretrust is very   likely to be a major beneficiary of that growth
column58: as the company   builds and acquires more and more facilities to house and care   for this aging population.With less than 160 properties today
column59: Caretrust is a very small   fish in a very big -- and growing -- pond. If management can   continue allocating capital well
column60: Caretrust has the makings of a   portfolio-changing income investment over the next 20 years.10 stocks we like better than ExxonMobilWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 10 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print Money;1/12/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsHistory has taught us that dividend growth stocks are the absolute best way to grow both your income and wealth over time.Source: StockSnap.ioOne such group of dividend stocks is known as the S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats -S&P 500companies that have increased their payouts for at least 25 consecutive years. Aristocrats havecollectively outperformed the S&P 500over time with less volatility.makeArticleAd();Of course
column3: to be able to pay secure and growing dividends

column6: which income investors canlearn more about here.The 7 Best Monthly Dividend Stocks for 2017Here they are

Plus

column1: Should I Buy FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;1/12/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCybersecurity stocks have taken a hit over the past few years
column4: but there has been one company that has made that bearishness look downright placid -FireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE).Source:David via Flickr (Modified)FEYE stock has lost value for the past three years
column5: and now trades a long way from its all-time high of $85 in early 2014.makeArticleAd();Indeed
column6: FEYE has many issues. There's the drastic slowdown in sales
column7: the abrupt departure of the CEO last year and
column8: of course
column9: the intense competitive environment. Not the least of which is FireEye's meandering transition to the cloud and its hesitancy to adopt next-generation technologies.In light of all this
column10: is it any wonder that FEYE stock has been so terrible? Nope.But when it comes to investing
column11: there are often nice opportunities with contrarian plays. So might this be the case with FireEye stock? Well
column12: to see
column13: let's take a look at three pros and three cons:FEYE Stock ProsStill a Solid Company:It does seem overblown that FEYE stock is headed for near oblivion. The fact is that the company still has an impressive business
column14: with a wide array of products and services. In the latest quarter
column15: FEYE added287 new customersand there were 47 that entered into transactions in excess of $1 million. The total customer account is over 5
column16: 000 and more than 940 are on the Forbes Global 2000. As for revenues
column17: they came to $186.4 million in the most recent quarter. In all
column18: there is $926.2 million in the bank. Consider that the market cap of FEYE stock is only about $2.2 billion.Strong Leadership:CEO Kevin Mandia has wasted little time in making serious restructuring efforts. Then again
column19: he is one of the top influencers in the cybersecurity industry. Hestarted his career in the United States Air Forceas a security officer and then as a cybercrime investigator in the Air Force Office of Special Investigation. After these stints
column20: he went into the private sector
column21: having worked at various firms like Sytex
column22: and also co-authored two well-regarded books. Then he went on to launch Mandiant in 2004
column23: eventuallyselling the company to FireEyein 2014.10 Stocks to Buy for Donald Trump's Second     WindIn other words
column24: Mandia has a rare blend of deep experience with the technical aspects of cybersecurity and also how to build successful companies. So regarding the product line
column25: a key part of his strategy is to offer more affordable solutions so as to cater to smaller customers. To this end
column26: FEYE has launched FireEye Essentials. But
column27: of course
column28: another high priority is the cloud
column29: which is part of the FireEye as a Service (FaaS) platform. Some of the recent product launches for this include Cloud MVX - which does not require a hardware appliance and is priced on a subscription basis - and MVX Smart Grid (this is for those companies that prefer on-premise approaches
column30: such as in industries like financial services and healthcare).Then there are other important tools like the FireEye Security Orchestrator
column31: which manages threats and responses across massive organizations. As a testament to its power
column32: a government agency made a seven-figure purchase of the software during thelatest quarter.Secular Trends:More than ever
column33: we rely on core technologies that are becoming essential to everyday living. No doubt
column34: there is the ubiquity of smartphones and wearables. But with the Internet of Things
column35: there is the growth in technology for autos
column36: homes and even medical devices. Protecting these systems from cyberattacks is only getting more complicated. As a result
column37: the growth for the industry is likely to remain strong for the long haul. According to a report fromIDC
column38: the global spending is expected to jump from $73.7 billion in 2016 to $101.6 billion by 2020.FEYE Stock ConsGrowth Issues:The deceleration of the top line has certainly been dramatic. During the first quarter of 2015
column39: revenues soared by69% to $125.4 million. Yet for the latest earnings report
column40: there was only a 13% gain. Keep in mind that FEYE expects the situation to get even worse. The guidance for the fourth quarter is for revenues of $187 million to $193 million
column41: which would translate to an increase of1.2% to 4.4%. It's important to note that a big part of the reduction has come from the transition to a subscription business model
column42: which means not as much revenue can be recognized up front. Despite this
column43: there is little doubt that FEYE has been losing momentum. That's why the company has focused on restructuring its operations.Competition:It's intense for the cybersecurity market. Just some of the top operators includeFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT)
column44: Palo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW)
column45: Check Point Software Technologies Ltd.(NASDAQ:CHKP) andProofpoint Inc(NASDAQ:PFPT). But some mega tech companies have also moved aggressively into the space
column46: such asCisco Systems
column47: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO). But perhaps the biggest threat is from the startups
column48: which have the benefit of a flush venture capital market. The fact is that a technology lead can easily disappear - and it can be very tough to regain it. A prime example of this isSymantec Corporation(NASDAQ:SYMC)
column49: which relied too long on its antivirus franchise and did not make enough investments to refresh its product offering.Losses:FEYE has been a consistent money loser. True
column50: this is fairly common throughout the cybersecurity industry. But then again
column51: losses become much more of a problem when sales are rapidly falling! Unfortunately
column52: there are no signs that FEYE will hit profitability anytime soon. For the current quarter
column53: analysts expect a net loss of 16 cents a share. The company has made progress with reducing costs
column54: yet asInvestorPlace Media'sJames Brumelynoted recently: ""… an even closer inspection reveals that relative improvement almost entirely came from the $10.7 million reduction in R&D spending - a cost cut that may come back to haunt the company in the long run.""Bottom Line on FEYE StockTech turnarounds are always difficult
column55: and many fail. But again
column56: FEYE has a CEO with a strong background and is making smart decisions. Actually
column57: the company is already starting to see positive results.FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Hit A Bottom ... But     Not THE BottomBesides
column58: the valuation is fairly reasonable. Consider that FEYE stock trades at about three times its sales. By comparison
column59: both PANW andCyberark Software Ltd(NASDAQ:CYBR) sport multiples of about eight times sales.OK then
column60: should you buy FEYE stock now?  I think so
column61: given that it looks like a good value play on a growth industry.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is a registered investment adviser representative (you   canvisit his siteto learn more about his financial planning services).He is also the author of various books on investing like All   About Commodities

column63: he did not hold a position in any of the   aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Companies The Coca-Cola Co (KO) Should Buy in     201710 Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement

column1: Will Cisco Systems Raise Its Dividend in 2017?;1/11/2017;"Technology stocks used to be stingy with their capital
column2: butCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) is proof of how much the tech industry has changed   when it comes to dividends. Cisco paid its first dividend just   six years ago
column3: but since then
column4: it has grown its quarterly payment   so much that the networking giant is now among the top dividend   paying stocks in theDow Jones Industrialsin terms of yield. Looking forward
column5: income investors want to know   if they can count on Cisco to continue its streak of rewarding   shareholders with higher dividends. Let's take a closer look at   Cisco Systems to see whether it will raise its dividend in   2017.Image source: Cisco Systems.Dividend stats on Cisco SystemsCurrent Quarterly Dividend Per SharemakeArticleAd();$0.26Current Yield3.4%Number of Consecutive Years With Dividend             Increases6 yearsPayout Ratio47%Last IncreaseApril 2016Data source: Yahoo! Finance. Last increase refers to   ex-dividend date.How Cisco became a dividend giantCisco's history of paying dividends is short but sweet. In   2011
column6: the networking giant declared a $0.06-per-share quarterly   dividend. Then-CFO Frank Calderoni told investors
column7: ""Cisco's   leadership position in the markets we serve is strong
column8: and the   time is right for Cisco to pay our first-ever cash dividend."" The   payout gave Cisco a modest dividend yield at the time of   1.4%.Yet Cisco wasn't content for very long with simply paying a   dividend. The following year
column9: the company gave investors a 33%   increase in April
column10: and then came back with a whopping 75% boost   in October. The second increase was part of Cisco's broader   capital management strategy
column11: which stated the company's intention   to return half of its free cash flow to shareholders in the form   of dividends and stock repurchases combined. Moreover
column12: then-CEO   John Chambers said
column13: ""We wanted to get the dividend to allow both   that the shareholders clearly understood we're committed to it
column14: and if we do our job right
column15: at the right times
column16: we're committed   to raising it.""CSCO dividenddata byYCharts.Since then
column17: Cisco has followed through on its commitment to   make the dividend an increasingly important part of its total   return for shareholders. Three double-digit percentage dividend   hikes followed in consecutive years
column18: and the most recent increase   came to 24%. Current CEO Chuck Robbins told investors after that   boost
column19: ""We have a tremendous amount of confidence in our business   long term
column20: [and] we heard from many of our shareholders that they   wanted to see us get more aggressive with the dividend   returns.""Yet even with the big increases in dividends
column21: Cisco hasn't   overextended itself. Dividend payouts make up just over half of   Cisco's earnings right now. If the company can sustain its growth   rates going forward
column22: then there should be more opportunities for   the networking giant to make further increases.Will Cisco raise its dividend in 2017?One outstanding issue that could spur another increase in   Cisco's capital return to shareholders is whether tax reform will   reduce the amount of tax that the tech giant would have to pay to   repatriate profits from overseas. As Robbins told investors in   December
column23: ""If we're able to bring those funds back to the U.S.
column24: then we would look at a combination of the options of dividends
column25: buybacks
column26: and M&A activity.""Yet it wouldn't take favorable movement on repatriation to   allow Cisco to make a further increase. Stock buybacks have   reduced Cisco's share count over the years
column27: and that permits the   company to make dividend increases without boosting the total   amount of cash it's paying to shareholders.Overall
column28: the odds are good that Cisco will raise its dividend   in 2017. There's a chance that the company could wait until later   in the year than its usual March-April time frame in order to   give lawmakers time to consider a tax reform package that could   include repatriation provisions. However
column29: what's more likely is   that investors will get a roughly 12% increase to $0.29 per share   early in the year
column30: with a possible further increase if things in   Washington go well. Regardless
column31: Cisco's total return of nearly   25% over the past year has kept long-term shareholders happy
column32: and   its growth prospects remain solid
column33: offering future support for   future dividend increases in 2017 and beyond.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cisco Systems wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column38: 2017Dan Caplingerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool     recommends Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Barrick Gold Doubled in 2016. Will It Soar Even Higher in 2017?;1/11/2017;"With prices rising as much as 21% last August

column5: however

column7: a global leader among gold stocks
column8: climbed more   than 106%. Let's dig into the company's performance in 2016
column9: and   see what we can expect in 2017.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Golden highlightsOne of the company's priorities in 2016 was to streamline its   operations so that it could still produce free cash flow if the   price of gold dipped to $1
column10: 000 per ounce. Though the company   hasn't reported its Q4 earnings yet
column11: as of Q3
column12: the company   reported that it had exceeded its target
column13: generating free cash   flow at a gold price below $1
column14: 000 per ounce.Barrick's skill at keeping its expenses down was partly   responsible for this success. The mining industry's version of   operating expenses -- all-in sustaining costs (AISC) -- provide   good insight into how efficiently a company is operating. And in   this regard
column15: Barrick was quite successful.As of Q3
column16: management estimated that AISC for fiscal 2016 will   total between $740 and $775 per gold ounce. By comparison

column22: which is sensitive to this

column24: which led to a   debt-reduction target of $2 billion in 2016. And as of Q3
column25: it had   achieved 71% of that target. Moreover
column26: on the Q3 conference call
column27: management reported that it was ""tracking well"" to the yearly   target.Growth catalysts in 2017Turning toward the new year

column31: Barrick's executive chairman

column38: in time
column39: result in larger financial gains.Besides monitoring progress with Cisco
column40: investors can watch   for Barrick's success in achieving its financial targets.   Arguably
column41: the strong performance of Barrick's stock was a result   of the company's strong performance in strengthening both its   balance sheet and cash flow.Image source: Barrick Gold.As a result
column42: continued success in shoring up the balance sheet   and improving cash flow may translate to a rise in shares. For   example
column43: in its Investor Day presentation from February
column44: management forecasted gold production to total between 5.0   million and 5.5 million ounces of gold. In addition
column45: management   estimated AISC to total between $740 and $790 per gold ounce.A golden valuation?We've looked at what's behind Barrick and what's ahead
column46: so   let's turn our attention now to its stock. Since the company   hasn't reported positive net income since 2011
column47: the traditional   price-to-earnings ratio won't provide much insight. Instead
column48: let's consider the stock in terms of its  free cash flow on   a trailing-12-month basis.Over the past year
column49: the stock has traded as low as 8.5 times   free cash flow and as high as 17.0 times free cash flow.   Currently
column50: shares are trading at about 13 times free cash flow --   almost exactly the midpoint of its range over the past year. This   suggests that shares are reasonably priced.Considering only one valuation metric seems inadequate to   properly gauge the stock
column51: so let's also look at it's   price-to-sales ratio on a trailing-12-month basis. Trading at   about 2.3 times sales
column52: shares seem to be a little bit higher than   the midpoint of its high and low for the year -- but not by   much.ABX Price to Free Cash Flow (TTM)data byYCharts.To provide more context for the stock's valuation
column53: let's   consider it alongside its peers:Goldcorp
column54: Kinross Gold
column55: Newmont Mining
column56: andYamana Gold. In terms of free cash flow
column57: Barrick's valuation certainly seems   fair. Although it may seem a little pricier than its peers
column58: the   stock's valuation in terms of sales doesn't raise any red   flags.ABX Price to Free Cash Flow (TTM)data byYCharts.Overall
column59: considering where shares are trading today
column60: the stock   seems fairly priced.The takeawayAlthough shares of Barrick Gold had a great run in 2016
column61: there's no guarantee that it will continue into 2017. At this   point
column62: in fact
column63: it seems that Wall Street has gotten this one   right by not baking in too many expectations
column64: or punishing it   unfairly. With its eyes on the future -- a digitized future --   and a circumspect approach to managing its debt
column65: Barrick Gold is   a reasonable consideration for investors looking to gain exposure   to the gold industry.10 stocks we like better than Barrick GoldWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column66: it can pay to listen. After all
column67: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column68: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column69: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Barrick Gold wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Which Of The Latest 13F Filers Holds Cisco Systems?;1/10/2017;"AtHoldings Channel

column5: we find it is a good idea to take a closer look.Before we proceed
column6: it is important to point out that 13F filings do not tell the whole story
column7: because these funds are only required to disclose theirlongpositions with the SEC
column8: but are not required to disclose theirshortpositions. A fund making a bearish bet against a stock by shorting calls
column9: for example
column10: might also be long some amount of stock as they trade around their overall bearish position. This long component could show up in a 13F filing and everyone might assume the fund is bullish
column11: but this tells only part of the storybecause the bearish/short side of the position is not seen.makeArticleAd();Having given that caveat

column1: Why Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Could Gain 30%;1/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCompetition in the tech space is fierce
column4: making it difficult for long-term investors to find quality stocks to beef up that aspect of their portfolios. The hottest companies are often the most expensive and those whose share prices are waning could be on their way toward the technology graveyard. However
column5: some solid
column6: reliable firms have been delivering for years that are being overlooked and are therefore undervalued.Source: ShutterstockCisco Systems
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) is one such company. Cisco stock has fallen nearly 4% over the last three months and the firm is poised to have a breakout year - making now a great time to buy.makeArticleAd();Although it's true that CSCO hasfallen prey to rising competitionin the tech space and the firm's efforts to break into new markets like security and software are likely to be riddled with obstacles. Even after taking into account the headwinds facing Cisco stock
column8: the company is undervalued.The firm's forward price-to-earnings ratio stands at 12; that's much lower than the rest of the tech industry and sits even further below theS&P 500as a whole. If CSCO stock was priced similarly to the broader market
column9: the stock would be making its way toward the $40 mark.Improvement Ahead for CSCO StockNot only is Cisco stock valued much lower than many of its peers
column10: but the company's plans are pretty impressive as well. CSCO is shifting its focus toward subscription-based services
column11: security and data centers. That means the company is laying the foundation to create a continuous revenue stream through subscription fees. The firm is also inserting itself into some of the fastest growing sectors in the tech space
column12: which is certainly something long-term investors should consider.7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in     2017One of the best reasons to buy and hold Cisco stock is the company's financial strength. The company's balance sheet shows that management is keeping the firm on the right track by controlling inventory effectively and maintaining a healthy cash flow
column13: a good sign that the firm can weather any storms as it makes its transition into new industries.Not only will the firm's financial backbone keep it from capitulating at every bump in the road
column14: but it reassures shareholders that their dividend payments are unlikely to go anywhere.Cisco Stock's Bonus DividendNot only could CSCO stock rise 30% in the coming year
column15: but the company also pays an impressive dividend. While a dividend yield of 3.44% may not sound like much
column16: Cisco's dividend payouts come in on the high end of the spectrum in the tech world. That means that long-term investors are rewarded with a steady income while they wait for a CSCO stock rally.That 3.44% could be on its way up as well. Cisco is one of the firms set to benefit from Donald Trump's plans to reform corporate taxes once he takes office. CSCO is sitting on about$60 billion overseas
column17: all of which could be repatriated if the tax laws are reformed. That money
column18: or at least part of it
column19: is likely to make its way into shareholders' pockets either through buybacks or a dividend hike.Wal-Mart Stores
column20: Inc (WMT) Has More Problems     Than the Trump TariffBut
column21: with all of that said
column22: it's not all roses for Cisco stock
column23: the company still has some major obstacles to overcome. The firm issued lackluster Q2 guidance
column24: proving that it is still struggling with its transition from hardware
column25: and many point to the fierce competition in security
column26: data centers and networking where CSCO plans to build its business.Bottom Line on CSCOWhile that is certainly a concern
column27: the troubles Cisco stock is facing are not unlike those plaguing most tech companies today. IT is a crowded space and competition will always be a worry
column28: but CSCO's financial stability and longevity are likely to help the company
column29: and its shareholders
column30: weather any storms along the way.As of this writing
column31: Laura Hoy did not hold a position in any   of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksThe 7 Best Monthly Dividend Stocks for 2017The postWhy Cisco Systems
column32: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Could Gain 30%appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: My 3 Biggest Stock Holdings;1/7/2017;"Some investors hold dozens of stocks at any given time
column2: using   diversification as a way to minimize the chance that a single   mistake causes an outsize amount of pain. There's nothing wrong   with that approach
column3: but it tends to dilute one's best ideas with   so-so stocks. As Warren Buffett says
column4: ""Diversification is   protection against ignorance."" If you're not confident in your   best ideas
column5: diversify away.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();I take the opposite approach. ""The way to become rich is to   put all your eggs in one basket and then watch that basket
column6: according to Andrew Carnegie. That's what Buffett has done his   entire career
column7: betting big when the odds were heavily in his   favor and doing nothing when they weren't.The top three holdings in my portfolio
column8: International Business Machines(NYSE: IBM)
column9: Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column10: andKulicke & Soffa Industries(NASDAQ: KLIC)
column11: account for a little less than 40% of its total   value. I bought each at a price that gave me a substantial margin   of safety
column12: giving me plenty of room to be wrong. My favorite kind   of investment is one where I have to be right about very few   things for it to work out well.A century-old tech companyIBM is my biggest position. The stock has been on a   roller-coaster ride since I first bought shares in late 2014
column13: dropping considerably in 2015 and then recovering in 2016. I   bought shares a total of eight times as the stock fell
column14: lowering   my cost basis to about $154 per share by the end. A 20% gain in   2016 brought the position back into the black.IBMdata byYChartsIn the case of IBM
column15: a slumping stock price didn't change my   thesis. The market had become extremely pessimistic about IBM's   ability to adapt to a world where cloud computing was   growing in importance. Revenue and profit were slumping as IBM   sold off underperforming businesses and shifted its focus to its   growth businesses. Currency didn't help
column16: with a strengthening   U.S. dollar in 2015 wreaking havoc on the company's international   numbers.IBM has the benefit of a broad base of global customers that   rely on its hardware
column17: software
column18: and services. This doesn't   guarantee that the company will remain relevant forever
column19: but it   does give it time to make the necessary changes. IBM's cloud   business is now booming
column20: bringing in $12.7 billion of revenue   over the past 12 months. Total software revenue isgrowing again
column21: and cognitive computing system Watson will be used
column22: both   directly and indirectly
column23: by more than 1 billion consumers by the   end of 2017.IBM expects to produce at least $13.50 in adjusted earnings   per share in 2016
column24: which is depressed because of its heavy   investments and the continued negative impact of currency. IBM   will need to eventually return to earnings growth for my   investment to reach its full potential
column25: but I'm confident that   thecompany's strategyis the right one.Another big tech companyI've owned shares of networking hardware giant Cisco since   mid-2012
column26: originally paying $16.61 per share. I added to that   position a couple of times
column27: including in early 2016
column28: when the   stock market had a brief but lucrative meltdown. My cost basis   currently sits at $20.40 per share.The stock has surged to around $30 per share since then
column29: driven mostly by the fact that the market was extremely   pessimistic about Cisco a few years ago. The company's results   have been fine but nothing to write home about. Growth has been   slow
column30: and its core switching and routing businesses have been   volatile. But Cisco continues to dominate those markets.CSCOdata byYChartsCisco is extremely profitable
column31: producing operating margins   around 25%. The company has produced $12.4 billion of free cash   flow over the past 12 months
column32: compared with a market   capitalization of about $150 billion. Back out the $36 billion of   net cash on the balance sheet
column33: and Cisco's cash-adjusted price to   free cash flow ratio is a paltry 9.2.The rise of cloud computing and software-defined networking   has introduced quite a bit of uncertainty. Whether Cisco can   remain as dominant as it is today in its core markets going   forward is an open question. But the pessimistic stock price   gives investors a substantial margin of safety. Cisco doesn't   need to be the growth company it once was for an investment in   the stock to work out well. It just needs to do better than the   market expects. And the market isn't expecting much.An overlooked small-cap stockKulicke & Soffa is not a well-known company. It   manufactures semiconductor packaging equipment
column34: holding a   dominant share of the market for wire bonding equipment.I first wrote about Kulicke & Soffain July 2015
column35: and I bought shares soon after. I bought a few more   times as the stock gyrated
column36: building up a substantial   position.Shares of Kulicke & Soffa have soared since bottoming out   a little over a year ago. The stock is up about 70% from its   52-week low. I sold about one-third of my position late last year   because it had become too big a part of my portfolio
column37: but Kulicke   & Soffa is still my third-largest holding.KLICdata byYChartsKulicke & Soffa's revenue and profit fluctuate along with   demand for its equipment
column38: leading to major swings in both. But   the company has done a good job remaining profitable during the   tough times
column39: only posting one annual net loss in the past decade.   Kulicke & Soffa's balance sheet was a big factor in my   decision to buy the stock in the first place. At the end of the   most recent quarter
column40: the company had $548 million in cash and no   debt. Even after the surge in the stock price
column41: cash still   represents nearly half of Kulicke & Soffa's market   capitalization.Averaging around $50 million in net income annually
column42: albeit   with a lot of variation
column43: Kulicke & Soffa was too cheap to   ignore when it was trading for around $10 per share. It's not   nearly as cheap today
column44: but it's still a solid company trading at   a reasonable price.10 stocks we like better than IBMWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Is More Attractive Than You Think;1/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's no longer a real secret thatCisco Systems
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) is on the defensive in the router/switching market - a market that thrust Cisco to the head of the class in the late 90's
column5: and a market that Cisco still mostly dominates. On the flipside
column6: investors more than a little familiar with CSCO stock also know the company's newest priority isn't the kind of heavy-hitting revenue generator its networking wares used to be.Source: ShutterstockThat new focus? Software
column7: and the Internet of Things in particular … a party to which Cisco showed up late
column8: and an arena that it still doesn't look like it's perfectly ready to compete in compared to other players likeGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE).makeArticleAd();Fear not
column9: however. Not only is Cisco equipped well enough to remain relevant in a future where IoT is everything
column10: some subtle clues recently dished out by key executives suggests the company ""gets it"" to a far greater degree than anyone's giving it credit for.CSCO Picks the Low-Hanging FruitThink Cisco has already missed the Internet of Things boat? Cisco stock holders need not worry.Maciej Kranz isn't exactly a name that rings a bell among owners of CSCO owners. But
column11: as Vice President of the company's Corporate Technology Group
column12: he's well positioned - perhaps more so than some higher-level executives - to determine how Cisco gets from point A to point B.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksAnd Kranz has an amazingly pragmatic view of where Cisco fits in the still-nascent IoT market.In a corporate blog post penned in early December
column13: Kranz opined:""Successful IoT deployments do have at least one thing in common
column14: however - they focus on solving the customer's real business problems.This third ingredient in my Recipe for IoT Success may seem obvious to you. Of course you focus on real problems! But you may be surprised at how often these efforts wander off track because someone is chasing a shiny new technology instead of starting with the customer - and the customer's problems - at the center.""It isn't sexy. That's the point. It's marketable. Rather than swinging for the fences (and risking a whiff)
column15: Cisco is gunning to hit singles and maybe the occasional double to secure its place in the Internet of Things market.With just a cursory glance at what Cisco has done thus far
column16: and plans to do
column17: owners of CSCO stock might not see such a practical bent to its efforts. Take a closer look though
column18: beginning with Cisco's answer to the need for Low Power Wireless Access hardware.It wasn't much of a consideration in the early era of IoT
column19: but a great number of ""connected"" devices don't need to frequently communicate with a network. They need tocommunicate infrequently
column20: but reliably
column21: sending a modest amount of data from remote locations. Water and gas meters are a couple of examples. Such devices require a new engineering model that allows for their nuances. Cisco's solution
column22: called LoRaWAN
column23: provides a real solution to a problem many IoT operators didn't foresee.Cisco has already deployed some commercializedLoRaWansolutions
column24: but has only scratched the surface of this market.The company has also began the development of so-called ""fog"" computing solutions.While the advent of cloud computing has been game-changing for the world
column25: the cloud has already put enormous strain on cellular and wi-fi networks
column26: gobbling up bandwidth that simply won't be available in the foreseeable future. Yet
column27: to halt such digital communication would be a step in the wrong direction.Boring Is Good for AT&T Inc. (T) StockThere is a happy medium. Rather than wirelessly delivering every last shred of data available and processing it at a centralized location
column28: why not handle some of that data-processing before needlessly uploading …everything? Such an approach will not only pre-solve many bandwidth/capacity problems
column29: but may actually result in greater efficiency since data is processed at the same locale where it's put into action.Cisco is already deploying this sort ofsolutiontoo.Bottom Line for Cisco StockAs was noted
column30: neither of these highly-marketable initiatives (or any of the other unmentioned ones) are sexy by any stretch of the imagination. Indeed
column31: the average consumer - and average investor - may not even realize these sorts of technological challenges exist
column32: or are being addressed. They're out there though
column33: and while some companies are looking to develop products that create paradigm shifts
column34: Cisco is quietly focused on coming up with solutions that are quickly becoming indispensable.CSCO stock remains one of the market's better picks
column35: largely because the company knows exactly what the future holds and it's not wasting time on hunting a whale it may never find. Oh
column36: and the 3.4% Cisco dividend yield doesn't hurt its appeal either.As of this writing
column37: James Brumley did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks That Won't Be Around a Year From     Now7 Beaten-Down Tech Stocks to Buy With 50%     Upside in 2017The postCisco Systems
column38: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Is More Attractive Than You Thinkappeared first onInvestorPlace."

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column15: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column16: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column17: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased

column1: 2 Top Stocks That Are Cash Cows;1/5/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Tech titansOracle Corporation(NYSE: ORCL) andCisco Systems
column2: Inc.(NASDAQ: CSCO) are cheap on a price-to-earnings basis and they   generate buckets of free cash flow (FCF). Their FCF generation   combined is about as much as the GDP of Uganda's 38   million people. Even if all they did was grow earnings and FCF in   line with inflation
column3: they would be raging buys. But
column4: of course
column5: investing is rarely this simple
column6: so let's take a look at what you   need to know before deciding whether to buy these large-cap cash   cows.makeArticleAd();The value propositionAs you can see in the table below
column7: both have attractive   FCF-to-enterprise value (market cap plus net debt) multiples. In   plain English
column8: this means that Cisco Systems is currently   generating more than 10% of its market cap in FCF
column9: while Oracle   clocks in around 8%.  H owever
column10: as is often the case with   cash cow stocks
column11: revenue growth is low.However
column12: both have good return on invested capital (net income   after tax divided by invested capital)
column13: a useful measure because   an increasing ROIC suggests a company can increase FCF in the   future even if revenue and earnings are flat. Declining ROIC is a   warning sign.CompanyFCF/EV5-Year Average Revenue GrowthReturn on Invested Capital*FCF/Sales*Oracle8.1%0.8%10%33.6%Cisco10.7%2.7%11.3%25.3%Data source: Company accounts. Table by author. *Last 12   months.In short
column14: they are classic low-growth but cheap cash cow   stocks. Is it time to buy? Not so fast -- these types of stocks   can be value traps out to catch an unsuspecting investor. Let's   look closer at them.Oracle analysisBoth companies have threats/opportunities from the cloud
column15: but   Oracle is arguably better placed to address them. Oracle's   challenge/opportunity in the next few years is to:Replace its declining hardware and on-premise software     license sales with its fast-growing cloud revenues.Grow revenue while navigating the shift to cloud-based     subscription sales
column16: which forgo a large part of upfront revenue     typically generated by on-license software sales.Here is a breakout of Oracle's revenue growth for the first   six months of its fiscal 2017
column17: which ends in May. As you can see   below
column18: growth in cloud-based revenue (software
column19: platform and   infrastructure as a service) is currently offsetting declines   elsewhere -- most notably in on-premise new software   licenses.SectorRevenue ChangeConstant-Currency GrowthShare of RevenueCloud SaaS and PaaS$74181%9%Cloud IaaS$219%2%On-premise new software licenses($452)(15%)13%On-premise software license updates and product           support$1913%55%Hardware products($183)(15%)6%Hardware support(57%)(4%)6%Service revenue($72)(3%)9%Total$1892%100%Data source: Oracle Corporation presentations. Table by   author. Data in millions of U.S. dollars.There are two reasons to be optimistic. First
column20: analysts are   forecasting Oracle's revenue to grow 1.3% in 2017
column21: with 3.3%   expected for 2018.Second
column22: cloud-based subscription sales don't show the full   picture
column23: because they produce an annual recurring revenue of   roughly a third of an up-font license sale. This is because   subscription revenue is recognized over time
column24: while sitting on   the balance sheet as deferred revenue.This means that reported revenue is not entirely reflective of   underlying growth. Moreover
column25: a look at short-term deferred   revenue -- up 8% in constant-currency terms in the second quarter   -- confirms Oracle's underlying business growth is good.Finally
column26: a quick look at FCF/sales suggests Oracle is holding   up well during the transition
column27: but declines in operating income   in the last two years have hit ROIC. No matter
column28: if EPS bounces   back to 9% growth as expected in the year ending May 2018
column29: the   stock will start to look very cheap.Data source: Oracle Corporation presentations. Chart by   author.Cisco analysisWhile Oracle seems to be on track
column30: the cloud appears to be   creating more problems than opportunities for Cisco Systems.   Increasing usage of network virtualization could mean companies   run their network architecture in the cloud rather than in   Cisco's sophisticated switches. Unfortunately
column31: these switches   tend to be expensive and good revenue generators for Cisco.Similarly
column32: if Cisco's routers and switches (which generate   around 45% of its revenue) become commoditized
column33: then less   expensive options from competitors like Huawei or ZTE could   threaten Cisco's market position. Indeed
column34: a look at its quarterly   switching and routing revenues shows that combined switching and   routing revenue growth has been negative for the last four   quarters.NGN = next-generation network. Data source: Cisco Systems   presentations. Chart by author.Put simply
column35: Cisco needs to stabilize its core switching and   routing revenue while using its FCF to invest and grow its   non-core operations. It's a different
column36: and more difficult
column37: problem than that faced by Oracle
column38: and for that reason Cisco   should trade at a discount to its tech peer.Will Oracle Corporation stock fly high in 2017? Image source:   Oracle Corporation website.Which is the better buy?Cisco is definitely a cash cow
column39: but the risk to its core   products remains
column40: and if its products become commoditized then   pricing
column41: earnings
column42: and cash flow could go into protracted   decline. Oracle
column43: on the other hand
column44: looks to be on track with its   transition toward the cloud
column45: and for that reason looks like a   more attractive investment.10 stocks we like better than OracleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column46: it can pay to listen. After all
column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share increased 12.8% to $2.47.The ePlus Hospital Without Walls SolutionNo better example of the innovative and critical solutions ePlus is trusted with can be found than in the healthcare sector with this week's news.On January 4
column10: PLUS announced that it designed and deployed a full technology infrastructure upgrade for Garrett Regional Medical Center in Maryland. This was important to the hospital as they fulfill the unique function of being a ""border"" hospital the serves patients from West Virginia and even Pennsylvania too.The solution included:Desktop and server virtualizationStorage area networkWireless and telemedicine infrastructureDisaster recoveryGarrett Regional Medical Center is a 55-bed
column11: not-for-profit
column12: acute care facility with a long history of serving the health care needs of Garrett County
column13: Maryland and the surrounding communities in West Virginia.The technology refresh for Garrett enables streamlined applications and clinician access
column14: bedside medication verification
column15: improved user experience
column16: enhanced collaboration on patient cases
column17: and continuity of care.Valuation and TargetsPLUS shares have had quite a run since that earnings report
column18: up over 30% from $90 to nearly $120. This has stretched the valuation somewhat. For example
column19: Stifel Nicolaus analysts raised their 12-month price target on shares in early December to $113 based on 14X their fiscal year 2018 (starts in April) EPS of $8.06.The Stifel analysts noted then that consolidation among major IT vendors like Dell buying EMC is a positive for ePlus as mergers typically lead to staff reduction and the need for resellers to help support smaller customers.Back in November
column20: another prominent Wall Street investment bank noted that at $90 the stock was trading at 12.5 times their calendar 2017 EPS estimate of $7.20
column21: compared to the peer group at a blended group median multiple of 11.8 times.It seems that given its growth in cloud services and security
column22: and its pedigree of partners that reads like a who's who of the top technology companies
column23: PLUS is afforded a higher multiple for a small cap stock with a 25-year history. I don't know when it makes new highs above $120
column24: but I would have it on my radar on dips to $110.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above
column25: would you like to know about our 10 finest tickers for the entirety of 2017? Who wouldn't? These 10 are painstakingly hand-picked from 4

column1: Better Buy: Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Co vs. Cisco Systems
column2: Inc;1/4/2017;"Some of the biggest players in the ever-changing tech industry   have been forced to reinvent themselves
column3: or risk becoming   obsolete. For networking kingCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column4: change has meant a shift away from legacy
column5: enterprise hardware to a focus on cloud infrastructure
column6: data   security
column7: the Internet of Things (IoT)
column8: and communication   solutions.If anything
column9: HP Enterprise(NYSE: HPE) is undergoing even more changes than its cloud   infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) brethren. Based on its more   than 50% jump in value last year
column10: most investors and pundits are   on board with the ""new"" HP Enterprise. So
column11: which is the better   buy
column12: HP Enterprise or Cisco?makeArticleAd();Image source:Cisco.The case for CiscoIf there were any questions as to Cisco's commitment to   transitioning to fast-growing new markets
column13: those were laid to   rest when it announced in August it would eliminate 5
column14: 500   jobs -- equal to about 7% of its global workforce -- to focus on   its ""key priority areas."" Namely
column15: the aforementioned cloud data   centers
column16: IoT
column17: security
column18: and collaboration offerings.Cisco is already making strides where it counts. Excluding its   now divested SP Video business
column19: Cisco's revenue climbed 1% to   $12.35 billion compared to a year ago. After removing one-time   items
column20: per-share earnings improved 3% to $0.61. That may not   appear overly impressive
column21: but Cisco was able to grow sales and   its bottom line despite a 7% decline in its old-school   switching business.Though switching sales remain the top revenue driver
column22: Cisco   was able to make up for the unit's decline thanks to its strong   6% jump in routing revenue to $2.1 billion
column23: due in large part to   cloud-related offerings
column24: and a whopping 11% year-over-year   improvement in data security sales. Better still
column25: particularly in   the long run
column26: Cisco's focus on building a recurring revenue model   is hitting on all cylinders.Last quarter
column27: subscription and software sales growth helped   boost service revenue 7.5% to $3 billion. Service-related   deferred revenue -- another measure of Cisco's recurring   sales model -- grew to $10.4 billion
column28: up 7.6% from a year ago.   Not only do recurring sales provide a stable revenue source
column29: it   costs less to generate than new sales. Cisco's drop in expenses   last quarter despite growing total revenue is a testament to   that.Image source:HP Enterprise.The case for HP EnterpriseChanges are most certainly afoot with HP Enterprise. Not the   least of which is its pending spinoff mergers. In keeping with   CEO Meg Whitman's strategy of better positioning HP Enterprise to   quickly adapt to new opportunities
column30: it is merging its   Enterprise Services unit withComputer Sciences Corp(NYSE: CSC)
column31: creating a ""$26 billion pure play IT services   company.""The CSC news was followed by a similar move to spin off   HP Enterprise's ""non-core software assets"" and merge them with   U.K.-basedMicro Focus(NASDAQOTH: MCFUF) . Both deals are expected to close at the end   of March.The result of the spinoffs
column32: in addition to HP Enterprise   becoming more nimble
column33: includes ownership stakes of approximately   50% in each of the ""new"" companies for shareholders -- not to   mention a tidy $2.5 billion cash payment to HP Enterprise
column34: strengthening its already impressive balance sheet.Last quarter
column35: HP Enterprise's cash and equivalents   climbed over $3 billion compared to a year ago
column36: to nearly $13   billion. Not only does its rock-solid balance sheet demonstrate   HP Enterprise's financial stability
column37: it also positions it to   target niche acquisitions to fill any gaps in its suite of   solutions. The recent $275 million deal for big data analytics   and high-performance computing provider SGI is a recent   example.Which is the better buy?Even after its banner 2016
column38: HP Enterprise stock is   trading at a mere 11 times future earnings
column39: making it one of   the best values in its sector. Cisco is trading at just 12   times forward earnings
column40: and with its nearly 3.5% dividend yield   and future prospects
column41: it's the better buy for growth and income   investors.That said
column42: when the smoke clears
column43: HP Enterprise will be   ideally positioned to grow by leaps and bounds as 2017 progresses   -- and beyond. For investors in search of pure growth potential
column44: HP Enterprise gets the nod.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: What Does 2017 Hold for the Internet of Things?;1/3/2017;"The Internet of Things (IoT)
column2: which links mobile devices
column3: wearables
column4: home automation devices
column5: cars
column6: and other gadgets to   each other and the cloud
column7: is frequently considered the next big   growth market for hardware and software makers.Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) estimates that the number of connected devices   worldwide will double from 25 billion in 2015 to 50 billion by   2020.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();That's why chipmakers likeIntelandQualcommlaunched new low-power chips for IoT devices
column8: and networking   leaders like Cisco andJuniper Networksadded IoT features to their networking hardware and software.   Looking ahead into 2017
column9: the battle over the IoT market will   likely heat up as these companies expand their hardware and   software ecosystems. Let's take a look at the four main trends   investors should pay close attention to.Security concernsThe Mirai botnet and its variantsrecently hijackedunsecured IoT devices -- like IP cameras and routers -- to take   down major websites with DDoS (distributed denial of service)   attacks. Those attacks revealed that many IoT devices were   poorly protected from a type of threat that was previously   rendered obsolete on PC and mobile platforms.If additional attacks occur in 2017
column10: many organizations and   consumers could reconsider connecting everything to the Internet   of Things. However
column11: Cisco
column12: Symantec(NASDAQ: SYMC)
column13: and other security giants are already developing   new tools forsecuring IoT devices.Cisco's acquisition of IoT platform provider Jasper will help   its cybersecurity tools reach more connected devices
column14: and   Symantec helps  IoT device makers build more secure   products. These efforts could eventually make IoT devices as   secure as PCs or mobile devices.Privacy concernsAnother key concern about the IoT market is privacy. Back in   2015
column15: several German automakers expressed concerns about lettingAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google track their drivers'   activities in connected cars. That's why Audi
column16: BMW
column17: andDaimlerteamed up to buyNokia's HERE Maps as aGoogle Maps alternativelater that year.A recent murder case for which anAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) Echo might provide evidence also highlights the   consequences of installing ""always on"" IoT devices in homes.   Police and  prosecutors believe that audio files from the   device could help them crack the case
column18: but Amazon has refused to   turn over the files due to privacy concerns.Amazon Echo. Image source: Amazon.Privacy advocates believe that the case would set a precedent   for letting law enforcement agencies access smart home devices.   That would pose a problem for companies like Amazon
column19: Google
column20: andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column21: which thrive on ""learning"" more about their users   to produce targeted shopping and advertising experiences.The brewing IoT bubbleBullish forecasts about the IoT market have fueled a land grab   across the market. That stampede yielded some innovative products   like Amazon's Echo and Google Home
column22: but the market is also filled   with oddball devices like smart water bottles
column23: fitness trackers   for dogs
column24: connected umbrellas
column25: and smart tampons.The proliferation of frivolous devices suggests that a big   bubble in the IoT market is brewing
column26: similar to the dot-com   bubble of the late 1990s in which websites were launched for all   sorts of impractical purposes. And just like the dot-com bust of   2000
column27: an IoT bust could purge the market of the weaker players   and create a more refined field for leaders like Amazon and   Google to expand their IoT ecosystems.The upcoming ecosystem warBut as Amazon
column28: Google
column29: and other companies gradually advance   into our homes
column30: their ecosystems will start overlapping. Amazon   will leverage its market-leading position in e-commerce and   prisoner-taking Prime ecosystem to push devices like the Echo
column31: Dash buttons
column32: Kindle Fire
column33: and Fire TV into homes to widen its   moat against potential challengers.Google will leverage its knowledge of your search
column34: web   browsing
column35: location
column36: and ad-clicking histories to personalize its   smart home devices like Home. Its connections to Android
column37: the   most popular mobile OS in the world
column38: make its smart home platform   a practical extension of mobile devices for many users.But that's not all:Appleis trying to tether IoT devices to its HomeKit platform
column39: and   Facebook plans to launch its Jarvis home AI in the near future.   This means that the same battle that was previously waged across   websites
column40: mobile apps
column41: and hardware will rage on in your living   rooms next year.The key takeawaysThe Internet of Things is a fascinating new market
column42: but   investors should take companies' lofty IoT promises with a grain   of salt. Security and privacy concerns will still loom large next   year
column43: while hardware and software companies will clash over   competing ecosystems.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of Nov. 7

column1: Should You Buy Target Corporation (TGT) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;1/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWith 2016 having just ended
column4: Target Corporation(NYSE:TGT) investors were dealt another year of TGT stock underperforming theS&P 500and some of its peers; it's something that's become a bit too familiar for Target shareholders in recent years.Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Like all companies
column5: it has got its good points and bad points; any decision to buy Target stock
column6: or any stock for that matter
column7: should take into consideration everything positive and negative about it
column8: leaving the ultimate decision without doubt.makeArticleAd();Certainly
column9: a man being fatallystabbedon Christmas Eve in a Target store in Northern California isn't a positive. Nor is its mishandling of the company's policy change regarding itstransgendercustomers' use of its bathrooms and fitting rooms.While these aren't game breakers by any means
column10: you can't help but wonder if Target is permanently off its game.Heading into 2017
column11: investors are going to be looking at what kind of Christmas the discount retailer had and whether there's any point in continuing to give TGT stock the benefit of the doubt.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017Here are three pros and cons central to whether you should buy Target stock.Target Stock ProsReversion to the Mean:Target stock has beenbeatenby the S&P 500 in four out of the last six years and by its discount store peers in three of the last six - not exactly the kind of performance investors are looking for.However
column12: if you believe
column13: as I do
column14: that stocks tend to return to their historical averages after a period of underperformance or over performance
column15: than TGT stock is ready for a bounce.In 2015
column16: Target underperformed the index by 289 basis points; in 2016
column17: that spread will jump to almost 900 basis points
column18: a much worse result than the year before.Looking at Target's financials
column19: one shouldn't be nearly as pessimistic about its chances.Bottom Line:While the top line faced some issues in 2016
column20: the bottom line fared much better. In the first nine months of the year ended October 29
column21: Target's EBITDA increased by 1.6% year-over-year to$5.3 billionand generating an EBITDA margin of 10.9%
column22: 90 basis points higher than in the same period a year earlier.Especially positive was its third-quarter report which saw EBITDA profits increase by a robust 6.8% to $1.6 billion generating an EBITDA margin of 9.9%
column23: 130 basis points higher than in the same quarter a year earlier.Even CEO Brian Cornell was surprised.""We are very pleased with our third quarter financial results
column24: which reflect meaningful improvement in our traffic and sales trends and much stronger-than-expected profitability
column25: saidCornell. ""Favorable gross margin mix and efficient execution by our team drove third quarter EPS performance well beyond our guidance.""It might be facing some top-line comp struggles but it can still deliver the goods when it comes to profitability and if I can only have strong top-line or strong bottom-line growth
column26: I'll take profits over sales any day of the week.Digital:Its online sales grew by 26% in the third quarter contributing 0.7% comparable sales growth against a 1% decline in comparable sales at its physical locations. Without the online business growing
column27: Target's Q3 2016 sales would have looked even more anemic than they actually were.Looking on the bright side
column28: its digital channel grew by 60 basis points in the first nine months of 2016 and now represents 3.5% of Target's overall revenue.InvestorPlace contributor Chris Fraley made a good pointrecentlythat Target shoppers are younger than the typicalWal-Mart Stores
column29: Inc.(NYSE:WMT) shopper which suggests that when it comes to growing its online business
column30: Target's got a much greater upside than WMT does.More importantly
column31: Target customers are wealthier than WMT customers
column32: which means they'll be more inclined to shop online and pay for the last minute shipping costs.Target Stock ConsDigital:Say what? Didn't I just say that its online business was a positive for the company? I did indeed. But
column33: business isn't always black or white. More often it's gray. Target should be ashamed of itself for generating only 3.5% of its business from its digital business.Sure
column34: $2.6 billion sounds big until you realize that Target generates more than $73 billion a year in annual revenues. I've said it before and I'll say it again. If you're a big-time retailer
column35: online revenue has to represent at least10%of overall sales on annual basis.Holiday Revenue:According to S&P Global Market Intelligence
column36: 10 U.S. retailers were expected to generate66%of this year's holiday revenues. Target's on the list
column37: which is good news
column38: but it's only expected to account for 3.7% of the retail revenue generated by all of the retail constituents that make up the S&P 1500.Meanwhile
column39: WMT
column40: its biggest rival other thanAmazon.com
column41: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column42: is expected to grab 23% of the holiday revenue generated by retailers in the broader index.That's a good news
column43: bad news type of situation for Target.The good news is that it spreads Target revenue across 12 months of the year making it less vulnerable to economic downturns where customers cut back on Christmas spending.The bad news is that Christmas
column44: as Black Friday's history suggests
column45: can be the difference between a good year and a great year. On that note
column46: WMT is much more likely to please its shareholders at this time of year.Groceries:I'm a big fan of Phil Lempert whose weeklyfood reviewsat Supermarketguru.com I watch them religiously. Recently
column47: he was asked about the negatives associated with Target's move to capture some grocery business from WMT and others.""[Target grocery sections were placed] not in the front of the store
column48: but off to the side
column49: or in the back
column50: LemperttoldFox News. ""It's still going to have food over here
column51: and tires over there. And for some people that's great.""I totally can relate to that.Before Target pulled out of Canada
column52: its grocery section was at the back of the store's second floor
column53: far removed from anything. Target failed in Canada for a lot of reasons and that was certainly one of them.Canadians aren't particularly fond of having to hunt for their food unless actual hunting is involved.Lempert suggests that the grocery sections are getting better placements these days but the damage may already have been done.Bottom Line on Target StockTarget stock is cheaper than all of its discount peers
column54: grocery stores
column55: and even most department stores with the exception ofDillard's
column56: Inc.(NYSE:DDS) whose P/E ratio is a very-low 11.1 times earnings.Why Cisco Systems
column57: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Won't Be     Growing Anytime SoonIt currently yields 3.3% which is better than most of its peers. If you currently own TGT stock
column58: I'd be inclined to own it as long as the yield remains above 3%.With a decent balance sheet and a good nose for profits
column59: Target won't be the worst stock to own in 2017. In fact
column60: I think if the markets overall don't go in the tank
column61: Target stock could hit $90 in the next year
column62: a level it hasn't seen since … ever.As of this writing
