column5: and Broadcom has to continuously invest in R&D
column6: in order to introduce value-added products that provide a hedge against competition. These
column7: in turn
column8: limit its profitability to a certain extent.However
column9: Broadcom is expected to enjoy synergistic benefits from the merger with Avago
column10: which will boost its profitability. In addition
column11: the company maintains an efficient global supply chain with a variable
column12: low-cost operating model
column13: enabling it to maintain sustainable revenue growth and expand margins. Meanwhile
column14: the company has recently flagged off the shipments of BCM15000 (BCM15K) - its latest line of 16 nm heterogeneous knowledge-based processors (KBPs) - that have been designed keeping in mind the modern network infrastructure
column15: including core
column16: edge
column17: switches and routers
column18: for the data centers.What is Special About BCM15K?The new line of BCM15K 16nm KBPs are capable of integrating SRAM
column19: TCAM and algorithmic search technology

column21: capable of handling hyperscale data center applications
column22: network security appliances. These are optimized for the next generation of service provider networks.The BCM15K KBPs can deliver internet search speeds of up to 7.2 billion searches per second. These are capable of transferring data at a whopping speed of 1 terabit per second
column23: which is an impressive improvement over the older KBPs.What Does This Mean for Broadcom?Given the fast proliferation of bandwidth-intense applications
column24: like video streaming and cloud computing
column25: global internet traffic is estimated to shoot through the roof in the coming years. As per a CiscoCSCOreport
column26: by the end of this year

column30: the requirement for advanced routers and switches having high performance KBPs
column31: capable of handling such huge amounts of data
column32: is likely to witness strong demand
column33: going ahead.We note that the 16 nm KBPs are the world's first to provide Broadcom an advantage over its peers and augur well for the company over the long run.BROADCOM LTD PriceBROADCOM LTD Price|BROADCOM LTD QuoteZacks Rank and Key PicksAt present

column1: Dow 30 Stock Roundup: Boeing, GE Raise Dividends; ExxonMobil Gets New CEO;12/16/2016;"The Dow enjoyed a week of strong gains on rising expectations about the likely industry friendly policies of the Trump administration. About that …Don't Buy AMZN Stock!Stocks generally perform better when the market's expectations   are low. If expectations are high
column15: so is the risk of   disappointment. Bye-bye valuation. If the market expects little
column16: the chance of surprising on the upside is higher.The media and analysts fawn over Amazon stock. With a mean   analyst rating of 1.9 on Yahoo Finance (representing a ""buy"")
column17: opinion seems split between those who view Amazon stock as a   ""buy"" and those who view it as a ""strong buy."" Themean analyst targetfor Amazon stock is $929
column18: implying a 23% upside.When a the market overvalues stocks and expectations are   high

column23: which didpass $500 billionbefore the tech bubble burst).We are seeing such optimism with Amazon now. Ark Invest   CEOCatherine Woodand RBC Capital managing directorMark Mahaneymade such predictions this year. These bullish estimates   still fall short of venture capitalist Chamath Palihapitiya 's   forecast of Amazon asa $3 trillion company.WhenAmazon Web Services first launchedexpectations were low
column24: and AWS pleasantly surprised analysts.   Amazon would get laughed out of the room. Now
column25: the public feels   that Amazon will conquer the world.Amazon trades at 176 times earnings
column26: and its valuation looks   frothy on other measures as well. Even relative to Amazon's past   experience. The price-book ratio stands at 20.5
column27: above the   13-year median of 14.96 . The price-sales ratio
column28: at 2.85 hovers   above the median of 2.02
column29: and is not too far off the 13-year high   of 3.16 .Bulls might retort that the market has overvalued Amazon stock   for the past 15 years
column30: during which it still managed to soar from   $6 in August 2001 to $840. At any rate
column31: further margin expansion   seems improbable
column32: especially since Amazon is now a $360 billion   company.Investors Will Rediscover ValueHistorically
column33: value stocks generallyoutperform growth stocks. During times of lackluster growth in the real economy
column34: growth   stocks such as Amazon tend to do well. During times of fast   growth
column35: value stocksperform better.This trend reversed in the aftermath of the 2009 recession.   Growth returned
column36: yet value stocks continued to underperform. The   gap between the performance of the market and of value stockswidened since 2007. This may be due to low interest rates reducing the cost of   borrowing.And investors lost their patients with most stocks
column37: where   management plugged profits into buying back shares rather than   investing in future growth. Investors were willing to pay a   premium for growth
column38: since companies that were actually investing   in growth could not be easily found.However
column39: stock buybacks have decreasedin 2016. This should erode the growth premium commanded by stocks   such as Amazon. With high corporate profits and stock prices   relatively overvalued
column40: interest should further shift to value   stocks.Bottom Line on AMZN StockInstead of buying Amazon and paying a premium
column41: investors   should look for conservatively valued stocks. Stocks such as   Cisco andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) will benefit from investors rediscovering value stocks.Cisco trades at 14.5 times earnings
column42: 12 times forward earnings   and 2.4 times book value. Cisco holds $14.12 of cash per share
column43: a   whopping 46.3% of its market capitalization. This suggests that   the market expects little from Cisco
column44: giving it a higher chance   of surprising on the upside.Readers' Choice: Amazon.com
column45: Inc. (AMZN) Will       Be 2017's Best StockTech stocks like Cisco also welcome a rise in interest rates   since it will increase interest payments on their cash. So hold   off on buying growth stocks at stretched valuations like   AMZN stock.As of writing

column1: Cisco Receives Adverse Ruling Against Arista in California;12/16/2016;"Cisco Systems Inc.CSCOrecently received an adverse ruling in a copyright infringement lawsuit against close rival Arista NetworksANET. The jurors at the federal court in San Jose
column2: CA ruled that Arista did not commit any notable infringement on any Cisco patent and consequently
column3: would not pay any damages.makeArticleAd();Per Reuters ""The jury found that Arista infringed some of Cisco's copyrights. However
column4: jurors also said Arista proved that external factors
column5: other than Cisco's creativity
column6: dictated the design of Cisco's content.""Cisco plans to appeal the jury ruling. The company had been seeking nearly $335 million in damages over patent infringement of its command-line interfaces. The lawsuit is one of the two cases the company filed in 2014 that accuses Arista of infringing 14 patents.The ruling is particularly shocking for Cisco given the fact that it recently won a patent ruling against Arista at the U.S International Trade Commission (ITC). The ITC judge found Arista guilty of infringing Cisco's two patents. The ruling is scheduled for a review over the next few months by the ITC. If found guilty
column7: ITC has the authority to place a ban on import of Arista's products in the U.S.CISCO SYSTEMS Price and ConsensusCISCO SYSTEMS Price and Consensus|CISCO SYSTEMS QuoteCisco-Arista Rivalry IntensifiesThe rivalry between Cisco and Arista has intensified in recent years. Although Cisco holds more than 50% of the market share in the switching business
column8: Arista's meteoric rise has affected its top-line growth and profitability.Arista was founded in 2004 by two former Cisco executives. Per Reuter's data
column9: the company's annual revenue jumped 43% since its Initial Public Offering (IPO) in 2014 to $837 million at the end of 2015. Over the same period
column10: Cisco's total revenue increased 4.3% to $49.25 billion.Notably
column11: Cisco's switching revenues increased 5.3% in fiscal 2015
column12: but remained almost flat in fiscal 2016. Apart from Arista
column13: the company's switching business faces significant competition from the likes of Huawei
column14: Hewlett Packard EnterpriseHPEand Juniper NetworksJNPR.Stock Price OverviewShares of Cisco have underperformed the broader ZacksComputer Networksindustry on a six-month basis. While the stock has returned 5.8%
column15: while the industry gained 6.5%.The underperformance could be attributed to intensifying competition from several smaller players
column16: slowing order growth from service providers and challenges in the emerging markets.Notably
column17: in the trailing six-month period
column18: Arista
column19: Juniper and Hewlett Packard shares have gained 34.4%
column21: respectively.Zacks Rank & Key PickCisco currently carries a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). Arista with Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) is a better-ranked stock in the sector. column1: Best Stocks for 2017: CoreSite Realty Corp (COR) Stock Is the Internet’s Landlord;12/15/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsEditor's note: This column is part of our Best Stocks for     2017 contest. Brett Owens' pick for the contest isCoreSite Realty Corp(NYSE:COR).Data centers - big warehouses of supercomputers - run most of   the internet these days. When people talk about ""the cloud
column3: they're referring to these data centers doing most of the heavy   lifting when it comes to computing.makeArticleAd();These days
column4: more and more devices are online thanks to these   facilities. Your own computer
column5: smartphone
column6: TV and even your car   are likely to access the cloud. As a result
column7: demand for data   centers is exploding.Research and Markets projects facility construction to grow by   9% annually between now and 2019.Tech giantCisco Systems
column8: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) is more aggressive
column9: seeing 16% yearly growth in private data   centers between now and then. And its latest internet traffic   forecast is even more bullish
column10: projecting 20%-25% annual   increases in internet traffic and 52.7% gains in mobile   traffic.CoreSite Realty Corp(NYSE:COR) buys and develops private data center facilities
column11: and then   leases them back to its clients. Think of CoreSite as part   developer
column12: part landlord. It builds
column13: and then signs its 900-plus   clients (such asMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andVerizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ)) to long-term leases.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017The firm currently owns19 data centersin eight geographic markets
column14: including a significant amount in   California.CoreSite's Presence in Eight Major MarketsBusiness is booming. Margins are expanding too
column15: thanks to a   higher number of smaller clients who neither demand nor obtain   the price breaks the big guys look for.More and more clients means that no single one pays more than   5.7% of CoreSite's total annual rent. Its 10 largest represent   less than 30% of its business
column16: and they're locked into leases   that last another 40 months on average. This is good   diversification.COR stock has grown revenues by 17% annually and funds from   operation (FFO) by 26% over the last three years. (FFO is the   REIT equivalent of earnings per share). REIT payouts are powered   by FFO
column17: and rising FFO usually translates into rising   dividends.And CoreSite's payoutsare actually accelerating higher. The firm boosted its dividend by 20% two years ago
column18: and 26%   last year. And that's nothing compared to the hike it just   announced - a fat 51% dividend increase!Why AT&T Inc. (T) Stock Is a Dividend       King That Will Never FallThere's just one ""problem"" - its stock price can't keep up   with this rapid dividend growth! Shares are due to catch up in   2017:COR Stock Price Playing ""Catch Up"" to PayoutCoreSite pays a generous 4.3% yield. And it's likely to   announce another big dividend increase at the end of 2017. Buy   this internet ""pick and shovel"" play today - before its share   price closes this current gap and looks ahead to the next payout   boost.Brett Owens is the Chief Investment Strategist forContrarian Outlook. As of this writing
column19: he was long COR.More From InvestorPlace5 Stocks to Buy for December10 Ways to Make Money in the Market in       2017The postBest Stocks for 2017: CoreSite Realty Corp (COR)   Stock Is the Internet's Landlordappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should I Buy Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock? 3 Pros
column3: 3 Cons;12/15/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) has been a flop as a long-term investment. For the past decade
column6: the return has been an awful 11%. But lately
column7: the CSCO stock price has been getting some mojo. In fact
column8: the return for this year is the same as for the past 10 years!Source:Prayitno via Flickr (Modified)Note that the company's CEO
column9: Chuck Robbins
column10: came on board in the summer of 2015 and has not wasted much time in making some big changes
column11: such as with divesting non-core assets and investing more aggressively in growth markets like cloud computing and mobile. All in all
column12: there are signs that these moves are gaining traction.makeArticleAd();The competitive environment remains intense
column13: however
column14: and Cisco stock is feeling the pressure on the company's main networking business. It's not exactly easy to make the transition from hardware to software.That means Cisco stock could be a value or a risk right now. To see
column15: here's a look at the pros and cons:Cisco Stock ProsTransformation: A key part of the growth strategy has been aggressive buying. It helps that the company has a long history of dealmaking. In other words
column16: the company knows how to spot opportunities as well as integrate diverse cultures. There are also the critical advantages of Cisco's global customer base
column17: strong sales organization and trusted brand
column18: especially when dealing with mission-critical technologies.The 7 Best Monthly Dividend Stocks for 2017Yet this does not imply that the core networking business will somehow not be an important driver. If anything
column19: the long-term prospects still look bright. According to Cisco's research
column20: the amount of mobile traffic is forecasted to surge byeight times from 2015 to 2020
column21: representing a 53% compound annual growth rate. Some of the factors include mega-trends like streaming video
column22: artificial intelligence
column23: virtual reality and the Internet of Things.Although
column24: Cisco has been adapting to the swift changes in the market. To this end
column25: the company is focusing more on software-based approaches and also subscription business models.Strong Financials: CSCO continues to show discipline with its costs. During the summer
column26: the company announced a7% reductionin the workforce
column27: translating into about 5
column28: 500 jobs. So yes
column29: CSCO has continued to be a nice cash generator. For the latestquarter
column30: operating cash flows came to $2.7 billion. In all
column31: there is $71 billion in the bank. Something about this: $61 billion of that amount is in foreign accounts. That is
column32: if Donald Trump passes legislation for lower taxes to repatriate capital - which seems like a pretty good bet - this will certainly be good news for holders of Cisco stock. The company will be able to use the resources for acquisitions
column33: share buybacks and higher dividend payouts.Valuation: Cisco stock looks like a good value. Consider that the forward price-earnings ratio is only about 12. Oh
column34: and when subtracting out the cash
column35: the multiple is a mere 6. By comparison
column36: the forward P/E ratio forMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is 19 andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) sports a multiple of 14 times earnings. Finally
column37: CSCO has a decent dividend yield of 3.4%.Cisco Stock ConsCompetition: Cisco must fight tough rivals in various markets. In the security space alone
column38: there are standout operators likePalo Alto NetworksInc(NYSE:PANW) andFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT). But perhaps the biggest competitive threat is to the core networking business. There are the long-time U.S. companies
column39: such asJuniper Networks
column40: Inc.(NYSE:JNPR) andHewlett Packard Enterprise Co(NYSE:HPE)
column41: as well as next-gen firms likeArista Networks Inc(NYSE:ANET). At the same time
column42: CSCO must fight againstHuaweiand other low-cost Chinese firms.Yet there is another important factor: Cisco's potential customers becoming competitors! To lower costs and improve performance
column43: mega tech companies likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column44: NASDAQ:GOOGL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) have been building their own networking technologies.Lumpiness of Revenues:Cisco sells to many large enterprise customers across the world. While this means that purchase orders are generally large and have long terms
column45: there is always the risk of deals falling through or being delayed. Actually
column46: if there are even minor snags
column47: the impact on revenues can be significant. Interestingly enough
column48: this happened during the latestquarter. The company gave a tepid outlook
column49: with a forecast of revenues expected to fall by 2% to 4% in the current quarter. CSCO indicated that
column50: yes
column51: large network service provider customers have been pulling back on orders.Growth: For a company at the scale of CSCO
column52: it is natural for the top line to be fairly moderate. The problem is that - for some time - the growth path has been meager. As noted above
column53: a key factor is that the core networking business is under pressure from the competition. During the latestquarter
column54: the revenues from switching hardware fell 7% and there was a 6% drop in the router segment. But even in the more promising categories there are troublesome issues. In the latest quarter
column55: the cloud-based collaboration business suffered a 3% decline in revenues and even the wireless gear segment was off by 5%.Then again
column56: CSCO management may be having difficulties in managing the complexities of diverse businesses. In other words
column57: it may make sense for the company to think about focusing on a smaller number of operations.Bottom Line on Cisco StockAgain
column58: Cisco faces some tough challenges. But it is important to keep in mind that turnarounds take time. As Robbins noted in theQ1 report: ""You have to look at it over time
column59: and not just quarter to quarter.""Besides
column60: Cisco is betting on the right markets
column61: such as cloud computing and mobile. In fact
column62: there are already indications that the security segment could be a key driver. In the latest quarter
column63: revenues jumped by 11%. Then again
column64: CSCO has been smart to build security features into its networking systems.Why Alphabet Inc (GOOG) Stock Will Win Big With     WaymoFinally
column65: the valuation on Cisco stock is attractive and so is the dividend - and cash flows should remain substantial.So for investors looking for a stable play in the tech sector
column66: the pros outweigh the cons.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is a registered investment adviser representative (you   canvisit his siteto learn more about his financial planning services).He is also the author of various books on investing like All   About Commodities
column67: All About Short Selling and High-Profit IPO   Strategies.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column68: he did not hold a position in any of the   aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 WORST Stocks to Buy for 201710 Dangerous High-Yield Dividend Stocks to     AvoidThe postShould I Buy Cisco Systems

column1: Tech and Trump: Can They Find Common Ground in New York?;12/13/2016;"Tomorrow
column2: all eyes will be on New York City's Trump Tower as President-Elect Donald Trump sits down with Silicon Valley's top tech leaders. While the meeting's agenda has yet to be disclosed
column3: it is safe to assume themes like job creation
column4: immigration
column5: regulation
column6: and encryption will all be likely discussion topics.It's been well documented that the vast majority of Silicon Valley leaders opposed Trump during the presidential election
column7: with some helping and fund-raising for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton during her campaign. The Obama administration has acted largely favorable towards large tech corporations over the years
column8: from its ""net-neutrality"" policy-which requires internet providers to treat all web traffic equally-to its hands-off tactics to the tech industry's growing concentration of power.Joining Trump on his side of the table will be Reince Preibus
column9: his chief of staff
column10: son-in-law Jared Kushner
column11: and key transition team member Peter Thiel
column12: a tech investor who was one of the few Silicon Valley names to support Mr. Trump.Expected tech executives include:AppleAAPLChief Executive Tim CookFacebookFBChief Operating Officer andLean Inauthor Sheryl SandbergMicrosoftMSFTCEO Satya NadellaAmazonAMZNCEO andThe Washington Postowner Jeff BezosTesla MotorsTSLACEO Elon MuskAlphabetGOOGLCEO and Chairman Larry Page and Eric SchmidtIntelINTCCEO Brian KrzanichIBMIBMCEO Ginni RomettyOracleORCLco-CEO Safra CatzCiscoCSCOCEO Chuck RobbinsSurprisingly
column13: TwitterTWTRCEO Jack Dorsey will not be present at the meeting
column14: given how much Mr. Trump prefers the social networking platform over others.Many of these tech companies
column15: including Facebook
column16: Amazon
column17: Apple
column18: and Microsoft
column19: saw theirshares slidethe day after the election on worries that a Trump presidency would negatively affect their manufacturing and product distribution methods here in the U.S. and especially abroad.One area of common ground
column20: however
column21: could be tax reform. According to theWall Street Journal
column22: the president-elect is ""expected to promote corporate tax reform
column23: which
column24: depending on the details
column25: could enable U.S. tech companies to bring home hundreds of billions of dollars they currently hold offshore.""The meeting is set for 2:00pm on Wednesday afternoon
column26: and the world will be watching
column27: waiting to learn all the minute details
column28: hoping for
column29: at least
column30: some agreement on key issues
column31: and realizing that the tech industry and Mr. Trump may need more from each other than either is willing to give.Stocks that Aren't in the News…YetYou are invited to download the full

column1: Should You Buy Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;12/13/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO) stock went public this year at $15 on the New York Stock   Exchange on June 23
column4: andsurged 92%on the first day of trading
column5: closing at $28.79 a share. Twilio   stock went as high as $70 in late September before gravity set in   and brought it down to $29 a share.Source:Web Summit Via FlickrmakeArticleAd();You may not have heard of Twilio before.Twilioenables software developers to program voice and text   messaging.When you install WhatsApp orFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) Messenger on your phone
column6: you will get a text with an   authorization code
column7: and this is powered by Twilio. This promises   great value for businesses
column8: helping them stay in contact with   customers in the digital age.Twilio Stock ProsRapid Growth:Those who buy TWLO stock will buy into a fast-growing business.   Twilio is growing customer accounts and revenues at a fast pace.   As of Sept. 30
column10: Twilio had23
column11: 822 accounts. A  year later
column12: TWLO's accounts grew to 34
column14: a 44.6%   increase. Twilio grew revenue even faster
column15: at a 75% rate
column16: which   suggests that it's growing its revenue per user.  Growth   should remain steady as the company branches out intoenterpriseservices.High-Gross Margin:Twilio is not profitable as of yet
column17: but it should be in the   future. Twilio's enjoys a high gross margin at 55.6%
column18: which   indicates adurable competitive advantage. Also
column19: while Twilio has not yet managed a profit
column20: the operating   cash flow is positive
column21: with $4.4 million net cash from   operations.The 10 Biggest Stock Market Failures of       2016This indicates that the underlying business is sound.    Twilio is establishing itself as a premium brand with cloud   communications
column22: with a simple and easy to use platform giving   customers global reach. Twilio's support matters for apps such asUber
column23: freeing them up to concentrate on core services. TWLO adds value   to customers
column24: and this could translate into higher margins in the   future.Spread of Cloud Communications:Twilio should benefit from some tailwinds as cloud-based   communication becomes adopted.Appslike Uber need totext their usersfor things such as authentication or notifying them that their   car is ready. The development of apps will increase the need for   services provided by a company like Twilio.Twilio will also benefit as businesses keep in contact with   their customers via their smartphones. Retailers will want to use   text messages to alert their customers to special sales or   promotions. Instead of calling helplines and dealing with   annoying phone trees
column25: millennialsprefer to interact with businesses via text.Twilio Stock ConsCompetition-Real and Potential:Twilio faces a long list ofcompetitors
column26: includingCisco Systems
column27: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO)Tropo
column28: Sinch
column29: Plivo
column30: CallFire
column31: Vonage Holdings Corp.(NYSE:VG) Nexmo
column32: thinQ and Bandwidth.com. Twilio's competitors
column33: such as   Plivo
column34: Sinch
column35: and Nexmo
column36: generallycharge lessfor their services.Also
column37: telecom companies could compete with TWLO by offering   their own cloud API services.AT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) has offered developers anAPI platformsince 2012. Telecom companies will facecost and pricing pressuresin the years to come
column38: and might move toward this. These network   providers
column39: currently are suppliers to Twilio
column40: providing phone   numbers and sending text messages and calls. Things might get   difficult if they decided to compete with Twilio.Tech giantswith deep pockets and huge platforms such asAmazon.com
column41: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) and Facebook might decide to compete with Twilio as well.   Facebook Messenger appears to be moving towardbusiness communications
column42: which could threaten TWLO. Amazon began offeringpush notificationsin 2013
column43: a move toward communications.Valuation:Twilio stock's high valuation bakes in a great deal of growth
column44: and buying TWLO now carries a lot of downside risk. Currently
column45: Twilio stock trades at 11 times sales and 9 times book value   while operating at a loss. This means that the market has high   expectations for TWLO stock. If Mr. Market is disappointed
column46: those   who buy TWLO stock will suffer.Buying Twilio stock at such expensive prices is a risky   proposition. A s richly valued as Twilio stock may be
column47: however
column48: it was trading at an even higher multiple of sales in October.   Twilio stock reached its 52-week high at $70.96 on Sept. 28. That   represented a multiple of nearly 25 times sales
column49: a stratospheric   valuation.Lock-Up Period Expiring:When Twilio listed in June
column50: insiders and major shareholders   agreed to a lock-up period during which they would not sell their   shares. This lock-up period will expire onDec. 20
column51: and you can expect some holders to sell TWLO stock
column52: driving   down the price. ABloombergarticle summarized this in June:""For Twilio's biggest shareholder
column53: Bessemer Venture Partners
column54: the wait is almost over. It is positioned for a major pay day   once the lockup period expires in December
column55: allowing it to sell   some or all of its stake. The firm owns 25% of the company.""When Twilio stock announced a secondary stock offering in   October
column56: sharesplunged 14%
column57: so holders of TWLO stock should expect a dip next week.The TakeawayTwilio does seem to be a promising company with a bright   future. Buying TWLO stock at this stage seems very risky
column58: however
column59: and might not be suited to all investors.This Metric Could Push Facebook Inc (FB)       Stock to DoubleThe possible return is high
column60: but so is the risk. Most   investors should probably resist the temptation to buy in at such   an early stage.As of writing
column61: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of     the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Dangerous High-Yield Dividend Stocks to       Avoid5 Big Banks Offering the Best Canadian Stocks       to BuyThe postShould You Buy Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock? 3 Pros

column1: 3 Reasons Why Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Is a Buy Now;12/13/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTechnology companyCisco Systems
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) has been down in the dumps after its most recent earnings report showed that sales in the second quarter were expected to be down 2% to 4%. This news spooked investors and sent Cisco stock down nearly 5%.Source:Prayitno via Flickr (Modified)While CSCO stock certainly has its share of headwinds to worry about in the coming year
column5: it could make for a good long-term bet.makeArticleAd();Transition Time for Cisco StockOne of the reasons Cisco stock is struggling is that the company is in the midst of a transition period and is therefore experiencing some growing pains. CSCO is moving away from its traditional hardware product lines and toward other parts of its business that will remain relevant in the future. The firm is focusing on subscription-based services
column6: security and data centers.If you look at Cisco's results in those areas
column7: the company looks much more promising. The firm saw deferred product revenue for its subscription-based products rise by 48% to nearly $4 billion.10 Ways to Make Money in the Market in 2017The firm's routing and security segments also turned in promising figures
column8: suggesting that once the company completes its transition
column9: growth will continue.CSCO Shareholders Will Be RewardedAnother reason to add Cisco to your portfolio is the potential income that the stock brings to the table. Not only will investors benefit from long-term growth as its business develops
column10: but CSCO stock has a respectable 3.4% dividend yield that is likely to increase further.Cisco holds more than $60 billion overseas
column11: making it one of the biggest beneficiaries of President-elect Donald Trump's promise to rework the corporate tax regime and make it easier for companies to repatriate their funds. Trump has said that the corporate tax issues are at the top of his list of priorities and that he will address them during his first 100 days in office.While Cisco hasn't made any definite remarks about what the firm will do with the money once it is brought back
column12: some part of it will likely make its way back to shareholders in one way or another.Worries Are OverdoneThe market's panic following CSCO's earnings release has made Cisco stock a much cheaper buy. Of course
column13: investors have reason to question the firm's stability in light of the weaker-than-expected second-quarter guidance
column14: but those fears are overdone. Not only is the company in a period of transition
column15: but the firm's business as a whole has proven to be relatively stable.Cisco CEO Chuck Robinssaidthat shareholders ""have too much focus on individual quarters
column16: especially when you look at a service provider
column17: which is dominated by incredibly large accounts."" He believes that ""you have to look at it over time
column18: and not just quarter to quarter."" And he's absolutely right. Cisco may not have a stellar second quarter
column19: but the firm's improvement in key transition areas is a signal that business isn't bad.Cisco stock isn't without its challenges - the company will struggle if macroeconomic conditions deteriorate and customers are less willing to spend on new systems.Should I Buy Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock? 3     Pros
column20: 3 ConsAnother big concern is that the firm's shift toward services puts it in direct competition withAmazon.com
column21: Inc.'s (NASDAQ:AMZN) Amazon Web Services.The Bottom LineDespite those headwinds
column22: Cisco stock appears ready for a rally and makes for a good buy for long-term investors. Those who are able to wait out a few rough patches will be rewarded when the firm makes its full transition
column23: and the company's dividend payments and the promise of repatriation make the wait that much more bearable.As of this writing
column24: Laura Hoy did not hold a position in any   of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Best Investments for 20175 Stocks to Buy for DecemberThe post3 Reasons Why Cisco Systems
column25: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Is a Buy Nowappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 2 Must-Know Investing Tips From Clayton Christensen;12/13/2016;"Motley Fool Explorer advisor Simon Erickson recently spoke with Clayton Christensen
column2: who is the world's pioneer and foremost thinker in the theory of disruptive innovation. (You can listen to their conversation above
column3: or scroll down below for the full transcript.)makeArticleAd();Christensen was the first to coin the term ""disruption"" in his 1997 book
column4: The Innovator's Dilemma. Disruption refers to how smaller
column5: nimbler organizations can introduce new products and services that overthrow larger
column6: more established competitors. The theory of disruption has influenced many in the business world and inspired several Motley Fool recommendations
column7: such asSplunk(NASDAQ: SPLK)  andVeeva Systems(NYSE: VEEV) .Christensen's academic theories are incredibly powerful. But perhaps even more impressive is that he's used them to achieve significant investing returns. He claims his personally managedRose Park Advisorshas returned an average of 36% annuallysince its founding in 2007. How has he managed to achieve these great returns? He shared two of the key qualities he looks for in his investments.IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGESBe disruptiveWall Street underestimates disruptive companies' ability to move upmarket to increase their sales and profits over time. Be on the lookout for companies whose products are initially inferior to those of the incumbents but are winning customers by introducing different forms of value. ThinkSouthwest Airlines(NYSE: LUV) offering lower-cost regional flights
column8: orNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) offering DVDs by mail.Focus on jobs to be doneCompanies that maximize customers' experience are difficult to displace
column9: which becomes the true source of a competitive advantage. Watch for companies that nail a nagging customer problem with an incredibly effective solution. That can eventually lead to their brands becoming synonymous with the solution. Examples include Ikea's easy-to-assemble furniture
column10: Intuit's(NASDAQ: INTU)  TurboTax product
column11: andStarbucks'(NASDAQ: SBUX)  coffee.Christensen elaborated on each of these during a recent interview. Hear him share his thoughts about the following topics:An overview ofCompeting Against Luck(0:00-2:27 minutes in)Industries undergoing disruption (2:28-5:54)How to build a competitive advantage (5:55-11:30)How companies should define their market (11:31-18:15)How we should think about big data (18:16-21:09)Two specific things to look for in investing (21:10-23:16)To conclude our discussion
column12: he played ""Buy
column13: Sell
column14: or Hold"" (23:17)
column15: making calls on several disruptive concepts
column16: includingUberand Bitcoin.Want a few more disruptive investment ideas? Motley Fool Explorerprovides a deep-dive into four companies each month
column17: tied together by a relevant investment theme. Explorer is now open to new members
column18: and you can get a 30-day trial (with a full membership-fee back guarantee)using this link.TranscriptErickson:Clay
column19: can you start with giving us a brief overview of your book
column20: Competing Against Luck? For those who haven't read it
column21: yet
column22: why did you write this book and what was the overview that you're getting at with it?Christensen:Well
column23: it's something that I have seen in my life
column24: and especially as I've tried to help people be better managers. Every time we put a new [product] into the market
column25: we think that our product will be successful. We've done a lot of study of the market and figured out what the competitors are and everything else. So every time we put a product into the market
column26: we think it will be successful.But the reality is that nearly 80% of those products that we think will be successful fail financially in the market
column27: so I [wondered] if innovation is intrinsically unpredictable. [That] you have to roll the dice many times in order to get a few wins
column28: but you can't predict which number will come up on top. Or [whether there is] some other explanation for the unpredictability that we see.And what we decided is the way people like me teach our students [at business schools] how to think of the structure of markets [means] we've created the problem ourselves
column29: and we concluded that unpredictability is not inherent to innovation. We can actually be successful much more frequently than we thought.So that was where the question came from
column30: originally
column31: and the reason why we gave it this title
column32: Competing Against Luck. That most of us think that innovation entails competing against luck
column33: but we don't think that that necessarily is the case.Erickson:Clay
column34: in the book you said it's a book you've been writing for the past 20 years
column35: just in thinking about the business world. We know that you've spent a career molding the theory of disruption. I wanted to ask how your thoughts about disruptive innovation [have] changed over the past two decades.Christensen:Well
column36: they've changed a lot
column37: and I'm glad that they did. You know
column38: never has a good theory just emerged in a perfect state from the person who developed it at the beginning. It's almost always [that] a theory at the beginning [is] half-baked and incomplete. The way a theory gets to have power is that people who read and use it have to find anomalies or things that the theory can't explain. And the only way the theory gets better is if the people who are the authors of the theory are willing to accept the anomalies as an opportunity to improve it.So that's what we did. Some of the anomalies [were] pointed out to us by other academics like us; but by far the most useful ones have been from our MBA students here at HBS. I teach a course that's broadly regarded
column39: and I [tell] the students [the following]
column40: as they prepare for a case (because we do it all by the case method).I say
column41: ""You've got three assignments to prepare for every case. The first one is there's a theory that we use in every session of every class
column42: and these are theories about management that emerge from our work or the work of others.""And then the second is
column43: ""You have a case
column44: and I want you to put the theory on like a set of lenses and examine today's case. The question is can you explain why and how this company got in the situation that it's in through the lens of that theory? And then
column45: given that
column46: what does the theory say the management ought to do to resolve the problem?""Then the third one is
column47: ""I want you to come to class prepared to tell Clay Christensen what's wrong with this theory.""And so that way
column48: year after year
column49: day after day
column50: more than 100 students [turn] their brains around to show Clay what it can't explain. And I'm really grateful to them that they took it seriously
column51: and they really were trying to find out what the theory can't explain. So as a consequence
column52: the theory of disruption and the theory of jobs to be done
column53: and a few others
column54: really are much better as a result of [having gone] through this crucible.Erickson:Are there certain things
column55: Clay
column56: which keep coming up? You said that students were always [asking] what's wrong
column57: or how can the initial theory of disruption [be changed]. Are there certain themes that continually came up in your class?Christensen:Yes. Very often they would come up with an example of an industry that didn't get disrupted. Has not ever been disrupted. And maybe the question is [whether] the theory only [applies] to a few situations. For example
column58: hotels for many years have just never been disrupted. Holiday Inn comes up in the 1950s at the low end of every market
column59: but 40 years later
column60: the Holiday Inn has not moved upmarket. The corporation bought Crowne Plaza and part of other businesses at different points in the constellation of hotels
column61: but the Holiday Inn
column62: itself
column63: still is at the bottom of the market. And in a similar way
column64: higher education hasn't been disrupted and we just couldn't explain it.And then as we worked with a couple of our students for their paper
column65: we realized that in describing the theory of disruption
column66: I had always assumed that the trajectory of performance improvement that innovating companies provide [means] they keep introducing better and better products. I assumed that it always had the same trajectory or slope. And it turns out that every market has a different trajectory of improvement [and so I did some studies].The first study about disruption [centered on] the disk drive market and boy
column67: technology moved at a rapid rate in that market. So a company would come in at the bottom of the market and in about eight years they're in the top. I described that market as a place where [00:09:39]. Their whole life was measured in a few years.But then I [reviewed] our study of the steel industry
column68: where the mini-mills came in at the bottom of the market. It took about 50 years for the industry to get turned upside down. And so the rate of technological change has a big impact on how long an industry will go without being disrupted.Then we realized that in hotels and higher education
column69: the trajectory of technological improvement has been zero. There just weren't any new business models that have occurred. And then we realized that oh
column70: my gosh
column71: but wait a minute. Airbnb in hotels is an innovator and a new business model
column72: and they very rapidly have disrupted a significant chunk of hotels. And online learning
column73: in a similar way
column74: is a new business model [and] in just a few years it's turned upside down higher education in many ways.So we realized that when we see disruption not occurring in an industry
column75: the result of that is the impact of technological change differs industry by industry
column76: and it isn't the case that it happens in some industries and not in others; but rather
column77: it occurs when [the pace of] technological progress changes.Erickson:I'll follow that up
column78: perhaps
column79: with a question about competition
column80: because you say that the pace of change differs in different industries
column81: but the investing community has typically looked at the incumbents (the companies that have the highest margins or the strongest cash flows) as a sign of a competitive advantage against others.But then from a lot of your research
column82: we've seen several of these companies are the same ones that get disrupted
column86: because of those market shifts and then competition coming in. How can we tell if a competitive advantage is actually sustainable?Christensen:There are two ways
column87: and the most important is that the theory of disruption predicts that if you have an incumbent leader and an entrant company wants to attack them
column88: if that entrant company tries to attack them head-on by winning the best customers of the established leaders
column89: the theory says that the incumbents are going to turn around and try to beat off the entrants and use its resources in powerful ways to beat the entrants.And the theory says that in almost every case
column90: the incumbent wins when an entrant tries to win through what we call sustaining innovations
column91: and sustaining innovations make good products better. And if somebody comes in at the bottom of the market with a product that is so much more affordable and accessible that a whole different population of people can now have access to and use a product that historically was beyond their reach
column92: almost always the incumbent leaders fail.And it has nothing to do with the power of the incumbent or with a lack of power of the entrant; but rather the incumbent leaders don't want to go after it. That's the essence of disruption. And so your question is answered by disruption.Erickson:Yes
column93: it does. It sounds like the competitive advantage of an incumbent for sustaining innovation can't really be understood against a disruptive company that's playing at the lower end [using a] different value in the industry
column95: and it is very predictable. And what's interesting
column96: in the question that you asked
column97: is why do investors not get it?Erickson:Right.Christensen:And it's a very interesting question. My son Matthew and I founded an investment company called Rose Park Advisors. It's been operating for about 12 years
column99: where we invest in just publicly traded companies. But the policy is if it's disruptive
column101: and if they are the incumbent and an entrant goes after them
column102: we'll short them occasionally. The greater return on that portfolio for 12 years
column104: is 36% on a compounded annual rate of return
column105: and without any shorting or hedging (occasionally we short)
column106: but it's not hedged or leveraged. But 36% compounded annual rate of return.Erickson:That's incredible.Christensen:And the ability to do that is known. We publish everything. But investors seem to be a little bit arrogant
column108: and not humble to listen to an academic theory in practice.Erickson:I think it's very interesting when you think about the concept of competitive moats like Warren Buffett has described for decades
column109: versus Jeff Bezos saying your margin is my opportunity. Most of the companies that are capturing all that value are the ones that are destined to be in the sights of disruptive competitors
column111: that's right. And I mentioned there's another type of innovation in which the incumbent can succeed
column112: and that is when the company follows [the jobs to be done in this new book that we published]. And when the incumbent leader has organized himself around developing products to get a job done for customers
column113: it's very hard for incumbents to win that game; because in many ways it makes disruption impossible to accomplish. So that's why we wrote the book. It took us
column116: but we finally were confident that what we were saying was true.Erickson:I wanted to highlight that a little bit - the jobs to be done - because that's one of the real themes of competing against luck in your book. Customers are hiring those companies to perform jobs that lead to progress for them. Another thing the investment community has typically done is categorized companies
column118: or selling products that are of a similar function. But based on this jobs to be done theory
column120: do you think there's a more effective way for companies to really define their own market and then also their competitor's?Christensen:Oh
column121: absolutely. I think that the way you describe it is exactly right - that the way managers and investors think of the structure of markets is the world is structured by product
column123: or customer category. Except that that's not the way that [the world] appears to a customer.Rather what happens - the way the world appears to a customer - is every day
column125: stuff happens to them. Some jobs that arise in our lives are just little
column126: incremental jobs that happen to us every day
column128: breakthrough innovations. But when a job arrives in our lives
column129: it forces us to go out and find something
column131: or use something to get the job done. And understanding the job is what's critical.So it's a silly example. Here I am talking to you. I'm 64 years old
column134: unfortunately. I married a wonderful wife
column135: fortunately. The youngest of our five children
column138: unfortunately. And I have all other characteristics and attributes about myself.But none of my characteristics or attributes have yet caused me to pick upThe New York Timestoday. Now
column139: there might be a correlation between my characteristics and the propensity that I would have to buyThe New York Times. Those characteristics don't cause me to do that
column140: nor do our characteristics and attributes cause us to buy any product or service.But rather what causes us to buy something is we have jobs to do
column141: and when we have a job
column142: we've got to find a product that gets the job done. And it's understanding [what the job is] that allows you to harness the causal mechanism behind that choice. That's why we decided predictability was so important to focus on
column143: because if you harness the causal mechanism around a choice
column144: you can predict the future quite well. Do you want me to give you an example?Erickson:Sure.Christensen:The third of our five children
column146: unfortunately went to Stanford to get a Ph.D. a few years ago
column147: and after he had been there for about a week
column148: he called us up and said
column150: I found my apartment and I need to furnish my apartment tomorrow."" And what had happened for Michael is he realized he has a job to do
column151: and that is he needs to furnish [his] apartment tomorrow.So I'll ask you
column152: Simon. When I described for you this job that Michael had to do (that he furnish the apartment tomorrow)
column153: is there a place where you could go to buy what they're selling to get that job done?Erickson:Sure.Christensen:Where would you go to get the job done?Erickson:Oh
column154: I would try to find whoever has got the best posters of the college I'm going to
column156: something right by the university that's close and that has everything that you need
column157: as quickly as possible.Christensen:And what company would that be?Erickson:Oh
column158: I believe that you referred toIkeaa couple of times as that company
column160: because it's organized around that particular job to be done. And the reason I refer to it is because anybody who's thoughtful about their lives realizes that that name pops into their mind and they have never been disrupted. In fact Ikea has been rolling its business model out around the world for 50 years
column161: and nobody has disrupted them.And it's not that they have any secrets
column162: and it's not that there's no money in it. Their owner is the third richest guy in the world
column163: and yet they have no competition. And the reason is that everybody else that sells furniture is organized around types of furniture. And if I want to compete against those guys
column164: I just have to make better products than they do.But Ikea is organized around the job to be done
column165: and if you do it in that way
column166: then you can describe all of the experiences - in purchase
column167: in use - that Ikea provides in order to nail that job perfectly. And because they organized themselves in a very unique and complicated way
column168: it's very hard for competitors to compete with them. So that's just an example of my thinking about the market in terms of the jobs to be done rather than products as a useful distinction.Erickson:And Clay
column169: you refer to a lot of those companies as purpose brands
column170: correct? The companies that become just synonymous with those jobs. Whether it's Ikea
column173: it's the company that immediately when I think of it
column174: I think of why I would go to that company
column175: and it's immediately apparent in my head
column176: right?Christensen:Absolutely right. Absolutely right. V8 Juice.Disney(NYSE: DIS) . There are really important ones all around you
column177: when you look at it.Erickson:Back to the mention you had of correlation versus causality. We're kind of in the buzzword age of big data and artificial intelligence
column178: right now...Christensen:Yes...Erickson:...where you've got tech that can quantitatively search through a ton of data. It's trying to find correlation between those input factors
column179: but it seems like it misses the qualitative aspects that you've described of what the job is to be done
column180: or what it is a customer wants to hire me to do. Is there some way that we could be using big data more effectively?Christensen:That's a great question
column182: it bothers me a lot that people can think that they can dispense with thinking and simply have somebody else develop an algorithm that will provide the answer. I think a much better way is to put data aside for a minute and try to figure out what causality is. And you can't look at causality - you can't observe causality - when you've got 200
column183: 000 points of data in a database.And [in] the case [of] physical sciences
column186: to observe things you have to look at an N of 1. And if you can explain what happens in that N of 1
column187: then you can try to explain what happens when the N is two and grow it that way. And data can be very valuable if you use it to validate or show anomalies to a theory.But the data doesn't yield the theory itself. The development of a theory comes from an N of 1
column188: and then the validation of the theory
column189: or identifying anomalies to the theory is where data occurs that can be useful. And so big data
column191: [has] nothing big about it. That's the wrong categorization scheme.Erickson:It sounds like we have the wrong buzzword for big data. It should be go back to small data.Christensen:Yes
column193: one of the other things you talk about in the book is organizational structure. You pointed out a study done by
column196: [which showed that] two-thirds of corporate reorganizations are actually destroying value and not accomplishing what they intended to do.Christensen:Uh-huh.Erickson:Why is it that businesses are so bad at reorging?Christensen:Boy
column197: that's a great question. To me
column198: the answer is there's a difference between interdependent and modularity in the architecture of systems. Some architectures are interdependent; that is
column200: it affects the way all of the other elements of the system have to change
column201: as well. You have to do everything in order to do anything. And if you change one thing
column203: so you have to understand the whole system.And a modular system is one which each component interfaces with the other components in standardized ways. And when you have a modular system
column204: it's real easy to map that architecture onto an org chart that you can stick up on a wall
column205: because somebody has to be responsible for [every component]: for making it
column210: and so on. So the organizational chart on the wall reflects the architecture of the product or service. And when you change the org chart
column211: you have to develop a different modular architecture so that people can snap the pieces together in a different way.In a product that is interdependent
column212: then an org chart almost always creates more problems than they resolve
column213: because if you change one thing
column214: you have to change everything. And I think the key reason for your question (why [organizational] changes eliminate more value than [they create]) is managers don't take the time to understand the nature of the interdependencies of what they're trying to implement. It's a complicated problem.Erickson:[Is a fair summary of that]
column216: that markets and products change perhaps faster than organizational structure does?Christensen:Yes
column217: that's a great way to frame it. That's a great way to frame it.Erickson:Yes
column218: a great point. And the last question before I'd like to get in a game of Buy
column220: Clay. The last question before that
column222: is our audience at The Motley Fool is primarily individual investors. You mentioned a bit about your investing
column223: and I wondered if there were specific things that you look for when you're buying stocks or you invest in companies. Are there certain attributes that you personally are looking for as an investor?Christensen:The answer is yes. Number one
column224: are they disruptive?Erickson:I'm not surprised by that.Christensen:Because if you invest in disruptive companies
column225: they move up upmarket in very predictable ways. The analysts don't understand that
column226: and so a disruptive company surprises the investors over and over again - that there is more growth in the product or that company than they thought.Because what the analysts see at the bottom of the market is products
column227: and they don't realize there's a trajectory of improvement over time that surprises the investors over and over again. And so
column228: that's the way you define what is disruptive. It starts at the bottom [and] they move up. And the analysts are too arrogant. They don't understand the theory
column229: and so they're surprised over and over again.And in a similar way
column230: if you focus on [investing in] companies that are organized around a job to be done
column231: they can be the incumbents in an industry
column232: but they can't be disrupted because they're providing all the experiences that customers need to have. They can't be disrupted. So those are two rules that we follow when we make investments.Erickson:OK. Clay
column234: we have to have a little bit of fun. We wanted to spot you up with game of Buy
column236: or Hold.Christensen:All right.Erickson:Not talking specific companies
column237: but I'm going to throw you a couple of concepts in a lightning round kind of format where you can conceptually buy
column239: or hold them based on your level of conviction in their future relevance. So larger role in the future is a buy
column240: less of a role is a sell
column241: and more data (you don't really know) is a hold. Are you ready?Christensen:Tell me those rules again.Erickson:So a buy would be you are very bullish on this concept in the future.Christensen:Buy
column243: hold. OK.Erickson:Are you ready?Christensen:Yup.Erickson:Topic one. Buy
column245: or hold in the big data era companies continuing to use small focus groups for market research?Christensen:Buy.Erickson:Why is that?Christensen:Because I already gave the answer to that question.Erickson:Yes
column246: fair enough on that. Topic two. Buy
column248: or hold accountable care organizations and just organizations that focus more on outcomes rather than procedural reimbursements as a part of the US healthcare system?Christensen:I'd say hold. I'm not sure I could answer your question because the way you frame it
column249: I think is not consistent with itself. Accountable care organizations
column252: because I don't think that they are organized in a way that help companies solve problems for customers. Sometimes an accountable care organization collectively develops enough clout that the bigger players can be bigger. But as a solution to healthcare problems
column253: I'd pretty strongly give it a sell.Erickson:Next up
column256: or hold the future of traditional four-year universities?Christensen:That's a sell.Erickson:Why is that?Christensen:Including the Harvard Business School.Erickson:The reason for that? [Are you thinking] more online learning? What's the direction you're taking?Christensen:That's right. We have not spent any energy at all trying to control the costs of higher education
column257: and tuition has increased at a faster rate than the cost of healthcare
column258: for example. It is so expensive that it is very hard for a graduating student to get a job in an operating company anymore
column259: because operating companies can't pay the salary that our graduating students need in order to pay off their student loans. So our students have to take a job with venture capitalists
column261: or consulting firms. But operating companies can't hire people with a Harvard MBA. That's why it's a sell.Erickson:Fair enough. The next one is buy
column263: or hold Uber?Christensen:Hold. Their model has been a wonderful model
column264: and it's been [disruptive in the past]
column265: in that its business model is hard for a taxi to put their arms around. But I think that model is understood
column267: and it's not clear how many other industries can be Uberized. There might be some
column268: but there are lot of interdependencies that I [still] need to think it through.Erickson:Well
column269: I'll be looking for ""uberize"" in the dictionary
column270: because I'm pretty sure that's going to be a verb that's going to get a lot of attention.Christensen:No kidding.Erickson:Last one for you
column273: or hold the future of digital currencies such as bitcoin?Christensen:That's a buy in a different way than many people think. The problem is that there is so much money around the world. The graduates of our business schools become leaders of large corporations and they spend their energy on what we call efficiency innovation; that is
column274: squeezing more and more free cash flow out of the companies that they run. And as a result of that
column276: and the cost of money is essentially zero. So the essence of what a bank historically has been becomes obviated
column278: when the cost of capital is zero.So the very concept of data - the different definition of capital needs to change. And I don't know what that is
column279: but the bitcoin is a concept that I think is something I would invest in.Erickson:Clayton Christensen is the Kim B. Clark Professor at Harvard Business School. He's twice been named the world's most influential business thinker in a biennial ranking conducted by Thinkers50 and he is the author of the recent bookCompeting Against Luck. Clay
column280: this was a lot of fun. Thanks for being with us this afternoon.Christensen:Oh
column281: it's been fun to do it. Call me again. I like to keep buying and selling things.Erickson:That is the most fun we always have
column284: and Hold at the end.Christensen:All right. Congratulations.Erickson:I really enjoyed it. Thanks very much
column285: Clay.Christensen:You're welcome.[End]Simon Ericksonowns shares of Netflix

column1: Our 3 Favorite Stocks to Invest in the Internet of Things;12/12/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.The Internet of Things (IoT) describes the growing network of   connected sensors and devices
column2: and the increasing connectivity is   already having significant impacts at the consumer
column3: enterprise
column4: and public levels. Research firmGartnerexpects the number of IoT devices to grow from 6.4 billion in   2016 to nearly 21 billion in 2020
column5: and estimates that more than   half of new business systems and processes will utilize the   Internet of Things by the end of that period. Growth in device   connectivity and machine-to-machine communication is creating an   explosion of new data
column6: and this information is being sorted and   analyzed to produce insights that can improve efficiency and   drive substantial economic value.makeArticleAd();With the Internet of Things triggering big shifts in commerce   and industry
column7: some of the companies leading the push are poised   to be major beneficiaries. In order to help investors ride   the trend
column8: we've asked three Motley Fool writers to pick their   top Internet of Things stock. Read on to learn whyAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column9: Verizon(NYSE: VZ)
column10: andCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) made the list.Buy the network
column11: not the device makersBrian Feroldi(Verizon):There's no doubt that the Internet of Things trend offers   tremendous growth opportunities for all kinds of tech companies.   However
column12: I personally do not think that buying an electronic   hardware manufacturer is the right way to play the trend. The   reason? Huge growth potential will attract a lot of   competition. Over time
column13: that competition will erode away profit   margins
column14: leaving investors with poor returns.For that reason
column15: I think it is a far smarter idea to buy   shares of a cellular network provider like Verizon Communications   instead. After all
column16: those billions of devices that are expected   to come online will need access to a mobile network in order to   work. That provides Verizon with a great new avenue for growth in   the years ahead.You might not be aware of it
column17: but Verizon is already   benefiting from the IoT trend. Last quarter
column18: Verizon's IoT   revenue grew by 24% to $217 million
column19: making it one of the   company's fastest-growing divisions. Sure
column20: that's still just a   drop in the bucket when compared with the company's wireless and   wireline revenue
column21: but over time IoT revenue holds promise to grow   like wildfire. That could help propel the company's   long-term revenue and profit growth.Verizon certainly believes that the IoT represents a huge   opportunity
column22: which is why it is investing accordingly. Earlier   this year
column23: Verizon bought Telogis and Sensity Systems
column24: both of   which will add to the company's IoT product offering. Over time I   think investors should expect even more bolt-on acquisitions to   ensure that it maintains a strong foothold in this important and   growing market. Throw in a dividend yield that tops 4.6% and I   think Verizon is a great way for conservative investors to get   their IoT exposure.An unlikely leaderChris Neiger(Amazon.com):The e-commerce giant probably isn't the first company you   think about when talking about the Internet of Things
column25: but I   think it has a few key advantages in the space.First
column26: Amazon is already a leader in the consumer IoT space.   Its Echo speaker is paired with its robust virtual assistant
column27: Alexa
column28: to power everything from turning on the sprinklers to   ordering an Uber. This may not seem earth-shattering right now
column29: but Amazon continues to open up Alexa to developers to connect   the virtual assistant to even more devices and tasks. As it does   that
column30: I think it'll continue to lead in the house-automation   space.The second advantage is the company's Dash Replenishment   Service (DRS). This built-in software allows home electronics   like washing machines to automatically order more detergent from   Amazon's website when they notice that they're running low.   Automation is a key ingredient in the IoT
column31: and Amazon is making   this a reality and already hasGeneral Electric
column32: Samsung
column33: andWhirlpoolon board. DRS may take a while to take off
column34: but as it does   you'll see Amazon lock customers -- and device makers -- even   further into its retail ecosystem.And last but not least
column35: Amazon's true IoT opportunity comes   from its cloud server business
column36: Amazon Web Services (AWS). It's   no secret that Amazon's AWS business is booming
column37: bringing in $3.2   billion in the third quarter of this year
column38: and $11 billion over   the past four quarters. And the company is leveraging that   success for the IoT as well
column39: by pushing its AWS IoT platform. AWS   IoT allows developers to interact with connected devices and   helps them collect and analyze data. With so many companies and   developers already using AWS for their hosting needs
column40: I think   it'll be natural for them to migrate to AWS IoT as more devices   come online.Amazon's lead in the cloud-computing space
column41: along with its own   IoT platform
column42: means that the company is poised to benefit from   the nearly 50 billion IoT devices that will be online by 2020.   Even if Amazon fails in the consumer IoT space
column43: its AWS offerings   in the IoT space will benefit the company for years to come.Own the company that owns the networkKeith Noonan(Cisco):Overcoming security and standardization issues that arise from   moving data between disparate devices and networks is one of the   main obstacles to the evolution of connectivity
column44: and no company   is better suited to deal with it than Cisco. The company's   Internet of Things and Applications Group vice president
column45: Rowan   Trollope
column46: recently said that the company can deliver many of the   connectivity and security needs brought on by IoT because ""it   owns the network."" There's some simplification involved in that   statement
column47: but Cisco's leading position in networking means that   the company is going to have a formative impact on the   progression of IoT.The company is in the process of giving device makers tools   and applications-programming interfaces to help with   standardization and to cut down on security threats that could   limit the progression of the tech. Cisco is taking these steps to   get the big players on board with its network and certification   process in order to facilitate its transition to a more   subscription-based business model. This year
column48: the company   purchased Jasper Technologies for $1.4 billion in order to   bolster its service offerings and fast-track its position in IoT   connectivity and analytics platforms.The big connectivity push also presents opportunities that   could lift Cisco's hardware businesses. The networking giant has   partnered withEricsson
column49: Intel
column50: and Verizon for the development of a 5G mobile router
column51: and   could benefit from demand for routers and switches that are   tailored for customers' IoT needs.Priced at just 12.5 times forward earnings estimates
column52: with   roughly $40 billion in cash and short-term investments on the   books
column53: and a 3.5% dividend yield
column54: Cisco stockoffers an inexpensive valuation
column55: hefty returned income
column56: and a   forefront position in the Internet of Things.10 stocks we like better than Verizon     CommunicationsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column57: it can pay to listen. After all
column58: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column59: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column60: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Verizon Communications     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of Nov. 7

column1: Bull of the Day: Acacia Communications (ACIA);12/12/2016;"CouldAcacia Communications(ACIA)
column2: the hottest IPO of 2016
column3: still offer significant upside in 2017?makeZacksArticleAd();Many investment banks believe so. And I think the odds are pretty good too. That's why I'm accumulating shares of Acacia over 45% off of its all-time highs above $125.This maker of optical interconnect products for cloud infrastructure operators and content and communication service providers -- think customers like Cisco (CSCO)
column4: Facebook (FB)
column5: Amazon (AMZN)
column6: Verizon (VZ) and Germany's ADVA -- delivered its second earnings report as a public company in early November and the analysts welcomed the outlook.The consensus for 2017 EPS shot up over 22% from $2.34 to $2.87
column7: making it a Zacks #1 Rank Strong Buy again.For a newly public company like this
column8: the analysts will be slow to raise expectations too high until they get to know management and the company's execution history. Since 2016 saw nearly 100% sales growth for Acacia
column9: many doubt this can be repeated and so the consensus projection right now is for 33% revenue growth.But at forward EPS of $2.87
column10: the stock is trading at under 25X. For 33% top line growth
column11: that's growth at a very reasonable price.And my sense is that sales will grow faster because Acacia's optical networking products will be in high demand as the cloud buildout demands more 100G speed. The 100 Gigabit Ethernet protocol is designed to deliver data at 100 gigabits per second.Here's a chart of Acacia's rise to investing stardom since the May IPO around $30 and the subsequent 62% fall back to reality...The Acacia OpportunityThe stock has pulled back quite a bit
column12: but the growth story is still intact. Let's look at five ""technical"" facts first as they tell their own story of what the institutions think of the fundamentals:1. Stock down over 25% since secondary of 4.5 million shares that was priced at $100 -- when it was trading $90! That was BOLD!2. 180-day lockup expiration was Nov 9 and shares have held $65-67 area
column13: even after Nov 4 lows of $61.80.3. Earnings were Nov 10 and they certainly helped support stock above that $65-67 support area.4. Shares tested 62% retracement of $27 all-time lows (since May IPO) to the $128 all-time highs over the summer. I don't get precise with Fibs and the market wasn't either
column14: with the 62% RT in the mid-$60s and the recent low
column15: during the early November market swoon
column16: at $61.80.5. Shares ran to $79 in late Nov
column17: then retested $65 in early Dec for a nice bounceThe bottom line: A lot of big players probably got hurt on the summer run-up above $100 and into the secondary offering. The stock had been trading above $100 from mid-August through September when the secondary came.But my sense is that if anybody was still itching to sell before or after the lockup expiration
column18: they already did. There is one more caveat on that front coming up. Meanwhile take a look at the sales and earnings estimates...The Analysts Before and After EarningsSeveral research analysts were busy upgrading the company before the secondary and they haven't changed their tune since.Bank of America restated a Buy rating and bumped their PT from $88 to $130 in a research report on September 5.Deutsche Bank raised their price target on Acacia from $90 to $125 and gave the stock a Buy rating in a research report on September 9. They reiterated their stance on Nov 30.Needham & Company raised their price target from $100 to $125 and gave the stock a Buy rating in a research report on October 11
column19: right before the secondary. They reiterated their stance on Nov 26.Goldman Sachs restated a Neutral rating on shares of Acacia on October 12
column20: the day the secondary was announced.Cowen & Co. reiterated their Outperform rating on Nov 10 and raised their PT from $90 to $99.Finally
column21: William Blair analysts raised their 2018 revenue expectations and took a more bullish view of Acacia's revenue opportunities and operating model post-earnings. ""We are maintaining our expectations for 30% revenue growth in 2017 while moving 2018 growth to 20% from 17%."" They reiterated their Outperform rating.The CaveatThere is another lock-up expiration on Jan 5 where early investors will be eligible to sell as much as 24.6 million shares.
