column1: As Networks Speed Up
column2: Arista Gains Ground On Giant Cisco;12/9/2016;"Without its stellar group of ""cloud titan"" customers
column3: network   gear makerArista Networks'(ANET) rise in the data center switching market vs. goliathCisco Systems(CSCO) might never have happened.Now it's poised to make an even stronger move in the market
column4: provided it can hang on to those customers
column5: the likes of which   includeMicrosoft(MSFT)
column6: Facebook(FB)
column7: Netflix(NFLX)
column8: Apple(AAPL)
column9: Alphabet'sGoogle(GOOGL)
column10: eBay(EBAY)  andYahoo(YHOO).These tech behemoths all buy speedy network switches and   software for use in data centers that provide cloud computing   services from Arista
column11: even though industry leader Cisco now holds   nearly 60% of the data center-switching market. Many of those   companies will rely on Arista more as they crave faster network   speeds to whisk content and apps to mobile devices or
column12: in   Netflix's case
column13: stream high-quality video.makeArticleAd();While some of Arista's blue-chip clients are now developing   their own switching hardware
column14: a development that has some   analysts worried
column15: others say Arista's software expertise gives it   an edge as the market evolves.""Arista is gaining share by focusing on the needs of a very   demanding set of data center customers. They have a big presence   with (web) hyperscalers
column16: the cloud titans
column17: said Brad   Casemore
column18: an analyst at research firm IDC.Arista had about 8.4% of the market in slower Ethernet   switching in 2015
column19: but its share is double that in higher-speed   40- and 100-gigabit sectors. Consequently
column20: Arista's share of the   overall market is close to 10%
column21: Casemore estimates. IDC   expects demand for 40- and 100-gigabit switches to boom through   2020 and for Arista to grow along with that.It's all helped Arista see its revenue jump 35% in the first   nine months of 2016 to $801 million. Its stock has nearly doubled   since reaching a low in early February. But shares dipped 1.4% to   93.14 Monday after a judge ruled that the company had infringed   on patents held by Cisco.Moving To The CloudWhen it was founded in 2004
column22: Arista first went after banks   that needed high-speed switching for equities trading. Four years   later
column23: it began focusing on cloud data centers
column24: says   Chief Executive Jayshree Ullal.""When we spotted the cloud opportunity we were almost too   early for it
column25: Ullal told IBD in an interview. ""What we saw was   the rise of cloud companies
column26: the proliferation of mobile devices   and new cloud applications that were very different than   enterprise applications
column27: very distributed
column28: and that required a   network that could aggregate information in a real-time   fashion.""Arista's Ethernet switches speed up communications between   computer servers packed into the data centers
column29: and interconnect   racks of servers in different buildings so they behave like one   data center. While Arista has feasted on cloud networking
column30: some   of its internet customers - notably Facebook - have been   developing their own data center technology.Facebook and Google have pioneered open-source software   concepts in data centers. They lowered data center costs by   running software on so-called ""white-box"" servers
column31: built by   lesser-known suppliers from Asia.One worry is that cloud builders may use contract   manufacturers to make their own network switches - basically   servers with built-in
column32: high-speed communications functions - at   the expense of Arista
column33: Cisco and other suppliers. Ullal says   Arista isn't worried about the white box trend.[ibdchart symbol=""ANET"" type=""daily"" size=""threequarter""   position=""rightchart"" ]""We're a software company
column34: she said. ""We   could run on anybody's white box if customers wanted it. We don't   view what Facebook or other companies do as a threat
column35: we see it   as an opportunity and as collaboration.""Facebook's ThreatSome analysts aren't so sure. When Facebook
column36: Arista's   second-biggest customer behind Microsoft
column37: in November announced   ""Backpack
column38: its first 100-gigabit switch
column39: it set off alarm   bells among industry watchers at Goldman Sachs.""Facebook believes it now has a full road-map to building a   data center
column40: a report from the investment bank said. ""We view   these developments as a long-term negative for data center   switching vendors Arista
column41: Cisco
column42: andJuniper (Networks)(JNPR).""IDC says original design manufacturer
column43: or ODM
column44: switch makers -   contract manufacturers of white-box switches - had 12.3% of the   100-gigabit data center market in 2015
column45: third in market share   behind Cisco and Arista. Players in that market include   Cumulus
column46: Pluribus Networks
column47: and Big Switch.Peter Christy
column48: an analyst at 451 Research
column49: says it's a ""fact   of life"" that Google
column50: Amazon.com(AMZN) and Facebook design and engineer their own massive data   centers. Microsoft is less focused on white-box switch   replacement
column51: analysts say.""They have unique networks
column52: Christy told IBD. ""It's a real   problem for the switching industry that the highest growth   segment is increasingly being (sourced) internally.""Worries Overblown?But Mark Moskowitz
column53: analyst at Barclays
column54: says worries over   Facebook's switching venture and those of others may be   overblown.""While cloud service providers from time-to-time experiment   with homegrown switching applications
column55: such initiatives are not   to fully displace the merchant suppliers
column56: Moskowitz said in a   report. ""In certain cases
column57: these homegrown efforts are designed   to influence the technology road maps of the merchant   suppliers.""Citigroup analyst Stanley Kovler said in a report that   Arista's risk of market share loss due to the white-box trend is   ""negligible as Arista's products are primarily in the core
column58: complex part of the data center.""IBD'S TAKE:Arista shares broke out above 90 in late November and have     reached new all-time highs in several sessions since then. The     company is at the top of the class among networking companies     in performance. For a stock checkup on Arista
column59: checkhere.IDC's Casemore says the white box trend as well as competition   from China-based Huawei in switching are reasons why Arista is   pushing into the $13 billion network router market
column60: taking on   Cisco and Juniper. Routers whisk data from data centers across   the internet. Arista is using a new Broadcom chip called   ""Jericho"" in router products
column61: now in trials.Arista
column62: which has over 4
column63: 000 switching customers
column64: aims to have   over 100 routing customers by mid-2017. Morgan Stanley
column65: in a   report
column66: estimates that Arista could garner $200 million to $300   million in revenue from router products by 2020.""Network design is changing. It's getting more difficult to   distinguish switching from routing
column67: Ullal said. ""This is a   natural opportunity for us
column68: but it's not going to happen   overnight.""$1 Billion In SalesArista
column69: which raised $226 million in its 2014 initial public   offering
column70: now is on track to easily top $1 billion in 2016 sales.   Barclay's Moskowitz says it could hit $2 billion by 2020 based on   share gains in the data center switching market alone.Aside from its push into the routing market
column71: Arista aims to   target the corporate market through a new alliance withHewlett-Packard Enterprise(HPE). And
column72: it aims to grow revenue from government customers as   well.Family trusts formed by co-founders Andy Bechtolsheim and   David Cheriton hold about 27% of outstanding shares
column73: while   Arista's top 10 shareholders own nearly 67% of the company's   float
column74: says Thomson Reuters.To keep its edge
column75: Arista Networks has been spending 20% to 22%   of sales on research and development.""Networking has been written off as being mature
column76: but Arista   is redefining networking for our customers
column77: Ullal said. ""The   company was really built by engineers for engineers."""

column1: Juniper Networks Stock Upgraded: What You Need to Know;12/7/2016;"2016 has been a year of disappointments for investors inJuniper Networks(NYSE: JNPR) . After beginning the year with a stock price of $27   and change
column2: Juniper stock now looks set to end the year right   back where it began.And yet
column3: if you ask the analysts at Credit Suisse
column4: 2016's   miserable performance sets up Juniper stock to outperform in   2017. This morning

column6: after crunching the numbers on likely revenue and profit margin   growth

column8: Credit Suisse argues that despite what its stock   price might suggest to you

column14: though sub-4% sales growth might not sound   impressive

column17: a move to 3.8%   sales growth
column18: for example

column22: and then $2.40 per share in FY2018. Both   those numbers would be a nice improvement over the $1.59 in   per-share earnings that Juniper produced last year
column23: and even   compared to the $2.07 per share that analysts are   forecasting for 2017.3. What's driving the growth?Credit Suisse believes Juniper is gaining on rivals such asCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO)

column1: How Risky Is FireEye Inc Stock?;12/7/2016;"Cybersecurity firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) lost nearly 40% of its market value this year due   to sluggish sales growth
column2: cash burn concerns
column3: and major executive   departures. But now that FireEye trades at a 35% discount to its   IPO price of $20
column4: is the stock still too risky to touch? Let's   examine its headwinds
column5: tailwinds
column6: cash flows
column7: and valuations to   find out.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The headwindsFireEye's revenue rose 13% annually to  $186.4 million   last quarter
column8: representing its slowest year-over-year growth rate   since its 2013 IPO. The company expects to finish fiscal 2016   with 15%-16% sales growth and 4%-6% billings growth -- which is a   big  drop from its 46% sales growth and 35% billings growth   in 2015.FireEye blamed that slowdown on its ongoing shift from on-site   security appliances to subscription-based services like FireEye   as a Service (Faas). Competition also remains fierce --Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) bundles threat prevention solutions with its   networking hardware and software
column9: andPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) andFortinet(NASDAQ: FTNT) have integrated threat prevention features into   their next-gen firewalls.FireEye also lost several key executives over the past two   years. CFO Michael Sheridan resigned last year
column10: CEO David DeWalt   stepped down this June
column11: and  founder Ashar Aziz resigned   from the board of directors in September.The tailwindsFireEye's current CEO is Kevin Mandia
column12: who joined the company   after FireEye acquired his company Mandiant in 2014. Mandia is   trying to boost FireEye's margins with hundreds of layoffs and   widening its moat with  Helix
column13: an all-in-one platform that   bundles together many of FireEye's services with a single user   interface. If it can successfully pivot away from appliances and   toward FaaS
column14: Helix
column15: and its other subscription-based services
column16: FireEye's revenue growthmightaccelerate again.Mandia is not actively trying to sell FireEye
column17: but the company   is still frequently cited as a takeover target for companies like   Cisco. Its Mandiant and iSight threat detection technologies are   still considered ""best in breed"" solutions
column18: and it serves over   5
column19: 000 customers across  67 countries -- including nearly   half the Forbes Global 2000.The cash flowsUnder DeWalt
column20: FireEye repeatedly struggled to generate   positive cash flows. FireEye relied on secondary stock and   convertible debt offerings to generate more cash
column21: but those moves   diluted existing shares and undermined investor confidence.FireEye's big stock-based compensation expenses
column22: which gobbled   up 32% of its revenues during the first nine months of 2016
column23: also   prevented it from becoming profitable on a GAAP-adjusted basis.   Mandia's decision to reduce its workforce and implement other   cost-cutting measures is clearly aimed at getting those costs   under control.Between the third quarters of 2015 and 2016
column24: FireEye's gross   margin rose from 73% to 74%
column25: its operating margin improved from   -32% to -14%
column26: and its operating cash flow rose from negative $8.3   million to $14.1 million. Thanks to those bottom line   improvements
column27: FireEye expects to generate positive free cash   flows for all of 2017. That would mark the first time that   FireEye haseverreported positive free cash flow since its IPO.Source:YChartsThe valuationsFireEye's enterprise value-to-sales ratio of 2.7 is lower than   Palo Alto and Fortinet's respective EV/Sales ratios of 7.3 and   3.4
column28: and its enterprise value of $2 billion is a fairly   affordable target for bigger tech players. However
column29: FireEye's   EV/FCF ratio (an oft-used metric to measure high-growth   companies) comparesverypoorly to Palo Alto
column30: Fortinet
column31: and many other cybersecurity   players due to its negative free cash flow.Source:YChartsIf FireEye's FCF rises to positive territory next year
column32: its   valuation would look much safer for investors and potential   acquirers
column33: and its stock could rebound. However
column34: Mandia's plan to   downsize FireEye in the face of rising competition could also   backfire if its sales and marketing teams get outgunned by teams   from larger rivals like Cisco
column35: Palo Alto
column36: and Fortinet.So how risky is FireEye?FireEye has certainly taken steps in the right direction
column37: but   it's still averyrisky stock. Its plan to pivot from appliances to services while   downsizing sounds reasonable on paper
column38: but it could be tough to   pull off amid unpredictable enterprise spending and tough   competition.Therefore
column39: my overall impression of FireEye has improved

column1: 5 Reasons Palo Alto Networks Inc Stock Could Fall;12/6/2016;"Next-gen firewall vendorPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) shed nearly 30% of its value over the past year due   to ongoing concerns about its slowing sales growth
column2: widening   losses
column3: and rising competition. But as Palo Alto hovers near its   52-week low
column4: investors might be tempted to start a position in   this high-growth stock. However
column5: I believe that the stock could   still fall further for five main reasons.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();1. Its high valuationPalo Alto currently trades at 8 times trailing sales. That's a   high P/S ratio compared to many of its cybersecurity peers --Fortinet(NASDAQ: FTNT) trades at 4 times sales
column6: FireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) trades at 3 times sales
column7: andSymantechas a P/S ratio of 4.With the market hovering near all-time highs and big investors   rotating out of the tech sector toward energy and financials
column8: tech stocks with high valuations and zero GAAP profits or   dividends (like Palo Alto) could be highly exposed to big   sell-offs.2. Slowing sales growthPalo Alto posted 34% year-over-year sales growth last quarter
column9: but that represented its slowest growth rate since its 2012 IPO.   Analysts expect the company to  post 31% sales growth this   year
column10: compared to 49% growth last  year. That slowdown has   been attributed to slower enterprise spending
column11: competition in the   perimeter security space
column12: and a market shift from on-site   appliances to automated solutions and subscription-based software   and services.3. The rise of bundled platformsTo stay competitive in that market
column13: Palo Alto launched its   Next-Generation Security Platform to bundle together natively   integrated technologies
column14: automated protection solutions
column15: and   threat intelligence sharing solutions on  a scalable   platform for businesses.However
column16: rivals like Fortinet and FireEye are also expanding   with similar bundled plays. Fortinet offers an integrated   security platform which bundles additional security services with   its firewall
column17: and FireEye recently unveiled Helix
column18: which bundles   its  threat prevention services together under a single user   interface.Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) also bundles next-gen firewalls and other security   tools with its networking hardware and software -- making it   tough for stand-alone players like Palo Alto and FireEye to stay   competitive.4. Widening GAAP lossesPalo Alto's bottom line  growth initially looks solid --   its non-GAAP net income rose 66% annually to $51.2 million last   quarter. But on a GAAP basis
column19: its net loss widened from $39.9   million to $61.8 million. That disparity was mainly caused by its   stock-based compensation (SBC) expenses
column20: which rose 55% annually   last quarter and gobbled up 29% of its revenues.High SBC expenses are common in the competitive Silicon Valley   job market
column21: but that puts Palo Alto at a clear disadvantage   against non-Silicon Valley rivals like Israeli firewall vendorCheck Point Software(NASDAQ: CHKP) -- which spent a mere 5% of its revenue on    SBC expenses last quarter. But if Palo Alto cuts jobs and   SBC expenses
column22: as FireEye is currently doing
column23: it could eventually   be outgunned by its rivals' better-funded R&D and sales   teams.5. Insiders still hate the stockIf Palo Alto shares were considered undervalued
column24: we should see   lots of insider buying. However
column25: insiders actually sold nearly   900
column26: 000 shares over  the past six months without buying a   single share on the open market. Many major executives
column27: including   CEO Mark McLaughlin
column28: sold large positions when the stock hit the   $140s earlier this year.Insiders have plenty of reasons to sell their shares
column29: but   those sales seemingly contradict the two-year $500 million   buyback plan the company announced in late August. But as I noted   in aprevious article
column30: that buyback plan is likely aimed at offsetting the share   dilution from its big stock bonuses instead of tightening up its   earnings per share.The key takeawayPalo Alto Networks mightlooklike a great growth stock
column31: but its sales growth is slowing down   and analysts' rosy projections for 32% annual earnings growth   over the next five years are based on its non-GAAP earnings.Palo Alto is still a ""best in breed"" player in the crowded   cybersecurity market
column32: but its stock could keep falling if it   doesn't counter its competitors in the security platform market   and get its costs under control. Therefore
column33: I'd suggest that   investors interested in the cybersecurity market take a closer   look at conservative plays like Cisco or profitable niche players   likeCyberArkinstead.10 stocks we like better than Palo Alto     NetworksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Cisco Systems Inc. Is Running out of Room to Grow...What's Next?;12/6/2016;"Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) is a ""mature"" tech stock which many investors likely own for income instead of price appreciation. The networking giant's revenue rose just 3% last year  and is expected to decline  about 2% this year due to sluggish enterprise spending and the commoditization of its core businesses of routers and switches.makeArticleAd();Image source: Cisco.Therefore
column2: investors might be wondering if Cisco can ever grow its business to generate fresh sales growth again. The answer lies in three key markets -- software defined networking
column3: cybersecurity
column4: and the Internet of Things.Software defined networkingSoftware defined networking (SDN) platforms consist of cloud-based networking solutions which depend more on software than hardware. As cloud-based services do the heavy lifting
column5: the need for on-site routers and switches declines and hurts Cisco's core business. Last year
column6: Guggenheim analyst Ryan Hutchinson warned that  Cisco's outlook was clouded by ""uncertainty around future network architectures as more workloads migrate to the cloud.""Cisco's major rival in this space isArista Networks(NYSE: ANET)
column7: which sells data center switches and routers optimized for  SDN platforms. Arista believes that the combination of its Jericho switches and FlexRoute software can replace on-site routers as cheaper SDN solutions. Cisco repeatedly sued  Arista over patent violation claims
column8: but those lawsuits aren't slowing Arista down -- the company is still expected to post  34% sales growth this year.The real way to counter Arista is with better support for SDN platforms. Cisco's hardware is already compatible with OpenFlow
column9: the same open-source protocol used by Arista and  OpFlex
column10: a newer protocol it introduced in 2014. It's unclear if those efforts will work
column11: but Cisco clearly needs to pivot its aging networking hardware devices toward SDN-optimized ones to stay ahead of the tech curve.CybersecurityCisco's fastest growing business is its cybersecurity division
column12: which protects its networking hardware and software from external attacks. The unit was built upon its acquisitions of companies like ThreatGRID
column13: Sourcefire
column14: OpenDNS
column15: and Lancope
column16: and competes directly against perimeter security players like firewall vendorPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) and threat prevention firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) .By bundling its cybersecurity solutions with its networking hardware and software
column17: Cisco gains the advantages of pricing power and scale against these stand-alone competitors. As a result
column18: Cisco's cybersecurity business has become its fastest growing division -- sales rose  13% to $1.97 billion last year and accounted for 4% of its top line. Last quarter
column19: the unit posted 11% sales growth.Image source: Getty Images.During last quarter's conference call
column20: Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins noted that the unit's ""integrated architecture approach and best-in-breed portfolio"" was well-received by customers
column21: and noted that it was driving more recurring subscription-based revenue. Its advanced threat security revenue rose 100%
column22: web security solutions revenue rose 60%
column23: and total deferred revenue -- a key indicator of future demand -- rose 39% annually.Looking ahead
column24: Cisco will likely acquire additional security companies to beef up that portfolio. It acquired cloud security firm CloudLock and containerization company ContainerX last quarter
column25: andrumors suggestthat it could be interested in acquiring FireEye or web application security companyImperva.The Internet of ThingsCisco estimates that the number of connected devices worldwide will double from 25 billion in 2015 to  50 billion in 2020. That so-called Internet of Things (IoT) market includes mobile devices
column26: wearables
column27: home automation appliances
column28: connected cars
column29: drones
column30: and other gadgets.As one of the world's top networking equipment companies
column31: Cisco views the IoT as a natural extension of its networks. That's why the company acquired IoT service platform Jasper Technologies (now known as its IoT Cloud Business Unit) for $1.4 billion earlier this year. Cisco is bundling those IoT services with its routers
column32: switches
column33: and UCS (Unified Computing Systems) servers
column34: which helps it counter competitors in each market.MicrosoftandIBMalready use Jasper's platform to link their cloud customers to  IoT devices.Cisco is also investing heavily in the connected car market. Earlier this year
column35: itpartnered withHyundaito develop in-vehicle network tech for  high-speed data transfers. The companies believe that the platform can bridge the gap between today's connected cars and driverless cars in the near future. Cisco also provides end-to-end security for vehicles
column36: delivers remote diagnostics and services
column37: and lets drivers access third-party cloud services.The key takeawayThe SDN
column38: cybersecurity
column39: and IoT markets all represent great long-term growth opportunities for Cisco
column40: but investors shouldn't expect the company to post double-digit sales growth anytime soon. Its core switches and routers businesses remain under pressure from cheaper rivals likeHuawei
column41: and it's struggling to counter nimbler rivals like Arista.Those challenges won't fade away anytime soon
column42: but I believe that Cisco's forward dividend yield of 3.6%
column43: low payout ratio of 47%
column44: and its P/E of 14 (which is lower than the industry average of 25) still make it a solid income play at current prices.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column45: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat: There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know investors! To be one of them
column46: just click here.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Arista Networks and FireEye. The Motley Fool owns shares of Microsoft. The Motley Fool recommends Cisco Systems and Palo Alto Networks. Try any of our Foolish newsletter servicesfree for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions
column47: but we all believe thatconsidering a diverse range of insightsmakes us better investors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Why Twitter Inc (TWTR) Stock Believers Need to Act Now;12/6/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTo sayTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) shareholders have been jostled a bit this year would be a significant understatement. The TWTR stock price started 2016 at $23
column3: fell to a low of $14 by the middle of the year
column4: soared to $25 by early October on rumors that an acquisition was coming
column5: and since then have peeled back to $18 when none of the suggested suitors actually pulled the trigger.makeArticleAd();Source:Freestocks via UnsplashAs the old saying goes
column6: ""Fool me once
column7: shame on you. Fool me twice
column8: shame on me."" Most owners of Twitter stock
column9: having been burned
column10: aren't apt to get their hopes up again that a buyout is looming.The irony? Now that most investors aren't expecting it
column11: they should probably be expecting it.TWTR Stock: Timing Is EverythingWere the business of buyouts not like junior-high romances
column12: it might be easier to digest the notion that Twitter is still a prime acquisition target. In other words
column13: whispers
column14: rumors
column15: other potential hookups and worries about what everyone else will say can often upset would-be eighth-grade relationships. Ditto for buyouts.And like middle-school love
column16: suitors are kind of funny about getting back together with an ""ex"" whenthings go sour as quickly as they didbetween TWTR andWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS)
column17: Twitter andSalesforce.com
column18: Inc.(NYSE:CRM) and even Twitter andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column19: NASDAQ:GOOGL). TWTR stock wasn't ready to be acquired then
column20: and with conclusions drawn
column21: it could be a while before the company is seen as buyable.5 Tech Stocks That Should Top Your 2016 Christmas Wish ListThe frustrating part: Twitter is still a very ownable company
column22: particularly in the hands of an organization that has dealt with consumers before. In early October though
column23: that simply wasn't the case.Plus
column24: there was the not-so-small matter of a sky-high Twitter stock price that made any deal too rich for most potential buyers by the time any of them could have made an offer.What a Difference Two Months MakesTo be clear
column25: TWTR hasn't successfully completed a turnaround since early October. A turnaround
column26: however
column27: has become much more plausible during that time.For one thing
column28: the power of using Twitter as a means of merging video and social networking has been validated in the meantime. TWTR had served as the venue foronly a second NFL gameby the point when the buyout rumors first surfaced
column29: but there's no denying it was still little more than an experiment at the time. If Walt Disney was looking for decisive evidence that it could revive its struggling ESPN division by melding it with the Twitter platform
column30: it certainly didn't have it at the time.Now
column31: however
column32: that partnership with the NFL is turning heads. The remainder of the ten games Twitter had contracted are airing
column33: andthe league is pleased. In the meantime
column34: Twitter has secured an actual sponsor for two NBA-related livestream programs that will air in the Philippines.It's not just the advent of sports and related television programming that reposition TWTR stock in a fruitful way
column35: however (although its sports partnerships go miles to answering the question ""why should I go to the Twitter page?"") The company is cleaning up its platform
column36: in multiple ways.Had it only been cited by Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff as one of the key reasons he couldn't justify doing a deal
column37: it may have been dismissed. But
column38: it wasn't just Benioff. Most observers agree that Twitter has a bullying problem.It may not matter much right away
column39: but in the middle of November
column40: the company finally started to get serious about dealing with the hateful rhetoric that makes the microblogging platform a liability.Point being
column41: much-needed changes are underway.Bottom Line for Twitter StockIt's never a good idea to own a stock simply because the company is a rumored acquisition target. TWTR stock is no exception. But
column42: when a much-needed turnaround is underway for that company
column43: decent odds of a buyout certainly don't hurt the bullish argument.And yes
column44: there's finally a light at the end of the tunnel for Twitter stock
column45: on its own
column46: or with a partner/buyer.Why Cisco Systems
column47: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Will Pay Off in the Long-TermTWTR still has a lot of problems to solve
column48: to be clear. To that end
column49: the fact that not one single company nibbled two months ago was a wakeup call for Jack Dorsey - changes have to be made. In the meantime
column50: they've started to be made.The catch: Anyone who thinks they can wait to profitably step into Twitter stock on hopes of a buyout right before that news becomes public knowledge is fooling themselves. To avoid the very price run up that turned a bunch of buyers off two months ago
column51: any deal is likely going to be done before any non-insider has any clue an agreement has been made.If you want to make a worthy trade on any buyout potential
column52: you have to own TWTR stock now
column53: when there's no real certainty it's going to happen.But
column54: you could do a lot worse.As of this writing
column55: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Ways to Make Money in the Market in 2017The 10 Biggest Stock Market Successes of 2016The postWhy Twitter Inc (TWTR) Stock Believers Need to Act Nowappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Will Pay Off in the Long-Term;12/6/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile most stocks remain in the midst of the post-Trump rally
column4: not every name has remained on that bullish train.Cisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) is one of those few exceptions. Although CSCO stock got November started on a bullish foot
column6: once the company unveiled its fiscal Q1 numbers on Nov. 17
column7: the selling has been brisk. Cisco stock fell 5% that day
column8: and since then
column9: it has continued to lose ground.makeArticleAd();Source:Prayitno via Flickr (Modified)It wasn't exactly the first quarter results
column10: however
column11: that did the bulk of the deed. It was the company's lackluster Q2 outlook (and beyond) that was the concern for owners of CSCO stock. In short
column12: the maker of networking hardware is facing a top-line and bottom-line headwind.Yet
column13: as CiscoCEO Chuck Robbins commentedin the aftermath of the Q1 report
column14: ""You have to look at it over time
column15: and not just quarter to quarter.""He's got a valid point. The question is
column16: what's Cisco going to look like in time
column17: once it completes its paradigm shift? Perhaps more important
column18: what might send CSCO lower should the transition not flow well?CSCO Changing Business ModelCSCO is well established as a networking equipment name. Indeed
column19: the company's moniker became synonymous with networking in the late 90s
column20: and although it has been dinged up a bit
column21: Cisco stock has held onto that crown ever since. Outright sales of hardware was its business model.10 Ways to Make Money in the Market in 2017As technology has changed though (and as competition caught up)
column22: CSCO is being forced to adapt. Hardware means less
column23: and software means more.This shift is readily evident in last quarter's revenue mix. Product revenue was down 1%
column24: while service revenue grew 7% on a year-over-year basis. Switching revenue - the company's bread and butter - was off 7%. Conversely
column25: deferred product revenue related to recurring and subscription-based business grew 48%.That's largely by design. As Robbins said of the prior quarter's numbers
column26: We've continued to have very good core execution in whatever the environment is
column27: and also to shift to more of a software and subscription model. We had another quarter with deferred growing nicely
column28: it was up 48%
column29: at almost $4 billion. And we continue to see fantastic growth in the security business … We are pleased with the continued transition to a software recurring model. For example
column30: the Cisco One business was a point-and-a-half of growth
column31: and that moved into a ratable model last quarter
column32: which would have previously been a one-time sale. And then there's the strength in security
column33: and our collaboration and next-gen data center businesses.""One of the side effects of a recurring revenue model is reliable revenue
column34: which in turn allows for a reliable dividend.And
column35: the companyhasstarted to respect the appeal of payouts. The Cisco dividend has grown from six cents per share per quarter in 2011 to 26 cents per share of CSCO stock now. That translates into a healthy dividend yield of 3.5%
column36: which is on par with stocks more commonly categorized as ""value"" names …an idea yours truly posed in the middle of November.Potential Pitfalls for CiscoWhile it's a necessary step in the right direction as virtualization and software becomes a better
column37: cheaper alternative to hardware
column38: this transition won't necessarily be an easy one.The biggest stumbling block for Cisco stock is the simple fact that the company doesn't have as firm of a hold on the new market that it did on the old one.Brocade Communications Systems
column39: Inc.(NASDAQ:BRCD) is one of those names that has positioned itself well in the modern era of networking. Its 5600 vRouter is the gold standard in software-based routers.Meanwhile
column40: though Robbins cheered the growth of the company's security services
column41: and that's an even more crowded field.Palo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW)
column42: Fortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT) andFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) are just a handful of the companies already in the security business
column43: and with a significant head start on CSCO.Can Walt Disney Co (DIS) Stock Spend Its Way to Gains?Still
column44: with $71 billion in the bank
column45: it's tough to think Cisco can't buy its way out of any problem it may find itself facing in the foreseeable future.Bottom Line for Cisco StockAlthough it's likely to be a long
column46: frustrating adjustment
column47: it is an adjustment CSCO stock is equipped to handle. The question is
column48: are owners of Cisco stock equipped to handle the adjustment? It could take a long while for CSCO to become the recurring revenue machine it's aiming to be.It may also require something of an adjustment in the valuation-perception of Cisco stock.The good news is that CSCO stock is presently valued at a trailing price-to-earnings ratio of 14.1 and a forward-looking price-to-earnings ratio of 11.8. That's in line with the market's typical multiple for a value stock. The bad news is
column49: the market may not be ready to view Cisco stock in that way
column50: punishing it for slowing growth … despite the growing stream of reliable revenue.Still
column51: for the true long-termer and fan of income
column52: CSCO could end up being a pleasant surprise.As of this writing
column53: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Tech Stocks That Should Top Your 2016 Christmas Wish ListThe 10 Biggest Stock Market Successes of 2016The postWhy Cisco Systems
column54: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Will Pay Off in the Long-Termappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 4 Biggest Losers for the Dow in November;12/1/2016;"makeZacksArticleAd();The Dow ended the month on a winning note
column2: rising during six of the last seven sessions. Setting multiple records over the month
column3: the blue-chip index gained 5.4% over the last thirty days. To a large extent
column4: these gains were largely attributable to Donald Trump's surprise victory in the U.S. presidential elections. Bullish economic data
column5: favorable news from overseas and expectations that GDP growth will continue were the other major reasons for gains made during the month.Most of the index's components notched up significant gains over this period with only a few ending in the red. While some felt the brunt of Trump's proposed policies
column6: others were affected by company specific factors. Overall
column7: the absence of any major downsides helped markets surge over the month.November's PerformanceThe index created eight records over November and breached the 19
column8: 000 mark for the first time ever on Nov 22. Markets surged after Donald Trump's election on Nov 8
column9: marking the beginning of a fierce rally for U.S. markets. Bonds fell out of favor as investors rushed to pick stocks which had been out of favor for some time now.Financials were the toast of the month with easier regulations for the sector around the corner.  The Utilities Select Sector SPDR ETFXLUslumped over the same period
column10: losing 3.5% as safe havens fell out of favor.Trump Pushes Stocks HigherAfter an initial hiccup
column11: investor warmed to the prospect of a Trump presidency and the Dow breached the 19
column12: 000 barrier for the first time in its history on Nov 22. The index has been on a bull run since the presidential election
column13: registering the third consecutive week of gains as investors anticipate lower corporate taxation and regulations
column14: along with higher infrastructure spending under a Trump administration.The Dow has gained 9.8% year-to-date and is likely to end 2016 nearly 9.9% higher
column15: marking its best since 2013. Last week
column16: the index shot up nearly 300 points
column17: highlighting an 800-point rise since the election. (Read:4 Blue Chip Stocks to Buy as Trump Rally Rages On)Bullish Domestic DataData released over the month suggests that the economy has strengthened and is likely to pick up pace during the last quarter. According to the Commerce Department's second estimate
column18: GDP increased by 3.2% in the third quarter. This is the fastest pace recorded in two years and the strongest year-over-year increase in nearly four.Among other notable releases this month
column19: construction spending rebounded
column20: the ISM manufacturing and services indexes moved higher. Retail sales surpassed expectations to increase by 0.8%. Industrial production rebounded while durable orders notched up record gains. Housing starts and home sales depicting that the housing market is in fine fettle. Finally
column21: Fed Chair Janet Yellen indicated that chances of a near term rate hike have increased significantly.OPEC Seals Output Cut Deal
column22: Third Quarter Earnings EncouragingConcluding months of discussions and related speculation
column23: OPEC sealed its first ever crude production deal on Nov 30. The group of oil producing countries agreed to cut production by 1.2 million barrels a day. The move aims to trim output to 32.5 million barrels per day. The likes of ExxonMobil Corp.XOM
column24: Chevron Corp.CVXwere the biggest gainers from this announcement. Both stocks have gained in excess of 4% over November asoil pricesmoved higher on expectations that the production bloc would finally agree on production controls.Banks were the biggest gainers from the third quarter earnings season with earnings rising nearly 13% on a yearly basis. Total earnings of 476 S&P 500 members reported in the third quarter
column25: are up 4% from the same period last year on 2.6% higher revenues
column26: with 73.1% beating EPS estimates and 55.5% coming ahead of revenue estimates. (Read:Making Sense of Retail's Q3 Results)4 Biggest LosersOnly five of the blue-chip indexes 30 stocks have ended the month in the red. This includes Apple Inc.AAPLwhich has ended the month0.9% lower. Of the rest
column27: most of have been weighed down by company or sector specific woes while only one has been dragged lower by Trump's victory.Visa Inc.Vhas yet to recover from the blow it received post Trump's surprise win. The stock suffered steady losses between Nov 9and Nov 14. It has made sporadic recoveries since then
column28: but its last spurt of gains petered out on Nov 25 and it has steadily declined since then.It is uncertain as to why the payment processor has been suffering. Revenues are garnered from transaction fees with card issuers such as JPMorganJPM
column29: which has gained more than 16% over the month. The Zacks Financial Services Transaction Market sector has also inched upward over the month. Possibly
column30: Visa has been hit by stock specific factors such as a litigation overhang and high client incentives. However
column31: the stock could soon recover since its projections for 2017 are encouraging. Also
column32: it reaffirmed that the acquisition of Visa Europe will be accretive in 2017.Visa has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Its earnings estimate for the current year has declined by 0.1% over the last 30 days. The stock has declined 5.3% over last month.VISA INC-A Price and ConsensusVISA INC-A Price and Consensus|VISA INC-A QuoteThe Procter & Gamble CompanyPGalso declined after the results of the presidential election were announced and has fallen only marginally lower than the level reached on Nov 10 at the end of the month. The Zacks Soaps and Cleaning Preparations Market sector has also moved lower over the month. The entire consumer staples sector remains weighed down by global economic uncertainty.However
column33: Procter & Gamble has incurred comparatively lower losses. Productivity improvements and aggressive cost-saving efforts have consistently improved margins with the trend expected to continue going ahead.Procter & Gamble has a Zacks Rank #3. Its earnings estimate for the current year has declined by 0.3% over the last 30 days. The stock has declined 5.1% over last month.PROCTER & GAMBL Price and ConsensusPROCTER & GAMBL Price and Consensus|PROCTER & GAMBL QuoteThe Coca-Cola CompanyKOsuffered a post election reverse from which it had recovered somewhat by Nov 28. The Zacks Soft Drinks Beverages Market has also been on a steady downtrend over the month.Severe macroeconomic challenges in certain international markets and the stronger U.S. dollar have negatively impacted the cola giant in keeping with the fortunes of the broader sector. However
column34: the stock itself has declined relatively lower. Higher prices for sodas and strong demand for water and sports drinks in North America are likely to push the stock higher going forward.Cola's earnings estimate for the current year has remained unchanged over the last 30 days. The stock has declined 4.2% over last month. The stock holds a Zacks Rank #3. You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.COCA COLA CO Price and ConsensusCOCA COLA CO Price and Consensus|COCA COLA CO QuoteCisco Systems
column35: Inc.CSCOwas the sole tech stock which notched up gains post Trump's victory. The company is likely to gain from Trump's infrastructure push as well as his plans for offshore tax reserves repatriation. However
column36: the stock declined on Nov 16 after releasing fiscal first-quarter results and has inched marginally lower since then. It has lost more than Zacks Computer Networks Market sector over last month.Cisco's disappointing earnings guidance is likely to remain an overhang on the stock. For the second-quarter of fiscal 2017
column37: revenues (excluding the SP Video CPE Business) are expected to decline in the range of 2% to 4% on a year-over-year basisCisco has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). Its earnings estimate for the current year has declined by 2.8% over the last 30 days. column1: Forget Baker Hughes
column2: General Electric Company (GE) Stock’s Best Buy-Outs Were a LOT Smaller;11/29/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe news dominating theGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) is undoubtedly its proposed tied-up with oil services firmBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI). Certainly
column4: that deal is transformative and deserve plenty of attention. In the end
column5: that will make GE a very different company - or two after it splits.Source:Anthony Quintano via FlickrIt very much warrants coverage.makeArticleAd();But while the investment world fawns over GE and BHI tying the knot
column6: General Electric was busy making other deals - much smaller deals outside of the world of industrial manufacturing.GE is quickly becoming one of the strongest and biggest technology stocks out there. Dubbed the industrial internet or smart factories
column7: the company is rapidly becoming one of the biggest players in the burgeoning Internet of Things (IoT) market.In the end
column8: the concept of smart factories
column9: appliances and other industrial products is really what's going to drive growth across throughout GE's future. And that includes anything that happens with Baker Hughes.GE Creates the Factory of the FutureThe last few years have been about transformation at GE. After shedding billions of dollars' worth of GE Capital and other financial assets
column10: General Electric has gone back to its roots as major industrial manufacturer. Except
column11: there's a hefty dose of code and programming going along with that focus on industrial manufacturing.The 7 Best Tech Stocks in the WorldDuring this whole shuffling of businesses lines
column12: asset sales and transformation
column13: General Electric quietly launched GE Digital. Taking tools that it used during its own internal processes
column14: General Electric created the blueprints for the smart factory of the future. Using its newPredix platform
column15: GE stocknow offers a whole suite of products built to combine machines and technology in one hand.Initially
column16: the suite of products used complex sensor across various pieces of machinery - say a jet engine or conveyor belt - and then software to analyze the billions of bytes worth of data. Looking at all the data generated
column17: it was done to help with maintenance time
column18: operational efficiencies and other cost-saving strategies.But GE hasn't stopped there. It has a gone on an IoT buying spree designed to make PredixTHEone-stop shop for the industrial internet.While the market was focused on the BHI merger
column19: it quietly addedShipXpressand asset performance management software firmMeridium. It also purchasedArcamandConcept Laser. It took outBit Stew- which handles efficient data integration.Wise.ioand its machine leaning AI ""natural selection"" software is now part of the GE Digital family. Industrial cyber security firmWurldtechwas added.The latest was a $915 million buyout ofServiceMax. The addition to GE Digital will allow field workers access to data
column20: contracts and other information from anywhere on any device. It brings software as a service (SaaS) into the Predix cloud suite.None of these acquisitions were big in terms of dollar amounts
column21: but all allow GE to really utilize everything that Predix potentially could offer. Machines and factories
column22: thinking and learning while running more efficiently.A Monster Opportunity for General Electric StockThe real opportunity for GE comes down to making money hand over fist with Predix. Despite only being a few years old
column23: GE is already generating plenty of revenues from the software infrastructure suite. This year
column24: General Electric estimatesthat sales of Predix will hit $7 billion. That's a billion more than what it earned on the IoT software program during 2015.The gains are coming from major companies as well. GE just signed mega-utilityExelon Corporation(NYSE:EXC) and India'sReliance Industries Limited- which wants to use it across its energy
column25: fertilizer
column26: power
column27: healthcare and telecom businesses.Longer term
column28: Predix should grow to more than $15 billion in annual sales by the time the calendar rolls over to 2020.And there's plenty of potential for cross selling and additional revenue drivers. Just bought a new jet engine from GE Aviation? How about buying it already loaded with sensors and year's trial to our Predix software suite?That kind of cross-selling and sales pitch will even work with the various oil service products that GE will sell after it snags Baker Hughes.General Electric estimatesthat a small 1% increase in efficiency could save the oil and gas industry more than $90 billion over a 15 year period.The fact that it makes the industrial products and sells the software gives it an upper hand against other industrial IoT rivals likeCisco Systems
column29: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO).""Techy"" GE Stock Is a Big BuyIn the end
column30: GE is quickly becoming the industrial internet leader with its smart and small buy-outs. The Brilliant Factory and connectivity among machines and industrial processes will be a huge trend in the upcoming decades. General Electric is building on its history for the next industrial revolution
column31: one that will be driven by coding rather than steam and coal.Betting Against PayPal Holdings Inc (PYPL)     Stock Is a BIG MistakeFor investors
column32: the sideways drift of GE stock makes it an incredible buy as its moves with gusto in the next stage of its transformation.Ultimately
column33: GE Digital will continue to see higher revenues and the high profit margins at the unit will only serve to strengthen GE overall.As of this writing
column34: Aaron Levitt did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Double-Whammy Dividend Stocks to Buy in     2017The 10 Best S&P 500 Blue-Chip Dividend     Stocks to Buy NowThe postForget Baker Hughes
column35: General Electric Company (GE) Stock's Best Buy-Outs Were a LOT Smallerappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 12 Facts About the Internet of Things Every Investor Should Know;11/29/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.The Internet of Things is one of those buzzwords you hear   everywhere
column2: but nobody ever bothers to explain what it is. The   concept is expected to fuel a staggering $3 trillion market by   2020
column3: just four short years from now.makeArticleAd();So I'm here to help. You should know these 12 facts about the   Internet of Things right now:The Internet of Things (IoT) may seem new and unfamiliar
column4: but it already exists and you use it all the time.ATMs started networking in an IoT-like way long before the     public internet was a thing. In the 1970s
column5: Carnegie Mellon     University followed up with the world's firstsoda machineequipped with remote inventory monitoring. These were important     baby steps in the direction of what we now think of as the     Internet of Things.Current examples popular with consumers includewearable fitness bands
column6: smartwatches
column7: smart TV sets
column8: connected cars
column9: and remote health monitors. Whenever your gadgets are sending     data to a central processing hub
column10: you're taking part in the     IoT.In the industrial sector
column11: you'll find IoT systems at work     in controlling manufacturing equipment
column12: managing energy use and production
column13: andmonitoring airplane engine performance. Sensors collect data
column14: while remote systems process the     massive information flows. Companies use the resulting analysis     to drive business decisions
column15: flag equipment for maintenance
column16: and much more.The IoT sector is consolidating quickly. In 2014
column17: NXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI) made a massive bet on automotive computing and     the IoT with the $11.8 billion acquisition of rival Freescale     Semiconductor. Less than a year later
column18: NXP became the target in     an even larger IoT deal
column19: as industry giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)launched a $47 billion bidfor the Netherlands-based chipmaker.When used correctly
column20: IoT systems can open up new business     opportunities and enhance existing processes. Some of the magic     lies in collecting the right data
column21: and the rest springs from     running the numbers through intelligent analysis tools.The IoT requires strict security policies and powerful     shields from malicious hacking attempts. This was always     obvious
column22: but the need for even more protection is a lesson     still being learned the hard way. In October
column23: an automated     network attack based on insecure IoT cameras
column24: network routers
column25: and digital video recorders brought down some of the biggest     online household names for several hours. IoT security is a     serious sub-market of its own with the potential to support     many billion-dollar specialists.The IoT is actually not terribly well-known yet. According     to a recent Harris Interactivepoll
column26: only 13% of consumers in the U.K. would call themselves very     familiar with the IoT
column27: and 48% were at least aware of the     concept. That leaves a lot of ground left to cover before the     IoT becomes as recognizable as refrigerators and bicycles.However
column28: nuggets from the industry have made it into the     mainstream
column29: even though they aren't always seen as examples of     the IoT. Harris found that 99% of its poll respondents were     aware of smart devices
column30: which is pretty much the same thing     under a different name. Fitness trackers fall in this     category.Proof that it's high time everyone learned what the concept     is all about: There have been more IoT devices than people in     the world since 2008
column31: according to global networking reports byCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) .Even so
column32: the vast majority of connectable things are still     not properly integrated into IoT. In a whitepaper published in     2011
column33: Cisco said that only 0.06% of all connectable devices     were networked
column34: leaving 99.94% of devices on the sidelines.     Later Cisco reports have lifted the proportion of IoT-active     devices to roughly 0.5%
column35: which still leaves room for a     2
column36: 000-fold explosion of smart
column37: connected gadgets.Lucky break or inevitable progress? You be the judge: The     IoT explosion dovetails neatly with the evolution of 4G and 5G     wireless networking standards
column38: enabling far more connected     devices than the old 2G and 3G platforms. Moreover
column39: the IoT     eruption would not be possible withoutthe IPv6 network address standard
column40: which in theory provides enough addresses to connect every     atom on our planet. We have officially been out of addresses     under the previous IPv4 standard since 2011
column41: making do with     workarounds and recycled addresses.We're already on our way toward the Internet of Things   revolution
column42: but there is a lot of growth and development left to   be done. Researchers and businesses are still figuring out how to   run this tantalizing megasystem
column43: so stay tuned for improvements   and new investing angles.10 stocks we like better than NXP     SemiconductorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and NXP Semiconductors wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of November 7

column1: 10 Key Metrics From Cisco Systems' First Quarter;11/28/2016;"Networking giantCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) managed to beat revenue and earnings estimates   when it reported its fiscal first-quarter results on Nov. 16
column2: but   the stock sank regardless. Cisco's core switching business was   weak
column3: some of its most important growth businesses didn't grow at   all
column4: and its guidance for the second quarter left a lot to be   desired. Here are 10 key metrics from Cisco's earnings report   that sum up the company's results.Image source: Cisco Systems.makeArticleAd();1%:Cisco's total revenue declined by 2.6% year over year during the   first quarter
column5: but this number doesn't take into account an   important divestiture. Cisco sold its set-top box business in   2015
column6: with the transaction closing in late November. Excluding   revenue from that business
column7: Cisco's total revenue increased by 1%   during the first quarter.1
column8: 326:Cisco announced a significant restructuring effort in August
column9: with the aim of cutting costs in low-growth areas and shifting   resources into the company's major growth initiatives. Cisco   planned to eliminate 5
column10: 500 positions beginning in the first   quarter
column11: about 7% of its global workforce
column12: with essentially all   of the cost savings slated for reinvestment. Cisco's headcount   dropped by 1
column13: 326 during the first quarter as part of this   restructuring plan
column14: with layoffs being partially offset by new   hires in growth businesses.-7%:Switching is Cisco's largest business
column15: responsible for 30% of   total revenue during the first quarter. It was also the weakest   segment for Cisco
column16: posting a 7% year-over-year revenue decline.   Cisco's switching business depends on its customers' willingness   to invest in their infrastructure
column17: which in turn depends on the   general economic outlook. When economic uncertainty rears its   ugly head
column18: Cisco's customers tend to slow down. CFO Kelly Kramer   pointed to campus switching as the major driver of the company's   weak results:I'd say for campus switching
column19: which is 2/3
column20: roughly
column21: of our     entire switching business
column22: which is our biggest business unit
column23: I'd say most of that is macro
column24: right? It is the one area
column25: and I     think we've talked about before. It's the one area that people     can put off doing a refresh if there are any macro concerns.     That's what we typically see any time you see any economic     pause or macro event.11%:One of the areas where Cisco is investing the cost savings from   its restructuring is security. The security business generated   $540 million of revenue during the first quarter -- up 11% year   over year -- making it the fastest-growing segment for the   company. Acquisitions are driving some of this growth
column26: with Cisco   aiming tooffer integrated solutionsthat stand out in a fragmented security industry.48%:Security is one area of Cisco's business that's shifting toward   software -- particularly subscription software. This shift is   spreading out revenue that would have previously been recognized   upfront
column27: hurting Cisco's headline numbers in the short run.   Kramer estimates that this transition reduced Cisco's revenue by   as much as two percentage points during the first quarter.Deferred revenue
column28: which is revenue that has not yet been   recognized
column29: is one way to measure the progress of Cisco's   subscription businesses. Total deferred revenue grew by 12% year   over year in the first quarter to $17 billion
column30: with the portion   of product deferred revenue related to recurring and subscription   businesses surging 48%.-3%:The data center segment
column31: which includes Cisco's UCS servers
column32: suffered a 3% year-over-year revenue decline during the first   quarter. Data center was growing at a double-digit pace not too   long ago
column33: making this result particularly disappointing. Cisco   pointed to a market shift from blade to rack servers as well as   general macro-economic uncertainty as the main drivers behind the   decline.$3.1 billion:Despite a weak quarter in many of Cisco's key segments
column34: the   company remained wildly profitable. Non-GAAP net income was $3.1   billion
column35: with a gross margin of 65.2% and an operating margin of   31.6%.-2% to -4%:One reason shares of Cisco fell following the company's earnings   report was weak guidance. Excluding the divested set-top   business
column36: Cisco expects second-quarter revenue to decline by   between 2% and 4%. The company isn't modeling any improvement in   capital expenditures from its service provider customers
column37: although CEO Chuck Robbins is hopeful that some headwinds will   turn into tailwinds once President-elect Trump takes office.$36.2 billion:Cisco is one of many large companies currently hoarding billions   of dollars overseas
column38: with $36.2 billion of net cash on its   balance sheet. As it stands today
column39: profits from international   operations can't be brought into the U.S. without that cash being   taxed at 35%. With President-elect Trump promising to enact a   repatriation tax holiday
column40: reducing that rate to 10%
column41: Cisco's mountain of overseas cash could finally be put to use.   The company is considering increased share buybacks
column42: a higher   dividend payment
column43: debt reduction
column44: acquisitions
column45: and strategic   investments as options if it's able to repatriate its overseas   cash.$14.4 billion:Even without using its overseas cash
column46: Cisco has been able to buy   back a tremendous number of shares
column47: in part by taking on debt.   The company spent $1 billion on share buybacks during the first   quarter
column48: and it's spent a total of $97.6 billion since it began   its share buyback program. $14.4 billion remains authorized for   further share buybacks
column49: although this number could rise if a   repatriation holiday becomes a reality.Cisco's first-quarter results may have beaten expectations

column51: and its data center business has stopped growing altogether. The   shift to subscription software and macro-economic uncertainty are   teaming up to cause all sorts of problems for the company -- at   least as far as the headline numbers are concerned. column1: How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Should Shell Out Its Cash;11/28/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOf all the news to come out the victory of President-Elect Donald J. Trump
column3: none will be greeted more warmly than a possible tax law change forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). That's because the much-vaunted cash hoard that most praise when speaking about the tech giant might finally be dumped (at least in part) onApple stockholders.Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrCorporate taxation rates in the U.S. remain at 35%
column4: the highest in the world. As a result
column5: many corporations that have earned money overseas leave their profits overseas
column6: as well. Thus
column7: those profits do not get taxed at U.S. rates.makeArticleAd();In the case of Apple stock
column8: that cash hoard has now reached $216 billion. Think about the sheer size of that cash pile
column9: and what could be done with it - because right now
column10: that cash pile is essentially worthless to AAPL.Well
column11: maybe notworthless.Maybe not even close to that.But it does hamstring Apple from being as efficient with its capital deployment as it could.Apple Stock and the Wonders of CashI've postulated that if the tax code isn't changed
column12: Apple would start making large acquisitions overseas. That way it could add to its top and bottom line
column13: even if the profits would still reside overseas. It would have to make acquisitions anyway
column14: because Tim Cook is not demonstrating that he has any vision for Apple - at least as a company - and is just a game manager.7 Stocks to Buy for the Santa Claus RallySo
column15: let's assume there is a repatriation of some kind
column16: either through an exemption or permanent change in the tax code. First
column17: let's look at where Apple stock would be presently valued.The prevailing wisdom is that repatriated cash will probably be subject to a 10% to 15% tax rate
column18: which means up to $33 billion would be taxed on AAPL
column19: leaving net proceeds of $183 billion. Add in the $21 billion of cash here in the U.S.
column20: and Apple stock has a total of $204 billion
column21: or about $40 per share in cash.At the current price of $111
column22: Apple stock is thus trading at $71 per share. So the market says the business itself is worth $376 billion. On trailing 12-month net income of $45.6 billion
column23: Apple stock is thus trading at 8.3 times net income.Normally
column24: we'd look at a company's earnings growth rate and make a judgment if the stock is fairly valued based on whether it is trading at a reasonable multiple compared to its growth rate. There's a small problem with that
column25: though.Apple's net income fell in fiscal 2016 by about 16%. Analysts project the five-year EPS to increase at 8% annually. However
column26: that's earnings per share
column27: not net income. And EPS growth is being juiced because of stock buybacks
column28: even if not by much.As long as Apple continues to be driven by iPhone sales
column29: which account for some two-thirds of revenue
column30: and Tim Cook doesn't show us what his vision of the company is going forward
column31: I'm not inclined to offer AAPL stock the kind of premium it used to command.Still
column32: at 8.3 times net income
column33: Apple stock isn't expensive
column34: either.I think the repatriation of that money is what tips the scales to a buy for me.How Apple Should Spend That CashMost people think that Apple would increase its stock buyback. I'm not so sure about that. It wouldcontinueto buy back shares
column35: but probably do so at a reasonable pace
column36: and certainly not all at once.Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Showing Signs     of HopeI think AAPL would be wise to prudently raise its dividend
column37: as well. Right now
column38: Apple stock only yields 2.1%. Given how much cash it has
column39: how much cash flow it generates
column40: and that it would like to remain competitive with bonds
column41: Apple could increase the dividend into the 4% range without breaking a sweat. That would only require an additional $10 billion per year
column42: and Apple stock suddenly would have the (price) support of the income crowd.Also
column43: I think it's clear that Apple needs to make some acquisitions to build itself out. If that seems obvious
column44: I agree. But remember: AAPL is not nearly as acquisition-happy as others in the tech space
column45: such asFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) orCisco Systems
column46: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO). It should purchase companies that are obviously synergistic with its current form
column47: and also branch into new areas that are capable of extending the Apple experience.Finally
column48: I believe Apple should set up a $10 billion content studio. Yes
column49: Netflix
column50: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) and others are more entrenched. But the dividends of content in this era will be paid for a long time to come.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column51: and manager of the   forthcomingLiberty   Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column52: he has no position in any stock mentioned.   He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column53: and has written   more than 1
column54: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be   reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlaceSleepy Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) Stock Could     Finally Wake UpThe 3 Best ETFs to Capture Small-Cap GrowthThe 10 Best Mutual Funds to Buy for 2017The postHow Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Should Shell Out Its Cashappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Verizon Retail Index Sees High eCommerce Holiday Traffic;11/28/2016;"According to a recent report by U.S. telecom behemothVerizon Communications Inc.VZEnterprise Solutions' third annual Verizon Retail Index
column2: the average daily eCommerce traffic volumes to U.S.-based retailers on Black Friday were up 9% year over year while peak ecommerce volumes were 39% higher than 2015 levels
column3: indicating increased consumer engagement through digital platforms. Moreover
column4: Thanksgiving (Nov 24) drove eCommerce traffic by 10% year over year while peak eCommerce volumes were 22% higher than 2015 levels.Verizon is known for its diversified business model
column5: which covers varied fields like communications
column6: technology
column7: wireless industry
column8: Internet of Things (IoT) along with the media video and digital platform. Toward this end
column9: the telco recently reported heavy eCommerce (Electronic commerce) and mCommerce (Mobilecommerce) traffic on Black Friday (Nov 25)
column10: courtesy of the promotional offers.The weekend before Thanksgiving also witnessed a moderate 15% hike in daily eCommerce traffic volumes to U.S.-based retailers compared to 2015 levels. Peak eCommerce volumes showed a 35% year-over-year rise
column11: implying encouraging response by consumers to the deals offered by retailers. However
column12: mCommerce traffic was down 2% year over year while peak mCommerce volumes were up 2% from a year ago.The Verizon Retail Index specializes in consumer ecommerce traffic during the holiday shopping season. The index also tracks eCommerce traffic across Verizon's broadband networks. The index also monitors network traffic throughout the holiday shopping season
column13: including events such as Black Friday and Cyber Monday.The next edition of the Verizon Retail Index will reveal digital shopping activity figures for the Nov 26-27 weekend and is scheduled to be released today. The escalation in eCommerce and mCommerce traffic on Black Friday implies that the telco's efforts to expand and strengthen its digital-video network have paid off. Verizon has also been engaged in a number of digital ventures.Recent EventsThis September

column15: Inc.

column18: ThingSpace. Meanwhile
column19: Verizon's rival AT&T Inc.Tpartnered with Cisco Systems
column20: Inc.CSCOto launch an all-in-one IoT Starter Kit. Notably
column21: these telecom companies are looking for alternative sources of revenue to offset the decline in their legacy businesses like fixed-line services.VERIZON COMM PriceVERIZON COMM Price|VERIZON COMM QuoteVerizon currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: Palo Alto Networks (PANW) Down to Strong Sell on Weak Q1;11/25/2016;"On Nov 24
column3: Zacks Investment Research downgraded network security solutions provider
column4: Palo Alto Networks Inc.PANWto a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell).Why the Downgrade?Palo Alto Networks' stock has been on a downtrend ever since it reported dismal first-quarter fiscal 2017 results. Shares slipped 13.3% since the announcement. In fact
column5: the company's stock price has been declining for a while now
column6: as is evident from its year-to-date plunge of 20.7%.Coming to the first-quarter results
column7: the company's adjusted loss per share (excluding amortization and other one-time items but including stock-based compensation)
column8: on a proportionate tax basis
column9: was 58 cents. The figure was significantly wider than the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a loss of 27 cents and the loss of 36 cents in the year-ago quarter.Though Palo Alto Networks' revenues of $398.1 million surged 34% year over year
column10: it missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $400 million.The company also reported an adjusted operating loss of $38.7 million
column11: which increased from a loss of $21.8 million suffered a year ago. Higher operating expenses (up approximately 38.7% year over year) impacted operating results.The company also provided a tepid second-quarter revenue guidance. For the second quarter of fiscal 2017
column12: Palo Alto Networks expects revenues in the range of $426 million to $432 million. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $432 million.We believe that all the aforementioned factors led to downward revisions in Palo Alto Networks' estimates. Over the past seven days
column13: the Zacks Consensus Estimate for fiscal 2017 increased from a loss of $1.10 per share to loss of $1.12.Also
column14: Palo Alto Networks has been witnessing an increase in operating expenses due to stepped-up investments in research and development
column15: and marketing strategies
column16: which have been offsetting the benefit of higher revenues. Going forward
column17: a volatile spending environment and competition from Cisco Systems
column18: Inc.CSCOand Check Point Software Technologies Ltd.CHKPremain concerns.PALO ALTO NETWK Price and ConsensusPALO ALTO NETWK Price and Consensus|PALO ALTO NETWK QuoteStocks to ConsiderA better-ranked stock in the technology sector is Seagate Technology plcSTX
