column1: Dow Jones Breaks 7-Day Win Streak With Oil in Focus;11/16/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsU.S. equities were fairly quiet on Wednesday
column3: with large caps   taking a break while tech stocks and small caps ran higher.   Investors instead focused on the happenings in the energy space
column4: with crude oil trading choppily on OPEC-related headlines and new   inventory data.The Federal Reserve is also getting some attention
column5: with Board   Chair Janet Yellen speaking to Congress later this week
column6: as   futures market odds of a December rate hike push above 90%.makeArticleAd();In the end
column7: theDow Jones Industrial Averagelost 0.3% (the first decline since before Election Day)
column8: theS&P 500 Indexlost 0.2%
column9: theNasdaq Compositegained 0.4% and theRussell 2000was unchanged. Elsewhere
column10: Treasury bonds were little changed
column11: the   dollar was stronger to push near 13-year highs
column12: gold was   relatively flat and oil fell 0.5% after trading in positive   territory earlier in the session.The 7 Best Tech Stocks in the WorldTelecom and technology stocks led the way with gains of 1% and   0.9%
column13: respectively.WatchmakerFossil Group Inc(NASDAQ:FOSL) gained 8.4% after being upgraded by analysts at KeyBanc on the   belief results are near an inflection point as the company enjoys   momentum in wearables.Target Corporation(NYSE:TGT) gained 6.4% on a third-quarter earnings per share beat with   comp-store sales not as bad as feared
column14: down 0.2%.WaltDisney Co(NYSE:DIS) gained 1.5% after an update by Deutsche Bank on a stabilization   in its ESPN subscriptions and optimism about parks and resort   growth.Financials and energy were the laggards
column15: down 1.4% and 0.9%
column16: respectively.Crude oil failed to follow up on Tuesday's big 6% rally. This   after the reporting of a large 5.3-million-barrel rise in U.S.   inventories when just a 1 million rise was expected. Adding to   the pressure was word Iran
column17: Iraq and Nigeria wouldn't attend an   ""informal"" meeting of OPEC officials in Doha this week.Tuesday's rally was driven by reports Russia will reportedly   attend that Doha meeting. After a rough production freeze deal   was hammered out in Algiers last month - secured only by Saudi   Arabia's willingness to shoulder production cuts to get the   Iranians to the table - the details are supposed to be ironed out   later this month.Hopes had dimmed somewhat in the wake of recalcitrance from   the Iraqis over what they claimed was overstated production data.   But now
column18: investors are excited at the prospect that Russia could   possibly add its name to the production agreement.Cisco Systems
column19: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Is       Screeching to a HaltWith OPEC officials teasing a production freeze deal since   February
column20: the market will soon demand something tangible. For   now
column21: however
column22: well placed headlines and a large short position in   oil futures are all that's needed to give the energy sector a   boost despite Wednesday's setback.In preparation

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Angers New MacBook Pro Fans Yet Again;11/16/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsHas a laptop launch ever generated as much drama asApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) new MacBook Pro?The laptop with its new Touch Bar and boosted price tag was widely derided when announced
column3: then unexpectedly recorded monster sales numbers. Now the new units are reaching customer hands
column4: there's an outcry about MacBook Pro upgradability. As in there is none. What you buy is what you get - forever.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleOnce again
column5: AAPL laptop fans are up in arms.Ifixit Confirms New MacBook Pro Can't Be UpgradedThe new MacBook Pro with Touch Bar began to ship to customers this week. This should have been a triumphant moment for Apple. After all the complaining about the direction the company made with its new professional level laptops - from the Touch Bar itself
column6: to the Butterfly keyboard
column7: higher prices and most of all switching to USB-C exclusively and ditching all legacy ports - the new MacBook Pro has been a surprise hit.Out of nowhere
column8: it bookedmassive pre-order sales numbers
column9: outselling all competitors by a huge margin.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Could Launch Apple Glasses by     2018The 13-inch base model began arriving two weeks ago
column10: and there was mainly positive feedback about its smaller size and zippy performance.This week
column11: however
column12: the more expensive new MacBook Pro models arrived.These are the ones aimed at the core MacBook Pro demographic
column13: the professional users. The 15-inch MacBook Pro in particular is the best laptop AAPL offers -and the most expensive
column14: with a $2
column15: 399startingprice. The outcry started almost immediately.IFIXITpublished one of the first tear downs of the new laptops andfound a big problem with MacBook Pro upgradability. For the first time
column16: AAPL has completely locked out users from upgrading anything in its professional series laptops. The new MacBook Pro not only has the RAM and CPU soldered to the motherboard
column17: the SSD is also soldered. So whatever configuration you order from AAPL is the laptop you are stuck with until you opt to buy a new one.Apple's March Toward Eliminating MacBook Pro UpgradabilityApple's MacBook Pro is well known for its longevity
column18: which is one of the reasons for its popularity. It was not uncommon for professional users to extend the useful lifespan of one beyond five years by upgrading the RAM and replacing the stock storage with the latest and greatest solid state storage.The reputation is great
column19: but long life makes it hard to make money. Better for profit if they instead buy a new laptop every two or three years. How do you get owners to upgrade more frequently? Apple embarked on a strategy that combined new features with increasingly limited MacBook Pro upgradability.In 2012
column20: its flagship laptop gained a high-resolution Retina display
column21: but AAPL also incorporated measures introduced with the MacBook Air: a non user-replaceable battery and RAM that was soldered to the motherboard. Apple often explains away the measures as necessary to make its laptops thinner
column22: but that argument doesn't explain moves like switching to proprietary pentalobe screws in a clear attempt to prevent owners from opening the laptop case.In 2015 the MacBook Pro got a Force Touch keyboard
column23: but users could still replace the stock SSD with a third-party option. However
column24: with the new MacBook Pro with Touch Bar
column25: the SSD is now soldered as well.That means the two primary ways a MacBook Pro owner could traditionally extend the useful life of their laptop - increasing the RAM and adding a bigger
column26: faster SSD - are now gone. If you want a MacBook Pro that's faster or has more storage capacity in a year or two
column27: you have no choice but to buy a new one.Reaction and Impact on AAPLAs might be expected
column28: the online reaction to Apple's move has been universally negative. No one other than Apple (and maybe external drive sellers) sees a win out of this move.Chinese Sabers Rattle Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock     to the CoreWill the discovery of non-upgradable SSDs put a damper on the new MacBook Pro's impressive sales? It's not going to make buyers happy
column29: but most are likely to suck it up and make the purchase anyway. Now that the detail is widely known
column30: AAPL is likely to end up generating even more revenue from sales.That base model 15-inch MacBook Pro comes with just 256GB of storage. Knowing they can never upgrade the storage
column31: buyers might grit their teeth and opt for more capacity when they order. Doubling it to 512GB boosts the laptop price by $200
column32: but maxing it out with 2TB of storage means shelling out an additional $1
column33: 400 to Apple.However
column34: the ill will Apple has been generating among its core MacBook Pro customers does open a door. A Windows PC manufacturer -Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) comes to mind as being positioned to offer the premium design Apple customers demand -couldleverage the situation to make a play that hurts the MacBook Pro in the long term.As of this writing
column35: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceBuy Cisco Systems

column10: Generac Holdings(NYSE:GNRC-Free Report) andNxstage Medical(NASDAQ:NXTM-Free Report).Screen of the Week of Zacks Investment Research by Kevin   Matras:Top Stocks with Big Potential Catch-up MovesGiven the recent run-up in the market last week
column11: here's a screen I've been using recently for my own stock picking.First
column12: it focuses on the top Zacks Ranked Sectors and Industries. Then it focuses on the Zacks Rank #1s
column13: #2s and #3s
column14: which are Strong Buys
column15: Buys and Holds
column16: respectively. But then it selects the outperforming stocks with the smallest percentage price change over the last 4 weeks.Why would I do something like that?Here's why.You've probably heard the old adage that roughly half of a stock's price movement can be attributed to the group that it's in. And that's true. In fact

column5: and   analysts have low expectations. That's because political and   economic uncertainty may have reduced capital spending on IT this   quarter. Yes

column7: but that position is in danger.Source:Prayitno via Flickr (Modified)makeArticleAd();And one of the lesser-sung culprits might be open-source   hardware.A Threat to Cisco StockFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has beenpioneering open-source hardwarefor a few years now. Other firms with big data centers
column8: such asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column9: are doing likewise
column10: designing their own hardware while Asian contract manufacturers   build it. Low-cost
column11: open-source hardware threatens to commoditize   networking routers and switches
column12: which firms such as CSCO rely   on. Other forms of hardware
column13: such as servers
column14: have been   commoditized
column15: but networking remains the ""last bastion of proprietary IT.""The development ofsoftware-defined networkingmakes it easier for customers to use commodity hardware
column16: known as   ""white boxes."" The appeal is twofold: this promises to reduce   costs while giving IT departmentsgreater control over the network
column17: important for companies likeLinkedIn Corp(NYSE:LNKD).Both Facebook and LinkedIn's hardware projects   received media attention in the past weeks. LinkedIn is   designing its own data hardware withProject Altair
column18: and software underProject Falco.10 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $10With Cisco's earnings due to be reported
column19: now is time to   re-examine the threat of open-source hardware to Cisco
column20: downside   risk to CSCO stock … and why Cisco should be able to   navigate this  transition without ending up on the   rocks.Cisco's Willingness to Disrupt ItselfOne problem Clayon Christensen writes about inThe Innovator's Dilemmais the failure of companies to disrupt themselves. Instead of   reacting to the threat of a low-cost disruptor
column21: they ignore it
column22: and eventually go under.Cisco isn't burying its head in the sand and shying away from   disruption. Last year
column23: former CEO John Chambers warned that   companies mustdisrupt themselvesor face disruption.Cisco has created ""spin-ins"" to deal with the threat of   software defined networking. As Varun Bhatiawrites:""Cisco disrupts itself by creating spin-ins
column24: separate   companies that are fully owned by Cisco. Insieme networks   disrupts Cisco's hardware business by developing software that   does the same thing
column25: only cheaper and with a lot less   hardware.""Lower-cost options could perhaps reduce Cisco's margins
column26: but   it's better for CSCO to do this now rather than wait for someone   else t o. Steve Jobs was fond of saying
column27: ""If you don't   cannibalize yourself
column28: someone else will."" And Cisco can make up   for this with high-margin software and services.Cisco stock has navigated many transitions in the marke t   before
column29: and with this proactive attitude
column30: its chances of   succeeding look good.Indeed
column31: Cisco might take a page out of theInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) playbook
column32: which transitioned from being a hardware producer to   a software and services provider.Low Valuation on CSCO SharesCisco stock trades at around 15 times earnings and 12 times   forward earnings
column33: below theDow Jones Industrial Averageand well below theS&P 500.  CSCO also trades at 2.5 times book value
column34: and only 2.4   times its cash position.Mr. Market doesn't expect Cisco to grow much
column35: limiting the   downside risk to CSCO stock. If the market were appraising Cisco   at 35 or 40 times earnings
column36: the downside risk would be   greater.Cisco's valuation is on par with that of a market leader in a   maturing industry.Cash PositionCisco last reported $7.631 billion in cash and $58.125 billion   in short-term investments. When combined
column37: these two equal 41% of   Cisco's $160 billion market capitalization.This gives Cisco a lot of breathing room
column38: and has allowed CSCO   to go on a buying spree
column39: announcing the purchase of IoT firmJasperin February and security startupCloudlockin June.Buying upstartsis a strategy for incumbents like Cisco to deal with   disruption.White Boxes Hold Limited AppealWhile white-box technology does promise companies lower costs   and greater control over their networks
column40: their appeal is limited   to mostly larger firms with major IT teams.Target Corporation (TGT) Stock Jumps on Q3       Earnings Beat
column41: But ...And the cost savings could be limited as well
column42: since upfront   capital costs on equipment are lower than operating expenses. As   a spokesperson said in 2014:"" It is our belief that the open source switch market
column43: sometimes called the ""white box"" market
column44: is largely only   attractive to a small
column45: highly-resourced subset of the overall   I.T. market. That's because the approach is loaded with hidden   hard and operational costs. For example
column46: networking capital   equipment outlays typically constitute only 30% of the cost of   running networks. Labor costs constitute 50%
column47: and will increase   with the white box approach as IT departments are required to   install
column48: integrate and update separate network operating systems   and network virtualization software.""Cisco's Margin Hasn't ErodedCisco's margins hold another sign that the IT behemoth has   greater staying power than expected. Instead of dropping in the   past few years
column49: they'veheld steady. From SDX Central:""WhenVMwareacquired Nicira in 2012
column50: many took it as a sign that the   SDN and white box eras were imminent
column51: and that Cisco 's gross   margins could drop into the 50 percent range
column52: writes analyst   Simon Leopold of Raymond James . However
column53: over the course of   fiscal 2016
column54: Cisco 's gross margins improved to almost 64 percent   with an operating margin at or above 30 percent.""Bottom LineCisco seems to be turning itself around
column55: and it's nearing its   52-week high. Yes
column56: it's possible that Cisco stock pulls back   after earnings tonight
column57: but if it does
column58: consider it a dip worth   buying.As of writing

column1: Ford (F) to Continue With Plans for Production Shift to Mexico;11/16/2016;"Ford Motor Co.Fintends to continue with its international plans
column2: including shifting the production of small cars to Mexico

column10: including Ford

column13: from India. The company said that it already has plants and investments globally

column1: Walt Disney Co (DIS) Stock Could Have a Sluggish Year Ahead;11/15/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS) increasingly looks like a 2018 story - if you give CEO Bob Iger the benefit of the doubt - and that makes the coming year look like a lackluster one for DIS stock.Source:Richard Stephenson via Flickr (Modified)ESPN lost a record number of subscribers in October
column3: an acceleration of a multiyear trend in which cord-cutters are leaving the sports network. ESPN's importance to DIS's operating profits is so critical that investors have a hard time focusing on anything else.makeArticleAd();That might have them missing Disney's wider strategy here.Old-line technology companies are going through painful transitions of their own. Places likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column4: Cisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) andOracle Corporation(NASDAQ:ORCL) are shrinking their traditional ways of distributing their goods and services in favor of the Cloud. Cloud-based services aren't growing fast enough to offset losses in the legacy businesses - but they will eventually.That's kind of what DIS is doing with ESPN. Sure
column6: consumers are cutting cords
column7: but that just means Disney has to reach them through new means of distribution
column8: like internet TV and related tech.That's why Iger is able to remain sanguine in the face of such hefty subscriber losses. He has a plan to make up for them
column9: but it's going to take time. As he said on a conference call with analysts after quarterly results:""[N]ew entrants in the marketplace
column10: particularly [internet TV services]
column11: are going to offer ESPN opportunities that they haven't had before to reach more people. And in particular
column12: we think those offerings
column13: because of their pricing
column14: user interface [and] mobile-friendly nature
column15: are likely to cause more Millennials to either stay in the multichannel ecosystem as subscribers or to enter it when they might not have in the past.""DIS Goes Over the TopIt's a credible strategy but it doesn't change the fact that DIS stock looks pretty pricey for a company in transition with a business as important as ESPN.From analysts at Barclays:""With newer Over The Top bundles emerging
column16: ESPN should be able to moderate some of the impact of legacy [pay-TV] declines. To be clear
column17: we continue to believe ESPN is secularly challenged
column18: and its affiliate growth of around 3%
column19: second-slowest after Viacom (VIAB)
column20: underlines this fact. However
column21: with more visibility at least over the next year
column22: we believe the drag from this factor on the stock is likely to moderate.""That can't happen fast enough for ESPN given its rate of decline
column23: but long-term bulls need to accept that this is going to be a slog. The network shed 621
column24: 000 subscribers in October. Advertising fell 13% in the most recent quarter and affiliate fee revenue - which is the highest in cable - also declined.Click to EnlargeHappily for investors inDisney stock
column25: the market is starting to buy in to Iger's vision. DIS missed Wall Street estimates and yet shares are up in the aftermath of earnings. That's a good sign. This is a stock that's lost more than 15% in the last 52 weeks pretty much on ESPN alone.But the market is going to remain very careful about this handoff to internet TV and over-the-top service providers. Like with CSCO and ORCL
column26: it wouldn't be surprising to see DIS stock just kind of tread water in 2017.Energize Your Portfolio With Energy Select     Sector SPDR (ETF) (XLE) OptionsThat said
column27: investors can find some relief in that the Disney stock price does appear to have stopped declining. Shares have been rallying all month long. On a technical basis
column28: the Disney stock price just overcame resistance at its 50-day moving average and 200-day moving average for the first time since May.If it can turn the 200-day MA into a level of support
column29: it will be a lot easier to go along for what could be a long run in the saga that is ESPN.As of this writing

column1: 3 Reasons Why Netflix
column2: Inc. (NFLX) Stock Is Worth Its Insane Valuation;11/15/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhy would anyone pay 300 times earnings for a stock
column4: let aloneNetflix
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)
column6: a company that made just$52 millionin the third quarter from $2.2 billion in revenue?Source:Via NetflixEven better
column7: why would someone buy Netflix stock when in Q3 2016 it used $462 million more in cash then came in the door from subscribers?makeArticleAd();For value investors
column8: the answer's an easy one. They wouldn't.But for those who can see past the financials
column9: I see three big reasons to remain interested in Netflix stock. Not the least of which is the fact the Netflix stock price has barely budged over the past 52 weeks
column10: up just 1.7% through Nov. 11. Indeed
column11: NFLX is due for a move higher.That said
column12: it's not easy for me to write about the upside potential of Netflix.5 Tech Stocks in Trouble After TrumpIn September
column13: I made the case whyAmazon.com
column14: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) wasa much better stock to buythan Netflix. Despite Jeff Bezos and Co.missingQ3 2016 earnings and revenue estimates
column15: Amazon Web Services continues to grow by 50% or more each year
column16: making it a very important piece of the Amazon pie.But really
column17: I just love how Amazon isn't afraid to invest heaps of money in areas it feels have the greatest growth potential
column18: regardless of the short-term hit to earnings. It's truly amazing.But there's something to be said of Netflix for adding 3.6 million members in the third quarter
column19: 57% higher than its forecast for the three-month period ended Sept. 30.Netflix Still GrowingNetflix
column20: Inc.'s subscriber growth represents a 4.3% increase in its global members
column21: from 83.2 million at the end of Q2. As a result of its unexpectedly high sign-up rate
column22: Netflix increased revenues in the third quarter by 36% year-over-year to $2.16 billion
column23: the first time it's gone over $2 billion in global streaming in a quarter.Forget earnings. That's a significant accomplishment
column24: especially on a constant currency basis where global streaming revenues in Q3 were up 39%
column25: or 400 basis points higher year-over-year.Picking up three million members outside the U.S. each quarter
column26: Netflix should see its international memberships overtake its U.S. memberships sometime in Q2 or Q3 2017. And that's without China coming on board anytime soon.Netflix has truly become a global business and the first global TV network.House of Cards Meets the House of MouseA couple of days afterInvestorPlacecontributor James Brumley wrote about why he thinkit makes senseforWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS) to buy Netflix
column27: fellow contributor Lawrence Meyers chimed in about the reasons whyit doesn't make sense.Both arguments are good ones.Brumley feels that Disney has to do something to pump up the tires of a lethargic ESPN subscriber count
column28: while Meyers believes paying $45 billion or more to acquire an over-the-top television service that barely makes money is hardly a smart allocation of Disney's capital.Who's right? I believe Brumley is.Sure
column29: buying Netflix would be Disney's largest acquisition ever - it acquiredCapital Cities/ABCin 1995 for$19 billion- and not an easy one to pull off
column30: but the alternative is to pass on the video streaming company and sit idly by while a competitor of some description gobbles it up.I just don't think Bob Iger
column31: Disney's CEO
column32: who is looking to retire at some point in the not-to-distant future
column33: will want to go out on a sour note.It might be a lot of money to pay
column34: but it sends a signal to investors that Disney is serious about the digital world. And hopefully it's enough to keep ESPN relevant for years to come.Reed HastingsAs I said previously
column35: Bob Iger is looking for the ideal person to replace himself at the head of the Disney table. Reed Hastings would be a logical candidate. He's built a huge business from scratch
column36: understands the entertainment business and the idea of convergence
column37: and he knows how Disney operates considering Netflix's existing pay-TVdealwith the company.It's not easy to find good CEOs; Hastings
column38: despite his company's inability to generate free cash flow
column39: is one of the best in the business. He might not be an internal candidate
column40: but if DIS wants someone who can hit the ground running
column41: I think he'd be at the top of the list.Bottom Line on Netflix StockNetflix stock's forward P/E is about half its trailing ratio
column42: so we're not quite in the nosebleed valuation zone
column43: but we're close. I believe that the value of a company to a large extent is what potential buyers are willing to pay.You might not think a baseball player is worth $30 million a season
column44: but if a team's willing to pay that price
column45: then the valuation
column46: at least in their opinion
column47: is more than fair.2 Post-Trump Trades for Cisco Systems
column48: Inc.     (CSCO) EarningsAt the end of the day
column49: that's all that really matters.I might not pay 150 or 300 times earnings for Netflix stock
column50: but eventually
column51: somebody will
column52: whether it's Disney or another multi-billion corporation.Netflix will be acquired. We just don't know by whom.As of this writing

column1: As Cybercrime Rises
column2: So Does Spending On Cyber Security;11/14/2016;"The world is becoming increasingly connected through networks and data in an ecosystem governed by digital technologies which have created immense opportunities for individuals
column3: businesses and organizations. The assimilation of mobile
column4: IoT devices
column5: cloud computing
column6: and other high-tech solutions have changed the way people
column7: businesses
column8: organizations and governments connect and work.While the interconnectivity of devices and use of sophisticated technologies is positively changing the world
column9: it is increasingly being challenged by cybercrime
column10: clearly reflected by the steep rise in the number of cyber-related frauds and crime reported in the recent years.Cisco points out that
column11: “Cybercriminals have refined their back-end infrastructures to carry out attacks in ways that increase efficiency and profits” and thus every industry
column12: from financial services to entertainment
column13: is vulnerable to such risks. In 2015
column14: cybercrime ranked as thesecond mostreported economic crime. Increasingly frequent and precision-based cyber-attacks call for a stronger fortification against them.makeArticleAd();Cyber attacks can be categorized across various degrees. While some involve data breaches which exposes sensitive information like trade secrets
column15: personal data
column16: intellectual property
column17: and other confidential information
column18: others threats involve disabling software infrastructure
column19: taking over systems
column20: or denial of service.The total number of cyber security incidents reported in 2009 were 3.4 million while the number increased to 59.1 million in 2015
column21: as per a PwC globalsurvey. “The U.S. Federal Reserve detected more than 50 cyber breaches between 2011 and 2015
column22: with several incidents described internally as ""espionage
column23: according to Fed records” asreportedby Reuters. A recently releasedreportby MetricStream reveals that 66.2% of financial organizations faced at least one cybersecurity attack in the last year.Popular retail houses such as Target and Home Depot have been victims of such activities resulting in loss of costumer data and credit card information. Not just companies
column24: even individuals are prone to risk with an estimated an “estimated 556 million people falling victim to cybercrime annually” which translates to 12 people every second. These figures perhaps don’t reflect the exact situation as many cybercrime incidents either go unreported or undetected for a long time.Cyber attacks don't just result in losses of money or data
column25: they also dent the reputation of the entity affected by the attack
column26: culminating in the loss of trust among suppliers and customers. Attacks can also trigger regulatory or legality proceedings
column27: negligence claims
column28: and can lead to the loss of productivity and competitiveness
column29: especially in cases of industry espionage which often go undetected. It ispredictedthat globally
column30: cybercrime costs will touch $6 trillion annually by 2021
column31: from $3 trillion in 2015.The race among the cyber criminals and cyber security providers is a tough and a challenging one. It is unbelievable how a computer node in part of the world can actually play mischief with bank accounts or get control of a company’s sensitive data
column32: which may be in another part of the world.Given the growing incidence and sophistication of cyber-attacks
column33: corporations and governments have increased allocations towards combating cybercrime. In fact
column34: many have even resorted to insurance coverage for cyber liability. It isestimatedthat the cyber insurance market could grow to $5 billion by 2018 in annual premium and to at least $7.5 billion by 2020.The global spending on cybersecurity products and services for defending against cybercrime is projected to exceed $1 trillion cumulatively over the next five years
column35: from 2017 to 2021 as per theestimatesof Cybersecurity Ventures.In the U.S.
column36: President Obama laid great emphasis on cybersecurity as he identified it “as the most serious economic and national security challenge.” According to the Cybersecurity National Action Plan (CNAP)
column37: the U.S. administrationannouncedan investment of over $19 billion for cybersecurity as part of the President’s Fiscal Year (FY) 2017 Budget
column38: representing a more than 35% increase from FY 2016 in overall Federal resources for cybersecurity.Microsoftestimatesthat by 2020
column39: 4 billion people will be online
column40: 50 billion devices will be connected and data volume will be 50 times great than it is today. It is also estimated that about 75% of infrastructure will be controlled by third party cloud or internet service providers. Thus
column41: “As we look to the future
column42: the explosion of connected devices and data flows are making it even more challenging to protect against advanced targeted attacks.”While this is a challenging situation
column43: there lies great opportunity for companies operating in the field of cyber security
column44: as they witness an increased demand for products which empower companies and institutions to fight the menace of cybercrime.International Business Machines Corporation (IBM)

column48: Inc. (PANW)

column54: Inc. (FEYE)

The increased competiveness within the space and the challenges thrown by hackers and cybercriminals are compelling these companies to stay ahead of the dark shadows looking to cast their spell."

column1: 3 Top Internet of Things Stocks to Buy Now;11/14/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.After a seemingly constant stream of discussion by the media

column24: 1 billion personal computers

column29: autonomous   delivery drones

column1: Dust Settles on Election
column2: Q3 Earnings;11/14/2016;"Monday
column3: November 14
column4: 2016makeArticleAd();Following the best week in the Dow for the past five years
column5: market futures are relatively tepid early this Monday. The immense relief rally that followed the year-and-a-half-long marathon of the U.S. General Election
column6: and the subsequent hopefulness in the Pharma
column7: Finance and Construction spaces from a President Trump administration helped markets rise ""bigly"" last week.Further
column8: we saw the Volatility Index (VIX) fall precipitously in the week
column9: tumbling to its third-largest weekly drop in history (the steepest week-long drop was the week following Great Britain's Brexit vote). Meanwhile
column10: the 10-year bond yield shot up to its highest level since the beginning of the year
column11: and continues to ride higher this morning at over 2.2%. The 10-year had been wallowing in 1.7% territory throughout most of the summer. Yields are rising at the same time the stock market is rising - how long can we expect this to last?Also

column13: with just 21 S&P 500 companies remaining to report this week
column14: mostly in big-box retail. Earnings from companies like Home DepotHDTuesday

column18: the last time before Q3 2016 we saw positive earnings results was back before the presidential election had gotten underway.Looking ahead
column19: we do see weakness in the oil market. An OPEC meeting scheduled for later this month appears to have its work cut out for itself
column20: at least in terms of oil-rich nations agreeing to cut back production and work down the global supply glut that has created headwinds for the market over the past year-plus. Ahead of today's bell
column21: we see the WTI -1.1% and Brent crude -0.9%.Market indices had been mixed earlier this morning
column22: but a half-hour before the opening bell we are again in positive territory: S&P 500 +6.5
column23: Dow +73 and Nasdaq +0.25. The tech-heavy Nasdaq has seen the most pressure since Donald Trump won the election

column1: Nokia (NOK) to Offer LTE-R Service to Korea Rail Network;11/14/2016;"Nokia CorporationNOKrecently inked a deal with Korea Rail Network Authority (""KRNA"") to provide LTE-R mobile broadband network to the latter. Notably
column2: this is the first time that such a technology will be deployed.KRNA maintains and develops railway infrastructure in South Koreaas well as several other countries. Its railway operations and employee services would
column3: therefore
column4: be highly benefited by the new broadband network technology. The LTE-R service will be initially introduced on a railway line between Wonju and Gangneung in South Korea as the country is gearing up to host a major international sporting event in 2018.Details of New TechnologyThe LTE-R technology is a version of the popular 4G LTE technology. The new technology is currently being developed to cater to the various requirements of railway operators. KRNA's communication network will utilize the LTE-R technology for operational and maintenance purposes. The company's high speed commercial railway line can reach speeds of up to 250 kilometers per hour and the LTE-R technology should ensure a secure
column5: trustworthy and high-speed connection among trains
column6: stations and other facilities.The company's project will also serve as the base for the future applications of the LTE-R technology. Nokia will be supplying radio access networks (RAN) base stations (eNodeBs) in addition to Nokia NetAct(TM) for this project. NetAct provides advanced assurance capabilities that forms a key component of the company's multi-domain Service Assurance program. NetAct is also utilized for providing railway operations and employee service management applications to KRNA.Despitestiff competition from peers like Cisco Systems

column1: A Weak Quarter Expected for Cisco Systems;11/13/2016;"Networking hardware giantCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) has made a habit of beating analyst estimates
column2: and   the company will try to extend that streak when it reports its   fiscal first-quarter results after the market close on Nov. 16.   Cisco performed better than expected during the fourth quarter
column3: but the announcement of significant layoffs balanced out that   good news. Revenue has declined for three quarters in a row

column7: which doesn't exclude that negative impact
column8: calls for revenue of $12.34 billion

column14: driven   by a higher gross margin and lower operating expenses. That kind   of growth is unlikely to be repeated during the first   quarter.A restructuring plan amid tepid growthCisco still derives the bulk of its revenue from networking   switches and routers

column1: 4 Cybersecurity Stats That Will Blow You Away;11/13/2016;"The global cybersecurity market could grow from $122.45   billion today to $202.36 billion by 2021

column7: and that the Asia   Pacific region will experience the highest growth as growing   markets like China and India deploy more cybersecurity   solutions.That forecast sounds bullish
column8: but investors should also   examine these four other stats to understand how rapidly the   cybersecurity market could grow within the next few years.Stat number oneNearly178 million personal recordswere exposed in data breaches in 2015
column9: according to the Identity   Theft Resource Center. Nearly 70% of those breaches occurred in   the healthcare sector
column10: and almost 20% occurred at   government/military agencies.These organizations will likely increase their cybersecurity   budgets considerably in the near future

column13: according to estimates fromLloyd's and Juniper Research. That includes direct damage as well as   post-attack disruptions. Payroll giantADP
column14: hard drive makerSeagate
column15: the FBI
column16: the IRS
column17: and the Department of Homeland Security --   which were all  struck by data breaches this year -- all   know how costly these attacks can be.While larger companies and organizations are gradually   responding to these threats
column18: Cisco's 2016 Annual Security Report   found that just 29% of small to medium-sized businesses used   basic security tools like configuration and patching to prevent   breaches --downfrom 39% in 2014.Stat number threeDespite that apparent complacence
column19: 52% of respondentsin CyberEdge Group's 2015Cyberthreat Defense Reportbelieved that their companies would be hit by successful   cyberattacks within the year. That fear is certainly justified --   Symantec
column20: best known to consumers as the maker of Norton   Antivirus

column23: and emails. That move makes it an ""end-to-end""   security provider which offers ""layers"" or protection
column24: which   previously required services from multiple vendors.Stat number four43% of data breaches were caused internally

column26: caused by poor security practices

column2: Inc.'s Q3 Earnings in 10 Wild Metrics;11/10/2016;"WhileFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) stock fell about 5% after its earnings release last   week

column7: which accounts for about   97% of the social network's total revenue

column10: hitting $5.7 billion. Mobile ad   revenue now accounts for about 84% of Facebook's total   revenue.$7 billion: This is the revenue Facebook brought in during Q3. Not only is   this figure above analysts' consensus estimate for third-quarter   revenue of about $6.9 billion

Seven billion dollars in third-quarter revenue   puts Facebook at an annualized revenue run rate of $28 billion --   just shy ofNike's annual revenue of $33 billion and aboveMcDonald'sand its annual revenue of about $25 billion.166%: Facebook isn't the typical growth tech company with nice   top-line growth and paltry earnings. In fact

column17: up from 896 million   in the year-ago quarter.1.79 billion: Facebook's monthly active users on its core social network   increased 16% year over year

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column18: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column19: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column20: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column21: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column22: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows »"

column1: Better Buy: Qualcomm Inc vs. Broadcom Ltd.;11/9/2016;"Qualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) andBroadcom(NASDAQ: AVGO) are two semiconductor giants that grew much larger   through acquisitions over the past few years. But those   acquisitions also dramatically altered the business models of   both companies
column2: and investors who haven't been following these   chipmakers might be surprised by their new strategies.Image source: Pixabay.makeArticleAd();What do Qualcomm and Broadcom do?Qualcomm
column3: the largest mobile chipmaker in the world
column4: generates   most of its revenue from SoCs (system on chips)
column5: which combine   application processors
column6: GPUs
column7: and baseband modems for smartphones   and tablets. But its patent licensing business
column8: which charges   OEMs licensing fees for every 3G/4G device sold
column9: generates the   lion's share of its profits.To offset slowing sales of smartphones and strengthen its   patent portfolio
column10: Qualcomm expanded into adjacent markets with   big acquisitions
column11: including wireless chipset maker Atheros in   2011
column12: IoT (Internet of Things) chipmaker CSR in 2015
column13: and itsplanned purchaseofNXP Semiconductors
column14: the biggest automotive chipmaker in the world.Broadcom once competed against Qualcomm in the mobile   application processor and baseband modem markets. But tough   competition forced Broadcom to leave both markets and pivot   toward radios for consumer devices and chips for data center   networking equipment. Avago
column15: a maker of analog and mixed-signal   chips
column16: acquired Broadcom earlier this year and assumed Broadcom's   name.The ""new"" Broadcomsubsequently soldits IoT business toCypress Semiconductor(NASDAQ: CY)
column17: and recently announced its plans to buy networking   equipment vendorBrocade(NASDAQ: BRCD) . That deal will make Broadcom one of the three   largest FC (fiber channel) equipment vendors in the  world   alongsideCiscoandCavium.Qualcomm's strengths and weaknessesQualcomm's chipmaking business faces several major headwinds   -- slowing demand for smartphones worldwide
column18: its loss of market   share to cheaper rivals likeMediaTek
column19: and the development of first-party ARM chips by leading OEMs   likeApple
column20: Huawei
column21: and Xiaomi.Qualcomm's licensing business also faces defiant OEMs and   regulators
column22: which claim that its fees are too high compared to   the low margins of the smartphone industry. It was already forced   to lower those fees  in China last year. Those pressures   caused Qualcomm's revenue and earnings to respectively fall 7%   and 5% last year.However
column23: Qualcomm's new high-end Snapdragon chips
column24: its   aggressive expansion into adjacent markets
column25: and new licensing   agreements with OEMs (especially in China) are expected to lift   its revenue by 1% and earnings by 7% this year. Closing the NXP   deal earlier would significantly boost those year-over-year   comparisons.Broadcom's strengths and weaknessesOver 10% of Broadcom's revenue comes from Apple . Prior to   merging
column26: Avago supplied power amplifier modules for iPhones and   iPads
column27: while Broadcom supplied touchscreen controllers and   combo-radios. This means that if sales Apple's iDevices continue   falling
column28: Broadcom's wireless business (27% of last quarter's   revenues) could take a hit.However
column29: Broadcom estimates that the unit will post 30%   sequential growth in the current quarter on the strength of its   unnamed ""North American smartphone customer"" (most likely Apple).   Meanwhile
column30: Broadcom's wired infrastructure business (54% of   revenues) will likely keep growing on robust demand for    switching
column31: routing
column32: and fiber optic solutions. Its   industrial segment
column33: which includes an IP licensing business
column34: also   posted double-digit annual sales growth last quarter.Broadcom's softest spot is its enterprise storage business
column35: which reported a 10% annual sales decline last quarter due to   general weakness in the data storage market. But looking ahead
column36: analysts expect Broadcom to post 94% sales growth this year   (inflated by merging with Avago)
column37: and 23% growth in 2017. On the   bottom line
column38: Broadcom's earnings are expected to rise 25% this   year and 20% next year.Buybacks and dividendsOver the past 12 months
column39: Qualcomm spent $3.3 billion on   buybacks and $3 billion on dividends
column40: compared to its free cash   flow of $6.9 billion during that period. However
column41: Qualcomm funded   most of thosebuybacks with debt
column42: and it's unclear how  its $47 billion purchase of NXP will   impact that strategy in the future. Qualcomm currently pays a   forward dividend yield of 3.2%. It's likely to keep raising that   dividend annually
column43: as it has done so for the past 13 years.Broadcom generated $2 billion in free cash flow over the past   12 months
column44: but it spent just $272 million on buybacks and $653   million on dividends. It also pays a much lower forward yield of   1.2%. Broadcom has raised that dividend annually for the past six   years.The valuations and verdictQualcomm trades at 20 times earnings
column45: which is slightly lower   than the industry average of 22 for the broad line semiconductor   companies. Broadcom's P/E is negative due to the costs of the   merger
column46: but it trades at 13 times forward earnings compared to   Qualcomm's forward P/E of 14.It's a close call between the two chipmakers
column47: but I believe   that Qualcomm's higher dividend
column48: more generous buybacks
column49: and its   purchase of NXP put it in a better position to grow than   Broadcom. However
column50: Broadcom's well-diversified business
column51: lower   valuation
column52: and solid top and bottom line growth still make it a   solid long-term semiconductor play.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column53: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock     price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know     investors! To be one of them
column54: just click here.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems and Qualcomm. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple
column55: NXP Semiconductors
column56: and     Qualcomm. The Motley Fool has the following options: long     January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool recommends Broadcom
column57: Cisco     Systems
column58: and Cypress Semiconductor. Try any of our Foolish     newsletter servicesfree for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions
column59: but we all     believe thatconsidering a diverse range of insightsmakes us better investors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 5 Takeaways From Barrick Gold's Q3 Earnings;11/6/2016;"Barrick Gold(NYSE: ABX) recently reported Q3 earnings. Reporting earnings per   share -- adjusted for non-recurring costs -- of $0.24
column2: the   company exceeded analysts' expectations of  $0.19 per share.   But there's much more to a company's quarterly performance than   just one number
column3: so let's dig in and mine the report for some of   the more interesting nuggets.Image source: Getty Images.Spilling the beans on the spillFollowing a request from the Argentine government
column4: Barrick   Goldsuspendedoperations at its Veladero mine -- one of its five core mines --   on Sept. 15 because of process solution that spilled from the   leach pad. The company resumed operations on Oct. 4
column5: having   conducted extensive water monitoring to confirm there was no   environmental impact. In addition
column6: Barrick implemented measures   to help ensure that a similar event would not occur again.makeArticleAd();Because of both the suspension of operations and adverse   weather conditions
column7: management revised Veladero's operating   guidance down for 2016. Gold production at Veladero is now   expected to fall between 530
column9: 000 ounces for   fiscal 2016 -- down about 9% from the previous guidance of   580
column11: 000. All-in sustaining costs (AISCs) have
column12: likewise
column13: been affected; management now estimates AISCs to be   between $800 and $870 per gold ounce at Veladero -- up from   the previous range of $790 to $860 per ounce.What's the deal with debt?Making a concerted effort to strengthen its balance sheet
column14: Barrick reduced its debt by approximately $3.1 billion in fiscal   2015. With a debt-reduction target of $2 billion for fiscal 2016
column15: the company reduced it by $968 million through the first half of   the year and by another $461 million during the third   quarter.Planning to dip into both some of the $2.65 billion in cash it   has on hand and some of the operating cash flow it generates in   the fourth quarter
column16: Barrick is confident it will achieve its   debt-reduction target for the year.With current outstanding debt of $8.5 billion
column17: the company is   looking to further strengthen its balance sheet
column18: setting in a   medium-term goal of reducing its debt to below $5   billion. Acknowledging the company's success in improving   its balance sheet
column19: Moody'sand S&P both upgraded their outlooks on Barrick's credit   rating.Operation: digitizationIn the third quarter
column20: Barrick announced that it will be   partnering withCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO) in an attempt to ""drive the digital reinvention of   [its] business.""Image source: Barrick Gold corporate website.Of the $100 million earmarked for digital projects in 2016 and   2017
column21: management has budgeted $50 million to be used in the first   wave of digital projects at its Cortez mine in Nevada. But Cortez   won't be alone in making use of the new technology. Further   demonstrating its commitment to the safety and security of   Veladero
column22: Barrick will make the Argentine mine a trial site   for digital technology that will improve upon its   environmental and water monitoring activities.Identifying the intended benefits of digitizing its   enterprise
column23: management claims that it will help ""us grow our cash   flow per share by enhancing productivity and efficiency at our   mines
column24: and improving decision-making and performance across our   business."" It's not just mines currently producing gold
column25: where   Barrick sees an opportunity for digitization. It is also working   to apply the digital technologies to help streamline the   permitting process.Going with the flowBesides debt reduction
column26: Barrick achieved another of its other   priorities: free cash flow growth. Generating more in the third   quarter -- $674 million -- than the first two quarters of fiscal   2016 combined
column27: Barrick has generated $1.13 billion in free cash   flow through the first nine months of 2016. Perhaps this in and   of itself doesn't mean much
column28: so let's compare it with the two   previous years: In fiscal 2014
column29: it reported negative-$136   million; in fiscal 2015
column30: it reported $471 million.The company's ability to grow its free cash flow speaks to how   well it has able to rein in spending. For the first nine months   of fiscal 2015
column31: Barrick reported $2.1 billion in operational cash   flow
column32: while it reported a comparable $1.9 billion for the same   period in 2016. The difference between the two years reflects how   well Barrick has been able to control capital expenditures.   Whereas Barrick reported $1.4 billion in capex through the first   nine months of 2015
column33: it reported only $800 million for the same   period in 2016.The lowdown on low costsEarlier this year
column34: during an investor presentation in   February
column35: management targeted AISCs to fall between $775 and $825   per gold ounce for fiscal 2016.Image source: Barrick Gold corporate website.For the third consecutive quarter
column36: management revised this   range
column37: providing improved costs guidance. It's now forecasting   AISCs to fall between $740 and $775 per gold ounce.Largely attributing the reduction in costs to ""a positive   change in [its] sales mix as a result of the divestment of [its]   high-cost mine sites
column38: Barrick reported AISCs of $704 per gold   ounce for Q3. The higher proportion of sales coming from   lower-cost operations didn't just positively affect Q3
column39: it's   benefited the first half of the year as well. In fact
column40: through   the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column41: Barrick's AISC equal $730   per gold ounce -- a 15.7% improvement over the $866 it reported   for the same period in fiscal 2015.The takeawayContinuing to execute its debt-reduction strategy and   commitment to free cash flow growth are just two of the reasons   Barrick -- and its investors -- could consider the third quarter   a success. column1: 2 Companies That Protect the Internet of Things;11/2/2016;"The Internet of Things (IoT)
column2: which consists of wearables
column3: smart appliances
column4: connected cars
column5: and other gadgets
column6: is widely   hyped as the ""next big thing"" in technology. Networking giantCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) estimates that the number of connected devices   worldwide will double from 25 billion in 2015 to  50 billion   in 2020.However
column7: the IoT's rapid growth was also recently implicated   in a series of DDoS (distributed denial of service) attacks which   affected over 80 popular websites worldwide. DDoS attacks occur   when hackers use botnets (a network of compromised computers) to   flood sites with so much traffic that they crash. Dyn DNS
column8: the   internet traffic management company which was hit by the attacks
column9: believes that poorly secured smart devices like  webcams
column10: surveillance cameras
column11: and thermostats were all hijacked to carry   out the attacks.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.In the past
column12: it was mostly PCs that were turned into ""bots""   for DDoS attacks. But since most IoT devices don't run   traditional security software
column13: they can be more easily hacked and   converted into bots . That glaring weakness should boost demand   for dedicated IoT security solutions
column14: which could be a boon for   companies likeCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andSymantec(NASDAQ: SYMC) in the near future.How Cisco protects the IoTAs one of the world's top networking equipment companies
column15: Cisco is already well-poised to profit from a more connected   world. But its security business also plays a key role in   thwarting attacks against its customers. These solutions include   cloud-based threat analysis
column16: advanced malware protection
column17: network   and perimeter security solutions
column18: physical safety and security   solutions
column19: and IP-based dispatch and incident response   systems.Cisco's security portfolio was mainly built through   acquisitions. Buying SourceFire and  ThreatGRID a few years   ago formed the foundations of its next-gen firewall and threat   prevention business. Additional purchases like OpenDNS
column20: Portcullis
column21: Lancope
column22: and CloudLock further strengthened that   business
column23: which accounted for 4% of Cisco's top line last year.   That percentage might seem small
column24: but the unit's 13% sales growth   outpaced the growth at all of Cisco's other main business   segments.Back in March
column25: Cisco acquired Jasper
column26: a cloud-based IoT    platform
column27: for $1.4 billion. By merging its networking
column28: security
column29: and IoT portfolios together
column30: Cisco offers compelling   product bundles which tackle both traditional cyberattacks and   newer IoT-based ones. Its massive free cash flow ($12.4 billion   over the past 12 months) also ensures that it can keep gobbling   up smaller security and IoT firms to become a main security   player for a hyper-connected world.How Symantec protects the IoTSymantec
column31: best known as the creator of Norton Antivirus
column32: sells   security products for PCs
column33: data centers
column34: and emails. Through its$4.65 billion acquisitionof Blue Coat earlier this year
column35: Symantec also gained security   solutions for networks and cloud services. Symantec claims that   bundling these services in end-to-end packages will enable it to   protect a wide range of platforms which would normally require   ""eight to ten"" different security vendors.Symantec is addressing the growing IoT security issues in two   main ways. First
column36: it's helping IoT device makers build more   secure IoT devices. Symantec advises these  companies on   implementing device authentication through SSL (secure sockets   layer)
column37: digital code signing
column38: endpoint protection
column39: over-the-air   updates
column40: and built-in analytics. Second
column41: it uses eight new ""Roots   of Trust"" optimized for  IoT devices. These ""roots""
column42: like   SSL authorization
column43: authenticate devices and let them communicate   with other trusted devices. By blocking access from unsecured   devices
column44: Symantec can prevent them from being hacked and   converted into bots.Like Cisco
column45: Symantec will likely keep growing its portfolio   through acquisitions. Both Cisco and Symantec have been named as   potential suitors for threat detection firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) . FireEye notably has a partnership with   ForeScout
column46: which detects unknown objects on networks to counter   IoT-based attacks.90% of IT networks could be at riskBack in 2014
column47: IDC predicted that a whopping 90% of all IT   networks will have experienced an  IoT-based security breach   by Dec. 2016. The Mirai botnet which  wreaked havoc across   the IoT in late October indicates that estimate could be   conservative
column48: and that demand for more robust solutions from   companies like Cisco and Symantec will keep growing.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column49: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock     price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know     investors! To be one of them
column50: just click here.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool owns shares of     and recommends FireEye. The Motley Fool recommends Cisco     Systems. Try any of our Foolish newsletter servicesfree for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions

column1: 10 Ways the Internet of Things Is Changing the World;10/28/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.The Internet of Things (IoT) is one of the most hyped trends   in tech

column3: IBM(NYSE: IBM)
column4: GE(NYSE: GE)
column5: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column6: andFitbit(NYSE: FIT)  are positioning themselves for the increasingly   connected future
column7: and expectations for what it will mean for   business and daily life are high. As just one example of what   connecting the world's devices could mean
column8: Cisco CEO John   Chambers has estimated that the IoT will ultimately have an   impact between five and 10 times greater than that of the   internet.makeArticleAd();The most transformative effects of near-ubiquitous device   connectivity are still far off and will take years to realize
column9: but the effects of the Internet of Things can already be   observed. Click through the presentation below to learn about 10   ways that the Internet of Things is changing the worldA secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column10: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock     price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know     investors! To be one of them
