column1: VR & AR World And Broadband World Forum Highlights;10/24/2016;"ByEdward Schneider
column2: CFA:I attended the inauguralVR & AR Worldconference as well as the 16th annualBroadband World Forum(BBWF) at the ExCel Centre in London from October 18th to October 20th. VR (virtual reality) & AR (augmented reality) World was ""virtually"" thriving with excitement and potential
column3: but was a bit short on current economic reality. In contrast
column4: BBWF was a more mundane event
column5: but with established carrier budgets in the billions of dollars behind the scenes making bets in areas likeG.fast.G.fast is a digital subscriber line [DSL] protocol for high-speed broadband transmission of around 300MB/second over copper lines. G.fast speed advantage runs out of steam beyond one kilometer. The cost is quite high
column6: however
column7: to rip out copper lines at the last kilometer of a network and replace it with super-fast optical fiber lines. British Telecom (BT) estimates it would cost about £29B ($35B) to replace its copper lines with fiber. BT plans to limit these optical fiber replacement costs
column8: by spending only £6B ($7B) through 2020
column9: retrofitting the last kilometer with G.fast processors and equipment. Beneficiaries of G.fast include companies like Broadcom
column10: now part of Avago (AVGO)
column11: as well as ADTRAN (ADTN). While G.fast is slower than optical fiber
column12: it is much faster than the 30MB-50MB/second speeds that most DSL consumers have today. G.fast
column13: in fact
column14: can be a conduit for millions of consumers to enjoy the new world of VR & AR.BBWF represents a more mature carrier and network infrastructure industry
column15: where carrier network spending is projected to decrease 3% in 2016. This carrier spending slowdown in part reflects the beginning of a shift to software defined networks (SDN) and network function virtualization (NFV)
column16: and away from traditional routing equipment from vendors such as Cisco (CSCO). Beneficiaries of this long-tailed transition to SDN and NFV include Red Hat (RHT) which provides open-source Linux integration for cloud infrastructure
column17: spanning OpenStack and software-defined networking. For more color on SDN and NFV
column18: please refer to mylatest articleon this subject.makeArticleAd();In contrast
column19: VR & AR is just at the beginning of a long journey
column20: in a market that is expected to grow from a small base today to several billion dollars by 2020. FutureSource projected VR content alone to reach $6B by 2020. Ovum forecasts the total VR market to reach $285B by 2020. In my opinion
column21: 2020 VR & AR revenues will be a fraction Ovum's estimate. Nonetheless
column22: the dynamic growth potential of the VR & AR markets is evident.Today
column23: consumers are just becoming aware of virtual and augmented reality
column24: mainly through games. This summer's Pokemon craze put AR on the map
column25: albeit in a dumbed-down version. To increase awareness and make VR & AR more widespread
column26: a few things need to happen.First
column27: the price-points need to come down to mass-market levels. Valve/HTC (2498.TW) VR headsetVive($800 ASP) and the soon-to-be-releasedMeta 2($949 ASP) AR headset are moving closer to critical-mass price points. Microsoft (MSFT)Hololens($3000 ASP) had some impressive features such as moving and changing virtual objects with your hands
column28: but is still priced too high for most consumers. First-mover Facebook (FB)Oculus Rift($800 ASP including Oculus Touch) is also helping to create a viable VR market. But $800 headsets are still out of reach for many consumers.To be fair
column29: there are some lower-priced
column30: generally less-advanced headsets including Sony (SNE)PlayStation VR($400 ASP plus PlayStation console)
column31: Samsung (SSNLF)Gear VR($200 ASP including controller plus smartphone
column32: co-designed with Oculus)
column33: Google (GOOG) (GOOGL)Daydream($100 ASP plus smartphone)
column34: LG (LGEAF)360 VR($250 ASP plus smartphone)
column35: and ZeissVR One($150 ASP plus smartphone). I was impressed with HumanEyes Technologies' Vuze 360 degree immersive audio/video camera and advanced video-editing stitching technology. I would categorize these technologies as quasi-VR
column36: although they have the most near-term potential. According to Digitimes
column37: shipments of VR-enabled smartphones are expected to soar to 70 million units in 2016
column38: accounting for 5% of global smartphone shipments.Second
column39: content needs to improve for wider-scale monetization. Vive has been on the market for six months. During that time
column40: Vive partnered with various game companies
column41: two of which have already achieved revenues in excess of $1M. As the breadth and quality of the games improve
column42: the market will grow. Today
column43: the VR & AR markets are still missing the killer app or game beyond Pokemon that will really spike the growth curve. Epic Games/Tencent Holdings' (TCEHY)Robo Recallto be launched in Q1 2017 potentially could be a killer game.Third
column44: the hardware needs to step up. The latency has to come down to the milliseconds
column45: the power consumption needs to decline dramatically
column46: field of vision needs to expand to closer to 180 degrees
column47: head-set weight and size need to shrink
column48: augmented display technology needs to improve
column49: and telecom networks need to be able to transmit these VR & AR features to consumers. Encouragingly
column50: progress on these fronts was demonstrated at the trade show. TheLighthouse laser trackingfor virtual navigation inside Vive is especially impressive.I chaired an Innovation Panel at VR & AR World
column51: with Christian Brändli ofInsightness
column52: Vitaly Ponomarev ofWayRayand Dominic Eskofier ofNvidia(NVDA). Insightness makes event-based visual positioning modules that process pixels like the human brain. The company's Silicon Eye vision sensors and proprietary processing algorithms lead to exponentially faster image processing/lower power consumption
column53: while providing 3D spatial awareness of where you are. Insightness can enable next-generation AR and VR hardware to meet the low power consumption
column54: fast millisecond response times
column55: and focal positioning to create a better end-user experience. WayRay builds AR car windshield navigation systems. The company's unique holographic and inertial sensor technology
column56: enable longer and wider fields of view than exist today. WayRay should be a boon to the budding driverless car market.Nvidia GeForce
column57: Quadro and Tegra graphic processor units (GPUs) are the engines for high-end gaming
column58: including VR & AR. Nvidia
column59: via its Tesla and GRID chips
column60: also has a fast-growing artificial intelligence [AI] business. Nvidia faces competition from a number of GPU competitors like Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) in gaming. For AI markets like data centers
column61: high-performance computing and driverless cars
column62: Nvidia faces competition from GPU-based Nirvana/Intel (INTC)
column63: Intel from the computer processing field
column64: CEVA (CEVA) from the digital signal processor angle
column65: ARM/SoftBank (SFTBF) and ThinCI. While Nvidia chips' parallel processing capabilities are impressive
column66: Nvidia's key competitive advantage may be providing software engineers well-documented platforms for building applications on top of its core processors
column67: such as CUDA for parallel programming and G-Sync for displays.Advances in processors and platforms (Nvidia)
column68: displays (WayRay) and image sensors (Insightness) can help VR & AR hardware reach its potential. Nvidia would be the publicly-quoted way to broadly access the future growth of VR
column69: AR and AI
column70: although the stock is not cheap.Visionaries espoused the potential of VR & AR in the coming decade. Huawei's Richard Li saw three main VR & AR markets - video
column71: gaming and online shopping. Video and gaming have the largest potential according to Mr. Li. For VR gaming
column72: Mr. Li estimated 216M gamers generating $11.5B in revenues by 2025. Shopping has potential
column73: but will require high-bandwidth real-time interaction with objects.Meta's Ryan Pamplin provided a vivid view of an augmented and virtual reality future. He pictured hardware devices to be 3D (not flat)
column74: wide viewing
column75: have interactive sculpting of virtual objects
column76: with the ability to turn on and off application layers that are contextually relevant to the user. By 2020
column77: the form factor will be small enough to put on glasses or lenses
column78: and AR and VR will become more main-stream from on-line shopping and fashion designers to mobile phones. By 2030
column79: Mr. Pamplin said that we will go beyond glasses to human brain-derived images
column80: millisecond latency
column81: multi-gigabit throughput
column83: all processed in the cloud.See alsoDepomed: A Gift From The Indexerson seekingalpha.com"

column1: Should You Buy Fortinet Inc. On Its Double-Digit Drop?;10/23/2016;"Cybersecurity firmFortinet(NASDAQ: FTNT) has fallen 13% over the past month
column2: with most of   the decline occurring after it pre-announced its  third   quarter earnings on Oct. 11. The numbers initially looked decent   -- the company expects revenue to rise 20% to 22% annually
column3: while   billings should improve 14% to 16%.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();However
column4: both estimates were reduced from higher guidance
column5: and   represent a significant slowdown from its 30% revenue growth and   26% billings growth in the previous quarter. It would also   represent Fortinet's slowest year-over-year sales growth since   the fourth quarter of 2013. CEO Ken Xie attributed that slowdown   to longer deal cycles
column6: sluggish enterprise spending
column7: sales   execution challenges in North America
column8: and macro challenges in   Latin America and the U.K.However
column9: Xie declared that the company remained ""confident in   the underlying strength of our business and long-term growth   opportunity
column10: and committed to delivering returns to our   shareholders."" The company also boosted its share buyback plan by   $100 million to $300 million. Should investors take advantage of   Fortinet's recent swoon to start a position? Let's take a closer   look at Fortinet's business to find out.What does Fortinet do?Fortinet is the  fourth largest network security   appliance vendor in the world afterCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column11: Check Point(NASDAQ: CHKP)
column12: andPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW)
column13: in that order. Fortinet serves over 280
column14: 000   customers worldwide
column15: including the ""majority"" of the    Fortune 500.Fortinet's core product is a next-gen firewall called   Fortigate
column16: which includes network security appliances connected   to its Fortinet Security Fabric. That ""fabric"" offers end-to-end   protection across on-premise
column17: cloud-based
column18: and Internet of Things   (IoT) devices. Fortinet also recently acquired security firm    AccelOps to strengthen its position in cloud and IoT   analytics.The bear case against FortinetFortinet's third quarter slowdown suggests that it is   gradually falling behind its closest rival
column19: Palo Alto Networks.   Fortinet's revenue rose 31% in 2015
column20: but  analysts expect   that growth to slow to 25% this year and 18% next year. Palo   Alto's revenue rose 49% last year
column21: and is expected to grow 33%   this year and 30% next year.Palo Alto is also growing its market share at a faster rate   than Fortinet. IDC reports that between the second quarters of   2015 and  2016
column22: Palo Alto's share of the network security   appliance market rose from 9.3% to 12.1%. During that period
column23: Fortinet's share grew from 8.2% to 9.8%.But even Palo Alto hasn't been growingfast enoughto satisfy investors -- that's why the stock has declined 16%   this year. If Palo Alto's growth rates are considered mediocre
column24: it's doubtful that investors will embrace Fortinet's slower   growth and smaller market share.Fortinet also isn't consistently profitable on a GAAP basis.   It reported a GAAP net loss of $1.4 million last quarter
column25: compared to a profit of $0.8 million in the prior year quarter.   Like Palo Alto
column26: stock-based compensation (SBC) expenses are a   major weight on Fortinet's bottom line
column27: gobbling up  22% of   its revenue last quarter.The bull case for FortinetHowever
column28: Fortinet trades at just 4.7 times sales
column29: compared to   Palo Alto's P/S ratio of 9.4. Fortinet's P/S ratio also hovers   near multi-year lows
column30: so itmightrepresent a good long-term buying opportunity if cybersecurity   stocks rebound on stronger enterprise spending.Source:YChartsFortinet is also selling more subscription bundles with its   hardware to boost its gross margins. That effort has clearly paid   off over the past two years.Source:YChartsMeanwhile
column31: Research and Markets estimates that the global   market of security appliances will  grow at a compound   annual growth rate of 11.4% between 2016 and 2020
column32: fueled by an   increase in data breaches.While Fortinet's annual sales growth is slowing down
column33: it's   unlikely to drop to the single digits for the foreseeable future.   With an enterprise value of $4.4 billion and a clean balance   sheet
column34: Fortinet could also be a lucrative takeover target for   larger players like Cisco.Is it time to buy Fortinet?I believe that Fortinet's lower valuation and consistent   margin expansion make it a more compelling buy than Palo Alto.   But I also believe that the market for firewalls and threat   prevention solutions is a crowded one
column35: and that Fortinet may   struggle to keep pace with its larger rivals over the long   term.Therefore
column36: I would avoid Fortinet unless its sales growth   accelerates again. Until that happens
column37: Fortinet will likely   remain under pressure as investors focus on higher-growth plays   in the cybersecurity sector.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column38: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock     price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know     investors! To be one of them
column39: just click here.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool owns shares of     and recommends Check Point Software Technologies. The Motley     Fool recommends Cisco Systems and Palo Alto Networks. Try any     of our Foolish newsletter servicesfree for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions
column40: but we all     believe thatconsidering a diverse range of insightsmakes us better investors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Ericsson's (ERIC) Q3 Earnings in the Red
column2: Shares Tumble;10/21/2016;"Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson (publ)ERICmore than delivered on its profit warning last week for its third-quarter 2016 results
column3: as it reported its first loss in nearly four years. Its diluted loss came in at SEK 7 (1 penny) in the quarter
column4: compared with earnings of SEK 94 in the prior-year period.The Swedish wireless equipment maker had released ominous preliminary results last week
column5: indicating a huge decline in top line
column6: citing a steadily weakening mobile broadband business and overall adverse industry trends. The news shocked investors and sent the stock plummeting 20%.Ericsson reported non-IFRS earnings per share (excluding amortizations
column7: write-downs of acquired intangible assets and restructuring charges) of SEK 34 (4 cents) for the quarter
column8: missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 9 cents by a whopping 55.6%. The bottom line fared even worse in year-over-year comparison
column9: having fallen a colossal 75% from the prior-year tally of SEK 1.34.Investors were terribly disappointed with the top- and bottom-line miss. Ericsson's shares were trending down significantly inpre-market trading
column10: falling 4.3% at one point.This is the third consecutive earnings miss for the Swedish giant. Ericsson missed earnings by nearly 29% in second-quarter 2016.The decline in bottom line can be attributed to the consistent weak product demand
column11: which gave rise to weakness across the company's segments. Also
column12: negative revaluation effects of currency hedge contracts and restructuring charges put further pressure on earnings.Inside the HeadlinesRevenues continued their downward spiral and fell 14% year over year to SEK 51.1 billion ($6 billion) for the quarter
column13: lagging the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $6.5 billion.Sluggish growth in emerging markets like Brazil
column14: Russia
column15: and the Middle East
column16: completion of major projects in European markets and adverse currency translation hampered revenues. Other broader negative trends from the first half of the year accelerated as well
column17: particularly impacting Networks segment.The decline in sales was all-pervasive
column18: with all three operating segments of the company charting negative revenue growth.Segmental PerformanceOn a segmental basis
column19: Networks revenues were down 19% year over year to SEK 23.3 billion ($2.7 billion). Markets with a weak macro environment recorded softness in both mobile broadband coverage and capacity sales. Delayed spectrum auction in India and lower 3G sales in China proved to be drag on sales in this segment.Also
column20: lack of revenues on account of completion of major European mobile broadband projects in 2015 compounded the segment's problems. However
column21: rapid 4G deployment in China
column22: along with strong core networks sales compensated the decline to some extent.Global Services revenues fell 8% year over year to SEK 24.8 billion ($2.9 billion). Continued decline in Network Rollout sales and tepid professional services performance led to the unimpressive sales.Support Solutions revenues also went down 11% year over year to SEK 2.9 billion ($340 million)
column23: dragged primarily by lower software licensing sales in transformation projects.Ericsson's gross margin (excluding restructuring charges) in the quarter contracted 560 basis points year over year to 28.3%.The company's efforts to curb costs failed to offset the diminishing sales and thus
column24: the company's margins contracted sharply. A bigger share of lower margin business like services business
column25: along with lower sales in Networks and mobile broadband businesses
column26: contributed to the compressed margins.The decline in Ericsson's operating margin (excluding restructuring charges) was even more pronounced
column27: plummeting 790 basis points on a year-over-year basis to 0.7%. The effect of lower gross margin trickled down to operating margins
column28: with higher R&D expenses further contracting it.Three-Pronged Growth PlanEricsson is presently following a three-pronged strategy to drive growth. The first strategic area is ""core business growth
column29: in which the company is focusing on deployment of 4G and promotion of 5G. The company constantly seeks to seize business opportunities as operators shift toward 4G deployment and prepare grounds for the forthcoming 5G revolution.The second area of focus
column30: which is to improve profitability in the targeted growth areas
column31: is witnessing the company concentrate on ""software sales"" and ""recurring businesses"" to drive growth in its thriving Professional Services.The final growth area is ""cost and efficiency program"" that has been devised to generate higher cost savings. In fact
column32: to adapt to and counteract the lower demand for mobile broadband investments
column33: Ericsson has mapped a set of significant actions to boost efficiency and cut costs further.The formerly announced cost and efficiency program
column34: through which Ericsson intends to unlock savings of SEK 9 billion in 2017
column35: is moving ahead per the plan. Ericsson further revealed plans to reduce cost of sales
column36: in order to adapt operations to weaker mobile broadband demand. The company plans to reduce the annual run rate of operating expenses (excluding restructuring charges) to SEK 53 billion in the second half of 2017
column37: through these initiatives. This is comparable to SEK 63 billion in 2014
column38: and equates to double the amount of savings in operating expenses that was previously targeted.LiquidityDuring the quarter
column39: cash utilized in operating activities came to SEK 2.3 billion ($270 million)
column40: compared with cash generated from operating activities of SEK 1.6 billion at the end of third-quarter 2015.Ericsson's cash and cash equivalents as on Sep 30
column41: 2016 totaled SEK 24.4 billion ($2.9 billion)
column42: compared with SEK 34 billion a year back.Changes in Company StructureIn first-quarter 2016
column43: Ericsson announced a set of structural changes to improve strategy execution and drive efficiency. The company plans to design five business units and one dedicated customer group for Industry & Society
column44: in line with its three-pronged growth strategy. With these changes
column45: Ericsson believes that it will be better equipped to cater to the needs of multiple customer segments and leverage on market opportunities to drive faster growth.To ConcludeEricsson has been grappling with an industry wide slump in demand and fierce competition from China has further exacerbated this cyclical downturn. Investors have steadily lost faith in this company
column46: which has tanked 49% over the past year.ERICSSON LM ADR Price and EPS SurpriseERICSSON LM ADR Price and EPS Surprise|ERICSSON LM ADR QuoteEricsson is contending with stiff competition from Huawei Technologies Co. and Nokia Corp.NOK. Slumping demand in Russia and Brazil
column47: and accelerating negative industry trends have further compounded its problems. Slowing pace of telecom industry
column48: upgrades to 4G standards
column49: and consequent lower spending from clients like Vodafone and Verizon have battered Ericsson's prospects.To combat such critical industry concerns
column50: Ericsson recently struck a partnership with Cisco Systems Inc.CSCO
column51: to boost its product lineup and sell more complete networks. The company expects that the deal would generate $1 billion or more in annual sales for each company by 2018.The company is also taking internal steps to stabilize its operations somewhat. It has plans to reduce its operating expenses by 10 billion kronor by 2017 compared with 2014. However
column52: the company has acknowledged that its savings plans and job reductions do not seem enough to weather the swiftly declining demand.Whether the growth and cost-streamlining efforts of this Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) company will help it beat industry-wide demand blues
column53: remains to be seen.InterDigital

column6: 2016 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeIntel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report)

I say good-ish because the company managed to continue growing its PC-related business despite what IDC and Gartner had to say about continued declines. It also saw IoT revenue grow strongly and one can hope that in the not-too-distant future (hopefully 2017)
column11: its next-generation memory chips will make it to market.Data center revenue grew as well
column12: but not as much as many were hoping. Drilling down further
column13: it appears that enterprise remains the spoilsport while cloud is putting up a good fight to make up for this weakness.Significantly
column14: while all costs declined as a percentage of sales sequentially as well as from last year
column15: R&D and engineering costs were down substantially. CEO Brian Krzanich expressed satisfaction about management's ongoing restructuring program and said ""We… continue to realign our resources to our strategy."" True enough
column16: non-PC businesses contributed nearly 53% of operating profit while generating around 43% of revenue in the last quarter.INTEL CORP Price and EPS Surprise|INTEL CORP QuoteIntel shares are sliding today as guidance for the upcoming quarter missed the Street's expectations.Here are five things I picked from the announcement that will hold true for other technology players as well:Earnings Beats May Not Mean Stock AppreciationInvestors this season have a lot of things on their minds what with the election coming up and the strong chances of a rate hike to follow soon thereafter. China growth concerns haven't helped matters (GDP is steady at 6.7% for the third straight quarter
column17: which is the lowest rate in 25 years
column18: but experts are betting this too will drop as the government takes measures to control escalating real estate prices).To top it all
column19: the U.S. dollar continues to strengthen
column20: reaching new highs just a couple of days ago. And as we all know
column21: most tech companies sell a lot of stuff abroad so a stronger dollar just doesn't help.So this quarter
column22: investors prefer a strong guidance to an earnings beat and shares of companies that fail on the former are going to be punished.PC Inventory BuildupBelieve it or not
column23: companies supplying into the PC (that includes laptops and hybrids) market could see some inventory accumulation and consequently
column24: weaker sales in the current quarter. IDC mentioned that ""Although we've now seen two consecutive quarters of strong market growth
column25: we believe the strong market performance has less to do with strengthening demand and more to do with increased appetite from the channel for inventory"" and
column26: ""We will need a strong holiday season to ensure that we don't enter 2017 in a poor inventory situation.""Check out what Intel says in explaining the below seasonal guidance for the client segment: ""we expect the worldwide PC supply-chain to reduce the inventory.""So the quarter is likely to see inventory corrections and some caution about spending on inventories that PC-exposed companies may experience.Growth Is Where the Cloud IsIntel management said that the cloud piece of its data center business grew 30%+ from the year-ago quarter compared to a 3% decline in the enterprise business. The enterprise softness is partly on account of companies moving their operations to the cloud. While this piece will remain a drag on results

column28: tech companies with a cloud focus
column29: such as and Salesforce (NYSE:CRM-Free Report)
column30: or those that are in rapid transition to it such as Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) and Intel or those that are primarily involved with connected/computing devices or services like Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) will be beneficiaries.Realigning Costs with Strategic PrioritiesThis has become a common theme for a growing number of technology companies
column31: particularly incumbents like Intel
column32: Microsoft and Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO-Free Report) over the past few years. These giants have implemented massive restructuring actions to adjust their products and revenue models with the reality of cloud computing. Efficient cost management if not total restructuring will remain important considerations for most players.Today

column1: Will Cisco Systems Buy These 2 Security Companies?;10/19/2016;"Networking equipment giantCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) generates nearly half of its revenue from routers   and switches -- two highly commoditized
column2: slow growth markets. Its   routing revenue fell 4% last year as its switching revenue stayed   flat. IDC also reports that Ciscoislosingmarket share in both markets to aggressive rivals likeHuawei.Image source: Getty.makeArticleAd();In response
column3: Cisco has been investing heavily in higher growth   businesses like service provider video
column4: collaboration
column5: and   security solutions. Security is the fastest growing business of   the three
column6: posting 13% annual sales growth last quarter and   accounting for 4% of Cisco's top line.Over the past few years
column7: Cisco beefed up that business by   acquiring security companies like threat protection firms   ThreatGRID
column8: SourceFire
column9: OpenDNS
column10: and Lancope. But looking ahead
column11: many analysts expect Cisco to dip into its free cash flow ($12.4   billion over the past 12 months) and make additional purchases   across the cybersecurity sector. Let's take a closer look at the   two most likely targets.FireEyeFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) is frequently cited as a takeover target for   Cisco
column12: since it's a ""best in breed"" threat prevention firm which   was  notably the first cybersecurity company to be certified   by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Buying FireEye would   strengthen Cisco's security portfolio
column13: and the company could   bundle all these technologies directly into its networking   hardware and software. These bundles could widen its moat against   rivals like Huawei andHPE.FireEye hasplunged 60%over the past 12 months due to slowing sales growth
column14: jarring   management changes
column15: and its alarming cash burn rate. But it now   has a fairly low enterprise value of $1.9 billion -- not a bad   price for a company that generated $623 million in revenues last   year. Moreover
column16: FireEye's revenues are  still expected to   rise 16% this year and 15% next year. FireEye is unprofitable
column17: but its operating costs would probably decline dramatically after   being integrated into Cisco's security unit.However
column18: FireEyereportedly rebuffedseveral takeover attempts earlier this year
column19: because its    suitors offered less than the $30 per share (140% higher   than its current price) it wanted. It's also believed that Kevin   Mandia
column20: the company's new CEO
column21: is less interested in selling the   company than his predecessor
column22: David DeWalt.Image source: Getty.ImpervaOver the summer
column23: several reports claimed that Cisco's channel   partners were urging it to buyImperva(NYSE: IMPV)
column24: the leaderin  the niche market of web application firewalls (WAF)   which shield individual apps from specialized attacks. Sandler   Research estimates that the WAF market could grow at a compound   annual growth rate of 17.3% between 2014 and 2019.Speaking toCRN
column25: an unnamed Cisco Gold solution provider suggested that    buying Imperva would help Cisco ""fill in some key holes""   toward becoming an end-to-end security provider. Greg Kushto
column26: director of Security and Enterprise Networks at Force 3
column27: also   toldCRNthat Imperva excels in areas where Cisco is weak
column28: including data   security
column29: encryption
column30: and data masking.Like FireEye
column31: shares of Imperva have slumped nearly 30% over   the past 12 months due to slowing sales growth
column32: mainly attributed   to extended sales cycles and the smaller size of larger   purchases. Analysts expect Imperva's sales to rise less than 7%   this year to $250 million before possibly accelerating back to   20% next year.But unlike FireEye
column33: Imperva is still trying to sell itself.Bloombergclaims that Cisco andIBMhave both expressed interest in buying the company
column34: which has a   fairly low enterprise value of $1.3 billion. Imperva also faces   pressure from activist investor Elliot Associates
column35: which holds    a stake of nearly 10% in the company
column36: to explore ""strategic   and operational opportunities"" like a potential sale.Will Cisco buy these companies?It seems more likely for Cisco to buy Imperva than FireEye
column37: since it's actually looking to sell. But I also wouldn't rule out   a hostile bid for FireEye
column38: since the company is much cheaper than   many of its peers with an EV/Sales ratio of around 3. Imperva
column39: for example
column40: has an EV/Sales ratio of 5.Investors should never buy a struggling company in   anticipation of a buyout
column41: but FireEye and Imperva's ""best in   breed"" strengths and beaten-down prices could be too tempting for   companies like Cisco to ignore.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column42: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock     price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know     investors! To be one of them
column43: just click here.Leo Sunowns shares of Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool owns shares of     and recommends FireEye. The Motley Fool recommends Cisco     Systems. Try any of our Foolish newsletter servicesfree for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions
column44: but we all     believe thatconsidering a diverse range of insightsmakes us better investors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Provides Spinoff Details
column2: '17 View;10/19/2016;"Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co.HPE
column3: in its recent Securities Analyst Meeting
column4: discussed details about the previously announced spinoff of its Enterprise Services (ES) and software business. Moreover
column5: the company provided its fiscal 2017 outlook while reaffirming the fiscal 2016 guidance.The SplitIn September
column6: the company announced its decision to spin off its software business and merge the same with British software firm
column7: Micro Focus International Plc
column8: in a cash-stock deal worth $8.8 billion.The transaction
column9: which is subject to some regulatory approvals
column10: is anticipated to be tax free for Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Per the agreement
column11: the company will receive $2.5 billion in cash and a 50.1% stake in the merged entity
column12: currently estimated to be valued at $6.3 billion.Earlier in May
column13: Hewlett Packard Enterprise had announced the spin-off its struggling IT services segment - Enterprise Services - and entered into an agreement to merge the same with Computer Sciences Corporation (CSC). The transaction
column14: which is scheduled to close in Mar 2017
column15: will deliver approximately $8.5 billion to the company's shareholders on an after-tax basis. This includes $4.5 billion in the form of equity in the combined company
column16: $1.5 billion in cash dividend and $2.5 billion of debt assumption.HPE's 2017 ProjectionsThe company provided full year 2017 outlook in three parts
column17: taking into account the spin off-merger of its ES and Software business with Computer Sciences and Micro Focus
column18: respectively.Hewlett Packard Enterprise expects combined non-GAAP earnings (including contribution from ES and Software business) for full year 2017 in the range of $2.00 to $2.10 per share. Revenues for the same period are expected to be flat to down 1%. Free cash flow is projected to be roughly $3.6 billion to $3.6 billion for full year 2017.The company provided its non-GAAP earnings guidance (which included partial year contributionsfrom ES and Software business) for full year 2017 in the range of $1.45 to $1.55 per share. Free cash flow is projected to be negative $1.8 billion for full year 2017
column19: mainly due to pension funding payment. The company however anticipates returning $3 billion in fiscal 2017 and anticipates net operating cash balance to be roughly $8 billion.The company also provided its non-GAAP earnings guidance for full year 2017 on completion of the ESand Software deals (excludingthe contributions from both ES and Software business). Non-GAAP EPS is expected to be in the range of $1.25 to $1.35. Revenues for the same period is expected to grow modestly. Free cash flow is projected to be approximately $2.1 to 2.4 billion for full year 2017.Fiscal 2016 Outlook ReaffirmedHewlett Packard Enterprise reiterated its fiscal 2016 outlook.  The company continues to expects non-GAAP earnings per share to be $1.90-$1.95 (mid-point: $1.925). The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged lower at $1.88. Revenues for the same period are expected to increase in a range of 1% to 2%.The company continues to anticipate returning $3 billion in fiscal 2016 and expects to deliver free cash flow of $1.7 to $1.9 billion in 2016.HEWLETT PKD ENT PriceHEWLETT PKD ENT Price|HEWLETT PKD ENT QuoteConclusionWe believe Hewlett Packard Enterprise can tap opportunities owing to the improving server market in the long run. Hewlett Packard Enterprise's massive restructuring moves will complement its focus on core businesses and enable it to compete with players like Oracle ( ORCL)
column20: Cisco ( CSCO) and NetApp ( NTAP) as well as the new entrant
column21: Dell going forward.Furthermore
column22: the company has done considerably well in the enterprise class server and storage markets. The company concentrates its resources on the high-margin software and security markets as well. We believe that the company's traction in the cloud
column23: security and Big Data segments will enhance its growth trajectory
column24: going forward.Also
column25: its strategic divestments and initiatives to return value to shareholders in the form of dividend and share repurchases bode well.However
column26: macroeconomic challenges and tepid IT spending remain near-term concerns. Competition from other players in the space adds to its woes.Currently
column27: Hewlett Packard Enterprise carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank(Strong Buy)stocks hereConfidential from ZacksBeyond this Analyst Blog

column1: 3 Top Stocks for Your Roth IRA;10/19/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.Building up a nest egg only to have it taxed into oblivion at   retirement is a problem that a Roth IRA solves. Contributions   aren't deductible
column2: but that money grows tax-free
column3: potentially for   decades
column4: and withdrawals after reaching the required age are free   and clear of any taxes or penalties.makeArticleAd();Both capital gains and dividends can accumulate tax-free in a   Roth IRA
column5: a fact that makes some stocks better than others. We   asked three of our contributors to discuss a stock that would be   a perfect fit for a Roth IRA due to their growth potential.   Here's what they had to say.Putting my mouth where my money isTyler Crowe:I guess there is no better way to suggest a company for a   Roth IRA than to say that it is a holding in my own Roth IRA:Waste Management(NYSE: WM) . What makes Waste Management a compelling stock to   own in a Roth is two fold. The first is that it is a business   that is likely to be around for a long time. The waste handling   business is extremely difficult to disrupt because of the amount   of capital needed to get a business large enough to compete.   Then
column6: there is the tricky regulatory and slightly political   aspect that gives established business a big advantage -- think   trying to get the permits for a new landfill. With that   competitive advantage platform
column7: Waste Management has built a   business that generates high rates of return and uses those   returns to reward shareholders.So Waste Management's business certainly has the qualities you   want for a long-term holding in a retirement account. The other   reason this one is worth adding to a Roth IRA is you get to use   the tax advantages of the account to benefit even more from the   company's dividend. While the company's 2.6% dividend yield today   won't wow anyone
column8: the company has grown its payout at a decent   clip of 6.5% annually over the past 12 years and has bought back   24% of all shares outstanding over that time frame. The efforts   from the company to increase shareholder value through these   means and thebenefits of reinvested dividendsin a tax advantaged account can do wonders for your retirement   portfolio. That's why I own it in my Roth IRA
column9: and why you should   consider it as well.Everyone should own at least one rare disease drugmakerGeorge Budwell:Novel drugs or therapies that target rare diseases are   perhaps the most coveted types of assets within the high growth   pharmaceutical industry. The basic issue at play is that   so-called ""orphan"" drugs
column10: or drugs indicated for diseases that   afflict fewer than 200
column11: 000 people
column12: come with a variety of   benefits for their manufacturers
column13: including premium prices
column14: little to no push back from payers
column15: extended periods of   exclusivity
column16: tax breaks
column17: and arguably less competition
column18: depending   on the indication. Orphan drugs
column19: on balance
column20: also tend to require   far less capital to bring to market
column21: enabling their manufacturers   to avoid taking on the unsightly amount of debt that frequently   plagues small to mid-sized biopharmas.With these advantages in mind
column22: I think the mid-cap orphan drug   specialistBioMarin(NASDAQ: BMRN) would be a great stock to sock away in a Roth IRA.   BioMarin presently has five drugs on the market for orphan   indications

column1: The 3 Biggest Challenges Facing Cisco Systems;10/18/2016;"Networking giantCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) isn't a high growth stock
column2: but it's generally   considered a solid income play which delivers fairly predictable   returns in volatile markets. Cisco's P/E of 14 is lower than the   industry average of 25 for networking equipment companies
column3: and   its forward yield of 3.5% is higher than the S&P 500's   average yield of 2.1%.Image source: Cisco.makeArticleAd();While those numbers will likely set a floor under Cisco's   stock
column4: a few headwinds could also prevent it from moving much   higher. Let's discuss three of those biggest challenges.1. Competition in switches and routersCisco is the world's largest vendor of ethernet switches and   routers. However
column5: it's been losing market share in both markets   to rivals likeHuaweiandHPE(NYSE: HPE) . IDC reported that between the first and    second quarters of 2016
column6: Cisco's share of the switching   market fell from 59% to 56.8%
column7: and its share of the combined   router and service provider market slipped from 48.8% to   44.8%.That's a big problem
column8: since Cisco's combined switches and   routers revenue accounted for nearly half  of its top line   last year. In the past
column9: Cisco marginalized smaller rivals like   Aruba Networks with aggressive hardware and software bundling   tactics. But now that many of the smaller players have either   been beaten or acquired
column10: larger companies are striking back with   their own bundling plays.Huawei
column11: the largest wireless infrastructure company in the   world
column12: is leveraging that leading market position to sell   switches and routers to telcos and large businesses. HPE
column13: which    acquired Aruba last year to increase its scale in both   switches and routers
column14: is also bundling its networking hardware   with various other IT services.2. The rise of cloud networkingA newer challenge for Cisco is the rise of cloud networking   solutions which rely more on software instead of hardware. These   platforms
column15: also known as SDN (software-defined networking) ones
column16: are often more cost efficient and scalable than older   hardware-based networks.Last year
column17: Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha declared   that  SDN platforms will simplify networking
column18: hurt demand   for Cisco's traditional networking equipment
column19: and ""shrink gross   profit dollars for the networking stack."" Guggenheim analyst Ryan   Hutchinson also warned that Cisco's outlook was clouded by   ""uncertainty around future network architectures as more   workloads migrate to the cloud.""Image source: Getty Images.Cisco's biggest adversary in this space isArista Networks(NYSE: ANET)
column20: which has posted double-digit sales growth for   seven straight quarters. Cisco has tried to slow Arista down    with patent infringement lawsuits
column21: which resulted in import   bans on some of its products. The International Trade Commission   and U.S. Trade Representative both  upheld that ban earlier   this year in separate rulings. That ban throws a few hurdles in   Arista's way
column22: but it might not prevent Cisco from falling behind   a crucial tech curve.3. Inorganically growing its security businessCisco's security revenue rose 13% last year
column23: making it the   company's fastest growing business. While the business merely   accounted for 4% of its top line
column24: Cisco has been aggressively   growing it by acquiring cybersecurity firms like ThreatGRID
column25: SourceFire
column26: OpenDNS
column27: and Lancope. That growth makes Cisco an   oft-cited threat to smaller cybersecurity companies. However
column28: many smaller players have ""best in breed"" reputations in certain   markets which Cisco lacks.For example
column29: Palo Alto Networks'(NYSE: PANW) firewalls are  approved by a large number of   agencies
column30: including the U.S. Department of Defense. Threat   prevention firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) was the  first cybersecurity company to be   certified by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.Therefore
column31: instead of developing better security platforms   than these leaders
column32: Cisco might need to acquire them instead.   That's why there are persistent rumors about Cisco buying smaller   players like FireEye orImperva. However
column33: many of these companies aren't profitable and are   trading at high valuations -- meaning that Cisco's cybersecurity   expansion could be costly relative to the actual revenue and   profits it generates.Is Cisco still a worthy investment?I believe that Cisco is still a solid long-term investment
column34: thanks to its dominant position in the networking market
column35: growth   opportunities in the Internet of Things and across 5G networks
column36: and expansion into higher growth markets like service provider   video
column37: collaboration
column38: and security solutions. However
column39: I also   believe investors should carefully evaluate these headwinds
column40: which could cause Cisco's top line growth to remain stagnant over   the next few years.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something
column41: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat:     There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets     and the coming revolution in technology. column1: 2 Rock-Solid Internet of Things Stocks With P/Es Under 15;10/16/2016;"The Internet of Things (IoT)
column2: the connection of various   objects to ""the cloud"" and to each other
column3: is one of the hottest   growth markets in the tech sector today.Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) predicts that the number of connected devices   worldwide will double from 25 billion in 2015 to 50 billion in   2025. IDC expects the market to  grow from $655.8 million in   2014 to $1.7 trillion in 2020.Those bullish expectations have inflated the valuations of   many IoT-related stocks
column4: making it hard to find ""cheap"" plays on   this growing market. So today
column5: I'll introduce two companies that   will profit from the growth of the IoT market but still trade   with fairly low P/E ratios below 15.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Juniper NetworksJuniper Networks'(NYSE: JNPR) networking hardware and software connect IoT   devices to each other
column6: but it's often overshadowed by larger   rival Cisco. IDC says Cisco controlled 56.8% of the global   ethernet switching market in the second quarter this year.   Juniper only controlled a single-digit share of that market
column7: but   it's much stronger in the combined service provider and routers   market
column8: where it held a 15.7% share against Cisco's 44.8%.Juniper's revenue rose 5% last year
column9: and is expected to rise   1% this year and 4% next year. Cisco's sales
column10: which stayed flat   last year
column11: are expected to grow 1% this year and 3% next year.   Near-term headwinds
column12: like slower enterprise spending
column13: are   throttling both companies' top-line growth. But looking ahead

column22: but soft router and   security sales are expected to cause earnings to fall 2% this   year. After those businesses stabilize

column1: Microsoft Holds Expo in Taiwan to Boost IoT Awareness;10/14/2016;"Microsoft CorporationMSFTis holding the first-of-its-kind Microsoft IoT Expo at the Hua Nan Bank International Conference Center in Taiwan. The company also officially launched the Microsoft IoT Innovation Center at the event.The expo is being attended by 393 companies from across 17 countries. The event comprises 33 IoT applications showcases and 70 keynote speeches

column1: Barrick Gold Raised to Buy on Strong Q2 & Strategic Initiatives;10/14/2016;"On Oct 14
column2: Barrick Gold CorporationABXwas upgraded to a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).Going by the Zacks model
column3: companies carrying a Zacks Rank #2 have better chances of performing above the broader market over the upcoming quarters.Why the Upgrade?Barrick's second-quarter 2016 adjusted earnings per share (excluding one-time items) of 14 cents were in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate. Earnings surged 180% from the year-ago quarter figure of 5 cents per share. Revenues plunged 9.8% year over year to $2
column4: 012 million in the reported quarter and missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2
column5: 036 million.Recently
column6: Barrick announced that it will partner with Cisco Systems
column7: Inc.CSCOfor the digital reinvention of the former's business. The companies intend to focus on R&D and utilize both their expertise to make Barrick's mines as well as offices more digital. Digitalization at the mines is expected to increase productivity
column8: precision as well as speed of maintenance and metallurgy. An enterprise-wide analytics hub will permit performance management along with financial and operational benchmarking. New digital tools will also enhance scenario planning and portfolio management. Further
column9: the technology will improve Barrick's environmental and safety performance. The use of digital technology will increase Barrick's permitting activities
column10: thereby improving transparency to stakeholders.Barrick has a healthy liquidity position and generates healthy cash flows. It is poised to capitalize on attractive development
column11: exploration and acquisition opportunities. The company continues to make high return investments in its businesses.The company maintains a significant focus on Nevada for growth opportunities. A considerable portion of its exploration budget for 2016 has been allocated to the Americas
column12: with an extensive focus on Nevada. At Goldstrike
column13: the miner has started development of new areas to access deeper reserves that are anticipated to come into production by end-2016.For the Turquoise Ridge mine
column14: the company is currently conducting an expansion of the underground mining. At Cortez
column15: it is conducting a feasibility study for expanded underground mining in the Deep South zone and is also advancing a feasibility study for an underground mine at its Goldrush deposit.The miner is also making significant progress with its cost and efficiency improvement programs. Barrick's initiatives including overhead expenses cut
column16: portfolio optimization and headcount reductions are anticipated to generate meaningful cost savings. Additionally
column17: the company is implementing a simplified operating model which will increase efficiency and contribute to cost reduction.Barrick has already reduced its total debt by $968 million in 2016
column18: representing nearly half of its debt reduction target for the year. Currently
column19: the miner has less than $150 million in debt due before 2018 and roughly $5 billion of its $9 billion outstanding debt will mature after 2032. In 2016
column20: the company plans to reduce its total debt by at least $2 billion. Barrick estimates to save roughly $180 million in interest expenses on an annualized basis.BARRICK GOLD CP Price and ConsensusBARRICK GOLD CP Price and Consensus|BARRICK GOLD CP QuoteStocks to ConsiderSome better-ranked companies in the mining space include Newmont Mining CorporationNEMand New Gold Inc.NGDboth carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). column1: Charter Communications Nominates ARRIS for WorldBox 2.0;10/13/2016;"Charter Communications Inc.CHTR
column2: the second largest cable MSO (multi service operator) in the U.S.
column3: has selectedARRIS International plc.ARRS
column4: leading customer premises equipment (CPE) manufacturer for the cable TV industry
column5: as its vendor partner for the cable MSO's next-generation WorldBox 2.0 set-top box. Initiated in early 2015

column7: content
column8: and new video features to its subscribers.Notably
column9: just six days ago
column10: Charter Communications entered into a share warrant agreement with ARRIS. Per the deal
column11: Charter Communications has the right to purchase up to 6 million shares of ARRIS' stock between now and the end of 2018. ARRIS will make certain number of shares available to Charter Communications only after the cable MSO purchases a specific volume of ARRIS' products and services
column12: specifically
column13: the Network & Cloud segment products of ARRIS.Charter Communications new set-top box called World Box offers great entertainment experience at a low cost. Cisco Systems Inc.CSCOand Humax Co. Ltd. were the two vendor partners for the first stage of WorldBox development. Worldbox 2.0 will expand the company's current downloadable conditional access capabilities and enhance legacy hardware-based CAS systems across its footprint.Charter Communications is taking various initiatives to upgrade its Spectrum product portfolio. The company has developed its cloud-based user interface named Spectrum Guide
column14: to run on all set-top boxes offering advanced video navigation. It is currently developing Charter TV applications for its video-on-demand content.Additionally
column15: Charter Communications has independently certified its new WiFi router to provide wireless services. Moreover
column16: it has initiated the rollout of its Spectrum WiFi
column17: which provides unlimited Internet access to residential customers even when they are outdoors.Importantly
column18: Charter Communications has announced that it will foray into the wireless market. The company will activate its MVNO (mobile virtual network operator) agreement with Verizon Communications Inc.VZ
column19: which was taken over after the acquisition of Time Warner Cable. It will also install several WiFi hotspots across cities to expand its wireless network. column1: 3 Cheap Tech Stocks With Dividends Over 3%;10/13/2016;"The rapidly changing tech landscape abounds with fantastic   opportunity to transform tired legacy businesses into providers   of cutting-edge solutions to meet new customer demands. Which is   exactly whatHP(NYSE: HPQ)
column2: IBM(NYSE: IBM)
column3: andCisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) are doing -- all while paying stellar dividends to   shareholders.One of the reasons HP
column4: along with IBM and Cisco
column5: offers such   tremendous value along with strong dividends is the impatience of   some investors. The transitions HP
column6: IBM
column7: and Cisco are in the   midst of take time
column8: which some investors simply aren't willing to   give. This situation creates a great opportunity for investors   with years in mind
column9: rather than weeks or months.makeArticleAd();Image source: HP.Patience is a virtueAs HP demonstrated last quarter
column10: the PC is not dead. Led by a   12% jump in net revenue from notebooks
column11: to $4.3 billion
column12: which   offset a 9% decline in desktop earnings
column13: the company's personal   systems segment sales soared 7% sequentially
column14: to $7.51   billion.In addition to its spot as the No. 1 PC manufacturer in the   U.S. market
column15: HP sold 12.96 million units in 2016's second   calendar quarter
column16: which was a 5.1% improvement compared to a year   ago
column17: increasing the company's global market share to 20.8% --   just a whisker behindLenovo's 21.2%. HP is winning in the PC wars by targeting niche   markets. The new Omen PC
column18: complete with virtual-reality-ready   capabilities
column19: is an ideal example.HP is following the same targeted strategy in its printing   unit. The $1.05 billion acquisition ofSamsung's printing and copier division combines Samsung's   multifunction printers with HP's PageWide technology
column20: creating a   less expensive all-in-one printing-and-copier solution for   commercial customers. The 3D printing market -- an estimated $13   billion opportunity by 2018 -- is another niche HP is   pursuing.A share price at just seven times trailing earnings
column21: combined   with the company's 3.2% dividend yield
column22: warrants HP a spot on a   list of cheap dividend-paying tech stocks.Image source: IBM.Still a bargainIBM stock is up 12% year to date
column23: which is a nice change for   shareholders. Despite its share-price run
column24: IBM still trades at   less than 11 times forward earnings
column25: and boasts a 3.65% dividend.   The guarded optimism surrounding IBM is due to the performance of   its ""strategic imperatives
column26: which include cloud
column27: Internet of   Things (IoT)
column28: cognitive computing
column29: mobile
column30: and data security.Strategic imperatives generated $8.3 billion of IBM's $20.2   billion total revenue last quarter
column31: good for a year-over-year   gain of 12%. Over the past 12 months
column32: strategic imperatives   accounted for $30.7 billion
column33: equal to 38% of total sales. CEO   Ginni Rometty's plan was to boost IBM's core unit sales to 40% of   revenue annually by 2018.With third-quarter earnings slated for release on Oct. 17
column34: IBM   may prove to have hit its key revenue mark well ahead of   Rometty's initial target. Leading the way are IBM's cloud sales
column35: which ballooned to an annual run rate of $11.6 billion last   quarter. IBM's strategy of incorporating its cognitive computing   wonder Watson
column36: IoT services
column37: data security
column38: and mobile solutions   into the cloud is spot-on. That strategy
column39: coupled with the   company's targeting of specific industries
column40: will continue to   serve IBM shareholders well.Image source: Cisco.Change is goodWhen Chuck Robbins took over as CEO in 2015
column41: Cisco needed to   change from relying on old-school enterprise routers and switches   to focusing on IoT
column42: the cloud
column43: security
column44: and data center sales.   And the change is working.Two of Cisco's top-performing divisions last fiscal year were   collaboration and security
column45: climbing 9% and 13%
column46: respectively.   Strong performance across the networking company's key business   areas
column47: along with shaving over $600 million in operating expenses   in fiscal 2016
column48: improved Cisco's gross margins and drove an   impressive 21% earnings-per-share jump
column49: to $2.11.The changes Cisco is undergoing also include cutting 5
column50: 500   jobs
column51: equal to about 7% of its global workforce
column52: which has made   some investors nervous. The realignment of its engineering   division
column53: including the pending departure of Cisco's CTO
column54: may   have also spooked some folks. One thing that hasn't changed is   Cisco's sky-high dividend of nearly 3.5%. Cisco is a cheap
column55: high-yield stock deserving of a long
column56: hard look.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something

column1: Close Update: Stocks End Mixed After FOMC Minutes;10/12/2016;"Stocks in the U.S. closed on a mixed note Wednesday
column2: with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 stronger but off the day's highs as the release of the Federal Open Market Committee's September meeting minutes seemed to firm up the view that a rate hike may be in the cards before the end of 2016.Eight of the 11 sectors on the S&P 500 were stronger
column3: with real estate adding 1.3% and utilities up 1%. Energy was off 0.4% as US oil futures were down about 1.1% to $50.24 a barrel.On the Dow
column4: 16 components were higher and 14 were lower when the session wrapped up. Nike (NKE) posted the best gain
column5: adding 1.2% while Cisco Systems (CSCO) was the leading decliner
column6: falling 2.3%.makeArticleAd();Members of the FOMC saw a stronger case for a rate hike in last month's monetary policy meeting
column7: with near-term risks to the economic outlook appearing ""roughly balanced
column8: according to minutes released on Wednesday afternoon. The probability of a December hike held steady on the CME Group's FedWatch tool
column9: with a likelihood of about 64% that the rate will rise to 0.5% to 0.75%.The day's other economic release showed the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey with 5.443 million open positions
column10: down from a revised 5.831 million in July
column11: and below estimates for 5.724 million job openings.Thursday's calendar has initial weekly jobless claims and September import and export prices at 8:30 a.m. ET with the September Treasury Budget due at 2 p.m. Fed speakers include Philadelphia President Patrick Harker on the economic outlook at 12:15 p.m. and Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari at 9 p.m.Here's where the markets stood by the close:US MARKETSDow Jones Industrial Average was up 15.54 points (+0.09%)S&P 500 was up 2.45 points (+0.11%)Nasdaq Composite Index was down 7.77 points (-0.15%)GLOBAL SENTIMENTFTSE 100 was down 0.66%Nikkei 225 was down 1.09%Hang Seng Index was down 0.6%Shanghai China Composite Index was down 0.22%UPSIDE MOVERS(+) VOXX (+49.02%) Swings to a Q2 profit on higher revenues(+) CUDA (+9.17%) Reported better-than-expected Q2 EPS and revenue(+) IPCI (+5.3%) Signed an exclusive license and commercial supply agreement with Mallinckrodt (MNK)(+) SMG (+2.18%) Study shows rising support for marijuana legalization ahead of November electionDOWNSIDE MOVERS(-) ERIC (-20.83%) Warns Q3 results will be significantly lower than expectations(-) FTNT (-10.15%) Cut Q3 revenue and earnings guidance(-) RXII (-9.47%) Enters into exclusive option deal to acquire MirImmune
column12: plans securities offering(-) NOK (-5.57%) Testing 5G technologies in North America with U.S. Cellular"

column1: Facebook
column2: Inc.'s Workplace Platform Is Here -- And It's Priced Competitively;10/11/2016;"Image source: Facebook.Asexpected
column3: social media giantFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) announced on Monday that its new workplace platform   is now live for ""any company or organization that wants to use   it."" Called Workplace
column4: the collaboration platform aims to enable   more effective communication at work.makeArticleAd();Workplace enters a highly competitive market for enterprise   collaboration platforms
column5: including names like the rapidly growing   Slack andCisco's Jabber
column6: among others. Can Workplace stand out from the   incumbents?Introducing WorkplaceWhat is Workplace?""Workplace is a dedicated and secure space for companies to   connect
column7: communicate and collaborate
column8: Facebook says on the   frequently asked-questions portion of its Workplace website.   ""Organizations of all sizes can use familiar Facebook features   such as News Feed
column9: groups
column10: messages and events to get things   done.""As a comprehensive collaboration tool
column11: Workplace can   essentially replace chat-based collaboration tools like Slack and   video conferencing platforms likeMiscrosoft's Skype.A key selling point is that the platform is ""easy to use   because it's based on familiar Facebook features
column12: Facebook   asserts. Users can interact through products used on the original   Facebook platform
column13: such as direct messages
column14: posts
column15: comments
column16: groups
column17: tagging
column18: live video
column19: the News Feed
column20: and more.Workplace. Image source: Facebook.Importantly
column21: Workplace doesn't require a personal Facebook   account and is totally separate from a user's Facebook friends   and family.Facebook actually started testing Workplace over a year ago.   So it's had some time to fine-tune the offering. The company says   it now has more than 1
column22: 000 organizations using the platform.""People have created nearly 100
column23: 000 groups and the top five   countries using Workplace are India
column24: the U.S.
column25: Norway
column26: UK and   France
column27: Facebook said in its announcement on Monday.Current customers using Workplace are wide ranging
column28: including   companies likeStarbucks
column29: Booking.com
column30: Danone
column31: YES Bank in India
column32: and the Government   Technology Agency of Singapore.The business modelFacebook is already monetizing the platform
column33: though not with   ads like it usually does. With the exception of non-profits and   educational institutions
column34: which can use the platform free of   charge
column35: Facebook is charging businesses between $1 and $3 per   monthly active user
column36: depending on how many users a company has on   the platform. This pricing is aggressive
column37: considering Slack costs   about $7 per user for its standard package.Further
column38: if Facebook's decision to undercut the fastest   growing workplace collaboration app so significantly isn't   already enough evidence of how seriously the social network is   taking this new product
column39: Facebook is also enlisting important   names
column40: including companies like Deloitte
column41: Sada Systems
column42: and G   Suite to help customers move over to Workplace.Facebook explained this partnership in its announcement on   Monday:To help more companies get started with Workplace
column43: we are     announcing the Workplace Partner Program
column44: a group of technology     and professional service organizations such as Deloitte who     will work with us to bring Workplace to even more businesses     across the globe. This means that companies will have more ways     to access Workplace -- by working with our teams directly or     via our approved and trained partners.While it's too early to judge how meaningful this product will   be for Facebook
column45: or whether or not it can successfully draw   customers away from existing collaboration platforms like Slack
column46: the company's running start clearly suggests the fast-growing   king of social networks intends to succeed in this market.A secret billion-dollar stock opportunityThe world's biggest tech company forgot to show you       something
column47: but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't       miss a beat: There's a small company that's powering their       brand-new gadgets and the coming revolution in technology. column1: Is Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. (CSCO) Stock Right for Retirement?;10/7/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRetirement planning demands that you find investments that can provide decent growth for the long-term. Often this involves targeting traditional businesses with strong moats that pay dividends. Those criteria haven't always included technology
column4: but holdings likeCisco Systems
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) stock have made investors rethink the norm.Source:Prayitno via Flickr (Modified)Cisco stockis one of those perfect opportunities that presents all those buy-and-hold qualities
column6: but also provides products or services that are on the cutting edge.makeArticleAd();The Growth of CiscoCSCO
column7: which has been around since the mid-1980s
column8: has proven adept at dealing with disruptive changes in technologies - not just through research and development
column9: but also aggressive mergers and acquisitions.From the company's inception
column10: the focus has been on building powerful networks. According toSequoia's Don Valentine
column11: who was an early investor:""By the 1980s
column12: we knew that the first personal computers needed
column13: in some way
column14: to be networked - although that word hadn't been invented yet…That's why I thought the opportunity was so fabulous at Cisco: Their product was able to route that packet at light speed to the right destination. Many people had products that were like a router but were not a router. And switches were common
column15: but switches couldn't do what Cisco's product did.""The networking business definitely turned into a gold mine for Cisco stock during the 1990s
column16: when the Internet revolution took off. And while the bust in 2002-03 saw a falloff
column17: Cisco came back as network-intensive services became more ubiquitous
column18: such as with cloud computing and social networking led by fast-growing companies likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) andSalesforce.com
column19: Inc.(NYSE:CRM).But Cisco stock could be poised for even more growth. According to the company's research
column20: the amount of mobile traffic isforecast to surge by 8X from 2015 to 2020
column21: representing a 53% compound annual growth rate. Some of the drivers include mega-trends like streaming video
column22: artificial intelligence
column23: virtual reality and the Internet of Things.Cisco is more than just about the network
column24: too. Keep in mind that the company has been fairly smart at leveraging this platform by moving intoadjacent categories
column25: such as collaboration ($4.4 billion in annual revenues)
column26: data center ($3.4 billion)
column27: wireless ($2.6 billion) and security ($2 billion).Cisco Stock Is a Lesson in ControlCisco is a disciplined organization that keeps costs manageable and is careful with capital allocations. CSCO recently announced a workforce reduction of 5
column28: 500 workers
column29: or about 7% of the total. Revenue per employee for Cisco is a hefty $668
column31: which isthree times higherthan forHewlett Packard Enterprise Co(NYSE:HPE) andInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM).No surprise
column32: then
column33: that Cisco stock is rock-solid financially.Cash flows from operations in the past year came to$13.6 billion
column34: up about $1 billion from the year before. Cisco also boasts a hefty $65.8 billion in the bank - enough resources to keep up with R&D and M&A
column35: but also to support the generous Cisco dividend
column36: which yields 3.3%.Valuation is reasonable
column37: too. CSCO stock trades at 15 times earnings. By comparison
column38: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is at 27X andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) sports a multiple of 19X.Yes
column39: Cisco's growth metrics have been sluggish
column40: with revenues up just 3% for the past year. But the company has made substantial investments in markets like security and wireless
column41: which should help perk things up. Plus
column42: long-term
column43: CSCO likely will get a lift from growth in the network.All in all
column44: Cisco stock really does have the kinds of factors that make for a core retirement holding: sustainable cash flows
column45: a nice dividend and the potential for a bump on the top line.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blog IPO Playbook and alsoOptionExercise.com
column46: which provides interactive tools and financial services for   those who have employee stock options (pre- and post-IPO).Follow him on Twitter at @ttaulli. As of this writing
column47: he did   not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Top Stocks to Buy for October10 Biotech Stocks to Put on Your Radar This     QuarterThe 10 Best ETFs on the PlanetThe postIs Cisco Systems

column1: 3 Tech Stocks I Never Plan to Buy;10/6/2016;"Many tech investors chase high-growth stocks
column2: but others like   to bottom-fish for contrarian bargains. However
column3: it's important   to recognize the difference between a broken stock and a broken   company -- the former might recover
column4: while the latter might not.   Let's examine three such broken companies which I never plan to   buy.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();InvenSenseInvenSense(NYSE: INVN) makes motion sensors for smartphones
column5: tablets
column6: smartwatches
column7: and other devices. While those sound like solid   growth markets
column8: the company respectively generated 40% and 16% of   its sales fromApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andSamsunglast year. Peaking sales of both companies' mobile devices are   weighing down InvenSense's revenue
column9: which is expected to decline   24% this year and another 52% next year.To make matters worse
column10: InvenSense faces fierce competition   from larger rivals likeSTMicroelectronics(NYSE: STM) andBosch. Apple installed STMicro's motion sensors instead of   InvenSense's into the Apple Watch last year -- raising concerns   that Apple would eventually use STMicro's motion sensors for its   flagship iOS devices.InvenSense tried to offset that loss by diversifying into   virtual reality headsets and Internet of Things gadgets
column11: but both   rivals are expanding into the same markets.Facebook's Oculus Rift
column12: for example
column13: uses Bosch's motion sensors. This   ongoing competitive pressure could eventually crush InvenSense's   margins. InvenSense was  unprofitable by both non-GAAP and   GAAP measures last quarter
column14: and its losses could keep widening   due to slowing sales and rising competition.FireEyeCybersecurity firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) provides threat detection services which monitor   the perimeters of enterprise networks. This market is a growing   one due to rising data breaches
column15: but it's saturated with many   rivals like next-gen firewall providerPalo Alto Networksand networking equipment giantCisco's bundled security services.Image source: FireEye.That competition caused FireEye's sales to  rise just 19%   annually last quarter
column16: compared to 34% growth in the previous   quarter and 56% growth in the prior year quarter. FireEye expects   sales to rise just 15% to 17% this year
column17: compared to 46% growth   in 2015. The company attributes that slowdown to its shift from   on-site appliances to its new cloud-based platform
column18: FireEye as a   Service (FaaS). Appliances generate revenue immediately
column19: but   subscription-based FaaS revenues are recognized over longer   periods of time.But with sales growth slowing down
column20: FireEye's net losses will   likely widen -- and its hefty stock-based compensation expenses   (35% of its revenues in the first half of 2015) could prove   unsustainable. The company's cash and equivalents also fell from   $402 million at the end of 2015 to $184 million last quarter --   raising the possibility of additional secondary or convertible   debt offerings.To top it off
column21: FireEye's longtime CFO Michael Sheridan   resigned last July amid cash burn concerns
column22: and CEO Dave DeWalt   resigned in June. FireEye's new CEO Kevin Mandia wants to cut   costs to improve profitability -- but that strategy could reduce   its competitiveness and result in even slower sales growth.SeagateSeagate(NASDAQ: STX) has constantly struggled with declining sales of   its core HDDs (hard disk drives)
column23: which are being replaced by   smaller
column24: faster
column25: and more power-efficient SSDs (solid state   drives) -- which the company lacks a meaningful presence in. The   ongoing slowdown in PC sales has also exacerbated that   decline.Image source: Pixabay.Seagate's revenue  fell 19% in 2015
column26: and analysts expect   its top line to fall another 5% this year due to weak PC sales   and demand from data centers. Its earnings are  expected to   rise 35% this year
column27: partially recovering from its 84% decline   last year. Those forecasts sound bullish
column28: but they're inflated by   easy year-over-year comparisons and buybacks.Seagate relies heavily on buybacks
column29: spending over $1 billion   on debt-funded buybacks over the past 12 months. To make matters   worse
column30: it's promised to keep paying its forward dividend yield of   6.5% -- which looks unsustainable relative to its earnings payout   ratio of almost 300%. Meanwhile
column31: low interest rates have caused   investors to flock to high-yielding stocks like Seagate
column32: boosting   its trailing P/E to 47 -- a steep premium to the industry average   of 19 for  data storage companies.Seagate also refuses to make a major acquisition
column33: likeWestern Digital's purchase of SanDisk
column34: to remain relevant in the flash storage   and SSD markets. Instead
column35: CEO Steve Luczo convinced activist   investor ValueAct Capital to  take a big stake in the   company and help the company turn around its data storage   business. That bizarre move indicates that Luczo simply doesn't   have a clear plan for Seagate's future.The bottom lineInvenSense
column36: FireEye
column37: and Seagate all still have bullish   supporters
column38: but I'm not buying their turnaround stories.   InvenSense remains at the mercy of larger rivals
column39: FireEye is   shrinking its business when it needs to expand
column40: and Seagate is   treading water with big buybacks and unsustainable dividends.   Therefore
