column1: What Rate Of Return Will An Investment In Johnson & Johnson Deliver? Part 2;10/5/2016;"ByChuck Carnevale:IntroductionI never invest in a common stock without a clear expectation of the future returns that it can generate for me. Consequently
column2: I consider this one of the most important steps in my research and due diligence process. Unfortunately
column3: my experience in dealing with investors has led me to conclude that this important step is rarely taken. Most investors possess only a vague idea of what they might earn from investing in a given stock. Many people simply buy a stock hoping that it will go up
column4: and if it pays a dividend
column5: hopeful that the dividend will increase over time.With this article
column6: I'm going to share my specific process on how I estimate the future return that a stock can be expected to offer me. My primary example will be based on a current investment in the blue-chip Dividend Aristocrat Johnson & Johnson (JNJ). Through this exercise
column7: I will offer a methodical approach designed to determine whether Johnson & Johnson is a viable investment choice at today's valuation.makeArticleAd();Johnson & Johnson: Forecasting Future   ReturnsInpart 1of this two-part series
column8: I reviewed Johnson & Johnson
column9: Consolidated Edison
column10: Inc. (ED) and Cisco Systems
column11: Inc. (CSCO) from a historical perspective. Reviewing a company's history and how the market has typically valued the company's operating results is typically the initial step in my due diligence process. However
column12: I consider forecasting the future potential of any company the most crucial step in my due diligence process.Directly stated
column13: I will never invest in a stock until I have made a determination of what rate of return the investment might potentially produce for me. This is essentially done under a most likely case
column14: best-case and worst-case scenarios. I'm not naïve enough to believe that I can make these calculations with absolute precision. Instead
column15: my objective is to determine future return possibilities within reasonable ranges of accuracy and predictability. But most importantly
column16: this gives me more that a vague idea of what the return potential that a company might produce for me. I call this investing with my eyes wide open.However
column17: before I move on to my forecasting process
column18: I would like to briefly review what I saw when I examined Johnson & Johnson's valuation history over different time periods. You can examine my historical approach more comprehensively by reviewing the link to my previous article above.In order to review historical valuations
column19: I rely on theF.A.S.T. Graphsfundamentals analyzer software tool. I always start by looking at all of the company's history available to me. The following long-term earnings and price correlated graph on Johnson & Johnson revealed two important aspects related to valuation. First of all
column20: I noticed that the market applied a premium valuation on Johnson & Johnson's shares from 1997 through the spring of 2007. However
column21: from that point forward
column22: the market was valuing Johnson & Johnson's shares at a lower valuation. I have drawn a line on the graph separating these two time periods. Note that the normal P/E ratio calculation of 20.2 is high because it is skewed by the high valuations over these first 10 years or so.(click to enlarge)When I shortened thetime frame to cover the period 2006 to current
column23: I discovered that the normal P/E ratio that the market has applied over thistime frame has been approximately 15. Importantly
column24: I consider these more recent valuation levels more relevant. Therefore
column25: my fair value assessment for Johnson & Johnson is set at the more conservative P/E ratio of 15 than at the longer-term normal P/E ratio of 20.2. Consequently
column26: with the current blended P/E ratio at 18.1
column27: I would consider Johnson & Johnson moderately overvalued at these levels. As promised
column28: what follows will be the rate of return calculations I believe this valuation level offers.(click to enlarge)When writing articles like this
column29: I can only include a picture of a live
column30: fully-functioning graph. Therefore
column31: I have arranged to have a live
column32: fully-functioning F.A.S.T. Graph available to readers. Next I will offer a few simple calculations utilizing the Forecasting Calculators and their calculating functionality. However
column33: the calculators allow me to run numerous ""what-if"" calculations based on various assumptions. If the reader follows the below link
column34: they will be able to quickly and easily run as many of their own calculations as they desire.Here is thelinkfor a FAST and FUN Preview of F.A.S.T Graphs using the   stock symbol JNJOnce you follow the link
column35: scroll down to the Forecasting Calculators where you will find five calculators that can be utilized to estimate the future return potential on Johnson & Johnson. Each calculator is color-coded and the following screenshot illustrates how to access each calculator. My first calculation will be based on utilizing Johnson & Johnson's normal P/E ratio of 15 (the dark blue tab and border).(click to enlarge)The calculator is presenting forecasts based on the consensus analyst estimates reporting to S&P Capital IQ. With this Johnson & Johnson example
column36: there are 23 analysts forecasting earnings for fiscal year-end December 2016 and 25 analysts forecasting earnings for fiscal year-end 2017. From there
column37: the number of analysts drops off to 17 analysts for fiscal year-end 2018 and only 11 analysts for fiscal year-end 2019. This information is found at the bottom of the graph as ""# Analysts.""Assuming that these analysts are reasonably correct
column38: and the company's stock price was valued at a normal P/E ratio of 15.3 (red circle)
column39: then Johnson & Johnson would be expected to deliver a total annualized rate of return of only 3.57% out to December 31
column40: 2019. Personally
column41: I would consider this too low of a rate of return potential which is due to moderately high current valuation. I consider this
column42: as I will elaborate later
column43: my most reasonable case scenario.(click to enlarge)In contrast
column44: if I ran these calculations utilizing the long-term historical normal P/E ratio of 20.1 (red circle)
column45: the investment in Johnson & Johnson looks a lot more attractive. Although I would consider this a possibility
column46: my confidence that Johnson & Johnson would trade at that valuation is low. Therefore
column47: I would consider this more of an optimistic or best-case scenario. Nevertheless
column48: the 11.97% total annual rate of return would be considered attractive.(click to enlarge)At this point
column49: I've run these expected and best-case scenarios utilizing the specific consensus analyst estimates over the next few years. However
column50: many investors hold a rather jaundice view of the accuracy of analyst estimates. On some companies
column51: these negative views on analyst estimates are justified
column52: however
column53: there are certain companies where the analysts' track records have been exceptional. Johnson & Johnson happens to be one of those companies that analysts have tended to estimate correctly.The following ""Analyst Scorecard"" summary shows that analysts have been accurate with their forecasts on Johnson & Johnson virtually 100% of the time. This record assumes a 10% margin of error for forecasts made one year in advance
column54: and a 20% margin of error for forecasts made two years in advance.(click to enlarge)This next screenshot provides a more detailed look at the record of analysts making a one year in advance forecast of earnings on Johnson & Johnson. Therefore
column55: I think it is reasonable to assume two things about Johnson & Johnson's estimates. One
column56: Johnson & Johnson must be a relatively easy company to make forecasts on. Two
column57: in my opinion
column58: since analysts rely heavily on company guidance
column59: Johnson & Johnson's management must give good solid guidance. However
column60: the main point I am making with these scorecards is that my confidence level is high regarding the earnings forecasts in the above calculators. Therefore
column61: I feel it is highly likely that they would turn out to be reasonably accurate.(click to enlarge)Once I have run calculations utilizing specific consensus estimates for the next few years
column62: I like to examine the return possibilities utilizing a longer-term three to five-year trend line calculation. The calculator utilized to run these calculations would be found on the third tab on the forecasting calculators' options.(click to enlarge)There are nine analysts (see FAST FACTS box to the right of the graph) offering a three to five-year trend line earnings growth estimate on Johnson & Johnson at 6.07% on average. If those trend line estimates happen to come to pass and Johnson & Johnson traded at a P/E ratio of 15 on December 31
column64: it would only offer me a 4.8% rate of return. Once again
column65: I would not be too excited about that long-term rate of return possibility notwithstanding Johnson & Johnson's impeccable quality.(click to enlarge)On the other hand
column66: if I utilize that same growth expectation but applied the long-term normal P/E ratio of approximately 21
column67: my rate of return potential would be much more attractive. However
column68: recent historical data suggests that valuation level might be overly-optimistic. Nevertheless
column69: this would be another possible best-case scenario.(click to enlarge)Once I have examined the consensus trend line estimates based on analysts reporting to S&P Capital IQ
column70: I like to check other sources to see what other analysts think. Therefore
column71: I checked the five-year growth forecast on Johnson & Johnson from Morningstar. Here I found a much lower estimate for longer-term growth of only 3.8% on average.""Morningstar Five-Year Growth Forecast""(click to enlarge)Consequently
column72: I then went to the ""Custom"" calculator option and entered a custom trend line growth rate of 3.8% (red circle) according to Morningstar. Once again
column73: utilizing the normal P/E ratio of 15
column74: my rate of return calculation on Johnson & Johnson based on Morningstar estimates only averaged 2.35% per annum. Perhaps this could be considered a worse case - or maybe even just a bad-case scenario for this blue-chip Dividend Aristocrat. Nevertheless
column75: it provides additional insights generated by my due diligence process.(click to enlarge)Additionally
column76: I often like to run rate of return calculations where I utilize historical earnings growth rates in lieu of analyst estimates. This is an approach that Ben Graham suggested. This next calculation utilizes the ""Historical CAGR"" (Compound Annual Growth Rate) of 5% (red circle) on average for Johnson & Johnson over the past five completed historical years. All things considered
column77: I consider this 5% growth rate achievable for Johnson & Johnson. Consequently
column78: I would consider this a plausible case scenario.(click to enlarge)However
column79: I never stop with just running calculations based on analyst estimates or historical earnings growth rates on any company I am researching. My next step is to check other research providers in order to assess the validity of the assumptions utilized in my calculations. What follows is one example utilizing Morningstar research and its discussion of Johnson & Johnson's economic moat. However
column80: I will check several other research providers for additional information as well.""Morningstar Research: Economic Moat07/19/2016We believe Johnson & Johnson carries one of the widest   moats in the healthcare sector
column81: supported by intellectual   property in the drug group
column82: switching costs in the device   segment
column83: and strong brand power from the consumer group. The   company's diverse revenue base
column85: and robust cash   flow generation create a very wide economic moat. An extensive   salesforce makes J&J a powerful candidate for a smaller   biotechnology company looking to partner on a new drug
column86: which   strengthens Johnson & Johnson's ability to bring new products   to market.Johnson & Johnson's diverse operations are a major pillar   supporting the wide moat. The company holds a leadership role in   a number of segments
column90: the company is not overly   dependent on one particular operating segment; the pharmaceutical   business
column96: within each segment no one product dominates sales
column97: as Pfizer's   Lipitor did. Despite carrying some lower-margin divisions
column98: J&J maintains strong pricing power and has posted gross   margins above 68% during the past five years
column101: I like to conclude my due diligence by going to the company's website to see what it has have to say about its future. The following excerpts are fromJohnson & Johnson's Second-Quarter 2016Earnings Presentation:(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)One of the areas I am most interested in is the company's earnings guidance. The following slides and the accompanying F.A.S.T. Graphs Forecasting Calculator illustrate that the company guidance and analysts' estimates are aligned. The 2016 earnings forecast of $6.69 is in the middle of the guidance range provided by Johnson & Johnson.(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)Johnson & Johnson - Why I'm Not SellingAfter running the above return calculations for Johnson & Johnson going forward utilizing various scenarios
column102: I have concluded that I do not consider Johnson & Johnson a compelling investment at today's valuation. However
column103: I make a distinction between making a buy decision versus a sell decision.The following historical graphs on Johnson & Johnson are marked with a green dot indicating the day that I bought this blue-chip. With the first graph
column104: I have run a calculation of the rate of return I have achieved on my Johnson & Johnson investment thus far. As you can see
column105: this has been a very profitable holding. Because I purchased the stock when it is undervalued
column106: and considering that it is now moderately overvalued
column107: my results have been better than what the company produced on an operating basis.(click to enlarge)With such a nice profit on my investment
column108: it would be very tempting to sell and harvest that return. However
column109: one of my primary reasons for investing in the stock was the company's impeccable history of increasing its dividend every year. Consequently
column111: I would be giving up that future dividend. But
column113: I believe in investing with my eyes wide open.Therefore
column114: I have run a calculation to see what my rate of return would be if the company reverted to the mean by year-end 2017. Obviously
column116: it would be lower. On the other hand
column117: I would still be earning a double-digit return. And of course
column118: there is the possibility that Johnson & Johnson's stock price would maintain its current P/E ratio. Once I've established a solid position in a great business like Johnson & Johnson
column119: I am very reluctant to sell unless valuations become extreme. I don't consider Johnson & Johnson's current valuation extreme; therefore
column120: I plan on continuing to hold it for a long time.(click to enlarge)The Bottom LineI hope the reader recognizes that the primary message I'm attempting to deliver with the above exercise is to always invest with your eyes wide open. To me
column121: this means establishing a reasonable expectation of what the business behind the stock is capable of delivering
column122: and then calculating a reasonable rate of return expectation on that basis. In other words
column123: never invest on just a hope or a prayer.Follow-Up Examples From Part 1In part 1 of this two-part series
column124: I covered two additional companies. Therefore
column126: I wanted to give the reader the opportunity to run their own calculations regarding the future return potential of Consolidated Edison
column129: I will spare the reader from repeating the exercise as I did with Johnson & Johnson above. Instead
column130: below I have provided links to live
column131: fully-functioning F.A.S.T. Graphs on both of these companies. Additionally
column132: I have provided a few screenshots just to get you started - you choose to take the opportunity to follow the links and run your own calculations.Consolidated Edison
column133: Inc.Here is thelinkfor a FAST and FUN Preview of F.A.S.T Graphs using the   stock symbol ED(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)Cisco Systems
column134: Inc.Here is thelinkfor a FAST and FUN Preview of our F.A.S.T Graphs using   the stock symbol CSCO(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)Summary and ConclusionsAs I stated in part 1 of this two-part series
column135: common stocks come in all sizes and shapes. There are certain companies that might be attractive based on their dividend yields. Other companies might be attractive based on their future growth potential. And
column137: there is everything in between. This simply implies that different types of companies are capable of producing significantly different future rates of return. The primary drivers will be the growth potential of each business
column138: coupled with the valuation you paid to purchase those results.The key to success is to identify the types of companies you are comfortable investing in
column139: and that are capable of meeting your own goals and objectives. However
column140: I believe that no matter how much you like the company
column141: you should always be keenly aware of the valuation you are being asked to pay. One of the best ways to implement and apply a disciplined approach to investing is to run the numbers out to their logical conclusions.With this article
column142: I utilized the ""Forecasting Calculators"" provided by the F.A.S.T. Graphs research tool. However
column143: the same process could be applied utilizing a simple spreadsheet. Earnings estimates are available from many sources
column144: and there is never a substitute for conducting your own comprehensive research and due diligence. My key message with this article is to always invest with your eyes wide open.If you enjoyed this article
column145: scroll up and click on the   ""Follow"" button next to our name to see updates on our future   articles in your feed.Disclaimer: The opinions in this document are for   informational and educational purposes only and should not be   construed as a recommendation to buy or sell the stocks mentioned   or to solicit transactions or clients. Past performance of the   companies discussed may not continue and the companies may not   achieve the earnings growth as predicted. The information in this   document is believed to be accurate
column146: but under no circumstances   should a person act upon the information contained within. We do   not recommend that anyone act upon any investment information   without first consulting an investment advisor as to the   suitability of such investments for his specific situation.See alsoAlcoa: Looking Past The Resultson seekingalpha.com"

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column19: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column20: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column21: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column22: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column23: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs   experienced notable outflows »"

column1: Retired? Here Are 2 Stocks You Should Consider Buying;10/5/2016;"If you recently retired
column2: you're probably looking for stocks   with low volatility and high dividends. Low interest rates have   recently inflated the value of manydividend   stockstounattractive levels
column3: but there are two solid income investments which I believe   retirees can still considerbuying --Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO) andBank of America's Preferred Lshares(NYSE: BAC-L) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();An underappreciated tech stock with a solid     yieldNetworking giant Cisco is only expected to post 1% sales   growth this year and 3% growth next year. That stagnation is   mainly attributed to slowing demand for its routers and switches
column4: which generated nearly half its revenue last quarter. Router   sales slid 6% annually during the quarter
column5: but switch sales   improved just 2%. Meanwhile
column6: newer cloud-based networking   solutions from companies likeArista Networksthreaten to reduce sales of Cisco's on-site networking   hardware.Cisco's core business might look mediocre
column7: but the company has   been aggressively expanding its higher-growth security
column8: service   provider video
column9: and collaboration services businesses. It also   inked major enterprise partnerships withApple
column10: IBM
column11: andSalesforceto widen its moat against smaller challengers
column12: and made   numerous acquisitions to expand inorganically across the growing   Internet of Things -- which could connect up to  50 billion   devices by 2020.Cisco generates plenty of free cash flow ($12.4 billion over   the past 12 months) for funding acquisitions
column13: buybacks
column14: and   dividends. It respectively spent 22% and 38% on buybacks and   dividends over the past year
column15: indicating that it has plenty of   room to increase both to boost shareholder value. Buybacks are   expected to increase Cisco's earnings by 3% this year and 6% next   year. Cisco hiked its dividend annually for the past five years   and currently pays a forward yield of 3.4% -- which is much   higher than the S&P 500's average yield of 2.1%.Lastly
column16: Cisco trades at just 15 times earnings
column17: which is much   lower than the industry average of 25 for networking and   communication device companies. That low valuation and its solid   yield should set a floor under the stock -- making it a low-risk
column18: long-term investment for most retirement portfolios.A preferred stock with unusual benefitsBank of America(NYSE: BAC) offers awide varietyofpreferred shareswhich are less volatile and pay higher dividends than its   common shares. Moreover
column19: if Bank of America became insolvent
column20: preferred shares could be redeemed at a ""par value"" like bonds
column21: while common shareholders might lose everything. Therefore
column22: the   par value represents a good safety net for retirees
column23: many of whom   likely remember that the global financial crisis wiped out many   major bank stocks.The trade-off is that preferred shares have less upside   potential than common shares
column24: since they become less attractive   as they rise above those par values. Moreover
column25: many preferred   shares can be redeemed
column26: meaning that Bank of America can buy back   those shares at par value at any time past their redemption   dates.The L-series preferred stock is an exception to that rule. The   stock has a par value of $1
column28: but can't be redeemed by Bank of   America at any time. However
column29: Bank of America can convert each L   share into 20 common shares
column30: if the common shares rise above   130% of $50 ($65) over 20 of 30 consecutive trading days. That   probably won't happen anytime soon
column31: since Bank of America was   trading for about $15 as of this writing.Therefore
column32: the 130% figure indicates that each L series share   could eventually be converted into $1
column33: 300 worth of stock (20   shares of the common stock at $65). So as long as the L series   stock remains below $1
column35: as it is now
column36: it trades at a discount   to its long-term value
column37: even though it has an ""uncallable"" par   value of $1
column38: 000. Meanwhile
column39: the L series stock pays quarterly   dividends for a 5.9% annual yield --more than triple the common stock's yield.Growth-oriented investors will probably accept the lower   dividend of Bank of America's common shares in exchange for   higher potential price growth. However
column40: I believe that the   L-series preferred shares are better suited for retirees
column41: because   they offer more predictable prices with a much higher yield.The key takeawayCisco and Bank of America's L series stock aren't exciting   investments for growth-oriented investors
column42: but they offer   stability and generous income -- two qualities which will serve   retirees well in their golden years. However
column43: investors should   also do their due diligence and fully understand the benefits and   drawbacks of ETFs
